questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents to the emergency department after a syncopal event at home. He has had two hours of left-sided flank pain radiating to the groin, which is associated with nausea and vomiting. Prior to this episode, he reports vague back pain and fatigue over the past several months. His past medical history is significant for an 80-pack-year smoking history, hypercholesterolemia, and hypertension. He has had no previous abdominal surgeries. His BMI is 30 kg/m2. His temperature is 37.0 °C (98.6 °F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 20/min, blood pressure is 90/60 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 95% on room air. Abdominal examination shows distension and diffuse tenderness on palpation, and cardiovascular examination shows a 1+ dorsalis pedis pulse in the left foot and 2+ pulse in the right foot. Laboratory findings show a WBC of 12,000/mm3. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Abdominal aortic aneurysms (AAA) should be considered in any older individual presenting with sudden onset abdominal, low back, or flank pain and a history of syncope with hypotension.  Risk factors for AAA include significant age >65 years, smoking, male gender, family history of AAA, and other risk factors for coronary artery disease or peripheral vascular disease including hypertension and hypercholesterolemia. Abdominal aortic aneurysms are true aneurysms, meaning all three layers of the blood vessel - the intima, media, and adventitia - are dilated. The pathophysiology of abdominal aortic aneurysms is a complex, multifactorial process that involves alterations in the structure of the vascular wall due to inflammatory changes, abnormal collagen remodeling and cross-linking, as well as loss of elastin and smooth muscle cells. This ultimately results in progressive thinning and weakening of the aortic wall and enlargement of the aortic diameter to a dilation 50% greater than the normal diameter of the aorta.  

AAAs commonly occur at the infrarenal level, or below the level of the renal arteries. People with near rupture or rapid expansion of a AAA commonly present with sudden onset back, flank, or abdominal pain and associated symptoms such as nausea and vomiting, mimicking a myriad of other conditions. Other associated symptoms may include diminished peripheral pulses due to expansion of the aneurysm compressing the internal iliac arteries. Although a pulsatile abdominal mass is a classic presentation, it may not always be detectable, especially if the patient is obese, such as in this vignette. If left untreated, AAAs can rupture, leading to severe hypotension, hemodynamic instability, and death. In a case where rupture has not occurred, repair should be offered when the aneurysm is >5 cm.

 

Option Analysis

❌ Renal colic:
Incorrect: Renal colic commonly causes flank pain radiating to the groin with associated nausea and vomiting; however, it rarely causes syncope. Patients commonly describe sharp severe flank pain with associated urinary symptoms, including dysuria and hematuria.   
❌ Acute pancreatitis:
Incorrect: Pancreatitis can present with nausea and vomiting, but it is also commonly associated with distinct mid-epigastric pain radiating to the back and a history of chronic right upper quadrant pain due to gallstones or recent alcohol use, neither of which this patient endorses.   
❌ Bowel obstruction:
Incorrect: Bowel obstructions may present with abdominal distension and pain, as well as nausea and vomiting. They are most commonly associated with a history of adhesions from prior abdominal surgeries. This patient has no past surgical history, making this diagnosis less likely.   
✅ Abdominal aortic aneurysm:
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Cholangitis:
Incorrect: Cholangitis refers to an ascending infection of the biliary tree. This disease classically presents with right upper quadrant tenderness, fever, and jaundice, referred to as Charcot’s triad. While the patient in this vignette has signs of sepsis including hypotension and tachycardia, there is no evidence of fever or jaundice, making this diagnosis less likely.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman is found to have an incidental brain mass after receiving a CT-scan of her head to investigate chronic sinusitis. The mass is located in the frontal lobe, occupying part of the white matter with areas of calcifications. She denies headaches or vision changes, and her medical history is non-contributory. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. A biopsy of the mass is performed and reveals sheets of cells with round nuclei surrounded by clear cytoplasm, with delicate, branching capillaries and microcalcifications. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This asymptomatic patient is presenting with an incidental mass in the frontal lobe found on imaging, as well as a characteristic appearance on biopsy, which favors the diagnosis of a slow growing oligodendroglioma.  

Oligodendrogliomas are rare tumors (approximately 5% of all neuroepithelial tumors of the CNS) of oligodendrocyte origin that often grow in the frontal lobes. Oligodendrogliomas are slow-growing, infiltrative tumors that may be silent for many years. Focal neurologic deficits and headache are uncommon at the time of diagnosis. On histology, cells have round nuclei with clear cytoplasm forming a “fried egg” appearance and the capillaries of the tumor are arranged in a “chicken-wire” pattern. Calcifications, which are characteristic of oligodendroglial tumors, but are neither sensitive nor specific, can be visualized on computed tomography (CT).  



Credit: Wikimedia Commons

Option Analysis

❌ Glioblastoma multiforme:
Incorrect: Glioblastoma multiforme is a common, highly malignant primary brain tumor with poor survival rates. On histopathology, it stains positive for glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP) and shows “pseudopalisading” pleomorphic tumor cells that border areas of central necrosis and hemorrhage. This patient is asymptomatic, and the histological appearance favors the diagnosis of oligodendroglioma.  
❌ Meningioma:
 Incorrect: Meningiomas are tumors of arachnoid cell origin that commonly grow in the parasagittal areas of the brain and may have a dural attachment (extra-axial). On histology, spindle cells are arranged concentrically in a whorled pattern along with “psammoma bodies” calcifications. Although this tumor biopsy shows calcifications, these are nonspecific, and this patient's lesion is intra-axial, which favors another diagnosis.   
❌ Hemangioblastoma:
Incorrect: Hemangioblastomas are uncommon, slow-growing tumors, which typically occur in the cerebellum, brainstem, or spinal cord. On histology, hemangioblastomas composed of an extensive vascular network and neoplastic "stromal cells" which are embedded among the vascular channels.  
❌ Schwannoma:
Incorrect: Schwannomas are tumors of Schwann cell origin that grow along the peripheral nerves, most commonly involving both cranial nerves VII and VIII. On histology, these tumors stain positive for S-100 and are characterized by biphasic architecture: Antoni A-dense, hypercellular areas containing spindle cells alternating with Antoni B-hypocellular myxoid areas.   
✅ Oligodendroglioma:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Pilocytic astrocytoma:
Incorrect: Pilocytic astrocytomas are benign, low-grade astrocytomas. They are the most common primary brain tumor in childhood, although they are occasionally seen in older individuals as well. Typically, they are found in the posterior fossa (e.g. cerebellum). On imaging, they are composed of cystic and solid components. On histology, they stain positive for glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP) and show eosinophilic corkscrew fibers (Rosenthal fibers).

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman, gravida 2 para 1, at 20 weeks gestation comes to the physician due to abdominal discomfort and early satiety for the past few days. She denies headache, visual changes, cramping or vaginal bleeding. Fetal movement is normal. Medical history is unremarkable. Abdominal ultrasound reveals a homogenous, well-demarcated, hyperechoic mass within the left lobe of the liver. A decision is made to follow up on the lesion post-partum. The follow-up ultrasound obtained 3 months after delivery shows an increase in the mass size without changes in the appearance. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This previously healthy pregnant woman most likely has a cavernous hemangioma.  

Cavernous hemangioma, also called hepatic hemangioma, is the most common benign tumor of the liver. Hemangiomas are tumors composed of large, dilated vascular channels that can arise throughout the body (e.g., liver, brain, eye). Their etiology is incompletely understood, but they are thought to arise from vascular malformations or hamartomas of congenital origin. A hemangioma can be diagnosed at any age but occurs most commonly in women between 30-50 years of age. Similar to adenomas, they tend to increase in size in response to estrogen exposure, but they can also occur in its absence. In contrast to hepatic adenoma, a cavernous hemangioma is unlikely to regress with estrogen withdrawal. Most tumors are asymptomatic and are often found as an incidental mass on imaging. When symptoms are present, right upper quadrant pain and abdominal fullness are common. Additional symptoms may include nausea, anorexia, and early satiety, due to compression of adjacent structures.  

Diagnosis is typically based on imaging, clinical presentation, and patient history. Ultrasound typically reveals a well-demarcated, hyperechoic, homogeneous mass. A biopsy is relatively contraindicated because of the risk of bleeding. Asymptomatic patients do not require treatment and are observed for the development of symptoms. When symptoms arise, surgery with resection or enucleation may be considered.    



Retrieved from: Wikimedia Commons

Option Analysis

❌ Hepatic adenoma:
Incorrect: Hepatic adenomas are rare, benign liver tumors arising from hepatocytes. The most common symptom is pain due to compression of adjacent structures. Hepatic adenomas tend to bleed and may result in life-threatening intra-abdominal bleeding. Hepatic adenomas carry some risk for malignant transformation. They have been associated with estrogen exposure (e.g. OCP and pregnancy). Although it is difficult to differentiate an adenoma from a hemangioma, the former often presents on ultrasound with central heterogeneous material and calcifications from bleeding. Also, adenomas are likely to regress in size with estrogen withdrawal, unlike this case.  
❌ Focal nodular hyperplasia:
Incorrect: Focal nodular hyperplasia, the second most common tumor of the liver, is thought to arise from a hyperplastic hepatocyte reaction to an underlying arteriovenous malformation. Ultrasound often shows a central scar, a highly suggestive finding for focal nodular hyperplasia.  
❌ Hepatocellular carcinoma:
Incorrect: Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) is the most common primary malignancy of the liver. Patients may present with jaundice, tender hepatomegaly, ascites, and anorexia. Risk factors include chronic hepatitis B or C infections, alcoholic and nonalcoholic fatty liver disease, autoimmune disease, hemochromatosis, Wilson disease, and specific carcinogens (e.g. aflatoxin). On ultrasound, HCC typically presents with poorly-defined margins and coarse, irregular internal echoes. This patient has none of those risk factors and her imaging results favor another diagnosis.   
✅ Cavernous hemangioma:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Metastatic colon cancer:
Incorrect: Patients with any type of metastatic disease are likely to be more symptomatic from the primary cancer. Also, multiple hypoechoic lesions are typically seen on ultrasound, rather than a single hyperechoic mass.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman comes to her primary care physician for evaluation of acid-reflux that began four months ago. The patient has tried ranitidine and pantoprazole; however, her symptoms have remained poorly controlled. Past medical history is notable for asthma, for which she is currently using an albuterol inhaler. Her temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F) and blood pressure is 118/67 mmHg. Physical examination is notable for skin tightening over the face, hands, and forearms. Several ulcers are observed at the fingertips. Which of the following is the most likely explanation of the patient’s presentation?

choices.text: Cholesterol deposition in peripheral blood vessels

questions.solution:
This patient has scleroderma (also termed systemic sclerosis), an autoimmune disorder characterized by the replacement of normal tissue by collagen. Scleroderma most often affects women over 50-years-old.  

The condition can be divided into type subtypes: diffuse cutaneous and limited cutaneous systemic scleroderma. Both cause thickening and tightening of the skin. In addition, both types can cause gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) secondary to replacement of the esophageal sphincter muscles by collagen.    

However, diffuse scleroderma is characterized by severe visceral organ involvement (e.g., renal injury, malabsorption, restrictive cardiomyopathy) and diffuse skin involvement. In contrast, limited scleroderma is characterized by mild visceral organ involvement and affects only skin of the face and distal extremities. Of note, the patient in this vignette most likely has limited scleroderma, as she presents with skin findings localized to the face and distal upper extremities.  

The pathology of this condition is not completely understood. However, it is believed that some individuals have a genetic predisposition to scleroderma, which is triggered by external factors. These triggers include: viral infection by cytomegalovirus and parvovirus B19; exposure to silica dust, organic solvents, vinyl chloride; and medication like cocaine, bleomycin, and pentazocine.    

Option Analysis

✅ Pathological collagen deposition:
Correct: See Main Explanation  
❌ Herniation of gastroesophageal junction:
Incorrect: This describes a hiatal hernia, which is a common cause of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) that is refractory to medical treatment. Although a hiatal hernia may explain the patient’s GERD, it would not explain the skin tightening or fingertip ulcerations.  
❌ Cholesterol deposition in peripheral blood vessels:
Incorrect: Severe atherosclerosis can reduce blood flow to the extremities and cause tissue necrosis. This may present with ulcers. However, ulcers secondary to atherosclerosis/peripheral artery disease are most often found in the lower extremities. Moreover, atherosclerosis would not explain the skin tightening or treatment-resistant acid-reflux.   
❌ Pathological keratin deposition:
Incorrect: This describes hyperkeratosis, which may be seen in vitamin A deficiency or dermatomyositis. The condition causes skin thickening and discomfort. However, it would be atypical for hyperkeratosis to present with fingertip ulcers or severe acid-reflux.  
❌ Gram-negative bacterial infection:
Incorrect: Infection by gram-negative bacteria, such as Helicobacter pylori (H. pylori), can cause gastric acid overproduction. This can result in peptic ulcer formation and potentially contribute to the development of acid-reflux. However, infection by H.pylori or other gram-negative pathogens would not account for the patient's skin changes.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after an episode of hematemesis. The patient had spent the night at a bar drinking with his colleagues. After leaving the bar, he vomited multiple times and noticed bright-red blood mixed with the vomitus, and he called an ambulance. Past medical history is notable for hypertension, for which he is taking lisinopril. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a patient in no acute distress. Cardiac, pulmonary, and abdominal exams are non-contributory. Which of the following additional findings will most likely develop in this patient?

choices.text: Passage of bright-red blood from the anus

questions.solution:
This patient likely has a Mallory-Weiss tear, which is characterized by lacerations of the esophageal mucosa secondary to forceful and repeated vomiting. Mallory-Weiss tears can lead to gastrointestinal (GI) bleeding.  

GI bleeding can be divided into upper and lower bleeding. Upper GI bleeding arises above the ligament of Treitz (also termed suspensory ligament of the duodenum), and the term includes bleeding from the esophagus, stomach, and duodenum. Symptoms include hematemesis (vomiting of fresh red blood), ‘coffee ground’ vomitus (vomiting of blood that has been oxidized by stomach acids), and melena (black and tarry stools). However, if the upper GI bleeding is brisk enough, it is possible to also have bright red blood in the stool following a presentation with melena.  

In contrast, lower GI bleeding arises below the ligament of Treitz and includes bleeding from the small intestine distal to the duodenum, large intestines, rectum, and anus. Typical presentation includes hematochezia (fresh blood passing through the anus).  

If individuals lose significant quantities of blood via GI bleeding, they can develop anemia.  

Option Analysis

✅ Black tarry stools:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Passage of bright-red blood from the anus:
Incorrect: Patients with a lower gastrointestinal (GI) bleed may notice bright-red blood mixed with their stool. In contrast, this patient most likely has a Mallory-Weiss tear, which is an upper GI bleed caused by forceful and repeated vomiting. Blood from an upper GI bleed will have oxidized by the time it is expelled and will thus appear dark in color.  
❌ Foul-smelling oily stools:
Incorrect: Foul-smelling and oily stools may be observed in patients with fat malabsorption, which can be due to various conditions, ranging from pancreatic insufficiency to Giardia infection. However, it would be atypical for patients to develop this symptom after an episode of GI bleeding.  
❌ Abdominal pain exacerbated with eating:
Incorrect: Patients with gastric ulcers have abdominal pain that is worsened by food intake. Gastric ulcers can cause an upper GI bleed and lead to hematemesis. However, this patient's history of bleeding after multiple episodes of vomiting is more consistent with a Mallory-Weiss tear.   
❌ Sloughed mucosa mixed with stool  :
Incorrect: This describes “currant-jelly stools,” which occur when sloughed mucosa, blood, and mucus are mixed with the stool. The symptom is often found in patients with intestinal ischemia or intussusception, both of which can lead to lower GI bleeding. In contrast, this patient has upper GI bleeding. Blood from an upper GI bleed will have oxidized by the time it is expelled with stool.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old woman comes to her physician seeking evaluation for postcoital vaginal bleeding. The patient reports that the symptoms started two months ago and have been progressively worsening, prompting her to seek medical care. Past medical history is notable for hypertension, for which she is currently taking propranolol. The patient consumes half-a-pack of cigarettes per day. Speculum exam reveals the following finding:  



Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons  

Biopsy of the lesion and subsequent histology results confirm the presence of a tumor with a width of 5.0 mm and stromal invasion depth of 1.5 mm. The patient’s history will most likely be notable for which of the additional symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient most likely has squamous cell carcinoma of the cervix. It is the most common subtype of cervical cancer. In the early stages, the condition is largely asymptomatic. However, if symptoms are present, they may include abnormal vaginal bleeding, especially after sexual intercourse, which is known as postcoital bleeding. Vaginal discomfort and a foul-smelling discharge might be also present. In general, tumors with a depth of invasion less than 3 mm will present with only local symptoms, since lymphovascular invasion is rare at this point.

In advanced cases, the cancer can spread to neighboring tissues. When the cancer has spread to the bladder, there may be symptoms such as urinary frequency, dysuria, and hematuria. If the ureters are obstructed, hydronephrosis and reduced urine output may manifest. If the cancer has spread to the rectum, there may be constipation. If the cancer damages the local lymphatics or blood vessels, lower extremity edema may manifest. Lastly, flank pain and sciatica may indicate pelvic wall invasion.  

In a symptomatic individual, diagnosis begins with a pelvic examination, where a lesion suggestive of cervical cancer, which may look like an ulceration or mass, is identified. In some cases, the cervix might be enlarged and indurated with a smooth surface. This is often termed a “barrel-shaped cervix.” Diagnosis will be confirmed with a biopsy.  Afterwards, a CT or MRI can be done to look for evidence of metastasis.  

Option Analysis

❌ Swelling of the lower extremities:
Incorrect: This may be seen in patients with late-stage cervical cancer that has spread to the lymphatics. Damage to the lymphatics or blood vessels in the pelvic area can result in lower extremity swelling.  
❌ Vaginal canal pruritus:
Incorrect: This symptom is most often associated with patients who have vaginal Candidiasis. The condition presents with white and sticky cervical discharge. While some patients with cervical cancer may also endorse pruritus, it is a relatively uncommon symptom.  
❌ Cervical pain on manipulation:
Incorrect: This describes cervical motion tenderness, which is most often found in patients with sexually transmitted infections, such as Gonorrhea and Chlamydia. It is possible for cervical cancer to cause this symptom if the malignancy has invaded surrounding nerves or the pelvic wall. However, this patient’s biopsy results indicate that the tumor is localized and unlikely to have invaded nearby structures.
❌ Reduced urine output:
Incorrect: Patients with late-stage cervical cancer can present with hydronephrosis and reduced urine output. This is because the cancer can compress the bilateral ureters. However, based on this patient’s biopsy results, the tumor is small, localized, and unlikely to have spread elsewhere.  
✅ Foul-smelling vaginal discharge:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman comes to the clinic due to feeling unbalanced and difficulty hearing. Her symptoms began gradually 2 months ago and have worsened since then. She describes episodes of a sensation that she is swaying, and she has difficulty maintaining her balance; the episodes last for a few hours. She also complains of constant buzzing sounds and mild pain in her left ear. Her symptoms seem to fluctuate throughout the day without a specific pattern. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows that rotation of the head does not provoke her symptoms. Audiometry reveals loss of low frequency sounds on the left ear. This patient’s presentation can be explained by which of the following conditions?

choices.text: Post-viral inflammation of the cranial nerve
Calcium debris within the semicircular canals

questions.solution:
This patient, who presents with hearing loss, tinnitus, ear pain, and vertigo, most likely has Ménière disease. 

Ménière disease, also known as idiopathic endolymphatic hydrops, is a condition that affects the inner ear. Endolymphatic hydrops refers to increased hydraulic pressure within the inner ear endolymphatic system. The excess pressure accumulation manifests as episodic hearing loss, vertigo, tinnitus, and ear pain or fullness sensation. The episodic attacks seen in Ménière disease typically lasts 20 minutes to 12 hours and symptoms wax and wane as the endolymphatic pressure rises and falls. The sensorineural hearing loss typically progresses, and may result in permanent hearing loss within 8 to 10 years.  

Diagnosis is made by fulfilling the following criteria:  
  •  2 or more spontaneous episodes of vertigo, lasting 20 minutes to 12 hours 
  •  Audiometry showing low- to mid-frequency sensorineural hearing loss in the affected ear 
  •  Waxing and waning aural symptoms (reduced or distorted hearing, tinnitus, or fullness) in the affected ear 
  •  Symptoms not explained by another vestibular diagnosis 

Option Analysis

❌ Post-viral inflammation of the cranial nerve:
Incorrect: Labyrinthitis, or vestibular neuritis, is an inflammation of the inner ear that results in vertigo, hearing loss or ringing in the ears. It is thought to be a viral or post-viral inflammatory disorder that leads to inflammation of the vestibular portion of the eighth cranial nerve. Patients often present with severe vertigo and possibly hearing loss and tinnitus. It typically occurs as an acute attack that lasts for days. This patient’s presentation and duration of symptoms favor another diagnosis.   
✅ Endolymphatic hydrops:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Autoimmune demyelination:
Incorrect: Multiple sclerosis (MS) is an autoimmune demyelinating disease of the central nervous system that damages the insulating covers of nerve cells. This damage disrupts neural transmission, resulting in a range of signs and symptoms, including physical, mental, and sometimes psychiatric problems. Patients may present with double vision, monocular blindness, muscle weakness, or sensory deficits. Although MS can present with similar symptoms as seen in this patient, the absence of other signs favors another diagnosis.  
❌ Perilymphatic fistula:
Incorrect: Perilymphatic fistula is a complication of head injury, barotrauma, or heavy lifting in which a fistula develops at the otic capsule. The fistula leads to pressure changes and altered signaling of the macular and cupular receptors. It is characterized by episodic vertigo and/or hearing loss provoked by sneezing, lifting, straining, coughing, and loud sounds.  
❌ Calcium debris within the semicircular canals :
Incorrect: Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV) refers to episodic vertigo sensation caused by calcium debris within the semicircular canals. Episodes typically provoked by head rotation and position changes. In contrast to other causes of vertigo, hearing and other neurologic symptoms are not seen.

questions.text:
A 1-hour-old boy is being evaluated in the neonatal intensive care unit for tachypnea, cyanosis, and nasal flaring. The infant was born at 30 weeks gestation via spontaneous vaginal delivery to a mother who received inconsistent prenatal care. His temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 221/min, and respirations are 67/min. A chest x-ray is obtained, as detailed below. Which of the following would have been most helpful in predicting the development of this patient’s disease process?  



Reproduced from: Wikipedia
questions.solution:
The patient in this vignette is a premature infant who presents with signs of respiratory distress and a chest x-ray significant for ground glass opacities, low volumes, and a bell-shaped thorax, all of which is concerning for neonatal respiratory distress syndrome (NRDS). Neonatal respiratory distress syndrome, formerly referred to as hyaline membrane disease, is caused by developmental insufficiency of surfactant production and structural immaturity in the lungs. NRDS is characterized by tachypnea, tachycardia, chest wall retractions, expiratory grunting, nasal flaring, and cyanosis. Histopathology demonstrates layers of hyaline membrane and collapsed alveoli.  

Fetal testing for lung maturity is rarely performed, but it is sometimes indicated in semi-elective but medically indicated births <39 weeks, in order to predict the level of care that will be required. The lecithin–sphingomyelin ratio can be used to determine fetal lung maturity. Lecithin, a phospholipid, is a major component of pulmonary surfactant, and over time, it outweighs the amount of sphingomyelin present; maturity is likely when the ratio is greater than 2.    

Additional studies include the lamellar body count, another test used for the determination of fetal lung maturity. Pulmonary surfactant is made by type II alveolar cells, which start developing after 24 weeks' gestation and store surfactant in lamellar bodies; the lamellar body count, therefore, provides a representation of how much surfactant is present in fetal lungs. The test is performed via amniocentesis, in which a small amount of fluid is sampled from the amniotic sac surrounding the developing fetus.  

Option Analysis

❌ α-fetoprotein:
Incorrect: α-fetoprotein (AFP) is a screening test for a subset of developmental abnormalities; it is sampled from maternal blood or amniotic fluid in utero. Diseases in which α-fetoprotein is elevated include: omphalocele, neural tube defects, nonseminomatous germ cell tumors, ataxia telangiectasia, hepatocellular carcinoma/hepatoma, and metastatic cancers of the liver.  
❌ Inhibin A :
Incorrect: Inhibin A regulates gonadal stromal cell proliferation and reflects the size of granulosa-cell tumors. It is used as a marker for primary and recurrent gonadal stromal cell tumors.  
✅ Lecithin-sphingomyelin ratio:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Karyotype analysis:
Incorrect: A karyotype analysis can be used in the early detection of chromosomal disorders such as trisomy 21, 18, 13, and Turner syndrome. It is not useful in predicting neonatal respiratory distress syndrome.    
❌ Nuchal translucency screening  :
Incorrect: Nuchal translucency screening measures the thickness of the space at the back of the fetus’s neck. Abnormal measurements can confer an increased risk of Down syndrome, aneuploidy, and defects of the heart, abdominal wall, and skeleton. It is not implicated in screening for neonatal respiratory distress syndrome.

questions.text: A 26-year-old man presents to his primary care physician with penile discharge. He also reports experiencing pain with urination starting 3 days ago. Last weekend, he engaged in unprotected sexual intercourse with a new female partner. His vital signs are 37 °C (98.6.°F), pulse is 67/min, respirations are 14/min, blood pressure is 126/74 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Physical examination shows mucoid discharge at the urethral meatus. Which of the following laboratory findings is most likely to be observed in this patient?

choices.text: Positive leukocyte esterase with no bacteria
Positive leukocyte esterase and positive nitrite
High white blood cell count and hyaline casts
Red blood cells and positive leukocyte esterase

questions.solution:
This young male patient, who is presenting with penile discharge and dysuria in the setting of recent unprotected sexual intercourse, likely has urethritis. Of the laboratory abnormalities listed, urinalysis with positive leukocyte esterase and no bacteria is most likely consistent with sterile pyuria.   

Urethritis refers to inflammation of the urethra. Clinically, it is difficult to distinguish from cystitis (bladder inflammation), since it presents with many similar symptoms including dysuria or discharge at the urethral meatus. However, urethritis can be differentiated clinically from pyelonephritis, based on absence of systemic features including fever, tachycardia, costovertebral angle tenderness, nausea, and vomiting.  

Urethritis can be further differentiated from other urinary tract infections based on the causative organisms and laboratory findings. In general, the majority of urethral infections are caused by sexuallay transmitted organisms, such as Chlamydia trachomatis and Neisseria gonorrhoeae. A urinalysis will reveal sterile pyuria, which refers to positive leukocyte esterase without identifiable bacteria on microscopy. Confirmatory diagnosis relies on urethral swabs with subsequent nucleic acid amplification testing, in addition to possible Gram-staining for N. gonorrhoeae.    

Option Analysis

✅ Positive leukocyte esterase with no bacteria:
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Positive leukocyte esterase and positive nitrite:
Incorrect: Positive leukocyte esterase and positive nitrite are more consistent with cystitis or pyelonephritis, which are most often caused by Escherichia coli. Urethritis is more commonly caused by Neisseria gonorrhea or Chlamydia trachomatis, which are non-nitrite producing organisms.   
❌ High white blood cell count and hyaline casts:
Incorrect: A high white blood cell count is not usually seen with lower urinary tract infections but is more commonly seen in the setting of pyelonephritis. Hyaline casts may also be observed in pyelonephritis.  
❌ Urine pH 8.5:
Incorrect: Alkaline urine is more commonly seen with infectious organisms such as Proteus mirabilis, a common culprit in patients with chronic pyelonephritis.   
❌ Red blood cells and positive leukocyte esterase:
Incorrect: These urinalysis findings are more commonly found in the setting of nephrolithiasis, which presents with lancinating flank radiating to the groin, nausea, and vomiting.

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl is brought to the clinic due to complaints of frequent, high-volume urination. For the past two months, the patient has been experiencing more frequent episodes of urination throughout the day, and the father says that the patient has been waking up at least three times a night to urinate. She has developed an unquenchable thirst and keeps a 2 liter water bottle next to her at all times. The patient is upset that she is losing weight despite eating more than normal in order to reach a certain size for boxing lessons. The patient’s mother has a history of vitiligo. The patient’s temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 90/65 mmHg. Physical examination shows a tired-appearing young female with dry mucous membranes and secondary sex characteristics consistent with Tanner stage II. Which of the following genes is most likely present in this patient’s human leukocyte antigen complex?
questions.solution:
This patient is experiencing the classic symptoms associated with uncontrolled hyperglycemia, including polyuria, polydipsia, and weight loss with polyphagia. Along with her mother’s history of vitiligo, which suggests a possible inherited autoimmune-associated gene, this patient most likely has type 1 diabetes mellitus (T1DM).  

In T1DM, the immune system targets and destroys the beta-cells of the pancreas. A common target is an enzyme inside beta cells called glutamic acid decarboxylase (GAD), which helps make gamma aminobutyric acid or GABA. GABA increases insulin release and also has a protective effect on the beta-cells. Without the protective effect of GABA, the number of beta cells progressively decreases, leading to the loss of endogenous insulin and the elevation of blood sugar levels.  

The gene complex involved in the regulation of the immune response, and which is often associated with various autoimmune conditions, is called the human leukocyte antigen (HLA) system. These genes code for the major histocompatibility complex, or MHC, which is a protein that helps the immune system recognize foreign molecules and maintain self-tolerance. People with T1DM often have specific HLA haplotype genes in common: HLA-DR3 and HLA-DR4.  



In T1DM, destruction of beta cells usually starts early in life, and individuals present with symptoms of diabetes before the age of 30. Their tissues are sensitive to insulin, but since there are fewer beta-cells, insulin levels are very low.  

In contrast, type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) is defined by insulin resistance. Risk factors for T2DM include obesity, environmental factors, and a multitude of heritable genetic factors. Insulin levels are increased at the start, but as the islet cells tire out and die, the level drops. T2DM usually manifests after the age of 40 and presents similarly to type 1 diabetes with polyuria, polydipsia, polyphagia, and unintentional weight loss.  

Option Analysis

❌ HLA-A3:
Incorrect: The HLA-A3 gene within the human leukocyte antigen complex is associated with increased susceptibility to multiple sclerosis, possibly by presenting myelin PLP1 self-peptide to autoreactive CD8-positive T cells.  
❌ HLA-B27:
Incorrect: The HLA-B27 gene within the human leukocyte antigen complex is associated with increased susceptibility to ankylosing spondylitis, Behçet disease, juvenile idiopathic arthritis, psoriatic arthritis, rheumatoid arthritis, shingles, and Steven-Johnson syndrome/toxic epidermal necrolysis.  
❌ HLA-DPB1:
Incorrect: The HLA-DPB1 gene within the human leukocyte antigen complex is associated with increased susceptibility to granulomatosis with polyangiitis, juvenile idiopathic arthritis, and rheumatoid arthritis.  
❌ HLA-DQB1  :
Incorrect: The HLA-DQB1 gene within the human leukocyte antigen complex is associated with increased susceptibility to narcolepsy with cataplexy. Most people with narcolepsy with cataplexy have a variant of the HLA-DQB1 gene.  
✅ HLA-DR3:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman comes to the emergency department with nausea and vomiting. Over the past few months, the patient has experienced episodes of nausea that occur primarily after eating meals and gradually resolve after a few hours. Tonight, 20 minutes after dinner, the patient experienced a sudden onset of abdominal pain with nausea and regurgitated the majority of her meal; the nausea has persisted. The patient has not had a bowel movement in 3 days. She has a history of type 1 diabetes which was diagnosed at age 12; it has been well managed with a strict insulin regimen delivered by an insulin pump. The patient also takes a multivitamin each evening. The patient’s temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 115/75 mmHg. Physical examination reveals the patient to be thin and uncomfortable, with a tender epigastrium and mild abdominal distention. Laboratory studies show a normal complete blood count, normal comprehensive metabolic profile, and negative urine β-hCG (human chorionic gonadotropin). Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient’s symptoms?

choices.text: Bacterial overgrowth in the small bowel
Impaired neural control of gastric function

questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with postprandial nausea and vomiting in the setting of long standing diabetes, suggesting a diagnosis of diabetic gastroparesis. Gastroparesis is defined as impaired neural control of gastric function and is caused by damage to the nerves of the upper gastrointestinal tract from chronic hyperglycemia. This condition leads to delayed gastric emptying (which can be quantified by a scintigraphic gastric emptying study) and produces symptoms of nausea, vomiting, upper abdominal pain, early satiety, postprandial fullness, and bloating. The presence of diarrhea suggests an alternate diagnosis.  

Gastroparesis is one of the clinical manifestations of diabetic autonomic neuropathy. Just as hyperglycemia damages peripheral nerve fibers, causing symmetric polyneuropathy of the hands and feet, it also damages autonomic nerves, leading to a wide range of conditions:  



Cardiovascular dysregulation leads to orthostatic hypotension and tachycardia on standing (postural tachycardia). Gastrointestinal effects other than gastroparesis include esophageal dysmotility and altered lower gut motility, which can cause symptoms that mimic irritable bowel syndrome. Parasympathetic functions like erections, ejaculations, and micturition can be affected. Patients may also lose the autonomic pathways that produce symptoms of hypoglycemia (like sweating), making unrecognized hypoglycemia especially dangerous.  

Option Analysis

❌ Bacterial overgrowth in the small bowel:
Incorrect: Small intestinal bacterial overgrowth (SIBO), wherein there are an abnormally high number of bacteria in the small intestine, can cause abnormal small bowel dysmotility and malabsorption. This condition leads to symptoms of bloating, flatulence, abdominal discomfort, and chronic watery diarrhea. Nausea and vomiting are not symptoms of SIBO.  
❌ Adverse medication effect:
Incorrect: Insulin generally does not cause nausea or vomiting, as it is an endogenous hormone and therefore well-tolerated. Multivitamins may cause transient nausea if taken on an empty stomach, but they would not be expected to cause symptoms outside of that timeframe.  
❌ Autoimmune reaction to gluten proteins:
Incorrect: Celiac disease is caused by autoantibodies to dietary gluten that cause intestinal mucosal inflammation, villous atrophy, and crypt hyperplasia when gluten is ingested. Symptoms stem from malabsorption and include diarrhea, flatulence, and nutrient deficiencies. The diagnosis is confirmed by serum antibody testing and upper endoscopy with duodenal biopsies.  
❌ Subepithelial collagen deposition:
Incorrect: Collagenous colitis (a form of microscopic colitis) is characterized by a layer of deposited collagen in the subepithelial colonic tissue. Microscopic colitis occurs most commonly in older women (> 60 years of age) and symptoms include chronic, non-bloody, watery diarrhea multiple times per day. Nausea and vomiting are not symptoms of colitis.  
✅ Impaired neural control of gastric function:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 2-week-old newborn boy is brought to the emergency department by his parents due to irritability and difficulty feeding over the past few days. Medical history is significant for a red, sac-like lesion noted shortly after birth that was located on the lower back, which presented with flaccid paralysis of the lower limbs and absence of rectal tone. The patient subsequently underwent surgery for the removal of the sac-like lesion. At present, the patient’s temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 120/min, respirations are 40/min, and blood pressure is 70/40 mmHg. An examination of the eyes is shown below:  



 Retrieved from: Wikimedia Commons    

The other eye reveals similar findings. This infant’s underlying condition is most likely caused by which of the following processes?
questions.solution:
The combination of irritability, difficulty feeding, and papilledema (all indicative of increased intracranial pressure), along with a recent spinal surgery for a symptomatic sac-like lesion on the lower back (myelomeningocele), is suggestive of Chiari type II malformation. Chiari malformations are a heterogeneous group of congenital disorders typified by anatomic anomalies of the cerebellum and brainstem, with downward herniation of the cerebellum into the spinal canal.  

Chiari II malformation is defined by herniation of both the cerebellar vermis and tonsils (mnemonic: type 2 includes 2 structure) via the foramen magnum, leading to aqueductal stenosis and noncommunicating hydrocephalus (which leads to increased intracranial pressure). Chiari II malformation is often seen with myelomeningocele and is more likely to present early in life. Myelomeningocele is a type of open neural tube defect typified by herniation of the meninges and the spinal cord through a bony defect. The presentation depends upon the level of the lesion and usually involves sensory, motor, bowel, and bladder deficits.

In contrast, Chiari I malformation involves the downward displacement of only the cerebellar tonsils, is associated with syringomyelia, and usually presents in adolescence or adulthood.    

 

Option Analysis

❌ Infection:
Incorrect: Meningitis in a newborn does tend to present with nonspecific signs such as irritability and difficulty feeding. However, the vitals in this case are normal, and the presence of papilledema suggests another diagnosis.    
❌ Malignancy :
Incorrect: Intracranial tumors can lead to increased intracranial pressure and papilledema as seen here; however, the combination of a recent spinal surgery for a sac-like lesion and the presence of increased intracranial pressure on exam favors another diagnosis.   
✅ Herniation :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Autoimmune :
Incorrect: Guillain-Barré syndrome (acute inflammatory demyelinating polyradiculopathy) is an autoimmune condition characterized by the destruction of Schwann cells. It does present with flaccid paralysis, but it would not present with signs of increased intracranial pressure. Furthermore, this patient’s history of surgical correction for a spinal lesion (likely a myelomeningocele) favors a different diagnosis.  
❌ Ischemic :
Incorrect: Conditions that might affect the blood flow to the brain include conditions such as stroke, vasculitis, and sickle cell disease. However, the combination of a recent spinal surgery for a sac-like lesion and the evidence of increased intracranial pressure favors another diagnosis.

questions.text: A 19-year-old man is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of abnormal behavior. He was having lunch with his family when he noted a pungent smell of burning rubber followed by uncontrollable lip smacking. The patient became unresponsive for a minute after which his whole body started shaking, and he fell to the ground. The patient experienced urinary incontinence during the episode. Past medical history is significant for seizures in childhood precipitated by high fevers. The patient’s temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. The patient appears confused and is unable to recall what happened. Physical examination shows bite marks on the tongue. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Focal seizures are defined as seizures originating in a single cerebral hemisphere. These are usually preceded by aura, depending on the area involved in the abnormal discharges, and are sub-divided into simple or complex based on whether consciousness is intact or lost. This patient most likely had a complex focal seizure arising from the temporal lobe, based on localization findings of olfactory hallucinations (smelling burning rubber) followed by automatisms (lip smacking) and loss of consciousness. Moreover, it secondarily generalized into tonic-clonic seizure, as evidenced by generalized shaking and tongue biting. Seizures arising from the temporal lobe are usually due to mesial temporal sclerosis, which is associated with childhood febrile seizures.  



Option Analysis

❌ Simple focal seizure:
Incorrect: Focal seizure with retained awareness (also called simple focal seizure) is a type of focal seizure in which the patient returns immediately to their pre-event baseline without losing consciousness. This patient has lost consciousness and is having postictal confusion.  
✅ Focal seizure with secondary generalization:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Stroke:
Incorrect: Stroke is very uncommon in this age group. When present, it is usually associated with genetic, cardiac, vascular or hematologic abnormalities, or CNS infections. It usually manifests as hemiparesis, aphasia, headache and/or vomiting. It is unlikely in this patient with olfactory aura and motor automatisms.  
❌ Febrile seizure:
Incorrect: A febrile seizure usually occurs between the age of 6 months to 6 years. It is associated with high fevers. Although this patient has a history of febrile seizures, the current body temperature is normal.  
❌ Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy:
Incorrect: Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy is a type of familial generalized epilepsy disorder that manifests as involuntary jerking movements involving both the extremities in adolescents. However, consciousness is preserved during and after the episode, with symptoms usually occurring in the morning.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male comes to the physician’s office due to scrotal pain for the past 2 weeks. The patient describes a dull pain and noticed that his scrotum appears larger. He also felt fatigued and hot for the past 2 months and thinks that his vision has become blurrier. Medical history is significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia. The patient has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes per day for 30 years. Medications include lovastatin and ramipril. The patient’s temperature is 37.7°C (99.9°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 145/85 mmHg. Physical examination reveals facial flushing. Examination of the scrotum shows left side swelling which is not reduced when the patient is lying down. When light is applied to the testicle it does not transilluminate. This patient’s underlying condition most likely originated from which of the following areas?
questions.solution:
This patient has a significant smoking history and hypertension, and he is now presenting with fatigue, low-grade fever, and blurry vision. This presentation, along with the physical exam showing testicular swelling that is not reduced when lying, is suggestive of a renal tumor. Varicoceles that fail to empty when the patient is recumbent are highly suspicious for a kidney tumor that obstructs the gonadal vein where it enters the renal vein. The facial flushing, hypertension and blurry vision are most likely secondary to ectopic production of erythropoietin by the renal tumor.   

Renal cell carcinomas (RCCs) are the most common primary tumors of the kidney, originating from the proximal convoluted tubules within the renal cortex. Transitional cell carcinomas of the renal pelvis are the second most common. Patients with RCC can present with a variety of symptoms, but unfortunately, such symptoms usually occur late in the course, when metastasis has already occurred. The classic triad of RCC includes flank pain, hematuria, and palpable abdominal renal mass. Hematuria occurs when the tumor invades the collecting system. When the tumor invades the inferior vena cava, it may lead to lower extremity edema, ascites, hepatic dysfunction (related to Budd-Chiari syndrome), and pulmonary emboli. RCC can cause various paraneoplastic syndromes including polycythemia/ erythrocytosis (due to EPO production), hypercalcemia (due to PTHrP production). Increased incidence of RCC is associated with smoking and obesity.   

Option Analysis

❌ Bone marrow:
Incorrect: Polycythemia vera is a myeloproliferative disorder in which the bone marrow makes too many red blood cells. Occasionally, the condition may result in the overproduction of white blood cells and platelets as well. Although this patient’s hypertension, blurry vision, and facial flushing can also be seen in polycythemia vera, varicoceles are not expected.   
❌ Testicles:
Incorrect: Testicular tumors also do not transilluminate, but these tumors usually present with a testicular mass rather than swelling. Also, a testicular tumor would not explain the patient’s hypertension, facial flushing, and blurry vision.   
✅ Kidney:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Lung:
Incorrect: Lung tumors are not associated with polycythemia as a paraneoplastic syndrome, and therefore, they will not cause facial flushing or blurry vision. Also, a lung tumor would not explain the patient's testicular findings.   
❌ Bone:
Incorrect: Bone tumors are not associated with polycythemia as a paraneoplastic syndrome, and therefore, they will not cause facial flushing or blurry vision. Also, a bone tumor would not explain the patient's testicular findings.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman, para 4 gravida 2 aborta 2, comes to the clinic for a follow-up appointment after a hospitalization. Two weeks ago, she had an incident of acute, severe abdominal pain and bloody stools. She was diagnosed with portal vein thrombosis. She denies similar episodes in the past. Medical history is notable for Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease as a child. She does not smoke, drink excessive alcohol, or use illicit drugs. She had 2 spontaneous abortions in the first trimester, following 2 successful pregnancies. Family history is remarkable for DVT in her maternal uncle and colon cancer in her father. The physician suspects an inherited condition. Which of the following will prompt further evaluation in this patient?
questions.solution:
Inherited thrombophilia refers to a genetic abnormality of the blood coagulation cascade that increases the risk of thrombosis. The most common presentation is venous thromboembolism (VTE).  

All patients with established VTE should undergo a thorough history and physical examination, imaging, and routine laboratory testing to provide clues for the presence of an inherited thrombophilia or a predisposing acquired condition (e.g., surgery, cancer).  

Inherited thrombophilias include factor V Leiden (most common), prothrombin gene mutation, as well as deficiencies in antithrombin, protein S, and protein C. Inherited thrombophilia should be suspected if any of the following is present:    

  •  VTE at a young age (e.g. <50 years)  
  •  VTE in an unusual location, such as the portal vein or cerebral vein  
  •  Recurrent VTE in an individual 
  •  Multiple first-degree relatives with VTE 
  •  Recurrent miscarriages - 3 consecutive pregnancy losses before 20 weeks  

Option Analysis

❌ Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease as a child:
Incorrect: Inherited thrombophilia should be suspected if: venous thromboembolism (VTE) occurs at a young age (e.g. <50 years), occurs in an unusual location (e.g., portal vein, cerebral vein), there is recurrent VTE in an individual, or there are multiple first-degree relatives with VTE. Another situation that warrants work-up for causes of thrombophilia is when a woman presents with recurrent miscarriages (3 consecutive pregnancy losses before 20 weeks).  
❌ The patient’s family history:
Incorrect: Inherited thrombophilia should be suspected if: venous thromboembolism (VTE) occurs at a young age (e.g. <50 years), occurs in an unusual location (e.g., portal vein, cerebral vein), recurrent VTE in an individual, there are multiple first-degree relatives with VTE. Another situation that warrants work-up for causes of thrombophilia is when a woman presents with recurrent miscarriages (3 consecutive pregnancy losses before 20 weeks). This patient has no first degree relative with VTE.   
❌ The patient’s obstetric history:
Incorrect: Inherited thrombophilia should be suspected if: venous thromboembolism (VTE) occurs at a young age (e.g. <50 years), occurs in an unusual location (e.g., portal vein, cerebral vein), recurrent VTE in an individual, there are multiple first-degree relatives with VTE. Another situation that warrants work-up for causes of thrombophilia is when a woman presents with recurrent miscarriages (3 consecutive pregnancy losses before 20 weeks). This patient had 2 miscarriages.   
✅ The thrombosis location  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ The type of thrombosis:
Incorrect: Patients with thrombophilia often present with venous thromboembolism (VTE) and less commonly arterial thromboembolism. An isolated instance of VTE does not warrant testing for inherited thrombophilia. However, patients with arterial thrombosis in the setting of prior VTE should be specifically tested for antiphospholipid syndrome and antibodies.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man comes to the office due to difficulty swallowing, food regurgitation, and chest pain for the past several months. The patient describes difficulty swallowing both liquids and solids. He often regurgitates large pieces of undigested food mixed with saliva. History is notable for drinking 2 beers every evening and smoking 1 pack of cigarettes per day for the past 5 years. He has had no recent illness, weight loss, or fatigue. He has not traveled out of the country recently. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination, including cardiopulmonary examination, is normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with dysphagia to both fluid and solids, regurgitation of big chunks of food mixed with saliva (implying food has not reached to the stomach), which favors the diagnosis of achalasia.  

Achalasia is a functional disorder of the esophagus resulting from inflammation and degeneration of neurons in the esophageal wall. In particular, the condition preferentially affects the myenteric (Auerbach) postganglionic inhibitory neurons, which contain nitric oxide and vasoactive intestinal peptide (which promote relaxation). The cholinergic neurons that contribute to lower esophageal sphincter (LES) tone by smooth muscle contraction are relatively spared. The result is decreased peristalsis movement in the distal esophagus and absence of relaxation of the LES, resulting in dysphagia to both liquids and solids. Achalasia can be primary (idiopathic) or secondary (e.g. Chagas disease).  

 

Option Analysis

❌ Globus sensation:
Incorrect: Globus sensation is a sensation of a lump or foreign body in the throat in the absence of symptoms of gastroesophageal reflux disease or other esophageal motility disorder. Although a definitive diagnosis requires further investigation, this patient’s presentation favors another diagnosis.   
❌ Esophageal cancer:
Incorrect: Esophageal cancer typically presents with progressively worsening dysphagia (dysphagia to solids initially followed by food later in the course). The most common types are squamous cell carcinoma and adenocarcinoma. Although this patient has significant risk factors for the condition, patients rarely present before the age of 55. Additionally, these symptoms favor another diagnosis.   
✅ Achalasia :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Gastroesophageal reflux disease:
Incorrect: Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) classically presents as heartburn and regurgitation. Other symptoms include dysphagia, chest pain, odynophagia, and extraesophageal symptoms (e.g., chronic cough, hoarseness). Patients often describe regurgitation of acidic material intermixed with small amounts of undigested food. This patient has dysphagia to both liquids and solids, as well as regurgitation of big chunks of food mixed with saliva, which favors another diagnosis.   
❌ Diffuse esophageal spasm:
Incorrect: Diffuse esophageal spasm (DES) is a medical condition characterized by uncoordinated esophageal contractions that present as dysphagia, regurgitation, and chest pain. The pain often simulates myocardial ischemia but without relation to exertion. There is no relationship to food, but it can be triggered by cold fluids. Barium study may show a “corkscrew”’ pattern at the time of the spasm. Manometry typically shows high intensity, disorganized, simultaneous contractions.

questions.text:
A 4-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parent because of a sore throat for the past 2 days. The patient’s parent reports that the patient feels tired all the time and has not been interested in playing his favorite video games over the last several weeks. Temperature is 38.3°C (101°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 105/65 mmHg. Physical examination shows pharyngeal erythema without exudates, mucosal pallor and petechiae on lower extremities. Abdominal examination reveals hepatosplenomegaly. Peripheral blood smear is shown below:  



 Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons 

The cells stain positive for terminal deoxynucleotidyl transferase (TdT) and CD10. The cells identified in this patient’s peripheral blood smear are precursors to which of the following cell types?
questions.solution:
This child’s presentation with fever, fatigue and sore throat (infection), together with lymphoblasts on peripheral smear and positive cell staining for terminal deoxynucleotidyl transferase (TdT) and CD10, is strongly suggestive of B-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia (B-ALL).  

ALL is a neoplasm of pre-B or pre-T cells. It is defined as the clonal expansion of malignant lymphoblasts in the bone marrow. It is the most common cancer in children and occurs more frequently in boys. It is associated with Down syndrome. Pathogenesis involves chromosomal aberrations including mutations in NOTCH1 (T-ALL) or translocation of t(12;21) or, rarely, t(9;22) (B-ALL). B-ALL accounts for approximately 70-80% of cases and peaks at around 3 years of age. Lymphoblasts stain positive for TdT, a specialized DNA polymerase that is expressed in pre-B and pre-T cells. B-cell lymphoblasts express CD10, CD19 and CD20.  

Clinically, ALL presents with findings of anemia (fatigue, dyspnea), thrombocytopenia (easy bruising), dysfunctional leukocytes (infections), hepatosplenomegaly, and/or lymphadenopathy. It may also manifest with mass effects secondary to neoplastic infiltration of the sub-periosteum (bone pain, refusal to bear weight), the central nervous system (headache, vomiting) or, rarely, the testicles (seen in T-ALL). Bone marrow biopsy shows ≥20% lymphoblasts which have scant basophilic cytoplasm and a large nucleus. Definitive diagnosis requires immunophenotypic evidence of lymphoid lineage by flow cytometry. Prognosis depends on age, gender and translocation (t[9;22] is associated with a worse prognosis).  



Option Analysis

❌ Monocytes:
Incorrect: The precursors of monocytes (myeloblasts, monoblasts and promonocytes) give rise to the M4 and M5 subtypes of acute myeloid leukemia (AML). AML is uncommon in children and expresses monocyte differentiation markers (e.g. CD14, CD4, CD64). Moreover, peripheral blood smear shows immature monoblasts with nuclear atypia and fine azurophilic granules.  
✅ B lymphocytes:
Correct: See Main Explanation  
❌ T lymphocytes:
Incorrect: Although T and B cell precursors appear similar on peripheral blood smear and both stain positive for TdT, pre-T cell surface markers are different and include CD2-5, CD7 and CD8. Moreover, T-ALL usually presents in adolescence with an anterior mediastinal mass and/or mass effects (eg, SVC-like syndrome, dysphagia, dyspnea).  
❌ Erythrocytes:
Incorrect: A rare subtype of acute myeloid leukemia, pure erythroid leukemia (M6) arises from erythroid precursors and mostly occurs in elderly patients. The cells express CD117 and appear on peripheral smear as abnormal erythroblasts with nuclear pulverization (loss of normal nuclear architecture), admixed with myeloblasts.  
❌ Platelets:
Incorrect: Acute megakaryoblastic leukemia, a subtype of acute myeloid leukemia (M7), arises from mutations involving primitive megakaryoblasts. It is associated with Down syndrome and does not cause splenomegaly. Megakaryocytic surface markers include CD41 and CD61.

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman comes to the emergency department due to an acute onset of epigastric pain. The pain started 30 minutes ago while she was gardening. She has been feeling nauseous and vomited once since the pain started. She denies chest pain or shortness of breath. Her medical history is significant for a 20-pack-year smoking history, hypertension, peptic ulcer disease, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and cholelithiasis. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 145/85 mmHg. The patient appears distressed and diaphoretic. Physical examination shows normal heart sounds with no murmurs or gallops on auscultation. Lung auscultation reveals normal breath. Abdominal examination shows a soft, nontender abdomen with normal bowel sounds. Which of the following investigations should be immediately performed in this patient?
questions.solution:
This female patient’s presentation with multiple coronary artery disease (CAD) risk factors (older age, smoking, hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus) and acute onset of epigastric pain and vomiting prompts immediate cardiac evaluation, including an electrocardiogram (ECG) and cardiac biomarkers (e.g. troponins) in order to rule out acute coronary syndrome (ACS). This patient’s presentation highlights the fact that certain populations may have atypical presentations of ACS, including women, older patients, and patients with diabetes mellitus.   

The typical presentation of ACS includes “crushing” substernal chest pain that radiates to the shoulder, neck, and/or jaw, along with associated symptoms such as dyspnea and diaphoresis. As seen in this case, atypical presentations may include more subtle chest pain, epigastric pain, or no pain at all. These patients may present only with dyspnea, palpitations, nausea and/or vomiting, or syncope. These atypical presentations can delay prompt diagnosis and management, leading to worse outcomes. Therefore, one must have a high index of suspicion in patients with multiple CAD risk factors who present with vague symptoms. Other tests may be considered but are not urgent as ruling out ACS. Thus, the best initial test in all patients with chest pain and in high-risk patients is an ECG.   

Option Analysis

❌ Colonoscopy:
Incorrect: A colonoscopy may be used to evaluate a number of gastrointestinal conditions including polyps, cancer, and diverticular disease. An urgent colonoscopy may be indicated in an older patient presenting with iron deficiency anemia or other evidence of gastrointestinal bleeding. This older female patient’s vague presentation of epigastric pain with multiple cardiac risk factors instead warrants urgent cardiovascular evaluation.   
❌ Abdominal ultrasound:
Incorrect: An abdominal ultrasound can help diagnose a number of abdominal and pelvic conditions such as cholelithiasis, acute cholecystitis and ovarian pathologies. This older female patient’s vague presentation of epigastric pain with multiple cardiac risk factors warrants urgent cardiovascular evaluation.   
❌ Serum amylase and lipase  :
Incorrect: Serum amylase and lipase can be obtained to support the diagnosis of acute pancreatitis. While the patient does have gallstones, which is a common cause of pancreatitis, this presentation is not consistent with acute pancreatitis. This older female patient’s vague presentation of epigastric pain with multiple cardiac risk factors instead warrants urgent cardiovascular evaluation.   
✅ Electrocardiogram:
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ D-dimer:
Incorrect: D-dimer is used to exclude pulmonary embolism when there is low clinical suspicion. This older female patient’s vague presentation of epigastric pain with multiple cardiac risk factors instead warrants urgent cardiovascular evaluation.   
❌ Upright abdominal x-ray:
Incorrect: An upright abdominal x-ray can help evaluate for a bowel obstruction by visualizing dilated loops of bowel and air-fluid levels. This older female patient’s vague presentation of epigastric pain with multiple cardiac risk factors instead warrants urgent cardiovascular evaluation.

questions.text: An 80-year-old man presents to the primary care physician with a chief complaint of a new rash that suddenly appeared several days ago. He reports the rash is not itchy, and he has not had a similar rash in the past. When questioned further, the patient reports a several-month history of abdominal pain, weight loss, early satiety, and fatigue. He reports discomfort in the mid-epigastrium postprandially that started one year ago and has worsened. The patient took a proton pump-inhibitor, which initially alleviated the pain but now has no effect on symptoms. He has lost 9.1-kg (20-lb) over the past six months. Further past medical history includes coronary artery disease, hypertension, recurrent H. pylori gastritis, and a twenty one pack year smoking history. Physical examination shows multiple seborrheic keratoses on his chest and back, as well as temporal wasting. Multiple enlarged supraclavicular lymph nodes are noted, predominantly on the left side. Laboratory results reveal a hemoglobin level of 8.0 g/dL and mean corpuscular volume of 70 fL. Which of the following findings is most likely to be present on endoscopic evaluation?

choices.text: Ulcerated mass on the lesser curvature with raised margins
Grossly thickened stomach wall with a leathery appearance
Fibrotic tissue at the pyloric sphincter
Round defect with a smooth base on the lesser curvature
Ill-defined white-yellow mass extruding from the sphincter of Oddi

questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation with a history of weight loss, early satiety, fatigue, a Leser-Trélat sign (the sudden appearance of diffuse seborrheic keratoses), and enlarged Virchow's node is concerning for intestinal gastric adenocarcinoma. Gastric adenocarcinoma is generally asymptomatic until the cancer is at an advanced stage. Typical signs and symptoms include weight loss, anorexia, dyspepsia, dysphagia, epigastric pain, and early satiety. The development of dysphagia is a common symptom when the tumors involve the proximal stomach or cardia. Additionally, some patients may develop upper gastrointestinal bleeding, causing hematemesis or melena.  

Gastric cancer is divided into two subtypes: intestinal and diffuse. Risk factors for intestinal gastric adenocarcinoma include diets high in nitrosamines (a component of smoked foods), smoking, and chronic H. pylori infection. In contrast, diffuse gastric cancer more commonly arises as a result of genetic mutations and is not associated with chronic H. pylori infection. In either case, advanced disease classically metastasizes to the supraclavicular lymph nodes (Virchow node), periumbilical lymph nodes (Sister Mary Joseph Nodule), and to the ovaries in biological females (Krukenberg tumor). Overall survival for gastric adenocarcinoma is poor due to its paucity of signs and symptoms until late in the disease process. Treatment typically involves chemotherapy or surgical resection, depending on the burden of disease.   

Option Analysis

✅ Ulcerated mass on the lesser curvature with raised margins:
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Grossly thickened stomach wall with a leathery appearance:
Incorrect: Linitis plastica is the gross pathological description of diffuse gastric cancer. This type of gastric adenocarcinoma is more commonly hereditary and is not associated with chronic H. pylori infection. Diffuse gastric adenocarcinomas secrete copious amounts of mucus. The mucus inside the cell pushes the nucleus to the periphery, giving it the histologic nomenclature of a “signet-ring cell.”  
❌ Fibrotic tissue at the pyloric sphincter:
Incorrect: Gastric outlet obstruction is characterized by a physical obstruction at the gastric pylorus, which is more commonly due to fibrotic tissue in older patients with a history of untreated duodenal peptic ulcer disease. These obstructions are generally characterized by recurrent non-bilious vomiting. The condition is less likely in this patient with associated systemic features concerning for an underlying malignancy.  
❌ Round defect with a smooth base on the lesser curvature :
Incorrect: Discomfort in the mid-epigastrium relieved by proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) is typical in peptic ulcer disease. Benign ulcers typically have smooth bases with regular borders. However, this patient has systemic features concerning for an underlying malignancy, and the pain has stopped responding to PPIs.  
❌ Ill-defined white-yellow mass extruding from the sphincter of Oddi:
Incorrect: Pancreatic adenocarcinoma typically presents with painless jaundice and weight loss. Similar to gastric adenocarcinoma, patients may also present with a Leser-Trélat sign and enlarged supraclavicular lymph nodes. However, without associated jaundice, a diagnosis of pancreatic adenocarcinoma is less likely.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman comes to the clinic due to a breast mass she noticed while showering. The patient is healthy, and she has no significant medical history. She is concerned because she recently found out she is a carrier of BRCA1 mutation. Her mother was diagnosed with breast cancer at the age of 48 and her sister at 46 years. The patient does not smoke or use alcohol excessively. Vitals are within normal limits. On physical examination, a well-circumscribed, soft non-tender mass is palpated in the right breast. There are no nipple or skin changes, and no palpable lymph nodes. A core-needle biopsy is obtained and reveals sheets of large anaplastic cells with dense lymphocytic infiltrates. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient has carcinoma with medullary features, a special type of triple-negative cancer comprising approximately 5% of invasive breast cancers. Triple-negative means negative for estrogen receptors, progesterone receptors, and excess HER2 protein. Clinically, it presents as a soft, palpable, circumscribed mass which may appear with or without lymphadenopathy. It is often seen as a round, oval or lobulated mass on mammography, which makes it hard to distinguish from benign tumors. On histology, it is characterized by a syncytial growth pattern, with large sheets of anaplastic cells with prominent lymphoplasmacytic infiltrate, and some areas of necrosis. The tumor cells are usually poorly differentiated (high-grade). This type of carcinoma is often associated with germline BRCA1 mutations; however, the majority of cancers in patients with BRCA1 gene mutations are not medullary. The prognosis for carcinoma with medullary features seems to be more favorable than that of infiltrating ductal carcinomas, despite their aggressive histologic appearance.  



Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons 

Option Analysis

❌ Comedocarcinoma :
Incorrect: A comedocarcinoma is a subtype of ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) which is characterized by extensive necrosis, aggressive behavior, and increased risk for recurrence. On histology, the lesion plugs the lactiferous duct and exhibits necrosis. Transected ducts produce cheese-like necrotic tissue that extrudes when gentle pressure is applied.   
❌ Fibroadenoma :
Incorrect: Fibroadenoma is the most common benign tumor of the breast, commonly seen in women in reproductive age. Patients often present with a small, well-defined, mobile mass on physical examination. On histology, it is characterized by nests of proliferation of the ductal elements embedded in a fibrous stroma. Although clinically fibroadenoma is difficult to distinguish from medullary breast cancer, the histology results in this case excluded this diagnosis.   
❌ Phyllodes tumor:
Incorrect: Phyllodes tumors are uncommon fibroepithelial breast tumors that typically present as a painless smooth, multinodular, well-defined, firm and mobile mass. On histology, the tumor is characterized by “phyllodes” (Greek for “leaflike”) growth pattern with bulbous nodules of proliferating stromal cells covered by epithelium. Phyllodes are typically seen in the 5th decade. This patient’s age and histological findings favor another diagnosis.   
✅ Medullary carcinoma:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Invasive ductal carcinoma:
Incorrect: Invasive ductal carcinoma is the most common type of breast cancer. Ductal carcinoma typically produces an extensive desmoplastic response, which is the growth of fibrous or connective tissue that surrounds the tumor and replaces the normal breast tissue. This reaction leads to an identifiable mammographic and sonographic density, and a hard, palpable irregular mass upon examination. On histology, the appearance varies from well-developed tubules to sheets of anaplastic cells. The histological presence of lymphocytic infiltrate and soft mass on physical examination favors another diagnosis in this case.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman comes to the office after discovering a lump in the left breast. She first noticed the mass on self-examination several weeks ago. Medical history is significant for smoking 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 10 years. She drinks alcohol socially and does not use illicit drugs. Vitals are within normal limits. On physical examination, a tender, circumscribed mass is palpated at the upper outer quadrant of the left breast. The patient is referred for biopsy, and the results are shown below:  


Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons  

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient has a fibroadenoma, the most common benign tumor in the breast, accounting for 50% of all breast biopsies. It is commonly found in women between the ages of 15 and 35 years. Simple fibroadenomas are benign solid tumors composed of glandular as well as fibrous tissue. It typically presents as a small, well-defined, mobile mass; however, multiple fibroadenomas may occur in the same breast or bilaterally. The etiology of fibroadenomas remains unclear, but a hormonal association has been established as they persist during the reproductive years (when estrogen levels are high), increase in size during pregnancy or with estrogen therapy, and regress after menopause (when estrogen levels become low). On ultrasound, fibroadenomas are seen as a well-defined solid mass. They can be managed with 3-6 months of ultrasound follow-up or a core needle biopsy for definitive diagnosis. On biopsy, it is characterized by a mixture of proliferating ductal elements (adenoma) nested in loose fibrous tissue (fibroma).  

Option Analysis

✅ Fibroadenoma :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Fat necrosis:
Incorrect: Fat necrosis typically occurs after trauma or surgery and presents as a firm and irregular mass. Fat necrosis from trauma is typically accompanied by skin ecchymosis, though the patient may not recall the specific trauma. Fat necrosis can be difficult to clinically distinguish from a malignant mass, and biopsy is often required. On histology, necrotic fat and giant cells are expected.  

 Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons   
❌ Ductal carcinoma in situ:
Incorrect: Ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) refers to a localized tumor that arises from monoclonal proliferation of the terminal duct cells which ductal lumen; by definition, the tumor does not cross the basement membrane. DCIS is typically recognized incidentally on mammogram screening as microcalcifications and rarely as a stony hard mass on physical examination.  


Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons  
❌ Paget disease:
Incorrect: Paget disease refers to an extension of underlying DCIS or invasive breast cancer to the lactiferous ducts and contiguous skin of the nipple, which presents as eczematous  patches over the nipple and areolar skin. On histology, collections of malignant, intraepithelial adenocarcinoma cells (Paget cells) are seen within the epidermis of the nipple.  


Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman presents to the emergency department due to sudden left-sided weakness. She reports over the past few weeks she has been experiencing worsening malaise, fevers and dyspnea on exertion, but today she woke up with weakness in her left arm. Past medical history is significant for systemic lupus erythematosus and nephropathy. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 182/85 mmHg. Physical examination demonstrates erythema of the cheeks and bridge of the nose with sparing of the nasolabial folds. There is 1+ edema of the lower extremities bilaterally. Neurologic examination is significant for 3/5 weakness in the left upper extremity and a rightward gaze deviation. Cardiopulmonary examination is significant for a holosystolic murmur best heard at the apex that was not heard at the last examination. Follow-up blood cultures are negative. Which of the following most accurately describes the pathophysiology underlying the clinical features observed in this patient?

choices.text: Deposition of sterile platelet thrombi over heart valves
Vasospasm of a large cerebral artery
Deposition of bacterial vegetations over heart valves
Rupture of an athersclerotic carotid plaque
