Deep vein thrombosis and a patent foramen ovale

questions.solution:
Non-infective endocarditis, or marantic endocarditis, refers to endocarditis that leads to the deposition of sterile platelet thrombi over heart valves. While the pathogenesis of this disease is not fully understood, current theories postulate that endothelial injury caused by circulating cytokines due to pro-inflammatory states (such as systemic lupus erythematosus) causes the deposition and aggregation of large platelet thrombi. The acute injury caused by cytokines results in platelet deposition and migration of inflammatory mononuclear cells to form thrombi interwoven with fibrin and immune complexes. It is important to note that these vegetations are always sterile, in contrast to infective endocarditis. Non-infective endocarditis typically affects the mitral or aortic valves, which explains this patient’s holosystolic murmur best heard at the apex, suggestive of mitral regurgitation.   

The disease is most common in patients with active cancer, lupus, or other hypercoagulable disorders. It presents with similar features to infective endocarditis, such as splinter hemorrhages or stroke-like features, as seen in this patient. However, in contrast to infective endocarditis, there is a higher propensity for vegetations in marantic endocarditis to embolize. Embolization can occur to the brain (resulting in stroke-like features), the eyes (resulting in blindness), the limbs (resulting in ischemia), or the lungs (resulting in pulmonary embolism). Treatment for marantic endocarditis involves treatment of the underlying condition, as well as systemic anticoagulation.  

Option Analysis

✅ Deposition of sterile platelet thrombi over heart valves:
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Vasospasm of a large cerebral artery:
Incorrect: While vasospasm of the middle cerebral artery may cause stroke-like features, it is less likely in this patient with signs and symptoms of endocarditis (e.g., fevers, malaise, new-onset holosystolic murmur).   
❌ Deposition of bacterial vegetations over heart valves:
Incorrect: While infective endocarditis remains a diagnostic possibility in this patient, it is less likely given the history of lupus as well as negative blood cultures.  
❌ Rupture of an athersclerotic carotid plaque:
Incorrect: While lupus can lead to accelerated atherosclerosis, and rupture of an atherosclerotic plaque can lead to stroke-like features, it is less likely in this patient with signs and symptoms of endocarditis (e.g., fevers, malaise, new-onset holosystolic murmur).  
❌ Deep vein thrombosis and a patent foramen ovale:
Incorrect: Patients with SLE are at risk for development of DVT due to widespread systemic inflammation. DVTs tend to present with unilateral lower extremity swelling, whereas the patient in this vignette has bilateral swelling as a result of protein loss nephropathy. Additionally, patients with a patent foramen ovale will typically not have a murmur, as blood flow across the defect is too slow to create substantial turbulence.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old male presents to the emergency department after a witnessed syncopal episode. According to EMS, the patient was walking across the street when he suddenly collapsed. Past medical history is notable for hypertension, type II diabetes mellitus, hyperlipidemia, prior myocardial infarction, and a twenty pack year smoking history. Temperature is 36.1°C (97.0°F), pulse is 202/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 82/62 mmHg. On physical exam, the patient is altered, pale, and has skin that is cool to the touch. Electrocardiogram is demonstrated below:  

 

Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

Based on this patient’s clinical presentation, this cardiac activity is likely the result of which of the following pathophysiologic processes?

choices.text: Re-entrant conduction below or within the bundle of His
Aberrant conduction through the bundle of Kent
Enhanced automaticity from the tricuspid annulus
Reentry circuit within the AV node

questions.solution:
This patient presents after a witnessed syncopal episode with unstable vital signs and electrocardiogram demonstrating monomorphic ventricular tachycardia in the setting of a history of coronary artery disease. Of the answer choices listed, the most likely etiology of this patient’s arrhythmia is an aberrant re-entry mechanism at or below the bundle of His.   

Ventricular tachycardia refers to an ectopic focus of electrical activity within the ventricle. The condition is electrocardiographically characterized by a rapid heart rate (>100 beats per minute) and wide QRS complexes (>120 ms). In general, ventricular tachycardia is further subdivided into monomorphic and polymorphic forms.  

Monomorphic ventricular tachycardia presents with QRS complexes that have a uniform appearance--meaning all of the QRS complexes are identical. Monomorphic ventricular tachycardia is classically associated with myocardial scarring, acute myocardial infarction, or structural heart disease. Polymorphic ventricular tachycardia is characterized by multiple ventricular foci and resultant QRS complexes that vary in amplitude, axis, and duration. Polymorphic ventricular tachycardia can be associated with cardiac ischemia, although it is more commonly due to underlying metabolic derangements, medication toxicities, or inherited channelopathies (e.g., Brugada syndrome, Romano-Ward syndrome).  

Option Analysis

✅ Re-entrant conduction below or within the bundle of His:
Correct: See main explanation  
❌ Aberrant conduction through the bundle of Kent:
Incorrect: Pre-excitation syndromes such as Wolff-Parkinson White (WPW) are characterized by an accessory bypass tract. WPW is electrocardiographically characterized by a delta wave, broad QRS complexes, and short PR interval.   
❌ Enhanced automaticity from the tricuspid annulus :
Incorrect: Multifocal atrial tachycardia (MAT) is defined by an irregularly irregular rhythm with varying intervals and at least 3 distinct P-wave morphologies in the same lead. Patients with underlying pulmonary disease are predisposed to this tachyarrhythmia; however, this patient’s rhythm is regular, and the QRS complexes are wide.   
❌ Multiple atrial micro-reentrant circuits:
Incorrect: Atrial fibrillation is defined electrocardiographically as irregularly irregular QRS complexes with absent p-waves; the impulse originates from multiple atrial micro-reentrant circuits. This patient's rhythm is regular, and the QRS complexes are wide.   
❌ Reentry circuit within the AV node:
Incorrect: Paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia presents with a heart rate ranging between 150 to 250 beats per minute, a narrow QRS complex, and in some cases, absent p-waves. This patient’s electrocardiogram demonstrates wide QRS complexes.

questions.text:
A 38-year-old male presents to the outpatient clinic due to shortness of breath. The patient’s symptoms began around a year ago and have progressively worsened. Past medical history is noncontributory. He has no history of tobacco or illicit substance use. Spirometry is performed and a flow-volume loop is obtained. The patient’s flow-volume loop is shown below on the right (normal is depicted by the flow-volume loop on the left).  

 
 
 Images reproduced from Wikimedia Commons  

Which of the following will most likely be discovered on further evaluation of this patient?

choices.text: History of cirrhosis in the absence of alcohol intake
Obese individual with chronic fatigue and hypersomnolence
Ptosis and diplopia that improves with edrophonium administration

questions.solution:
This patient has shortness of breath, no smoking history, and a flow-volume loop showing an obstructive lung pattern, which raises concerns for alpha-1 antitrypsin (AAT) deficiency. AAT is an enzyme that normally protects the body from elastase. In AAT deficiency, there is impaired hepatic secretion of AAT, which results in emphysema (due to increased breakdown of lung tissue) and liver cirrhosis (due to AAT accumulation within the liver)  

A flow-volume loop can be obtained as part of the work-up process. The graph plots inspiratory and expiratory flow (on the Y-axis) against volume (on the X-axis) while the patient performs maximally forced inspiratory and expiratory maneuvers. The upper-half of the loop (above the X-axis) shows the expiratory effort of the patient, whereas the lower-half of the loop (below the X-axis) shows the inspiratory effort of the patient.  

This patient’s flow-volume loop demonstrates a concave or "scooped-out" appearance that is classically seen in obstructive lung diseases (e.g., asthma, emphysema). Physiologically, the concave pattern seen on expiration occurs due to loss of airway support secondary to destruction of the surrounding lung parenchyma, which causes premature airway closure and air-trapping.  

Option Analysis

✅ History of cirrhosis in the absence of alcohol intake:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Amiodarone intake:
Incorrect: Amiodarone can cause pulmonary fibrosis. This side-effect occurs due to the medication’s toxic effects on pulmonary cells, which results in cell death and fibrosis. This patient’s flow-volume loop suggests an obstructive lung condition, as opposed to the restrictive lung disease pattern seen in patients with pulmonary fibrosis. 
❌ Occupational exposure to asbestos:
Incorrect: Asbestosis is a type of pneumoconiosis caused by chronic inhalation of asbestos fibers. Chronic asbestos exposure results in pulmonary fibrosis, which instead causes a restrictive lung disease pattern to be seen on spirometry. 
❌ Obese individual with chronic fatigue and hypersomnolence :
Incorrect: Obesity hypoventilation syndrome is a form of restrictive lung disease caused by a mechanical limitation of the chest wall to expand to full capacity. However, this patient’s flow-volume loop is suggestive of an obstructive lung condition.
❌ Ptosis and diplopia that improves with edrophonium administration:
Incorrect: Myasthenia gravis is a neuromuscular disorder that results in a restrictive lung disease due to weakness of the inspiratory muscles. This prevents the chest cavity from expanding to its largest potential size. However, this patient’s flow-volume loop is more consistent with that of an obstructive lung condition.

questions.text: A 13-year-old girl is brought to her outpatient provider due to recurrent episodes of dyspnea and wheezing over the past several months. These episodes last around 30 minutes and spontaneously resolve. Past medical history is noncontributory. The patient’s uncle passed away from cystic fibrosis at a young age. In the office, temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 78/min, respirations are 14/min, blood pressure is 112/74 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. The patient is resting comfortably. Physical examination reveals scattered wheezes on chest auscultation. Cardiac and abdominal examinations are noncontributory. Which of the following is the next best step in diagnosing this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Spirometry before and after bronchodilator administration
Sweat chloride test after pilocarpine administration

questions.solution:
This patient has intermittent episodes of shortness of breath that spontaneously resolve. She likely has asthma, which can be diagnosed by performing spirometry before and after bronchodilation administration.  

Asthma is an episodic disorder caused by inflammation and hyperresponsiveness of the bronchial smooth muscle, which leads to reversible bronchoconstriction. Patients develop symptoms in childhood and may present with cough, wheezing, dyspnea, and chest tightness.  

Clinical suspicion for asthma should arise if a patient has symptoms that vary in intensity and severity over time. In addition, two characteristics need to be demonstrated in order to diagnose asthma, which are: 1) evidence of airway obstruction, and 2) reversibility in the degree of obstruction.    

Spirometry is the first-line diagnostic test. During an asthma attack, spirometry will demonstrate results consistent with obstructive lung disease, such as a reduced FEV1/FVC ratio. The reversibility of the airflow obstruction can be tested by administering a short-acting bronchodilator (e.g. albuterol) and repeating the spirometry. Reversibility is defined as a 12% or greater increase in FEV1 after bronchodilator administration.   

Option Analysis

✅ Spirometry before and after bronchodilator administration:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Sweat chloride test after pilocarpine administration:
Incorrect: A sweat chloride test can be used to diagnose cystic fibrosis in patients with respiratory complaints. These patients may also present with frequent foul-smelling stools, recurrent pneumonia, and failure to thrive. However, none of these other symptoms are present in this patient. 
❌ Skin allergy testing:
Incorrect: Although certain allergens such as pet dander, molds, or dust mites can trigger asthma in children, skin allergy testing is not necessary for the diagnosis of asthma. Instead, skin allergen testing can be used as an ancillary test to identify triggers and develop strategies to avoid them.
❌ Chest radiograph after bronchodilator administration :
Incorrect: Chest imaging can be performed if initial testing with spirometry is inconclusive. A chest radiograph can be used to evaluate for structural causes (e.g. vascular ring) that may lead to wheezing.
❌ Serum immunoglobulin E (IgE) measurement :
Incorrect: Patients with asthma typically have elevated IgE levels. However, measurement of serum IgE levels is not needed to diagnose a patient with the condition.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old male presents to the primary care physician with worsening constipation over the past several weeks despite laxative therapy. He has also been experiencing nausea, fatigue, decreased appetite, and weight loss. Past medical history is notable for hypertension, hyperlipidemia, chronic kidney disease stage II, and a twenty pack year smoking history. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 92/min, respirations are 16/min, blood pressure is 143/74 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 96% on room air.  Physical exam demonstrates an ill-appearing man in no acute distress. Chest x-ray is demonstrated below:  

 

Image reproduced from Radiopaedia

Which of the following best describes the mechanism causing this patient’s symptoms?

choices.text: Osteolytic metastases with local release of cytokines
Increase in RANK-ligand mediated bone resorption

questions.solution:
This patient has symptoms of moderate hypercalcemia including constipation, anorexia, and nausea. The history, physical exam, and chest x-ray findings are concerning for a lung malignancy. Of the pathophysiologic processes listed, secretion of parathyroid hormone-related protein (PTHrP) is the most likely etiology. PTHrP mimics the effects of parathyroid hormone and is commonly secreted by various squamous cell malignancies, including lung cancer.  

Extracellular calcium ions regulate numerous biological processes including coagulation, muscle contraction, and cardiac conduction. Serum calcium concentrations are carefully maintained via hormonal regulation with parathyroid hormone (upregulates calcium) and calcitonin (downregulates calcium). The differential diagnosis of hypercalcemia is divided into parathyroid-mediated and non-parathyroid etiologies.  

Parathyroid-mediated etiologies include primary hyperparathyroidism, familial hypocalciuric hypercalcemia, and tertiary hyperparathyroidism. In these conditions, elevated levels of parathyroid hormone results in activation of osteoclasts, leading to increased bone resorption and subsequent hypercalcemia. Non-parathyroid etiologies include hypercalcemia of malignancy, vitamin D intoxication, and chronic granulomatous disorders. Miscellaneous causes include thiazide diuretics, lithium, hyperthyroidism, prolonged immobilization, and milk-alkali syndrome.  

Regardless of etiology, the symptoms are similar and include nausea, malaise, polyuria, and constipation. At high levels, hypercalcemia can lead to stupor and coma. Cardiac conduction abnormalities may also arise, and ECG will demonstrate a shortened QT interval.   

Option Analysis

✅ Secretion of parathyroid hormone-related peptide (PTHrP):
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Osteolytic metastases with local release of cytokines:
Incorrect: Osteolytic bone lesions can occur with metastatic disease, especially in patients with multiple myeloma or breast cancer. However, this patient's clinical presentation and radiographic findings are more consistent with squamous cell cancer of the lung. 
❌ Increased calcitriol production:
Incorrect: Increased production of 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D is the cause of hypercalcemia in cases of Hodgkin lymphoma, non-Hodgkin lymphoma, and granulomatous disorders (e.g. sarcoidosis). However, this patient has an opacity in the left lung and a long history of smoking, which is concerning lung cancer. Lung cancers are more likely to cause hypercalcemia by producing parathyroid hormone-related peptides (PTHrP).
❌ Increase in RANK-ligand mediated bone resorption:
Incorrect: Thyrotoxicosis is a rare but known cause of hypercalcemia and is thought to mediate bone resorption via activation of RANK-ligand. This patient has no history of hyperthyroidism.
❌ Parathyroid hyperplasia:
Incorrect: Patients with severe chronic kidney disease (CKD) can develop hypercalcemia secondary to parathyroid hyperplasia. In contrast, this patient has only mild CKD. Furthermore, this patient has a radiopaque area and cavitary lesion in the left lung, making hypercalcemia secondary to an underlying lung malignancy a more likely diagnosis.

questions.text: A 29-year-old Chinese primigravid woman comes to the clinic at 24 weeks gestation for the first time due to decreased fetal movements. Her prenatal care has been inconsistent, but she has been taking vitamins daily. The patient’s past medical history is significant for anemia. An ultrasound is performed and shows increased placental thickness. The ultrasound also reveals fetal ascites as well as pericardial and pleural effusions. The amniotic fluid index is measured to be 26 cm. Which of the following most accurately describes the predominant form of hemoglobin found in this fetus?
questions.solution:
The ultrasound findings in this case show a massive accumulation of fluid in serous cavities (e.g., ascites, pleural and pericardial effusions), which is characteristic of hydrops fetalis. This fetus likely has hemoglobin Barts disease due to deletion of all 4 alpha-globin genes, resulting in anemia and subsequent high-output cardiac failure causing massive total body edema.  

Hemoglobin Barts occurs when alpha-globin chains are not synthesized, resulting in 4 gamma-globin chains which cluster and form a tetramer. This form of hemoglobin has an extremely high affinity for oxygen, causing widespread tissue hypoxia. The resulting fetal anemia leads to a hemodynamic compensatory process that involves increasing intravascular volume to provide enough tissue perfusion, ultimately leading to the hydrops features commonly seen in these fetuses.    

Hemoglobin Barts disease is incompatible with life, with most cases resulting in fetal death usually in the second through third trimester of pregnancy or within a few hours after birth.  

Hemoblogin Barts disease is more common in individuals of Asian descent, since the cis-deletion of the alpha-globin genes is more prevalent in this population. In this vignette, the mother’s previous history of anemia and Asian descent likely means she is a carrier of the cis-deletion. In order for the fetus to have hemoglobin Barts disease, the child’s father must have had a similar cis-deletion.  



Option Analysis

✅ γγγγ:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ ααββ:
Incorrect:  HbA1 is the predominant form of hemoglobin present in adults, and consists of 2α-globin subunits and 2β-globin subunits. The fetus in this case likely has a severe form of alpha thalassemia, wherein α-globin subunits cannot be synthesized. Hence, it is unlikely this fetus has predominantly HbA1 hemoglobin.
❌ ααγγ:
Incorrect: Fetal hemoglobin (HbF) is a hemoglobin variant made of 2α-globin subunits and 2γ-globin subunits. In healthy fetuses, HbF is the predominant type of hemoglobin since it has a higher affinity for oxygen than adult hemoglobin. The fetus in this case likely has a severe form of alpha thalassemia wherein α-globin subunits cannot be synthesized, therefore making this form of hemoglobin unlikely in the fetus. 
❌ ααδδ:
Incorrect: HbA2 is a minor form of hemoglobin (makes up less than 3% of total hemoglobin) present in adults, and consists of 2α-globin subunits and 2δ-globin subunits. Increased levels of HbA2 can be seen in patients with beta-thalassemia, since these patients have a reduced ability to form HbA1 (ααββ) which requires β-globin subunits. The ultrasound of the fetus demonstrates a severe form of alpha-thalassemia wherein α-globin subunits cannot be synthesized. Hence, it is unlikely this fetus has predominantly HbA2 hemoglobin.
❌ ααβSβS:
Incorrect: Sickle cell disease is caused by a mutation in the β-globin subunit of hemoglobin, resulting in dysfunctional hemoglobin that distorts into a sickle shape. The abnormal hemoglobin can occlude vessels and cause ischemia. Sickle cell disease typically presents early in childhood and would not present with massive effusions and ascites in a fetus.

questions.text: A 34-year-old male with a past medical medical history of HIV, type I diabetes mellitus, and polysubstance abuse presents to the emergency department with worsening cough and night-sweats. He has been unable to sleep at night due to the cough. The patient has occasionally noticed blood in his sputum. He is currently undomiciled, drinks several beers daily, and smokes one pack of cigarettes per day. The patient’s temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 94/min, respirations are 16/min, blood pressure is 136/74 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 94% on room air. A screening PPD test is positive. Which of the following is the strongest risk factor for the development of this patient's disease process?
questions.solution:
This patient who is HIV positive and undomiciled presents with cough, night sweats, and a positive purified protein derivative test. These findings are concerning for active tuberculosis infection. Among this patient’s risk factors, HIV infection carries the highest risk for developing active pulmonary disease.  

Risk factors for tuberculosis include patient-related risk factors and exposure-related risk factors. Homeless populations, prisoners, healthcare workers, and those from endemic countries with a high prevalence of tuberculosis have increased exposure-related risk. Patient-related risk factors that lend toward progression to active infection include systemic diseases (e.g., COPD, diabetes, ESRD), active immunosuppression or HIV infection, extremes of age, and substance use.    

Option Analysis

✅ HIV :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Homelessness:
Incorrect: Homeless populations, as well as prisoners, healthcare workers, and those from endemic countries, are at risk for exposure to tuberculosis. However, immunosuppression is a stronger risk factor for the development of active disease.
❌ Diabetes mellitus  :
Incorrect: Patients with underlying chronic diseases such as diabetes, end-stage renal disease (ESRD), and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) are at risk for developing active tuberculosis. However, HIV infection is the strongest risk factor.   
❌ Active smoking:
Incorrect: Substance use, including smoking and drinking alcohol (>40 g/day) can predispose patients to developing active tuberculosis, but it is not the strongest risk factor for active disease.
❌ Age:
Incorrect: Those at the extremes of age are more susceptible to active tuberculosis infections. However, age is not the strongest risk factor.

questions.text:
A 52-year-old female comes to the primary care physician due to worsening weight gain. She has gained approximately 20 lbs over the past six weeks. In addition, the patient has been experiencing lower extremity edema and has noticed her urine appears more cloudy than usual. Past medical history is notable for hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 76/min, respirations are 18/min, blood pressure is 137/84 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 97% on room air. Physical exam is notable for bilateral pitting edema of the lower extremities. A urinalysis is notable for 4+ protein and oval fat bodies but no hematuria. A renal biopsy is performed, and the following is visualized on light microscopy:  


Reproduced from: Wikipedia  
Which of the following is most suggestive of this patient’s underlying diagnosis?

choices.text: IgG4 antibodies against phospholipase A2 receptor
IgG autoantibody that stabilizes C3 convertase

questions.solution:
This patient has worsening weight gain, edema, and a urinalysis revealing proteinuria and oval fat bodies. In addition, light microscopy demonstrates diffuse capillary and glomerular basement membrane thickening. Taking into account these findings, this patient likely has membranous nephropathy, which is associated with the presence of IgG4 antibodies against phospholipase A2 receptors.   

Membranous nephropathy, also termed membranous glomerulonephritis, is among the most common causes of nephrotic syndrome in adults. Primary disease is thought to be due to antibodies against phospholipase A2 receptors, with titers correlating with disease severity. Secondary disease is associated with drugs (e.g., NSAIDs, penicillamine) and infections (e.g., HBV, HCV, syphilis). Other associations for secondary disease include systemic lupus erythematosus and solid tumors. Pathogenesis involves subepithelial immune complex deposition, which activates the complement system, resulting in damage to podocytes and mesangial cells.  

Light microscopy will demonstrate diffuse capillary and basement membrane thickening, immunofluorescence will demonstrate a granular appearance due to immune complex deposition, and electron microscopy will demonstrate a spike and dome appearance due to subepithelial deposits. Treatment involves a course of corticosteroids, although patients generally have a poor response to treatment.  



Option Analysis

✅ IgG4 antibodies against phospholipase A2 receptor :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Decreased serum levels of C3:
Incorrect: Decreased serum levels of C3 are observed in post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis and membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis. Both conditions are nephritic syndromes. In contrast, this patient's presentation is more consistent with nephrotic syndrome. 
❌ Mutation in type IV collagen:
Incorrect: Alport syndrome is due to a mutation in type IV collagen. This mutation leads to thinning and splitting of the glomerular basement membrane and results in nephritic syndrome. This disease usually presents with associated hearing loss and vision disturbance.
❌ IgG autoantibody that stabilizes C3 convertase:
Incorrect: Type II membrano-proliferative glomerulonephritis is a nephritic syndrome associated with C3 nephritic factor. Periodic acid-schiff (PAS) and hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stains will demonstrate a “tram-track” appearance. In contrast, this patient’s biopsy reveals diffuse capillary and glomerular basement membrane thickening, which is more consistent with the presentation of membranous nephropathy.
❌ Positive glomerular immunostaining for IgA:
Incorrect: IgA nephropathy is a nephritic syndrome characterized by hematuria. It occurs after or concurrently with respiratory or gastrointestinal tract infections. Renal biopsy will demonstrate IgA immune complex deposition in the mesangium.

questions.text: A 26-year-old nulliparous woman presents to the office for the evaluation of infertility. She has been monogamous with her male partner for two years and has had unprotected intercourse regularly since then. She has also been experiencing episodic dull pelvic pain for the past 3 years that usually begins 3 days before menses and resolves after menstruation. She also complains of pain during sexual intercourse for the past 6 months. Her menstrual cycle is regular with periods occurring every 25th day and lasting for 6 days. She usually soaks 5-6 pads during her periods. The couple is currently not using contraception and has no history of sexually transmitted disease. She has had no hot flashes. Speculum examination reveals a moist vaginal mucosa with no abnormalities. Pelvic examination shows a normal-sized retroverted uterus. There is tenderness and nodularity in the posterior cul-de-sac. Semen analysis of her partner is normal. Which of the following is the most likely cause of infertility in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient presenting with infertility and accompanying pelvic pain, dysmenorrhea (painful menstruation) and dyspareunia (painful sexual intercourse) is most likely suffering from endometriosis.  

Endometriosis refers to implantation of endometrial glands and stroma outside the endometrium that grow and trigger an inflammatory response. It commonly involves the ovary, fallopian tubes and uterine ligament but can also affect other structures including the perimetrium, rectovaginal septum, recto-uterine pouch, bowel, diaphragm and pleural cavity. The pathogenesis of this condition is not well-established, although the prevailing theory is retrograde menstruation, in which endometrial cells flow backwards through the fallopian tubes and into the peritoneal cavity during menses. Other less popular theories include lymphatic dissemination, coelomic metaplasia, and a dysfunctional immune system.  

Endometriosis classically presents in women of reproductive age with pelvic pain, vaginal bleeding, dysmenorrhea and deep dyspareunia (due to lesions in posterior cul-de-sac). The inflammatory response associated with endometriosis causes scarring and adhesions of the reproductive structures, inhibiting the release of the ovum, its movement through the fallopian tube or its implantation in the uterus, ultimately causing infertility. Examination findings are variable depending upon the site involved and include tenderness on vaginal exam, posterior fornix nodularity, adnexal mass (endometrioma), and/or immobile uterus. Less common findings include dyschezia (posterior cul-de-sac), urinary frequency and urgency (bladder), and diarrhea/constipation (bowel).  

Option Analysis

❌ Asherman syndrome:
Incorrect: Asherman syndrome results from trauma to basal layer of endometrium leading to fibrosis and intrauterine adhesions. It is commonly caused by uterine manipulation and presents with amenorrhea. It is unlikely in this patient with dysmenorrhea and no history of uterine manipulation.
❌ Fibroids:
Incorrect: Uterine fibroids (leiomyoma) are usually asymptomatic but may present with heavy and painful menstrual bleeding, pressure symptoms like constipation, and infertility. Examination shows an enlarged and irregular uterus. It is unlikely in this patient with a normal-sized uterus and normal menstrual flow.
✅ Endometriosis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Adenomyosis:
Incorrect: Adenomyosis is the presence of endometrial glandular tissue in the myometrium. Findings include heavy menstrual bleeding, dysmenorrhea, pelvic pain, and a uniformly enlarged uterus. It is unlikely in this patient with a normal-sized uterus and normal menstrual flow. 
❌ Premature ovarian failure:
Incorrect: Accelerated follicular depletion can be due to primary ovarian insufficiency or secondary to follicular atresia due to other causes (radiation, chemotherapy, autoimmune). It commonly presents with an irregular menstrual cycle and symptoms of hypoestrogenism (e.g., hot flashes, vaginal dryness), neither of which are seen in this patient.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman comes to the clinic accompanied by her daughter for a follow-up appointment for cognitive decline. During the past 2 years, the daughter says the patient has been having difficulty managing her accounts and is often confused. She has some “good days” when she manages the household and some “bad days” when she is confused and needs assistance. The patient’s partner passed away 3 years ago from a myocardial infarction, and in the past few months, her daughter found the patient talking to him as though he is in the room. About 6 months ago, the patient started having a mild resting tremor in her right hand. Since then, the patient’s movements have slowed down, and she often loses balance. Vitals are within normal limits. No orthostasis is seen. On physical examination, the patient has a flat affect, and a resting tremor is noted in the right hand. The patient walks slowly with small steps and has a kyphotic posture. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with progressive dementia, cognitive fluctuation (“good” and “bad” days), and recent onset of parkinsonian signs, all favoring the diagnosis of dementia with Lewy bodies (DLB).  

DLB is a common type of degenerative dementia. In addition to dementia, a patient with DLB must have at least 2 of the 4 core features, including:

  •  cognitive fluctuations 
  •  visual hallucinations 
  •  rapid eye movement (REM) sleep behavior disorder 
  • parkinsonism, which is characterized by the 4 clinical signs of tremor, rigidity, akinesia, and postural instability (TRAP) 
Patients typically show an early decline in executive function (e.g. calculations), and visuoperceptual ability (e.g. missing traffic signs). The diagnosis of DLB is based upon the presence of core clinical features, history, and physical examination. MRI will likely show nonspecific diffuse cortical atrophy. The hallmark of the disease is the presence of Lewy bodies on pathological examination of the brain; these are eosinophilic intracytoplasmic inclusions containing aggregated alpha-synuclein in the deep cortical layers.  

The differentiation of Parkinson disease from DLB is typically based on the timeline in which symptoms occur. If Parkinsonian motor symptoms are present for more than 1 year before dementia, the diagnosis is Parkinson disease dementia, whereas if dementia occurs concomitantly with or before parkinsonian motor signs, or no more than a year after onset, it is considered dementia with Lewy bodies.    

Several neurodegenerative conditions may present with the classic signs of PD (e.g., tremor, rigidity) which may be hard to differentiate. These conditions are often referred to as Parkinson-plus syndromes and include multiple system atrophy, progressive supranuclear palsy, and DLB. Each has unique features that may help in establishing the diagnosis.  



Option Analysis

❌ Progressive supranuclear palsy:
Incorrect: Progressive supranuclear palsy (PSP) is a neurodegenerative disease characterized by personality and behavior changes, parkinsonism, loss of balance and vertical eye palsy. The absence of vertical eye palsy and marked personality changes favors another diagnosis. 
❌ Parkinson disease:
Incorrect: If Parkinson motor symptoms are present for more than 1 year before dementia, the diagnosis is Parkinson disease dementia. If dementia appears before or together with the motor symptoms, or less than a year after, the diagnosis is considered dementia with Lewy bodies. This patient had signs of dementia a year and a half before motor signs. 
❌ Frontotemporal dementia:
Incorrect: Frontotemporal dementia, formerly known as Pick disease, is characterized by early personality and behavior changes or aphasia. Patients with frontotemporal dementia may also have associated movement disorders (e.g. parkinsonism). This patient has not had marked personality changes. Additionally, parkinsonism, if present, occurs very late in the course of the disease. 
✅ Dementia with Lewy bodies:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Multiple system atrophy:
Incorrect: Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a group of neurodegenerative syndromes with similar underlying brain pathology that are characterized by parkinsonism, autonomic dysfunction, cerebellar abnormalities, and corticospinal degeneration. This patient has no autonomic dysfunction (e.g. orthostatic hypotension), which favors another diagnosis. Additionally, in contrast to idiopathic Parkinson disease, patients with MSA have preserved cognitive function.

questions.text:
A 55 year-old female comes to her outpatient physician because of urinary incontinence. The patient reports a sense of fullness in the bladder and continuous dribbling of urine over the past two months. Past medical history is notable for type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. However, the patient reports being inconsistent in taking her medications. Her temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), blood pressure is 158/91 mmHg, and pulse is 75/min. Physical exam reveals decreased sensation to soft touch and pinprick in the distal arms and legs. Laboratory results are as follows:  
 
 Laboratory value  Result 
 Glucose  167 mg/dL 
 HbA1c  8.1% 
 Postvoid residual volume   170 ml 

Which of the following best describes the pathophysiology of this patient’s symptoms?

choices.text: Impaired parasympathetic innervation of the bladder
Impaired sympathetic innervation of the bladder
Peripheral vascular disease causing reduced blood supply to the urethra
Abnormal connection between the bladder and vagina
Pelvic floor musculature weakness causing hypermobile urethra

questions.solution:
This patient has overflow incontinence secondary to diabetic neuropathy. To understand the mechanism behind the patient’s condition, it is important to first understand urinary tract and pelvic physiology.  

The bladder is connected to the urethra via the urethrovesical junction. At the junction are two sphincters, the internal sphincter which is regulated by the autonomic nervous system, and external sphincter which is regulated by the somatic nervous system.  

Neurological control of the bladder and internal urethral sphincter is provided by both the sympathetic and parasympathetic nervous system. Sympathetic signals ensure continence by preventing detrusor muscle contraction and promoting internal sphincter contraction (increases bladder outlet resistance). In contrast, parasympathetic signals promote micturition by inducing contraction of the detrusor and relaxing the internal sphincter.    

Another line of regulation involves controlling blood flow to the urethra. Increased urethral blood flow increases intraurethral pressure, ultimately preventing urine loss.    

In this vignette, the patient has poorly controlled diabetes that has caused somatic and autonomic neuropathy. The patient’s symptoms of suprapubic fullness, continuous dribbling of urine, and increased postvoid residual volume are consistent with those of overflow incontinence. This condition would manifest if parasympathetic signals had difficulty reaching the bladder or urethra, resulting in a lack of detrusor contraction and urethral sphincter relaxation.    

Option Analysis

✅ Impaired parasympathetic innervation of the bladder:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Impaired sympathetic innervation of the bladder:
Incorrect: This patient has symptoms of overflow incontinence such as bladder fullness, continuous dribbling of urine, and an ultrasound showing an increased postvoid residual volume. The sympathetic nervous system prevents micturition by contracting the internal urethral sphincter and relaxing the detrusor. As a result, reduced sympathetic innervation would cause increased detrusor activity and reduced sphincter tone, resulting in symptoms more consistent with those of urge incontinence.
❌ Peripheral vascular disease causing reduced blood supply to the urethra:
Incorrect: Poorly controlled diabetes mellitus can lead to peripheral vascular disease. In healthy patients, increased blood supply to the urethra increases intraurethral pressure and prevents urinary loss. In contrast, reduced blood flow would cause a decrease in intraurethral pressure, ultimately causing symptoms similar to those seen in stress incontinence.
❌ Abnormal connection between the bladder and vagina :
Incorrect: This describes a vesicovaginal fistula. In patients with this condition, urine from the bladder can pass through the fistula and leak into the vagina, resulting in continuous incontinence. Having an elevated postvoid residual volume or sense of pubic fullness would be atypical in patients with a vesicovaginal fistula.
❌ Pelvic floor musculature weakness causing hypermobile urethra:
Incorrect: A hypermobile urethra can cause stress incontinence. This is because increases in abdominal pressure will be transmitted more to the bladder and less to the urethra. As a result, pressure within the bladder will exceed that within the urethra, resulting in urine expulsion. Stress incontinence typically presents as loss of urine with activities that increase intra-abdominal pressure (e.g., coughing, sneezing, laughing), which is inconsistent with this patient’s presentation.

questions.text:
A 39-year-old man comes to his primary care physician for evaluation of fatigue and 5 kg (11 lb) weight gain over the past 4 months. In addition, the patient reports headaches that are worse in the morning. Past medical history is notable for asthma, and he is currently managed with albuterol and predisonoline inhalers. He is not taking any other medications. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F) and blood pressure is 147/80 mmHg. Physical exam is notable for 4/5 muscle strength in the upper and lower extremities. The patient also has wide reddish-purple streaks on the abdomen. Laboratory testing reveals the following results:  
 
 Laboratory value  Result 
 Sodium  146 mmol/L 
 Potassium  3.8 mmol/L 
 Fasting glucose  133 mg/dL 
 Serum ACTH*  35 pg/mL 
*Normal range: 5-20 pg/mL  
Which of the following findings would be most likely present in this patient’s adrenal glands?

choices.text: Hyperplasia of the zona fasciculata and reticularis
Atrophy of the zona fasciculata and reticularis

questions.solution:
The patient has Cushing disease due to an ACTH-secreting pituitary adenoma, a benign tumor of the pituitary gland. This diagnosis is supported by the elevated ACTH levels on laboratory testing and the morning headaches, since the expanding mass causes elevated intracranial pressure, which is normally highest in the morning. Additional causes of ACTH overproduction include malignancies such as small-cell lung cancer and renal cell carcinoma, which can secrete ACTH as part of their paraneoplastic syndromes, causing Cushing syndrome.  

Regardless of the source, excess ACTH will stimulate the adrenal glands. In particular, ACTH will act on the zona fasciculata and reticularis to induce cortisol and androgen production, respectively. Over time, there will be hyperplasia of both the zona fasciculata and reticularis.   

Excess cortisol leads to severe muscle and skin breakdown. This leads to muscle wasting and thin extremities, easy bruising and abdominal striae (reddish-purple streaks). Patients can also develop fractures secondary to osteoporosis. Cortisol also stimulates gluconeogenesis, which results in hyperglycemia, and increased appetite, which results in weight gain, particularly to the abdomen. There is also fat redistribution to the cheeks, resulting in a round, moon-shaped face, and to the back of the neck, causing “buffalo hump.” Cushing syndrome can also lead to hypertension, since cortisol can act as a mineralocorticoid agonist and amplify the effects of catecholamines.  

Option Analysis

❌ Hyperplasia of the zona glomerulosa:
Incorrect: The zona glomerulosa produces aldosterone. It is regulated upstream by renin and angiotensin. Conditions such as a renin-secreting tumor or sarcoidosis, which increases angiotensin production, would cause hyperplasia of the zona glomerulosa and increased aldosterone production. This would explain the patient’s hypertension but would not account for the striae or muscle weakness.   
❌ Atrophy of the zona glomerulosa:
Incorrect: The zona glomerulosa is involved in aldosterone production, which regulates serum sodium and blood pressure. In contrast, this patient’s symptoms of abdominal striae, muscle atrophy, and hyperglycemia are most consistent with the presentation of hypercortisolism. The zona glomerulosa is not directly involved in cortisol synthesis. 
✅ Hyperplasia of the zona fasciculata and reticularis :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Atrophy of the zona fasciculata and reticularis:
Incorrect: The patient has elevated serum ACTH levels. This finding, in combination with the patient’s morning headaches, is suggestive of a pituitary adenoma. The adenoma will release excess ACTH, leading to increased corticosteroid production by the zona fasciculata and reticularis. Over time, these regions of the adrenal gland will undergo hyperplasia, as opposed to atrophy. 
❌ Hyperplasia of the adrenal medulla:
Incorrect: The adrenal medulla is involved in the production of catecholamines. Catecholamine overproduction may account for the patient’s hypertension and headaches, but it would not account for the muscle weakness and abdominal striae.

questions.text:
A 33-year-old female comes to the clinic for a follow-up visit. She visited several weeks ago for a routine visit, and a complete blood count (CBC) showed mild anemia, with a hemoglobin level of 11.2 g/dL. The physician prescribed her daily oral iron supplementation, and she has been taking it as prescribed. The patient’s menstrual periods have been regular with normal flow. She immigrated from Greece 15 years ago and has had no significant past medical history. Laboratory results obtained at the current visit are shown below:  
 
 Laboratory Value  Result 
 Hemoglobin  11.3 g/dL 
 Mean corpuscular volume  71 fL 

Which of the following sets of additional laboratory findings are most likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
This adult female, who has mild anemia refractory to iron supplementation, likely has B-thalassemia minor. B-thalassemia minor is caused by a mutation of only 1 of the 2 B-globin genes. Patients with the condition usually present with mild microcytic, hypochromic anemia and are asymptomatic. Most patients are unaware that they are carriers; oftentimes, the mild microcytic anemia is incorrectly attributed to iron deficiency, but iron supplements do not benefit these patients since they have sufficient levels of iron.  

Normal adult hemoglobin (hemoglobin A1) consists of 2 alpha chains and 2 beta chains (ααββ) along with heme. Beta-thalassemias, both minor and major, are caused by faulty B-globin chain synthesis due to point mutations in promoter sequences or splice sites, affecting transcription, mRNA processing, and translation, ultimately resulting in decreased B-globin chain synthesis. In patients with B-thalassemia minor, the mildly reduced synthesis of B-globin chains results in increased production of hemoglobin that does not involve incorporation of B-globin, such as hemoglobin A2 (HbA2) and fetal hemoglobin (HbF). Therefore, there is an increased production of HbA2, which consists of 2 alpha chains and 2 delta chains (ααδδ), and occasionally HbF, which consists of 2 alpha chains and 2 gamma chains (αα��).    

Iron studies in patients with thalassemia will show increased iron levels and transferrin saturation. Ferritin levels will be elevated in individuals with thalassemia major and normal/elevated in individuals with thalassemia minor. These findings manifest since the body increases gastrointestinal iron uptake in an attempt to increase hemoglobin synthesis.  




Option Analysis

✅   Serum Ferritin  HbA1  HbA2  HbF  RDW  Increased  Low  Increased  Increased  Normal :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌   Serum Ferritin  HbA1  HbA2  HbF  RDW  Increased  absent Increased  Increased  Normal :
Incorrect:  This set of laboratory findings can be seen in patients with B-thalassemia major. Due to the absence of B-globin synthesis, HbA1 (ααββ), composed of 2 B-globin subunits, would be absent. This deficiency causes a resultant increase in HbA2 (ααδδ), since B-globin subunits are not required for this hemoglobin variant. Additionally, patients with B-thalassemia major typically present with severe hemolytic anemia that requires transfusion early in childhood, making this diagnosis unlikely in an adult female. 
❌   Serum Ferritin  HbA1  HbA2  HbF  RDW LowNormalNormalNormalHigh:
Incorrect: This set of laboratory findings can be seen in patients with iron deficiency anemia (IDA). The low serum ferritin indicates that there is not enough iron available for heme synthesis. This patient was empirically started on iron supplements, which did not improve her condition, making IDA a less likely diagnosis. 
❌   Serum Ferritin  HbA1  HbA2  HbF  RDW NormalAbsentAbsentDecreased Normal :
Incorrect: This set of laboratory findings can be seen in newborns with hemoglobin Barts disease. In this condition, no α-globin is produced, resulting in an absence of hemoglobin variants that incorporate the α-globin subunit (such as HbA1, HbA2, and HbF). However, hemoglobin Barts disease causes an extremely severe form of anemia, and symptoms are present at birth, making it an unlikely diagnosis in this adult female. 
❌   Serum Ferritin  HbA1  HbA2  HbF  RDW  Increased  NormalNormalNormal Normal :
Incorrect: This set of laboratory findings can be seen in patients with anemia of chronic disease. This condition occurs secondary to chronic disease (e.g., rheumatoid arthritis, systemic lupus erythematosus).

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman, gravida 1 para 0 comes to the clinic at 22 weeks of gestation for a follow-up appointment after she had an elevated blood pressure of 145/95 in the previous appointment. The pregnancy has been uneventful so far, and she has been taking prenatal vitamins daily. Medical history is unremarkable. She has not had any headaches, visual disturbances or urinary symptoms. She does not smoke cigarettes, drink alcohol or use illicit drugs. Repeated blood measurements at home are 147/92 and 146/93.  The patient’s current temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 100/min, and blood pressure is 144/93 mmHg. On physical examination, cardiovascular and lung examination are unremarkable. Uterus size is consistent with 22 weeks, and fetal vital signs on nonstress test are reassuring. Urinary protein excretion on 24-hour urine is minimal, and serum creatinine concentration is 1.1 mg/dL. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with elevated blood pressure on 2 separate occasions, no signs of end-organ damage, and normal laboratory values after 20 weeks of gestation, favoring the diagnosis of gestational hypertension.    

Gestational hypertension is defined by the new onset of hypertension at ≥20 weeks of gestation in a patient with systolic blood pressure (SBP) ≥140 mmHg and/or diastolic blood pressure (DBP) ≥90 mmHg, in the absence of proteinuria or signs of end-organ dysfunction. The measurements should be documented on at least two occasions at least four hours apart. Evaluation of gestational hypertension includes measurement of urine protein, evaluation for severe features of preeclampsia (e.g., visual disturbance, renal insufficiency), and assessment of fetal status.    

Treatment of gestational hypertension with antihypertensive medications is not indicated unless hypertension is severe (SBP ≥160 mmHg or DBP ≥110 mmHg), approaching the severe range, or the patient has preexisting end organ dysfunction that may be worsened by hypertension. If criteria for medical management are met, pharmacologic treatments that are safe during pregnancy include labetalol and hydralazine.  



Option Analysis

❌ Normal physiologic response to pregnancy:
Incorrect: During early pregnancy systolic and diastolic blood pressure typically falls approximately 5 to 10 mmHg below baseline due to a reduction in systemic vascular resistance. During the third trimester, blood pressure gradually increases and normalizes to normal values by term.
❌ Chronic hypertension:
Incorrect: Chronic hypertension is diagnosed if the hypertension was first detected before the 20th week of pregnancy. This patient had normal prenatal care and no preexisting conditions, making this diagnosis unlikely. If gestational blood pressure elevation persists after 12 weeks postpartum, the diagnosis is then changed to chronic hypertension. 
✅ Gestational hypertension:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Preeclampsia:
Incorrect: Preeclampsia is defined as new-onset hypertension with either proteinuria or end-organ dysfunction after 20th week of gestation. This patient has no signs of end-organ dysfunction and has normal protein excretion and creatinine. Proteinuria of 300 mg/day in a 24-hour urine specimen or protein/creatinine ratio ≥ 0.3 (30 mg/mmol) defines preeclampsia.   
❌ Eclampsia:
Incorrect: Eclampsia is defined as preeclampsia plus maternal seizures, neither of which are seen in this patient.

questions.text: A 1-hour-old newborn girl is evaluated in the nursery for respiratory distress. She was born at 34 weeks gestation to a 17-year-old primigravida woman who did not receive prenatal care. The patient’s temperature is 36.4°C (97.5°F), pulse is 128/min, respirations are 80/min, and blood pressure is 75/30 mmHg. Oxygen saturation is 85% on room air. On physical examination, she appears cyanotic, and subcostal retractions and nasal flaring are noted. The nasal tip is flattened, the ears are low-set, and the chin is small and retracted backward. Appropriate treatment is initiated. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause for this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with respiratory distress and a characteristic appearance of Potter syndrome, most likely due to oligohydramnios. From the answers above, only preeclampsia, which is associated with placental insufficiency, will likely result in low amniotic fluid and fetal compression.    

Any condition that results in low amniotic fluid production or excretion can lead to fetal compression and Potter sequence. During the first trimester, amniotic fluid volume is derived from the maternal compartment, fetal secretions, and the placenta. During the second trimester, fetal urine becomes the primary source of amniotic fluid. Placental insufficiency (e.g., placental abruption, thrombosis, infarction, preeclampsia) will therefore result in low amniotic fluid production. The results of Potter sequence include severe intrauterine growth restriction, craniofacial and limb deformities, as well as lung hypoplasia. Lung hypoplasia occurs because the fetus needs to aspirate a certain amount of amniotic fluid in order to expand and develop its lungs.  






Option Analysis

❌ Posterior urethral valve:
Incorrect: Posterior urethral valve is the most common cause of urinary tract obstruction in newborn males and is associated with oligohydramnios due to obstruction of urine. It is due to membrane remnants in the posterior urethra leading to urine obstruction. In utero, ultrasound may reveal bilateral hydronephrosis and thickened bladder. This infant is a female and posterior urethral valve occurs exclusively in boys. 
❌ Lung hypoplasia :
Incorrect: Any condition that results in low amniotic fluid production or excretion can lead to fetal compression and Potter sequence. The results of Potter sequence include severe intrauterine growth restriction, craniofacial and limb deformities, as well as lung hypoplasia. Lung hypoplasia occurs because the fetus needs to aspirate a certain amount of amniotic fluid in order to expand and develop its lungs. Lung hypoplasia is a consequence of low amniotic fluid, not a cause. 
❌ Esophageal atresia:
Incorrect: Esophageal atresia will impair the fetus's ability to swallow amniotic fluid and will result in polyhydramnios. High amniotic fluid is not associated with Potter sequence or fetal compression, as seen in this patient. Any cause of high urine production or a decrease in fetal swallowing can lead to polyhydramnios. Potter sequence is associated with conditions that result in low amniotic fluid. 
✅ Maternal preeclampsia  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Maternal diabetes mellitus :
Incorrect: A hyperglycemic state in the mother causes osmotic diuresis in the fetus, which results in polyhydramnios. Common congenital anomalies in infants of diabetic mothers include neurologic abnormalities (e.g. microcephaly), cardiovascular anomalies (e.g. transposition of the great vessels), and gastrointestinal and renal malformations (e.g. duodenal atresia, ureteral duplication). In contrast, Potter sequence is associated with oligohydramnios.

questions.text: A 61-year-old man comes to the clinic for a routine evaluation. He has had a chronic productive cough for the past 5 years, with occasional dyspnea and wheezing. He smoked a pack of cigarettes a day for 40 years, but stopped several months ago. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals bilateral diffuse crackles and rales on chest auscultation. Pulmonary function testing (PFT) is performed, which confirms the diagnosis of chronic bronchitis-predominant chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. Which of the following PFT findings are most likely present in this patient?

choices.text: Diffusing capacity for carbon monoxide (DLCO)  Total lung capacity  ↑   ↑
Diffusing capacity for carbon monoxide (DLCO)  Total lung capacity ↓ ↑
Diffusing capacity for carbon monoxide (DLCO)  Total lung capacity ↓↓

questions.solution:
Chronic bronchitis (CB) is diagnosed on clinical grounds. It is defined by the presence of a persistent productive cough for at least 3 consecutive months in at least 2 consecutive years. Signs and symptoms of CB include productive cough (due to excess mucus secretion) and wheezing (due to airway narrowing).  

CB is characterized by inflammation of the tracheobronchial tree, which leads to increased mucus production. The most important cause is cigarette smoking, which irritates the mucosa of the airways, leading to hypertrophy and hyperplasia of mucinous glands in the main bronchi and goblet cells in the bronchioles. This histological change increases mucus production, causing airway obstruction.   

The subsequent air-trapping causes an increase in total lung capacity. However, in contrast with emphysema, where there is destruction of pulmonary parenchyma, alveolar tissue is relatively intact in CB. Therefore, patients with CB-predominant COPD typically have a normal diffusing capacity for carbon monoxide (DLCO). In contrast, patients with emphysema-predominant COPD have a reduced DLCO.  



Option Analysis

✅   Diffusing capacity for carbon monoxide (DLCO)  Total lung capacity  Normal  ↑ :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌   Diffusing capacity for carbon monoxide (DLCO)  Total lung capacity  ↑   ↑ :
Incorrect: In patients with asthma, there is increased total lung capacity. The DLCO is either normal or elevated, depending on the severity of the asthma exacerbation. One potential explanation for the elevated DLCO is that increases in negative intrathoracic pressure during inspiration draws blood into the thorax. This leads to improved ventilation-perfusion matching secondary to increased perfusion of the lung apices.
❌   Diffusing capacity for carbon monoxide (DLCO)  Total lung capacity ↓ ↑ :
Incorrect: Patients with emphysema typically have increased total lung capacity due to air trapping and decreased DLCO since alveolar destruction decreases the surface area for gaseous exchange. However, this patient has a chronic bronchitis-predominant pattern of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).
❌   Diffusing capacity for carbon monoxide (DLCO)  Total lung capacity ↓↓:
Incorrect: Patients with interstitial lung disease typically have decreased total lung capacity due to irreversible fibrosis of the lung parenchyma. The fibrosis also contributes to poor diffusing capacity for carbon monoxide (CO) across the alveolar wall. 
❌   Diffusing capacity for carbon monoxide (DLCO)  Total lung capacity  Normal  Normal:
Incorrect: This patient with chronic bronchitis-predominant COPD would not have normal lung function on testing.

questions.text: A 17-month-old boy is brought to the physician for developmental delay and aggressive behavior. The patient constantly bites his own finger tips, which has forced his parents to put mittens on his hands. He is unable to walk without assistance and has not yet said words like “mama.” His parent states that she has occasionally noticed yellow, sand-like crystals in his diaper when she changes him. Vital signs are within normal limits. There is increased muscle tone in the extremities. Serum studies show an increased level of uric acid. Activity of which of the following enzymes is increased in this patient?
questions.solution:
This child is presenting with signs of developmental delay, self-mutilating behaviors, and increased serum uric acid. He most likely has Lesch-Nyhan syndrome.    

Lesch-Nyhan syndrome is an X-linked recessive disorder resulting in a deficiency of the enzyme hypoxanthine guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HGPRT), which is necessary in the purine salvage pathway. Since purine waste-products are no longer able to be recycled for purine regeneration, they are instead metabolized into uric acid. Additionally, since recycling can no longer contribute to purine production, increased de novo purine synthesis is required, resulting in an increase in enzymes involved in purine synthesis, such as phosphoribosyl pyrophosphate (PRPP) synthetase. The combination of increased purine degradation and increased de novo purine synthesis (which results in even more purines being broken down into uric acid) leads to hyperuricemia.  

Symptoms in these patients are secondary to hyperuricemia. Urate crystals, often presenting as yellow-orange sand-like crystals, are often found in the diaper. Urate crystals can also deposit in joints, resulting in gout. Additionally, elevated serum uric acid levels interfere with proper neurologic development, resulting in the characteristic aggressive, self-mutilating behavior seen in these patients.



Option Analysis

✅ Phosphoribosyl pyrophosphate synthetase:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Hypoxanthine guanine phosphoribosyltransferase:
Incorrect: Hypoxanthine guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HGPRT) is deficient in patients with Lesch-Nyhan syndrome, and therefore, its activity would be decreased in this patient.
❌ Uridine monophosphate synthetase:
Incorrect: Uridine monophosphate (UMP) synthetase is involved in pyrimidine base production, not purine base production, and therefore, it would not be affected in patients with Lesch-Nyhan syndrome. A deficiency of UMP synthetase is seen in patients with orotic aciduria, which typically presents as folate/B12 resistant megaloblastic anemia in children with failure to thrive. 
❌ Dihydrofolate reductase :
Incorrect: Dihydrofolate (DHF) reductase is involved in pyrimidine base production, not purine base production, and therefore, it would not be affected in patients with Lesch-Nyhan syndrome. DHF reductase is targeted by many pharmacotherapies, such as methotrexate (chemotherapeutic and immunosuppressive drug) and trimethoprim (antibiotic). 
❌ Carbamoyl phosphate synthetase II:
Incorrect: Carbamoyl phosphate synthetase II (CPSII) is involved in pyrimidine base production, not purine base production, and therefore, it would not be affected in patients with Lesch-Nyhan syndrome.

questions.text:
A 9-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parents due to prolonged bleeding following a tooth extraction earlier in the day. Past medical history is noncontributory. Temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 88/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 112/62 mmHg. Physical exam shows gingival bleeding and petechiae. Laboratory testing is obtained, and the results are shown below.  
 
Laboratory value  Result
 Hematologic  
 Hemoglobin  12 g/dL 
 Hematocrit  40% 
 Platelet count  95,000/mm3  
 Leukocyte count  9,000/mm3  
Coagulation studies  
 Prothrombin time (PT)  12 seconds 
 Activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT)  29 seconds 
 Bleeding time*  15 minutes 
*Reference Range: 2-7 minutes  

Which of the following conditions is the patient at greatest risk of developing?
questions.solution:
This patient has prolonged bleeding following a minor surgical procedure (e.g. tooth extraction) as well as a reduced platelet count and elevated bleeding time on laboratory testing. He most likely has an underlying platelet disorder.  

Patients with platelet disorders commonly present with anterior epistaxis, petechiae, purpura, and mucous membrane bleeding. Epistaxis most commonly occurs in the anterior inferior part of the nasal septum, which is a watershed area containing the Kiesselbach plexus, and is relatively mild. In contrast, posterior epistaxis causes a severe and potentially life-threatening hemorrhage secondary to sphenopalatine artery damage.  

Coagulation studies can be used to differentiate between platelet disorders and coagulation disorders. Platelet disorders typically result in increased bleeding time, while coagulation disorders result in increased prothrombin time (PT) or activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT).

Common laboratory tests used in differentiating between the different types of platelet disorders include a complete blood count, peripheral blood smear, renal and liver function tests, ristocetin cofactor assay, and plasma mixing studies.    

Option Analysis

❌ Bleeding from the sphenopalatine artery :
Incorrect: Bleeding from the sphenopalatine artery, also known as posterior epistaxis, is a severe and potentially life-threatening hemorrhage. Anterior epistaxis, which is more mild, is associated with platelet disorders. 
❌ Deep vein thrombosis:
Incorrect: Deep vein thrombosis is a potential complication of a hypercoagulability disorder, such as factor V Leiden, antithrombin III deficiency, prothrombin gene mutation, or protein C or S deficiency. 
❌ Varicocele:
Incorrect: A varicocele can, in rare circumstances, arise secondary to a deep vein thrombosis or thrombosis of the pampiniform plexus. These conditions are more likely to arise in individuals with a hypercoagulability disorder. In contrast, this patient is at increased risk of bleeding.
❌ Hemarthrosis :
Incorrect: Hemarthrosis is defined as bleeding into a joint cavity. It commonly occurs in the knee and is associated with coagulation disorders, such as hemophilia A, B, and C.   
✅ Anterior epistaxis :
Correct: See Main explanation.

questions.text:
A 36-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of chest pain and difficulty breathing that came on gradually over the past two weeks. The patient also describes feeling fatigued and feverish for the past three months. The pain is characterized as a sharp, stabbing pain in both sides of the chest that is worse with deep breathing and sneezing. The dyspnea is characterized by shortness of breath when walking across the street outside her home and is associated with a mild, non-productive cough. She denies any travel outside of the country or any sick contacts at home or work. The patient’s temperature is 37.8°C (100.0°F), pulse is 95/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 128/78 mmHg. Physical examination reveals diminished breath sounds at both lung bases with decreased tactile fremitus. An upright chest X-ray is obtained and shows the following:    


Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons  
Thoracentesis is performed and laboratory tests show the following:  

Laboratory value  Result Reference range 
 Serum  
 Lactate dehydrogenase  50 U/L  45-90 U/L 
 Total protein   7.0 g/dL  6.0-7.8 g/dL 
 Amylase   50 U/L  25-125 U/L 
 Glucose  90 mg/dL  40-70 mg/dL 
Pleural fluid   
 Appearance  Yellow-green, viscous  Pale yellow 
 pH  7.35  - 
 Total protein   4.5 g/dL  - 
 Glucose  40 mg/dL  - 
 Lactate dehydrogenase  80 U/L  - 
 Amylase  25 U/L  - 
 Total nucleated cells  20,000/mm3  0-1,000/mm3 
 Neutrophils  7%  - 
 Lymphocytes  80%  - 
 Monocytes  6%  - 
 Eosinophils  4%  - 
 Basophils  3%  - 
 Microbiological staining  No organisms seen on Gram or acid-fast staining  - 
Which of the following is the most likely underlying etiology of this patient’s findings?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with a pleural effusion secondary to pleuritis from systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). Because SLE is mediated by immune complex deposition, any organ system can be involved. This patient’s chest pain (sharp and worse with deep breathing) is characteristic of pleuritis; the physical examination showing diminished breath sounds and chest X-ray showing blunting of the costophrenic angles indicate bilateral pleural effusions. The patient’s 3 month history of feeling feverish and fatigued indicates a systemic inflammatory disease like SLE, rather than an acute infection like pneumonia.  

SLE commonly involves the membranes and can manifest as: 1) oral or nasopharyngeal ulceration, usually painless, and 2) serositis, resulting in pleuritis or pericarditis. Lupus pleuritis (inflammation of the pleura lining the lungs and inner chest wall) can cause pleural effusions, as seen in this patient, which are usually bilateral.  

Thoracentesis can identify the specific cause of a pleural effusion. Light criteria is used to classify an effusion as either transudative (think: imbalance between hydrostatic and oncotic pressures) or exudative (think: leaky capillaries spilling protein).


Based on her studies, this patient has an exudative effusion by Light criteria. A pleural effusion caused by SLE will be exudative (because of damaged capillaries from immune complex deposition), with a lymphocytic predominance ( >70%), a high lactate dehydrogenase (LDH), and a low glucose.    

Option Analysis

❌ Elevated central venous pressure:
Incorrect: Congestive heart failure leads to increased hydrostatic pressure as fluid backs up into the lungs. This causes a transudative effusion, characterized by lower pleural fluid protein.
✅ Immune complex deposition:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Hypoalbuminemia:
Incorrect: Cirrhosis and nephrotic syndrome lead to decreased synthesis and excessive loss of albumin, respectively, leading to decreased oncotic pressure. This causes a transudative effusion, characterized by lower pleural fluid protein.
❌ Streptococcal infection:
Incorrect: Streptococcus pneumoniae lung infection may cause an exudative parapneumonic pleural effusion. Parapneumonic effusions are more likely to be unilateral (on the side of infection) and are characterized by pleural fluid with a neutrophilic predominance. 
❌ Pancreatic autodigestion:
Incorrect: Acute pancreatitis may cause an exudative pleural effusion via movement of liquid from the abdomen to the pleural space in the setting of inflammatory capillary permeability. However, pleural fluid amylase concentrations are usually high (greater than the serum reference range or serum concentration).

questions.text:
A 65-year-old woman comes to the clinic because of shortness of breath and fatigue for the past 2 months. The patient states that she feels tired all day and has little energy to get out of bed. She also reports frequently stopping to catch her breath after climbing a flight of stairs. Past medical history is significant for breast cancer treated with chemoradiotherapy 10 years ago. Family history is noncontributory. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 101/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. Physical examination shows mucosal pallor but no lymphadenopathy. Laboratory evaluation reveals:  
 
 Laboratory value  Result 
 Complete blood count 
 Hemoglobin   8.0 g/dL 
 Platelet count   70,000/mm3 
 Leukocyte count   16,100/mm3 

Peripheral blood smear is shown below:  

Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient’s clinical presentation (fatigue, dyspnea) in combination with laboratory evidence of anemia, thrombocytopenia and leukocytosis, and peripheral blood smear showing myeloblasts with Auer rods, is consistent with acute myeloid leukemia (AML).  

AML is defined as clonal expansion of malignant immature myeloid cells (>20%) in the bone marrow. It usually arises in older adults (average 50-60 years) and is mostly a result of acquired chromosomal abnormalities, particularly translocations. These mutations cause proliferation of immature myeloid cells in the bone marrow, which suppresses the growth and proliferation of other hematopoietic stem cells. Risk factors for the development of AML include radiation, chemotherapy (as in this patient), tobacco smoking, Down syndrome, and myeloproliferative disorders.

AML is divided into eight types (M0 through M7) based on cytogenetic abnormalities, cell lineage and surface markers. It commonly presents with signs and symptoms of pancytopenia (fatigue, dyspnea, easy bruising and infections). Laboratory analysis may show normochromic normocytic anemia, thrombocytopenia and leukocytosis (due to circulating blasts). Peripheral blood smear reveals myeloblasts with nuclear atypia and fine azurophilic granules. Auer rods are pathognomonic of AML and appear as pink/red rod-like granular structures in the cytoplasm, as shown with the arrow below. Definitive diagnosis requires bone marrow aspiration and biopsy showing ≥20% blast cells.  


Retrieved from:Wikimedia Commons  



Option Analysis

❌ Acute lymphoblastic leukemia:
Incorrect: Acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) is common in children and usually presents with bone pain. Peripheral blood smear shows blast cells with scant agranular cytoplasm and inconspicuous nucleoli. This patient’s peripheral blood smear is evident of myeloblasts.
✅ Acute myelogenous leukemia:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Hairy cell leukemia:
Incorrect: Patients with hairy cell leukemia usually presents with symptomatic splenomegaly and pancytopenia. Peripheral blood smear shows a mononuclear cell with indistinct cytoplasmic outline, giving it a hairy appearance. This smear instead reveals myeloblasts and Auer rods, indicative of AML.
❌ Infectious mononucleosis:
Incorrect: Although infectious mononucleosis is a common cause of prolonged fever and fatigue, it is usually accompanied by pharyngitis, lymphadenopathy and splenomegaly. Peripheral blood smear shows atypical lymphocytes (not myeloblasts).
❌ Recurrence of breast cancer:
Incorrect: Recurrence of breast cancer usually presents as a mass in the chest wall, regional lymphadenopathy (e.g., infraclavicular, supraclavicular, and axillary regions), or changes in the overlying skin. Though it can also present with signs of metastatic disease, bone marrow involvement with pancytopenia is rare. Moreover, myeloblasts with Auer rods are not seen.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman comes to the clinic due to anxiety and eye pain for the past few months. The patient also discloses a 10 lb (4.5 kg) weight loss over the past 2 months without changes in her diet. Medical history is unremarkable, and she does not use caffeine, alcohol, or illicit drugs. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 110/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. On physical examination, the patient's skin is moist, and a diffuse goiter is noted. Examination of the eyes reveals mild exophthalmos and conjunctival erythema. Which of the following is most likely involved in the pathogenesis of this patient’s eye condition?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with classic signs of hyperthyroidism including goiter, tachycardia, diaphoresis, and weight loss. In addition, the patient has exophthalmos, which is a characteristic finding in patients with Graves disease.  

Graves disease, the most common cause of hyperthyroidism, is an autoimmune condition caused by the production of autoantibodies to the thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) receptor (TRAb). These antibodies imitate the action of TSH and activate the receptor, leading to increased thyroid hormone synthesis and secretion, as well as the development of a diffuse goiter (thyroid growth).  

TSH receptors are expressed mainly in the thyroid but are also found in adipocytes, fibroblasts, and other tissues throughout the body. In the eye, the presence of TRAb and activated T cells leads to the activation of retro-ocular fibroblasts and adipocytes. This activation results in the infiltration of mononuclear cells, inflammatory edema, swelling of the extraocular muscles, accumulation of hydrophilic glycosaminoglycans (e.g. hyaluronic acid), and increased numbers of adipocytes (fatty infiltration) in the retro-ocular space. Ultimately, these changes displace the eyeball forward and interfere with extraocular muscle function. Of note, Graves disease and exophthalmos are not synonymous. This distinction exists since some individuals can have orbitopathy without signs of hyperthyroidism (e.g., tachycardia, palpitations, weight loss).  



Option Analysis

❌ Sympathetic hyperactivity:
Incorrect: Stare and lid lag occur in patients with hyperthyroidism. These symptoms are associated with sympathetic overactivity, which is believed to occur due to increased alpha-adrenergic receptor expression in some tissues. Exophthalmos, however, is mediated by a different mechanism.
❌ Thyroid-stimulating hormone:
Incorrect: Thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) is low in patients with Graves disease or toxic multinodular goiter. In patients with Graves disease, thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulin activates the TSH receptors, causing an increased release of thyroid hormone. The high levels of thyroid hormones increase the negative feedback to the pituitary gland and decrease TSH levels. TSH is not the cause of Graves orbitopathy.
❌ T4 hormone:
Incorrect: Thyroid hormones exert their effect throughout the body on various tissue processes including brain maturation, bone growth, β-adrenergic effects (increase β1 receptors in heart), basal metabolic rate (by increasing Na+/K+-ATPase activity), blood sugar levels (by increasing glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis), and break down of lipids (increase lipolysis). However, thyroid hormones themselves are not the cause of Graves orbitopathy.  
❌ T3 hormone:
Incorrect: Thyroid hormones exert their effect throughout the body on various tissue processes including brain maturation, bone growth, β-adrenergic effects (increase β1 receptors in heart), basal metabolic rate (by increasing Na+/K+-ATPase activity), blood sugar levels (by increasing glycogenolysis, and gluconeogenesis) and break down of lipids (increase lipolysis). However, thyroid hormones themselves are not the cause of Graves orbitopathy.
✅ Glycosaminoglycans deposition:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 34-year-old woman comes to the office complaining of consistent diarrhea for the last 2 months. The patient has experienced watery, tea-colored diarrhea that happens even when she has not eaten anything. She denies any associated abdominal pain or difficulty swallowing. The patient feels fatigued and weak with muscle cramps which she attributes to being dehydrated. Medical history includes hyperparathyroidism and nephrolithiasis. The patient’s temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 100/60 mmHg.
