Physical examination shows dry mucous membranes and decreased skin turgor without abdominal tenderness. Laboratory tests show the following:  
 
Laboratory value  Result
 Sodium  144 mEq/L 
 Potassium   2.5 mEq/L 
 Chloride  93 mEq/L 
 Bicarbonate  21 mEq/L 
 Calcium   12 mg/dL 
 Glucose  250 mg/dL 
 Parathyroid hormone  350 pg/mL 

Which of the following is the most likely mechanism of this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient’s gastrointestinal symptoms are caused by the effects of excess vasoactive intestinal peptide (VIP) from a VIPoma. VIP is a neuropeptide that functions as a neuromodulator and neurotransmitter, and a VIPoma is a rare endocrine tumor that usually originates from the non-β islet cells of the pancreas. VIP’s effects include vasodilation, smooth muscle relaxation, and bicarbonate secretion from bile duct cholangiocytes. In excess, VIP binds to intestinal epithelial cells, increasing cAMP and causing fluid and electrolyte secretion into the lumen, which results in profuse secretory diarrhea with hypokalemia and metabolic acidosis. Electrolyte derangements and dehydration cause symptoms of fatigue, muscle cramps, flushing, and weakness.  .

VIPomas are associated with multiple endocrine neoplasia syndrome type 1 (MEN type 1). MEN1 is a gene that is found on chromosome 11 and codes for a tumor suppressor protein called menin, which  normally stops cells from dividing uncontrollably. MEN1 mutations cause MEN type 1, which is an autosomal dominant genetic disorder. There are three types of tumors associated with MEN type 1: parathyroid, pancreatic, and pituitary. This patient has a history of hyperparathyroidism from a parathyroid adenoma, as well as symptoms consistent with a pancreatic tumor, the VIPoma, suggesting a diagnosis of MEN type 1.  


Other pancreatic tumors that can occur in MEN type 1 include gastrinomas (stomach ulcers) and insulinomas (hypoglycemia) or glucagonomas (hyperglycemia). Pituitary adenomas may include prolactinomas (galactorrhea, gynecomastia) and growth hormone-releasing tumors (gigantism, acromegaly). Although parathyroid tumors can also occur in MEN type 2, pancreatic and pituitary tumors are exclusively found in MEN type 1.  

Option Analysis

❌ Calcitonin secretion:
Incorrect: Calcitonin is a peptide hormone released by the parafollicular cells (C cells) of the thyroid gland. Its normal function is to reduce serum calcium levels, opposing the actions of parathyroid hormone (PTH). Calcitonin levels can be elevated from medullary thyroid cancer, which is seen in MEN type 2A and MEN type 2B, but it is unlikely to be seen in this patient with MEN type 1.   
❌ Catecholamine secretion:
Incorrect: Tumor secretion of the catecholamines norepinephrine, epinephrine, and dopamine are responsible for the symptoms associated with a pheochromocytoma, including hypertension, headache, sweating, and tachycardia. Pheochromocytoma is almost never associated with MEN type 1, from which this patient likely suffers.
❌ Gastrin secretion:
Incorrect: Gastrin is a peptide hormone released by the G cells in the pyloric antrum of the stomach, duodenum, and pancreas that stimulates secretion of gastric acid by the parietal cells of the stomach. Gastrinomas, specifically of pancreatic origin, are associated with MEN type 1; however, they typically cause upper gastrointestinal ulcers and gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), as opposed to this patient’s persistent diarrhea and electrolyte derangements.   
❌ Somatostatin secretion:
Incorrect: Somatostatin is a peptide hormone secreted by delta cells in the pyloric antrum of the stomach, duodenum, and pancreas that acts on G protein-coupled somatostatin receptors to inhibit the release of several secondary hormones, including insulin and glucagon. Somatostatin analogues are used in the treatment of several neuroendocrine tumors.  
✅ Vasoactive intestinal peptide secretion:
Correct: See Main Explanation below.

questions.text:
A 16-year-old African American boy presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of weakness, shortness of breath, and fatigue. The patient denies chest pain, and his mother explains that the patient has had symptoms of “the common cold” for the past few days. Family history includes sickle cell disease. Temperature is 37°C (98.9°F), pulse is 91/min, respirations are 19/min, and blood pressure is 126/76 mmHg. Physical examination reveals scleral icterus and pallor. Cardiopulmonary examination is within normal limits, and abdominal examination does not reveal hepatosplenomegaly. Chest x-ray is within normal limits. Laboratory tests are obtained, and the results are shown below.


Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient with a family history of sickle cell disease, recent respiratory infection, and anemia has aplastic crisis secondary to parvovirus B19 infection and sickle cell disease. Sickle cell disease (SCD) is a chronic condition marked by hemolytic anemia that is typically well-compensated with appropriate reticulocytosis. Aplastic crisis typically occurs secondary to parvovirus B19 infections because of the virus’s predisposition for infecting proliferating erythroid progenitors; the condition is characterized by anemia with transient arrest of erythropoiesis and therefore decreased reticulocyte count (less than 1%).  



Other complications associated with sickle cell disease result from either intravascular hemolysis or vaso-occlusion. Intravascular hemolysis is associated with anemia, jaundice, gallstones, and extramedullary hematopoiesis. Extramedullary hematopoiesis presents with enlarged cheeks, ‘hair-on-end’ appearance on x-ray, and hepatomegaly.



Vaso-occlusion can present acutely or chronically. Acute vaso-occlusion, also called sickle cell crisis, can present in many different parts of the body and is classified accordingly. Patients typically experience excruciating pain that starts suddenly and lasts from hours to days.





Chronic complications of vaso-occlusion may include growth and developmental delay, learning and behavioral disorders, pulmonary hypertension, kidney disease, autosplenectomy, and susceptibility to encapsulated bacteria. Autosplenectomy results from vaso-occlusion and splenic infarcts. Biopsy of the spleen will reveal significant fibrosis and atrophy, and since the spleen plays an important role in immunity against encapsulated bacteria, the person will be susceptible to Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae, Neisseria meningitidis infections.


Abdominal CT of patient with autosplenectomy

One common complication of increased susceptibility to encapsulated bacteria is osteomyelitis. The most common cause of osteomyelitis in patients with SCD is Salmonella species, with Staphylococcus aureus (the most common in patients without SCD) accounts for less than 25% of cases.


Option Analysis

❌ Acute chest syndrome:
Incorrect: Acute chest syndrome is characterized by chest pain, fever, and pulmonary infiltrates on chest X-ray. This patient with no chest pain, a normal chest x-ray, anemia, and severe reticulocytopenia has aplastic crisis.
❌ Aplastic anemia  :
Incorrect: Aplastic anemia is characterized by fatigue, pallor, and dyspnea, which is consistent with the signs and symptoms seen in the vignette; however, the laboratory findings for aplastic anemia should show pancytopenia.
✅ Aplastic crisis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Hyperhemolytic crisis:
Incorrect: Hyperhemolytic crisis is a rare complication of sickle cell disease and is characterized by sudden severe anemia with an appropriate reticulocyte response. This patient with a low reticulocyte count has aplastic crisis.
❌ Splenic sequestration crisis:
Incorrect: Splenic sequestration occurs secondary to vaso-occlusion of red blood cells in the spleen, leading to hypotensive shock. Physical examination would reveal splenomegaly.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man is brought to the emergency department due to severe right flank pain accompanied by nausea and vomiting for the past 2 hours. He has never had such pain before. Medical history is significant for hypertension. He has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes per day for 25 years. An abdominal ultrasound is obtained and successfully visualizes a stone in the right ureter. Appropriate measurements are taken, and the patient eventually passes the stone. Microscopic analysis of the patient’s urine reveals wedge-shaped crystals. Which of the following conditions would most likely favor the formation of this type of stone over calcium oxalate stones?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with flank pain, nausea, and vomiting. He most likely has nephrolithiasis. Other symptoms of nephrolithiasis include hematuria, dysuria, and urinary urgency. The urinalysis shows wedge-shaped crystals, favoring the diagnosis of calcium phosphate stones.  

The most common type of kidney stone is calcium oxalate, which accounts for approximately 80% of cases. Most risk factors are common to both types of calcium stones (see table below), However, high urinary oxalate levels favor the formation of calcium oxalate stones, whereas high urine pH (pH > 6.5) favors the formation of calcium phosphate stones. In contrast, calcium oxalate stone formation is not affected by urine pH.  



Option Analysis

❌ Low urine volume:
Incorrect: Low urine volume is a risk factor for all kinds of renal stones including calcium oxalate, calcium phosphate, uric acid, and cysteine. The rationale behind this risk factor is that low urine volume causes supersaturation of substances filtered by the kidney.
❌ High urine calcium:
Incorrect: High urine calcium is associated with both calcium oxalate and calcium phosphate stone formation
❌ Low urine citrate:
Incorrect: Low urine citrate is associated with both calcium oxalate and calcium phosphate stones.  Citrate decreases urinary supersaturation of calcium salts by forming soluble complexes with calcium ions, thus preventing crystal growth and aggregation.  
✅ High urine pH:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ High urine oxalate:
Incorrect: High urine oxalate is associated with the formation of calcium oxalate stones. However, this patient’s urinalysis reveals wedge-shaped crystals, which is more consistent with the presentation of calcium phosphate stones.

questions.text:
A 1-day-old boy is brought to the intensive care unit from the nursery due to increased work of breathing. The patient was born at 31 weeks to a mother with a history of multiple preterm deliveries, polysubstance abuse and HIV. His temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), pulse is 215/min, respirations are 76/min, blood pressure is 60/41 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 85% on room air. Physical exam shows tachypnea, nasal flaring, and subcostal retractions. Administration of supplemental oxygen and positive pressure ventilation improve the patient's oxygen saturation to 95%. Blood glucose is 95 mg/dL. Chest x-ray and laboratory results are shown below:  

 

Reproduced from: Wikipedia
 
Laboratory value  Result 
Blood Gases, Serum 
pH  7.23 
 PCO2  55 mmHg 
 PO2  30 mmHg 
Which of the following best describes the etiology of this infant’s disease process?

choices.text: Insufficiency of a surface-active lipoprotein complex
Delayed resorption of fetal alveolar fluid

questions.solution:
The patient in this vignette is a premature infant who presents with signs of respiratory distress and a chest x-ray significant for ground glass opacities, low volumes, and a bell-shaped thorax concerning for neonatal respiratory distress syndrome (NRDS), which is caused by an insufficiency of pulmonary surfactant. Surfactant allows the alveoli to remain open at end-expiration based on LaPlace's law, which states the pressure necessary to keep the sphere (alveoli) open is proportional to the surface tension and inversely proportional to the radius of a sphere.  

Surfactant normally reduces the alveolar surface tension, allowing for alveolar expansion and reducing the likelihood of alveolar collapse. Surfactant-deficient alveoli, therefore, have increased surface tension, leading to decreased compliance and distensibility. At end-expiration, surfactant allows the alveoli to remain open; however, when premature neonates who are deficient in alveolar surfactant begin to use their lungs, this increased surface tension results in an increased tendency for lung atelectasis, leading to a ventilation/perfusion mismatch, hypoxia, and clinical features of increased work of breathing (e.g., tachypnea, nasal flaring, and subcostal retractions).  

The most important risk factor for NRDS is preterm birth before 36 weeks gestation, as well as male gender. Other risk factors are primarily maternal and include gestational diabetes, cesarean section and maternal-fetal infection.    

Complications from neonatal respiratory distress syndrome can include barotrauma from positive pressure ventilation and ventilator-associated pneumonia. Unfortunately, NRDS is still the leading cause of death in infants <1 month old, and many patients die from persistent hypoxemia and associated metabolic derangements.  

Option Analysis

❌  Low levels of circulating blood glucose :
Incorrect: Hypoglycemia is a common cause of respiratory distress in the newborn and can also be associated with neonatal respiratory distress syndrome (NRDS); however, the patient’s documented blood glucose is within normal limits.
❌ Transposition of the great vessels:
Incorrect: Transposition of the great vessels can cause respiratory distress and cyanosis in a neonate. However, the patient in this vignette responds to supplemental oxygen therapy, which does not commonly occur in patients with transposition of the great vessels.
❌ Viral inflammation of lung parenchyma:
Incorrect: While the patient in this vignette was born to an HIV-positive mother, HIV-associated pneumonia is unlikely to be the cause of respiratory distress in this premature neonate just 1 day after delivery. 
✅ Insufficiency of a surface-active lipoprotein complex:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Delayed resorption of fetal alveolar fluid :
Incorrect: This answer describes the proposed pathophysiology of transient tachypnea of the newborn (TTN). Unlike NRDS, TTN is a self-limited condition that resolves spontaneously. It can be differentiated from NRDS by chest radiograph and the degree of supplemental oxygen support. Infants with TTN will require little to no oxygen, and a chest radiograph will often demonstrate increased lung volumes with flat diaphragms, mild cardiomegaly, and prominent vascular markings in a sunburst pattern originating at the hilum.

questions.text:
A 4-week-old female is brought to the pediatrician for evaluation of jaundice which began 3 weeks ago. In addition, according to the mother, the patient’s urine has become progressively darker and is “yellowish-brown” in color. The patient was born at 40 weeks gestation via an uncomplicated vaginal delivery. Her blood is type A, Rh-negative. The mother’s blood is type AB, Rh-positive. The patient is exclusively breastfed and products between 6-7 wet diapers daily. Physical examination shows scleral icterus, as well as jaundice of the head and neck. Abdominal exam is notable for a firm and enlarged liver. The remainder of the physical examination is noncontributory. Laboratory testing reveals the following findings:
 
 Laboratory value  Result 
 Total bilirubin  7.2 mg/dL 
 Conjugated bilirubin  6.5 mg/dL 
 Alkaline phosphatase  115 U/L 
Which of the following best describes the most likely cause of this patient’s finding?

choices.text: Red blood cell destruction by maternal antibodies
Impaired elimination of bilirubin via feces
Fibro-obliterative destruction of extrahepatic bile ducts

questions.solution:
This patient likely has biliary atresia, a childhood condition characterized by fibro-obliterative destruction of the extrahepatic biliary tree. The exact cause of biliary atresia is unknown; however, it is hypothesized to be caused by biliary tract inflammation secondary to viral infections or toxins. The biliary tree is totally obstructed by the end of the third week after birth.  

Patients with biliary atresia have normal birth weight and weight gain. However, they will eventually develop jaundice, hepatomegaly, acholic stools, and dark urine (since the water-soluble conjugated bilirubin is now exclusively eliminated via urine). Physical examination will reveal a firm and enlarged liver. Laboratory testing will reveal increased levels of conjugated bilirubin, alkaline phosphatase, and gamma-glutamyl transferase.

Diagnosis of the condition can be made using cholangiogram (radiographic imaging of the biliary tree) and liver biopsy. The biopsy will show intrahepatic bile duct proliferation, fibrosis and edema, and obstructed bile ducts. Surgical intervention, which may involve linking the liver directly to the small intestines, is needed to enable bile outflow and prevent progression to biliary cirrhosis.

Option Analysis

❌ Red blood cell destruction by maternal antibodies:
Incorrect: Hemolytic disease of the newborn can be caused by Rhesus (Rh) or ABO incompatibility. It would cause unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia and manifest with symptoms shortly after birth. In contrast, it would be atypical for hemolytic disease of the newborn to present with symptoms 4 weeks after birth.
❌ Impaired elimination of bilirubin via feces:
 Incorrect:  Breastfeeding failure jaundice typically occurs within the first week of life. It is due to poor breast milk intake. As a result, these babies have inadequate stooling and decreased elimination of bilirubin via feces. However, breastfeeding failure jaundice would not cause conjugated hyperbilirubinemia on laboratory findings or hepatomegaly on physical exam.   
✅ Fibro-obliterative destruction of extrahepatic bile ducts:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Reduced glucuronidation of bilirubin:
Incorrect: This answer describes Crigler-Najjar syndrome, a congenital condition caused by reduced or absent UDP-glucuronosyl transferase activity. It can cause unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia and jaundice. In contrast, this patient has conjugated hyperbilirubinemia.  
❌ Lymphocytic infiltration of bile ducts:
Incorrect: Primary biliary cholangitis (PBC) is an autoimmune condition that damages the biliary tract. The condition most often affects middle-aged females with autoimmune conditions. Overtime, PBC can lead to conjugated hyperbilirubinemia and elevated alkaline phosphatase. However, it would be atypical for PBC to affect a newborn.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of right eye pain of several hours duration. His mother states, “He’s been fighting something all week. He's been blowing his nose non-stop; I think he had a fever too.” He has no significant past medical history. Temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 106/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 112/84 mmHg. Physical examination reveals tenderness to palpation over the right orbit with associated right eyelid swelling with erythema. The patient reports significant pain with extraocular eye movement. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient with a history suspicious for recent sinusitis is now presenting with eye swelling, pain, and pain with movement of the extraocular eye muscles, consistent with a diagnosis of orbital cellulitis.   

Orbital cellulitis refers to an infection of the connective tissue of the orbit, and it is usually incited by a preceding sinus infection or physical trauma (e.g. bug bite). Symptoms include pain with eye movements, proptosis or bulging of the eyeball, redness and swelling of the eyelid, and in some cases, ophthalmoplegia or impairment of eye movements. This condition is often accompanied by systemic symptoms, such as fever and chills.  

In contrast, preseptal (periorbital) cellulitis, affects only the anterior portion of the eyelid, without actually involving the orbit. This condition does not present with pain with eye movement, though it can progress to orbital cellulitis.  

If orbital cellulitis goes untreated, the infection can extend into deeper intracranial structures, causing meningitis, intracerebral abscess, or sinus venous thrombosis. Treatment involves antibiotics like nafcillin, ceftriaxone, and metronidazole, which cover gram positive organisms.  

Option Analysis

✅ Orbital cellulitis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Periorbital cellulitis:
Incorrect: Preseptal cellulitis affects the anterior portion of the eyelid, without actually involving the orbit. Preseptal cellulitis does not present with pain with extraocular eye movements. 
❌ Venous sinus thrombosis:
Incorrect: Venous sinus thrombosis, particularly of the cavernous sinus, is the most devastating complication of orbital cellulitis. This condition presents with a severe headache, photophobia, as well as nausea and vomiting. 
❌ Chalazion:
Incorrect: Chalazions result from the obstruction of sebaceous glands of the eyelids, without an underlying infection. It presents as a slow-growing, painless rubbery nodule, usually in the middle of the upper eyelid. 
❌ Hordeolum:
Incorrect: Hordeolums, also known as styes, are a common bacterial infection of the sebaceous glands of the eyelids that present as painful, red, pus-filled lumps at the lid margin. The most commonly implicated pathogen is Staphylococcus aureus. This patient’s pain with eye movement and fever suggest a more serious infectious process.

questions.text:
A 73-year-old female presents to the emergency department with shortness of breath. She is concerned her “COPD is flaring up.” Past medical history is notable for hypertension, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, and type II diabetes mellitus. She has been smoking one pack of cigarettes per day for twenty years. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 136/min, respirations are 22/min, blood pressure is 104/72 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 92% on room air. The patient is currently speaking in three to four word sentences and demonstrates increased work of breathing. There are bilateral rales throughout the lung fields, and the electrocardiogram from triage is shown below:  


Based on this patient's electrocardiogram, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response

questions.solution:
This patient presents with features consistent with a COPD exacerbation and an electrocardiogram that demonstrates an irregular tachycardia, with three distinct P-wave morphologies. These features are most consistent with multifocal atrial tachycardia.  

Multifocal atrial tachycardia (MAT) is an electrocardiographic diagnosis that arises due to enhanced automaticity in non-sinus node sites of either the left or right atrium. On electrocardiogram, MAT manifests as an irregular rhythm with varying R-R intervals and at least 3 distinct P-wave morphologies in the same lead. MAT is commonly mistaken for atrial fibrillation. However, careful evaluation of the above ECG demonstrates varying P-wave morphologies; whereas in atrial fibrillation P-waves are absent.

Nearly 60% of patients with MAT have underlying pulmonary disease, most commonly COPD. In addition, MAT is associated with heart disease, metabolic disturbances, and pulmonary embolism. Treatment is aimed at correcting the underlying cause, as the arrhythmia is often resistant to cardioversion or temporary rate control.      



Option Analysis

✅ Multifocal atrial tachycardia:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Atrial flutter:
Incorrect: Atrial flutter is defined by atrial depolarization occurring at a rate of 250 to 350 beats/min. It is usually caused by an atrial reentry circuit that runs around the tricuspid annulus. The condition is characterized by "flutter waves," which have a sawtooth appearance, and the presence of multiple P-waves between QRS complexes. 
❌ Paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia  :
Incorrect: Paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia is defined as a regular rhythm with a rate ranging between 150 to 250 beats per minute, a narrow QRS complex, and absent P-waves. In contrast, P-waves are seen on this patient’s electrocardiogram.
❌ Atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response:
Incorrect: Atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (RVR) is defined as an abnormally fast heart rate with irregularly irregular QRS complexes and absent P-waves. However, P-waves are present on this patient’s electrocardiogram, making atrial fibrillation unlikely.
❌ Sinus tachycardia:
Incorrect: Sinus tachycardia is characterized by a fast (>100 beats per minutes) rate, regular rhythm, and an identifiable P-wave before every QRS complex. Sinus tachycardia would not, however, manifest with the variable P-wave morphologies seen on this patient’s electrocardiogram.

questions.text: A 24-year-old female presents to the emergency department with shortness of breath. She is accompanied by her college-roommate, who reports she found the patient wheezing in her room. The patient is unable to provide additional history due to her labored work of breathing. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 115 min, respirations are 28/min, blood pressure is 90/60 mmHg, and O<sub>2</sub> saturation is 90% on room air. On physical exam, the patient has diffuse wheezing throughout the lung fields as well as a diffuse erythematous macular rash over the chest wall. The posterior pharynx is not visualized due to severe lip and tongue swelling. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s clinical presentation?

choices.text: Systemic release of histamine and bradykinin
Bacteremia due to a Gram-negative diplococci
Bacterial histidine decarboxylase conversion of histidine to histamine

questions.solution:
This patient presents with wheezing, hypotension, airway edema, and a diffuse macular rash consistent with anaphylactic shock. This subtype of distributive shock, or “warm shock,” is due to systemic release of histamine and bradykinin in response to an allergen.  

Anaphylaxis is the most extreme physiologic response to an allergen. Common triggers include peanut allergies or bee stings. It is classified as a type I hypersensitivity reaction, wherein the antigen cross-links performed IgE on presensitized mast cells, resulting in immediate degranulation of histamine and bradykinin. These mediators further trigger an inflammatory response that results in massive vasodilation and soft tissue edema. Edema of the airway causes bronchoconstriction, wheezing, and hypoxemic respiratory failure. Vasodilation subsequently decreases systemic vascular resistance, venous return, and pulmonary capillary wedge pressure. These changes can result in inadequate tissue perfusion. In response, the body compensates by increasing heart rate and cardiac output.  

Emergent treatment of anaphylaxis involves intramuscular epinephrine, which reverses these pathologic effects via vasoconstriction (by stimulating alpha-1 receptors) and bronchodilation (by stimulating beta-2 receptors). Additional therapy includes systemic corticosteroids and antihistamines.  


Option Analysis

✅ Systemic release of histamine and bradykinin:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Bacteremia due to a Gram-negative diplococci:
Incorrect: Infection by the Gram-negative diplococci Neisseria meningitis can lead to septic shock. However, septic shock would not typically present with diffuse wheezing or severe lip and tongue swelling.
❌ C1 esterase inhibitor deficiency:
Incorrect: Hereditary angioedema is caused by a deficiency in C1 esterase and manifests with tongue, lip, and pharyngeal swelling that can progress to hypoxemic failure. Unlike anaphylaxis, this disease does not typically present with a diffuse macular rash.
❌ Paraneoplastic serotonin secretion:
Incorrect: Carcinoid syndrome is due to release of serotonin and vasoactive peptides from a carcinoid tumor. Symptoms include diarrhea, flushing, and wheezing. However, carcinoid syndrome is overall a rare condition and would not account for the patient’s lip and tongue swelling.
❌ Bacterial histidine decarboxylase conversion of histidine to histamine  :
Incorrect: Scombroid toxicity is a common mimicker of anaphylaxis. It is caused by consumption of spoiled dark-meat fish such as tuna, mahi-mahi, mackerel, and bonito. This patient has no history of ingestion of these fish products, making this diagnosis unlikely.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents to the clinic with increasing lower back pain. He reports his pain is worse in the morning and improves with exercise. His other past medical history is notable for ulcerative colitis. He undergoes testing for HLA-B27, and his results are positive. On follow up several years later, the patient reports worsening shortness of breath with exertion. Which of the following pulmonary parameters is most likely to be normal in this patient?
questions.solution:
This male patient presents with low back pain, worse with exertion, and on follow up several years later, he has increasing shortness of breath. This overall clinical presentation is consistent with ankylosing spondylitis, which can cause restrictive lung disease due to altered breathing mechanics. Of the pulmonary parameters listed, only the A-a gradient can determine if his shortness of breath is from a pulmonary etiology or an extrapulmonary etiology; in the setting of ankylosing spondylitis, it is most likely to be normal.  

Extrapulmonary restrictive lung disease refers to diseases that interfere with the structural mechanics of breathing. In these disease states, the A-a gradient and diffusing capacity gases is normal, because the lung tissue itself is not damaged. Extrapulmonary restrictive lung diseases due to weakness of respiratory muscles include polio, myasthenia gravis, or Guillain-Barré syndrome. Diseases resulting in restrictive lung disease due to structural abnormalities include scoliosis, morbid obesity, and ankylosing spondylitis.    

Option Analysis

✅ A-a gradient :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Functional residual capacity:
Incorrect: Functional residual capacity refers to the volume of air in the lungs after normal expiration. It is overall decreased in restrictive lung diseases such as ankylosing spondylitis. 
❌ FEV1/FVC:
Incorrect: The FEV1/FVC ratio is typically increased in restrictive lung diseases; however, it cannot be used to differentiate between intrapulmonary and extrapulmonary disease. 
❌ Total lung capacity:
Incorrect: Total lung capacity refers to the volume of air in the lungs at maximal inspiration. It is overall decreased in restrictive lung diseases. 
❌  Forced vital capacity:
Incorrect: Forced vital capacity refers to the amount of air that can be forcibly exhaled from your lungs after taking the deepest breath possible.  It is overall decreased in restrictive lung diseases.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of an episode of hematemesis. The patient appears disheveled and disoriented to time and place. Past medical history is notable for alcohol use disorder and hepatitis C infection. Abdominal examination shows distension with a fluid wave and protruding paraumbilical veins. Examination of the extremities reveals bilateral asterixis and 2+ edema in the bilateral lower extremities. A picture of his palms is shown below:


Image reproduced from Wikipedia

Which of the following is most likely responsible for the appearance of this patient's palms?
questions.solution:
Liver cirrhosis leads to many clinical symptoms and signs related to the decreased synthetic capacity of the liver and progressive loss of liver functionality. This patient has several of the classic signs of decompensated liver disease including ascites and lower extremity edema due to hypoalbuminemia, asterixis and confusion due to hyperammonemia, and esophageal varices and caput medusae due to portal hypertension. The image of the patient’s palms demonstrates palmar erythema, which is due to hyperestrogenism.  

Given the loss of functional liver tissue, patients are unable to metabolize circulating estrogens through phase I (hydroxylation) and phase II (conjugation) pathways. As a result, there is increased circulating estrogen within the body. The increased estrogen is responsible for several clinical features of cirrhosis including palmar erythema, spider angiomas, gynecomastia, and testicular atrophy in men.  


Image reproduced from

Option Analysis

❌ Hyperammonemia:
Incorrect: Hyperammonemia is responsible for this patient’s altered mental status. In a healthy liver, ammonia is detoxified and metabolized into urea. Liver damage causes accumulation of ammonia, which can cross the blood-brain barrier and lead to diminished neuronal function.
❌ Hyperbilirubinemia:
Incorrect: Bilirubin is produced from heme breakdown. The liver takes up circulating bilirubin, conjugates it to increase water solubility, and excretes it in bile. Patients with liver disease will have reduced hepatic processing of bilirubin and can have jaundice. However, hyperbilirubinemia is not the cause of palmar erythema.
✅ Hyperestrogenism:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Hypoalbuminemia:
Incorrect: Albumin is produced in the liver and is the predominant protein in serum. It functions as a regulator of osmotic balance and transports a wide variety of molecules. Hypoalbuminemia causes a decrease in the intravascular oncotic pressure, resulting in fluid extravasation into the extravascular space. Low albumin can cause pedal edema and ascites, but not palmar erythema.
❌ Portal hypertension:
Incorrect: Portal hypertension occurs due to increased resistance within the hepatic sinusoids to portal venous blood flow. Collateral pathways subsequently open between the portal and systemic veins as a result of this increased pressure. This causes features such as esophageal varices, caput-medusae (protruding veins on the abdomen), hemorrhoids, and splenomegaly.

questions.text: A 47-year-old female comes to her primary care physician with chronic fatigue, abdominal pain, and sleep disturbance. Past medical history is notable for hypothyroidism, for which she takes levothyroxine. Vital signs are within normal limits, and physical examination is notable for mucosal hyperpigmentation. Laboratory testing is notable for hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, and a TSH that is within normal limits. Which of the following hormonal parameters are most reflective of this patient’s clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with fatigue, non-specific abdominal pain, and features of Addison disease (e.g., hyperpigmentation, hyperkalemia, hyponatremia). Addison disease is a type of primary adrenal insufficiency, which is reflected by elevated hormonal levels of corticotropin releasing hormone (CRH) and adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH), with decreased levels of aldosterone and cortisol.    

Adrenal insufficiency is divided into primary, secondary, and tertiary etiologies. Primary adrenal insufficiency results from decreased production by the adrenal gland itself, and thus it is the only form of adrenal insufficiency that will also have decreased aldosterone levels. Etiologies of primary adrenal insufficiency include autoimmune disease and chronic infections (e.g., HIV, tuberculosis).    

Secondary adrenal insufficiency is due to decreased ACTH production and is commonly the result of pituitary tumors, trauma, or other central nervous system tumors. In contrast to primary adrenal insufficiency, secondary adrenal insufficiency will have normal levels of aldosterone, since the adrenal glands’ synthetic function remains unaffected.  

Tertiary adrenal insufficiency is reflective of hypothalamic dysfunction and decreased CRH production. The most common etiology is the sudden withdrawal of chronic glucocorticoid use, since exogenous steroid use suppresses CRH release. When steroids are abruptly withdrawn, the hypothalamus can no longer produce endogenous CRH, resulting in decreased ACTH and decreased cortisol levels. Other etiologies of tertiary adrenal insufficiency include suprasellar lesions, trauma, and hypothalamic tumors. Like secondary adrenal insufficiency, aldosterone levels will be normal in tertiary adrenal insufficiency.

Option Analysis

✅   Corticotropin release hormone (CRH)  Adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH)  Aldosterone  Cortisol  ↑   ↑   ↓  ↓ :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌   Corticotropin release hormone (CRH)  Adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH)  Aldosterone  Cortisol  ↓  ↓  normal  ↓ :
Incorrect: Tertiary adrenal insufficiency is commonly due to abrupt withdrawal of exogenous steroids after chronic use. Less commonly, it is due to mass effect on the hypothalamus from a suprasellar lesion. In contrast, this patient has mucosal hyperpigmentation, which is more suggestive of primary adrenal insufficiency.
❌   Corticotropin release hormone (CRH)  Adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH)  Aldosterone  Cortisol  ↑   ↓  normal  ↓ :
Incorrect: These findings are characteristic of secondary adrenal insufficiency, which most commonly occurs in the setting of a non-functional pituitary macroadenoma. A pituitary macroadenoma would also likely present with headaches, vision changes, and panhypopituitarism.
❌   Corticotropin release hormone (CRH)  Adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH)  Aldosterone  Cortisol  ↑   ↑   normal  ↑  :
Incorrect: Ectopic CRH-releasing tumors are rare but are associated with medullary thyroid carcinoma, pheochromocytoma, and prostate cancer. Increased levels of cortisol would manifest with Cushingoid features (e.g., abdominal striae, truncal obesity, hyperglycemia), which are absent in this patient.
❌   Corticotropin release hormone (CRH)  Adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH)  Aldosterone  Cortisol  ↓  ↓  normal  ↑  :
Incorrect: Cortisol producing tumors are rare but are often due to an adrenal adenoma or carcinoma. These values would also lead to Cushingoid symptoms (e.g., abdominal striae, truncal obesity, hyperglycemia), which are absent in this patient.

questions.text: A 62-year-old male presents to the emergency department obtunded after being involved in a motor vehicle collision. He is currently altered and unable to provide any history. Chart review reveals a history of melanoma resection and asthma for which he recently completed a steroid taper. The patient’s temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 14/min, blood pressure is 94/62 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 95% on room air. His primary and secondary survey is notable for diffuse bruising over the anterior abdominal wall. A focused assessment with sonography for trauma (FAST) does not demonstrate any evidence of free fluid in Morrison’s pouch. The patient is given two liters of intravenous fluid, one unit of type O negative blood, and initiated on norepinephrine. However, there is no improvement in his blood pressure and a repeat FAST exam is negative. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Autoimmune mediated damage to the adrenal glands

questions.solution:
This patient presents with altered mental status and refractory shock after being involved in a high speed motor vehicle collision. His focused assessment with sonography in trauma (FAST) is unrevealing for hemorrhage in the peritoneum. Together, these findings are concerning for acute adrenal crisis, likely due to bilateral adrenal hemorrhage.  

Acute adrenal insufficiency (also termed adrenal crisis) refers to acute loss of the key adrenal hormones aldosterone and cortisol. Clinically, it is characterized by hypotension and refractory shock. In other words, patients will have shock that does not respond to intravenous fluids, blood products, pressors, or antibiotics. Additional features are often dependent on etiology but can include anorexia, nausea, vomiting, weakness, fatigue, lethargy, fever, confusion, and coma.  

This presentation stands in contrast to chronic adrenal insufficiency, which does not typically present with acute onset hypotension, confusion, or coma. Instead, chronic adrenal insufficiency presents with findings such as insidious abdominal pain, fatigue, and skin hyperpigmentation.  

Adrenal crisis is generally triggered by an acute stressor such as abdominal trauma, infectious etiologies (Neisseria meningitidis), or adrenal vein thrombosis. In patients with known primary adrenal insufficiency, abrupt withdrawal of steroids, infections, or surgery can also precipitate adrenal crises.  



Option Analysis

✅ Bilateral adrenal hemorrhage :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Autoimmune mediated damage to the adrenal glands:
Incorrect: Autoimmune mediated damage to the adrenal glands is most commonly the result of genetic predisposition. It more typically manifests with chronic indolent symptoms such as fatigue, weight loss, non-specific abdominal pain, and hyperpigmentation.
❌ Abrupt withdrawal of exogenous glucocorticoid:
Incorrect: Patients who are on persistently high doses of exogenous glucocorticoids can develop adrenal crisis if the medication is abruptly withdrawn. Although this patient was recently treated for an asthma exacerbation, he has no history of chronic steroid use, making this diagnosis unlikely.
❌ Bilateral adrenal metastases:
Incorrect: Metastatic invasion of the adrenal glands can result in primary adrenal insufficiency; however, it tends to do so chronically.
❌ Splenic rupture:
Incorrect: This patient was involved in a motor vehicle accident and has anterior abdominal bruising. However, two repeat negative FAST examinations nearly rules out the possibility of significant intraperitoneal hemorrhage.

questions.text:
A 56-year-old woman goes to the emergency department for evaluation of productive cough and shortness of breath, which have been going on for the past 3 days. She has also experienced chest pain that worsens with deep inspiration. Past medical history is significant for persistent atrial fibrillation that has been well-controlled with amiodarone. She has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 20 years. She does not drink alcohol or use illicit substances. Temperature is 38.0°C (100.4°F), pulse is 98/min, blood pressure is 138/85 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 92% on room air. A chest x-ray is obtained and demonstrates the following finding:  

 

Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons  

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Pneumonia is an infectious process resulting from the invasion and overgrowth of microorganisms within the lung parenchyma. Pneumonia can be characterized by the location in which the infection occurs. In bronchopneumonia, the infection is patchy throughout the lungs and involves the bronchioles as well as alveoli. In atypical or interstitial pneumonia, the infection is mainly outside the alveoli and in the interstitium. Finally, in lobar pneumonia, the infection causes consolidation within a lobe of the lung, meaning the entire consolidated area is filled with fluid. The patient in this vignette has lobar pneumonia, and the area of consolidation is identified by the red circle (Figure 1).

Usually, lobar pneumonia is described as having 4 stages: 

  1.  The first stage is congestion. It occurs between days 1-2, when blood vessels and alveoli start filling with excess fluid.  
  2.  The next stage is red hepatization and occurs between days 3-4, when exudate, which contains red blood cells, neutrophils, and fibrin, starts filling airspaces, making them more solid. The name hepatization refers to the lungs taking on a liver-like appearance due to the accumulation of reddish-brown exudate.  
  3.  The third stage is gray hepatization, which occurs around days 5-7. In this stage, the lungs are still firm but become pale gray because the red blood cells in the exudate begin breaking down.  
  4.  The last stage is resolution, which occurs around day 8 and can continue for 3 weeks. In this stage, the exudate is digested by enzymes, ingested by macrophages, and/or coughed up. 
 Figure 1: Lobar pneumonia within right middle lobe  
 


Option Analysis

❌ Bronchopneumonia:
Incorrect: Bronchopneumonia is characterized by multiple opacifications throughout the lungs due to  bronchiole as well as alveoli involvement. This patient’s infiltrate is localized to a single lobe, which is more consistent with the imaging findings of lobar pneumonia.
❌ Drug-induced pulmonary fibrosis:
Incorrect: Although this patient is at risk for amiodarone-induced pulmonary fibrosis, the acuity of her symptoms and presence of consolidation in the right lung are more suggestive of pneumonia. Pulmonary fibrosis typically presents as dyspnea that progresses over a period of months, not days.
❌ Interstitial pneumonia:
Incorrect: In atypical or interstitial pneumonia, the infection prominently affects the interstitium. Imaging will reveal reticular (web-like) infiltrates spread throughout the lungs but are often concentrated in the perihilar regions. In contrast, this patient’s imaging findings are more suggestive of lobar pneumonia. 
✅ Lobar pneumonia:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Sarcoidosis:
Incorrect: The acuity of this patient’s symptoms is more suggestive of pneumonia. Sarcoidosis typically presents with dyspnea that progresses over a period of months, not days. Furthermore, chest radiographs typically show hilar lymphadenopathy with or without bilateral reticular opacities, as opposed to lobar consolidation.

questions.text:
A 56-year-old man comes to his outpatient provider for evaluation of a painless “mole” that has slowly appeared on his face. Past medical history is notable for hypertension and atherosclerosis. Family history is notable for melanoma in his mother. Temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), blood pressure is 147/84 mmHg, pulse is 76/min, and respiratory rate is 16/min. Examination of the patient’s skin reveals the following finding
 

 Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons

A similar lesion is also noted on the patient’s chest and has a “stuck-on” appearance. Cardiac, pulmonary, and abdominal examinations are noncontributory. Which of the following best describes the pathophysiology of this patient’s lesion?
questions.solution:
This patient has seborrhoeic keratoses, which are benign and slow growing lesions that appear as people age. The condition arises due to the benign proliferation of keratinocytes.   

Seborrheic keratoses are well demarcated, round or oval lesions that can appear in various colors and have a dull, verrucous and slightly elevated surface. Dermatologic examinations tend to describe them as coin-shaped, waxy, and having a typical “stuck on appearance,” meaning that they look like a spot that can be peeled away from the surface of the skin. Most seborrheic keratoses are asymptomatic. However, chronic irritation due to friction trauma can cause itching, pain, and bleeding.    

One commonly tested topic is the Leser-Trelat sign, which is the sudden onset of multiple seborrhoeic keratoses. This sign is suggestive of an underlying carcinoma, especially of the gastrointestinal tract.    

Definitive diagnosis can be made with a biopsy, which will show the proliferation of immature keratinocytes and the presence of keratin-filled cysts. Since seborrheic keratoses are benign, treatment is generally not required. However, removal for cosmetic reasons can be done with surgical excision, cryotherapy, or electrodesiccation.

Option Analysis

❌ Deposition of disorganized collagen tissue  :
Incorrect: Keloids are caused by excess collagen deposition at an injury site. They manifest as firm, rubbery nodules that are elevated from the skin’s surface. While keloids can be hyperpigmented, it would be atypical for one to manifest as a black “stuck-on” lesion, which is more consistent with the presentation of seborrheic keratosis.  
❌ Benign proliferation of fibroblasts :
Incorrect: This answer choice describes dermatofibroma, which often manifests as a small skin-colored nodule that is 7-10 mm in diameter. However, it would be atypical for a dermatofibroma to be a balck “stuck-on” lesion. 
✅ Benign proliferation of keratinocytes :
 Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Malignant proliferation of melanocytes :
Incorrect: This answer choice describes malignant melanoma. The ABCDE rule (Asymmetrical, Border irregularities, Color inconsistency, Diameter enlarges, Evolving lesion) can help distinguish malignant melanoma from benign lesions. In contrast, this patient’s lesion is symmetrical, has well-defined borders, is of uniform color, and has not changed in size, making malignant melanoma unlikely. 
❌ Benign proliferation of melanocytes :
Incorrect: Melanocytic nevi occur due to the benign proliferation of melanocytes. Certain types of nevi, such as intradermal nevi, can be elevated. However, it would be unusual for a nevi to present with a “stuck-on” appearance.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl comes to her primary care physician for evaluation of abdominal pain, bloating, and diarrhea. The symptoms began several months ago. She describes the diarrhea as bulky and foul-smelling. Over the past week, the patient also developed a pruritic rash on the bilateral forearms. Past medical history is significant for type I diabetes mellitus, which is well managed with insulin. She recently traveled to Mexico and ate food from local street vendors. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals conjunctival pallor, as well as multiple tense, grouped blisters on her forearms and excoriations. The abdomen is mildly tender to palpation. Laboratory testing reveals positive anti-tissue transglutaminase antibodies. If this patient’s condition is untreated, which of the following complications is she at greatest risk of developing?

choices.text: Dysplasia and subsequent neoplastic growth in the colon
Migratory arthralgias of the large joints

questions.solution:
This adolescent female is presenting with steatorrhea, dermatitis herpetiformis (pruritic rash on her forearms), and abdominal pain. Her laboratory testing is notable for anti-endomysial antibodies. As a result, she likely has celiac disease.

Celiac disease is caused by a hypersensitivity reaction to gliadin in gluten-containing foods, which in turn activates T-cells. These activated T-cells release cytokines that ultimately damage the intestinal mucosa, resulting in flattened villi and crypt hyperplasia. Clinically, celiac disease can present with abdominal pain, bloating, and diarrhea. It can also cause anemia, coagulopathy, and osteoporosis due to malabsorption of nutrients such as folate, vitamin K, and calcium. Cutaneously, it can cause dermatitis herpetiformis, which are small, pruritic vesicles that pop up symmetrically on the extensor surfaces. These lesions arise when circulating anti-tissue transglutaminase antibodies bind and damage transglutaminase found in the dermal papillae of the epidermis.

In patients with refractory celiac disease, or in those who do not comply with gluten-free diets, there is chronic intestinal inflammation. This chronic inflammation of the small bowel can lead to uncontrolled proliferation of T-cells, resulting in enteropathy-associated T-cell lymphoma (EATL). Patients with celiac disease are also predisposed to other autoimmune endocrinopathies, such as hypo- or hyperthyroidism, type I diabetes mellitus, and selective IgA deficiency.

Option Analysis

✅ Neoplasm of the small bowel:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Hemolytic uremic syndrome:
Incorrect: Hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS) is characterized by a preceding diarrheal illness, followed by the triad of thrombocytopenia, renal dysfunction, and microangiopathic hemolytic anemia. Although this patient has diarrhea, she lacks other features consistent with HUS.
❌ Dysplasia and subsequent neoplastic growth in the colon:
Incorrect: Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), especially ulcerative colitis (UC), is associated with increased risk of colon cancer. UC commonly causes recurring episodes of bloody diarrhea (although it can also be watery), and patients are often p-ANCA positive. This patient’s symptoms and laboratory findings are inconsistent with those of UC. 
❌ Inflammation of the uvea:
Incorrect: Uveitis, which is inflammation of the uvea, can be an extraintestinal finding of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). Patients with Crohn disease may test positive for anti-Saccharomyces cerevisiae antibodies, whereas patients with ulcerative colitis may test positive for p-ANCA antibodies. This patient lacks clinical features and laboratory findings consistent with IBD.
❌ Migratory arthralgias of the large joints:
Incorrect: Migratory arthralgias can be seen in patients with reactive arthritis, which is characterized by a preceding diarrheal illness commonly caused by Shigella or Campylobacter. Reactive arthritis is usually associated with other clinical features, such as uveitis and urethritis, which are not seen in this patient.

questions.text: A 37-year-old male presents to the emergency department with worsening weakness and shortness of breath. The patient feels unsteady on his feet and has been tripping over himself while walking. Additionally, he has dyspnea at rest and feels like he “cannot take a deep breath.” The patient had a sore throat approximately 2-3 weeks ago but is otherwise healthy. He does not consume alcohol, tobacco, or illicit substances. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 94/min, respirations are 10/min, blood pressure is 130/64 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 93% on room air. His negative inspiratory force is 27 cm H2O (normal >60 cm H2O). Which of the following additional clinical features is most likely to be observed on physical exam?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with lower extremity weakness and shortness of breath after a recent viral illness. His findings are most consistent with Guillain Barré syndrome, which is a cause of lower motor neuron disease. Of the clinical findings listed, fasciculations, or muscle twitches that result from incomplete firing of the damaged lower motor neuron, are most consistent with this disease.  

In general, upper motor neuron diseases refer to lesions of the neural pathway above the anterior horn of the spinal cord or motor nuclei of the cranial nerves. Classic examples include stroke, intracranial hemorrhage, and cerebral palsy. In contrast, lower motor neuron lesions affect nerve fibers traveling from the anterior horn of the spinal cord to associated muscle tissue. Examples include Guillain-Barré syndrome, myasthenia gravis, and cauda equina syndrome.    

Distinguishing between upper and lower motor neuron diseases can be elicited by a careful neurologic examination. Upper motor neuron lesions result in disinhibition of lower motor neurons, resulting in excitatory symptoms including increased muscle tone, spastic paralysis, hyperactive reflexes, and postive Babinski sign. In contrast, lower motor neuron lesions result in inhibition of muscle contraction and cause flaccid paralysis, muscle atrophy, decreased deep tendon reflexes, and fasciculations.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Fasciculations:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Spastic paresis:
Incorrect: Spastic paresis is a complex condtion characterized by paralysis and muscle spasms. It is associated with etiologies leading to upper motor neuron disease, such as strokes, intracranial bleeding, or cerebral palsy. In contrast, this patient’s symptoms are more concerning for Guillain-Barre syndrome, which is a lower motor neuron disease. 
❌  Increased muscle tone:
Incorrect: Increased muscle tone is associated with upper motor neuron disease. This phenomenon occurs since upper motor neuron damage leads to loss of inhibition of lower motor neurons, resulting in sustained muscle contraction. 
❌ Babinski reflex:
Incorrect: The Babinski reflex is a normal reflex in infants, characterized by upgoing toes when the sole of the foot is stimulated with a blunt instrument. In adults, this finding is pathologic and consistent with upper motor neuron disease. However, this patient’s history of muscle weakness and shortness of breath after a recent respiratory infection is more consistent with Guillain-Barre syndrome, which leads to lower motor neuron symptoms. 
❌ Clonus:
Incorrect: Clonus refers to a series of rhythmic repeating muscle contractions and relaxations in response to reflex stimulation. This finding is more commonly observed in patients with upper motor neuron lesions. In contrast, this patient most likely has Guillain-Barre syndrome, which causes lower motor neuron symptoms.

questions.text:
A 57-year-old man comes to the emergency department seeking evaluation for bone pain. The symptoms began 4 months ago and have progressively worsened. The pain is most prominent at the thighs and is worse with weight bearing. Past medical history includes chronic kidney disease due to type 2 diabetes mellitus. The patient is currently receiving insulin therapy and receives dialysis three times per week. Temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), blood pressure 143/89, and pulse is 77/min. There is tenderness to palpation over the anterior thighs. Laboratory testing reveals the following findings:

 
 Laboratory value  Result 
 Sodium  142 mmol/L 
 Potassium  4.5 mmol/L 
 Calcium  7.8 mmol/L 
 Phosphorous  2.5 mmol/L 
 Alkaline phosphatase  90 U/L 

Which of the following additional symptoms will most likely also be present in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient has osteomalacia, a condition in adults that is characterized by inadequate bone mineralization. In particular, it is because of vitamin D deficiency secondary to chronic kidney disease. This is because in normal individuals, the kidneys help activate vitamin D, which subsequently increases intestinal absorption of calcium and phosphate.

Patients with osteomalacia may present with diffuse bone and joint pain, proximal muscle weakness, and increased risk of fragility fractures. However, unlike rickets, patients will not present with bow legs, rachitic rosary, or other bone deformities. This is because the growth plates in the bones of adults have already fused, making them less susceptible to deformation.

Bone pain in osteomalacia is usually most pronounced in the lower spine, pelvis, and lower extremities, where fractures have taken place, and may be associated with tenderness to palpation. The pain is characterized as dull and aching and is worsened by activity and weight bearing. Fractures may occur with little or no trauma, typically involving the ribs, vertebrae, and long bones. Muscle weakness is typically proximal and may be associated with muscle wasting, hypotonia, as well as a waddling gait.



Option Analysis

❌ Enlarged spleen and liver:
Incorrect: This answer describes hepatosplenomegaly, which may be present in patients in osteopetrosis. In this condition, expansion of cortical bone into the bone marrow leads to extramedullary hematopoiesis in the liver and speen. However, osteopetrosis presents with symptoms most often in infancy or early adulthood.
❌ Bending of the bilateral femurs:
Incorrect: This symptom may be seen in children with rickets, since they have unfused growth plates. In contrast, this symptom would be atypical in adults like this patient with osteomalacia.
❌ Expansion of costochondral junctions:
Incorrect: This phenomenon may be seen in rickets due to a lack of mineralization and overgrowth of the costochondral joint cartilage. This symptom is more often seen in children, who have unfused growth plates, and would be uncommon in adults.
❌ Sensorineural hearing loss:
Incorrect: This finding may be seen in osteopetrosis and Paget disease of the bone due to cranial nerve impingement. However, osteopetrosis presents with symptoms during infancy or early adulthood. As for Paget disease of the bone, the condition presents with normal serum calcium and phosphate levels.
✅ Difficulty walking and waddling gait:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 65 year-old man comes to his primary care physician because of lower back pain, recurrent sinus infections, and 4 kg (8.8 lb) unintentional weight loss over the past three months. Past medical history is notable for osteoporosis and atherosclerosis. The patient consumes 4-5 glasses of wine per week and is sexually active with his spouse. His temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), blood pressure is 125/76 mmHg, pulse is 65/min, and respiratory rate is 15/min. Cardiac, pulmonary, and abdominal exams are normal. Pain is elicited with palpation of the lumbar spine. As part of the diagnostic work-up, a peripheral blood smear is ordered, and the results are as follows:
 

Image from Wikimedia

 Which of the following findings will provide a definitive diagnosis of the patient’s condition?

choices.text: Dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry showing reduced bone mineral density
Bone marrow biopsy showing greater than 20% myeloblasts
Bone marrow biopsy showing greater than 10% plasma cells
Complete blood count showing elevated hematocrit
Urinalysis showing large, waxy, laminated casts

questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation with chronic low back pain, weight loss and recurrent sinus infections, together with a peripheral smear showing rouleaux formation (stacking up of RBCs), makes multiple myeloma (MM) the most likely provisional diagnosis. MM is a result of neoplastic proliferation of plasma cells that produce monoclonal immunoglobulins. Patients with MM are at increased risk of infection due to impaired lymphocyte function, suppression of normal plasma cell function, and hypogammaglobulinemia.  

Patients with MM often present with the CRAB symptoms (hyperCalcemia, Renal insufficiency, Anemia, and Bone lesions). Initial work-up involves non-invasive testing, which involves:  
  •  Complete blood count showing normocytic, normochromic anemia. Pancytopenia is sometimes observed later in the disease course. 
  •  Peripheral smear showing rouleaux formation due to increased serum proteins (e.g. globulins). 
  •  Serum and urine protein electrophoresis showing Ig light chains (M-protein) with negative urine dipstick. 
  •  X-ray of the involved bones may show lytic lesions (appearing as “punched-out”). 
  Definitive diagnosis requires a bone marrow biopsy showing greater than 10% plasma cells.

Option Analysis

❌ Dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry showing reduced bone mineral density :
Incorrect: Dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry (DEXA) is used in the screening and diagnosis of osteoporosis, a condition characterized by reduced bone strength and increased susceptibility to fractures. While fracture secondary to osteoporosis may explain the patient’s lower back pain, it would not explain the recurrent infections, unintentional weight loss, or rouleaux formation seen on the peripheral blood smear. 
❌ Bone marrow biopsy showing greater than 20% myeloblasts :
Incorrect: This finding would diagnose the patient with acute myeloid leukemia (AML). It is often seen in the elderly, with a median age of diagnosis at 65 years-old. AML usually presents with fatigue, lymphadenopathy and hepatosplenomegaly, none of which are seen in this patient. Rouleaux formation is atypical. 
✅ Bone marrow biopsy showing greater than 10% plasma cells :
Correct: See Main Explanation 
❌ Complete blood count showing elevated hematocrit :
Incorrect: Elevated hematocrit is usually seen in patients with polycythemia vera, a myeloproliferative neoplasm characterized by elevated red blood cell (RBC) mass. Though constitutional symptoms (e.g., fatigue, weight loss) may sometimes be seen, these are usually accompanied by findings secondary to increased blood viscosity (e.g., visual disturbances, thrombosis), which are not seen in this patient.. 
❌ Urinalysis showing large, waxy, laminated casts :
Incorrect: Large, waxy, laminated casts are seen in patients with multiple myeloma when it is complicated by myeloma cast nephropathy. These casts are composed of monoclonal light chain proteins. Dipstick is negative for protein, as it only detects albumin and not urinary M protein (Bence Jones proteinuria). However, these findings are not considered diagnostic for multiple myeloma.

questions.text:
A 2-hour-old male neonate develops difficulty breathing while in the nursery. He was born at 36-weeks gestational age via a vaginal delivery. Prenatal development was complicated by maternal gestational diabetes. The patient’s vitals are notable for tachypnea. Physical exam reveals nasal flaring and intercostal retractions. The apical impulse is displaced to the right. Imaging is ordered, and the results are as follows:
 

Image reproduced from Radiopedia

Which of the following best describes the cause of this patient’s respiratory presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient has a congenital diaphragmatic hernia, which is when a malformation of the diaphragm leaves a hole that allows abdominal organs to herniate into the thoracic cavity. It is due to impaired development of the pleuroperitoneal membranes, the embryological structures that give rise to the diaphragm. Since the pleuroperitoneal membranes on the left-side take longer to develop, hernias are more frequently located on this side (as indicated by the red arrow in the radiograph).      

The herniated abdominal organs can push against the developing lung (causing pulmonary hypoplasia), the blood vessels supplying the lungs (causing pulmonary hypertension), and the heart (causing a displaced apical impulse). After birth, patients can present with tachypnea, respiratory distress, and cyanosis.  

Diagnosis is made using chest radiography, which shows herniation of abdominal contents into the thorax.  

Option Analysis

❌  Aspiration of meconium  :
Incorrect: This answer describes meconium aspiration syndrome, which occurs when meconium enters the airways and causes obstruction. It is most often seen in post-term infants. In contrast, this patient is preterm. Moreover, meconium aspiration syndrome would not account for the displaced apical impulse or imaging findings, which demonstrate bowel loops in the thoracic cavity. 
✅ Severe pulmonary hypoplasia :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Inadequate pulmonary surfactant production:
Incorrect: Inadequate surfactant production can result in neonatal respiratory distress syndrome. Maternal diabetes and preterm birth are risk factors. However, X-ray imaging will show ground glass opacities and air bronchograms. Thus the presence of bowel loops in the thorax is inconsistent with the presentation of this condition. 
❌ Free radical induced lung damage:
Incorrect: Oxygen therapy can result in the production of free radicals that can injure organs, resulting in pulmonary dysplasia and blindness. However, this neonate has no history of supplemental oxygen therapy. 
❌  Infection by gram-positive organism :
Incorrect: An infection by bacteria, such as Streptococcus agalactiae, can cause sepsis and tachypnea. However, an infection would not account for the displaced apical impulse or radiographic findings.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man with a history of trisomy 21 comes to the physician for evaluation of worsening cognition. The patient has a moderate intellectual disability at baseline; he has some difficulty with executive functioning and attention span. He lives independently and has been able to work as a store clerk for several years; however, he was recently released from work due to declining performance and inability to remember tasks. The patient recalls having gotten lost in the store while restocking shelves. He drinks 1-2 beers each evening, and he does not use tobacco or recreational drugs. The patient also participates in a local rugby league, but he has found it increasingly difficult to remember practice times. His grandfather died from frontotemporal dementia at the age of 78. The patient’s vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination is notable for upward slanting eyelids and bilateral transverse palmar creases. No gait or motor abnormalities are noted. Which of the following risk factors is the most likely cause of this patient’s cognitive decline?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with declining cognitive function and an inability to perform tasks of daily living (e.g., getting lost in familiar places, forgetting practice times) in the setting of trisomy 21. These findings are concerning for Alzheimer disease (AD).  

Trisomy 21 (Down syndrome) is associated with early-onset AD, which is defined as cases occurring before the age of 65. Early-onset AD accounts for 5-10% of cases. The association exists because patients with trisomy 21 have three copies of the amyloid precursor protein (APP) gene (located on chromosome 21). The extra copy of APP causes overproduction of the protein, which subsequently undergoes abnormal enzymatic cleavage into beta-amyloid peptides and aggregates to form insoluble plaques.   

These plaques decrease the number of synapses and alter neuronal functioning. Patients with trisomy 21 typically have AD brain pathology by the age of 40 and approximately two-thirds will develop dementia by the age of 60.  

Additionally, mutations in PSEN-1 and PSEN-2 genes have been linked to early-onset AD. These genes encode for presenilin-1 and presenilin-2, which are both protein subunits of gamma-secretase. Mutations in these genes change the location where gamma secretase cleaves APP, resulting in the production of different sized beta amyloid molecules, which aggregate into plaques.  

Option Analysis

✅ Aneuploidy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Age:
Incorrect: Alzheimer dementia is more prevalent in older populations, with most patients experiencing initial symptoms (e.g., cognitive decline, impaired ability to perform tasks of daily living) after the age of 60. This patient’s age is an unlikely risk factor for developing dementia. 
❌ Family history :
Incorrect: Although frontotemporal dementia (FTD) may have a genetic component, patients typically present first with behavioral changes (e.g., social disinhibition, apathy). In contrast, this patient is presenting with declining memory and an inability to perform tasks of daily living, which is more concerning for Alzheimer disease. Furthermore, this patient’s underlying genetic condition puts him at a substantially higher risk of developing Alzheimer disease.
❌ Substance use:
Incorrect: Significant alcohol use for many years can result in alcohol-related dementia. This patient is drinking 1-2 beers daily, which is on the higher end of the recommended range. However, this amount of alcohol intake is unlikely to be the cause of the patient’s significant cognitive impairments. 
❌ Physical contact sports :
Incorrect: Repeated concussive and subconcussive blows to the head can cause chronic traumatic encephalopathy (CTE); this condition has been shown to occur in boxers and football players. Patients may present with significant cognitive decline, as in the case of this patient. However, patients often manifest with additional behavioral abnormalities (e.g., aggression, paranoia) and psychiatric disturbances (e.g., depression, anxiety, suicidality), which are absent in this patient.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man comes to his physician, accompanied by his partner, for evaluation of “abnormal movements that occur while he sleeps.” Symptoms began around four months ago. According to the partner, the patient has on multiple occasions exhibited various movements, such as throwing a ball or punching invisible objects, while asleep. The partner has been sleeping in the guest bedroom for the past several weeks to avoid getting hurt by him. The patient is unaware of these activities, but he recalls vivid dreams of playing baseball and fighting off home invaders. Past medical history is noncontributory. His temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), blood pressure is 138/87 mmHg, and pulse is 71 beats/min. The physician orders a polysomnogram, which reveals REM sleep without atonia. Which of the following findings is this patient likely to develop in the future?

choices.text: Episodes of disinhibited behavior in public

questions.solution:
Dementia with Lewy bodies (DBL) is a neurodegenerative condition that results in cerebral atrophy, especially of the frontal lobe. The condition is characterized by the accumulation of Lewy bodies, which are composed of alpha-synuclein. Alpha-synuclein is a protein found at presynaptic terminals and is involved in neurotransmitter release. In times of increased oxidative stress and under pathologic conditions, alpha-synuclein undergoes a structural change, forming oligomers and beta sheet structures which ultimately deposit as Lewy bodies. The accumulation of Lewy bodies leads to myelin and glial dysfunction with subsequent neuronal degeneration. On histological analysis, Lewy bodies are seen as round, eosinophilic cytoplasmic inclusions inside neurons.  

Clinically, DBL can cause REM sleep behavior disorders, wherein patients physically act out dreams since they lack the muscle atonia that characterizes normal REM sleep. Additional symptoms include fluctuating cognitive function (characterized by variation in attention and episodes of drowsiness), visual hallucinations, and Parkinsonism (muscle rigidity, tremors, bradykinesia). In some patients, the abnormalities with REM sleep can precede the other symptoms by several years. This phenomenon likely arises due to early deposition of alpha-synuclein in the pontine and medullary nuclei, which control REM sleep.  




Option Analysis

✅ Visual hallucinations:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Episodes of disinhibited behavior in public:
Incorrect: Frontotemporal dementia (FTD) is characterized by early changes in personality and behavior. It occurs due to degeneration of the frontal lobe and impaired executive functioning. Early signs of FTD include failure to observe social etiquette and disinhibition (e.g., hyperorality, hypersexual behavior). This patient is presenting with a REM sleep behavior disorder, which is a prodromal phase for another neurodegenerative condition.  
❌ Memory loss and confabulation:
Incorrect: Korsakoff syndrome may develop in patients chronic alcohol use due to thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency. Thiamine deficiency results in decreased cerebral glucose metabolism and neuronal injury. Patients typically exhibit anterograde and retrograde amnesia with compensatory confabulations, wherein they fabricate stories to fill lapses in memory. 
❌ Language deficits and spatial disorientation:
Incorrect: Alzheimer disease (AD) is characterized by cognitive decline, which results in a loss of temporal and spatial orientation as well as language deficits. This patient is currently presenting with a REM sleep behavior disorder, which is a prodromal phase for another neurodegenerative condition.
❌ Myoclonus and seizures:
Incorrect: Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD) is a prion-mediated, rapidly progressive dementia. Classic clinical features include myoclonus (involuntary contraction of muscles) brought about by loud sounds, which is termed “startle myoclonus.” Sleep disturbances are also common in CFD, but they typically manifest as hypersomnia or insomnia. REM sleep behavior disorders would be highly unusual in CJD.

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy comes to his physician due to multiple, painless nodules on his jaw and forehead. He also has been experiencing recurrent constipation, and he has occasionally noticed blood in his stool. The patient’s mother died from colon cancer at the age of 42, and his maternal grandfather also died from colon cancer at a young age. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals several bony growths on his mandible and forehead. Fundoscopic examination reveals multiple darkly pigmented lesions on the retina. Colonoscopy followed by genetic testing is performed, confirming the diagnosis. A mutation in which of the following genes is most likely responsible for this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This young patient is presenting with multiple osteomas on his face, as well as congenital hypertrophy of the retinal epithelium. He likely has Gardner syndrome, which is a variant of familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP).    

FAP is an autosomal dominant disease characterized by the presence of hundreds of adenomatous polyps lining the intestinal mucosal surface. These polyps have a near 100% chance for malignant transformation. The condition is caused by mutations of the adenomatous polyposis coli (APC) gene located on chromosome 5; APC is a tumor suppressor protein, and mutations in this gene result in uncontrolled cell proliferation. Patients will have a family history of early-onset colon cancer and will often require a prophylactic colectomy to reduce the risk of developing colon cancer.  

Gardner syndrome, other than causing colon cancer, also causes prominent extracolonic bone and soft tissue tumors, such as osteomas, fibromas, lipomas, desmoid tumors, and epidermoid cysts. Moreover, a characteristic finding is bilateral, multiple, pigmented, ocular fundus lesions, known as congenital hypertrophy of the retinal epithelium. These patients can also have supernumerary impacted teeth, and multiple jaw osteomas and odontomas.  

Option Analysis

✅ APC:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ STK11:
Incorrect: Mutations in the STK11 gene are present in patients with Peutz-Jeghers syndrome. Patients with this condition typically present with mucocutaneous hyperpigmentation, as well as multiple hamartomatous polyps in the gastrointestinal tract. However, Peutz-Jeghers syndrome would not explain this patient’s bony growths or retinal lesions.
❌ MLH1:
Incorrect: Mutations in various DNA mismatch repair genes, such as MLH1, are seen in patients with Lynch syndrome. Patients are typically asymptomatic until the development of colorectal cancer; therefore, this patient’s other symptoms are suggestive of a different underlying diagnosis.  
❌ BRCA1:
Incorrect: Mutations in BRCA1 and BRCA2 are associated with the development of breast and ovarian cancer. Although there is also an association with colon cancer formation, this patient’s other symptoms suggest a different underlying diagnosis. 
❌ MEN1:
Incorrect: Mutations in the MEN1 gene are associated with multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1 syndrome, which results in pituitary tumors, parathyroid hyperplasia, and pancreatic adenomas.

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman comes to her primary care physician for evaluation of dizziness and hearing loss. The patient has had multiple episodes of dizziness lasting between 20 minutes to several hours. These episodes are associated with ringing in the left ear. The patient states, “These episodes are so debilitating I have to lie in bed until they are over. Sometimes the spinning sensation is so intense that I vomit.” Past medical history is noncontributory. She has not had any recent bacterial or viral infections. Vital signs are within normal limits, and physical examination reveals no significant findings. Audiometric testing demonstrates low-mid frequency hearing loss in the left ear. Hearing in the right ear is normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with episodes of vertigo, tinnitus, and low-mid frequency hearing loss. These findings are most consistent with Meniere disease.
