A chest x-ray is ordered, and the results are shown below. Which of the following findings is also associated with this patient’s condition?  



Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
This boy has a fever and productive cough in the setting of chronic diarrhea, recurrent pneumonia, and imaging findings consistent with bronchiectasis. The gastrointestinal symptoms are likely secondary to pancreatic insufficiency. Given these findings, the patient most likely has cystic fibrosis.    

Cystic fibrosis (CF) is the most common genetically inherited recessive disease in the Caucasian population. The many manifestations of this illness are caused by a defective cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) gene. This mutation results in an absent or mutated CFTR protein. Patients with cystic fibrosis typically have thickened mucus secretions in the lungs and pancreas, leading to chronic cough, frequent lung infections, difficulty digesting food, pancreatic insufficiency, and increased risk of developing diabetes.  

Primary ciliary dyskinesia (PCD) is a condition with symptoms similar to cystic fibrosis. It is caused by a mutation in dynein, a ciliary motor protein. Both conditions can present with nasal polyps, recurrent respiratory infections, and infertility. However, PCD would not typically cause pancreatic insufficiency. Additionally, patients with PCD may also present with dextrocardia.

Option Analysis

❌ Immotile sperm:
Incorrect: Males with cystic fibrosis and primary ciliary dyskinesia do typically present with infertility. This patient, who has cystic fibrosis, would have normal sperm but an obliterated vas deferens. In contrast, in primary ciliary dyskinesia, there is a normal vas deferens, but the sperm are immotile. 
❌ Situs inversus:
Incorrect: Situs inversus is a congenital condition in which the major organs are mirrored or reversed from their normal position. Situs inversus is associated with primary ciliary dyskinesia but not cystic fibrosis.  
✅ Nasal polyps:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Normal mucous secretions:
Incorrect: Cystic fibrosis is an inherited disease due to a mutation in the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) gene. The mutation results in impaired chloride secretion, increased water reabsorption from mucosal surfaces, and the formation of hyperviscous mucus.  
❌ Elevated nasal nitric oxide:
Incorrect: This patient has findings consistent with cystic fibrosis. Decreased nasal nitric oxide levels are found in patients with cystic fibrosis and primary ciliary dyskinesia.

questions.text:
A 70-year-old man is brought to his primary care physician for evaluation of personality changes. Over the past two months, he has become progressively irritable and apathetic. His partner also notes fluctuations in his behavior stating, “He has good and bad days.” His medical history includes hypertension and atrial fibrillation, for which he takes hydrochlorothiazide and warfarin. The patient’s temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 75/min, and blood pressure is 150/80 mmHg. On physical examination, the patient appears indifferent and responds vaguely to questions. The patient undergoes a non-contrast CT brain as demonstrated below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?  


Reproduced from: Radiopaedia
questions.solution:
This older patient presents with a progressive decline in function and associated personality changes, raising concern for an underlying toxic, metabolic, or traumatic cause. The CT-brain demonstrates a crescent-shaped lesion, confirming the diagnosis of subdural hematoma (SDH).

SDH refers to bleeding into the space between the dura and arachnoid layers induced by tearing of the bridging veins. These veins connect the surface of the brain to the dural sinuses. SDH can be further classified as acute, subacute, chronic, or acute on chronic. In acute subdural hematoma formation, up to 50% of patients experience coma, while others may present with a “lucid interval” before deterioration from the expanding hematoma. In contrast, a chronic SDH is marked by an insidious onset of headaches, fluctuations in cognitive function, apathy, somnolence, and occasional seizures, which become evident weeks following the initial insult.

Patients at risk for SDH include elderly patients (due to underlying cerebral atrophy), individuals with chronic alcohol use, and those with previous traumatic brain injury. Other risk factors include the use of antithrombotic agents (e.g. aspirin, warfarin). On imaging, acute SDH appears as a high-density crescentic collection on head CT, while chronic SDH appears as a hypodense crescent-shaped lesion. Depending on the severity, treatment involves surgical evacuation or conservative management.



Option Analysis

❌ Epidural hematoma:
Incorrect: The majority of cases of epidural hematoma are caused by severe head trauma during accidents, falls, and assaults. Epidural hematomas are most commonly caused by rupture of the middle meningeal artery as it passes under the pterion. Patients often present with a “lucid interval” followed by rapid deterioration and death if left untreated. On a non-contrast head CT, a lens-shaped lesion is observed. This patient’s imaging and timeline are more consistent with subdural hematoma.
❌ Cerebral contusion:
Incorrect: Cerebral contusion refers to bruising of the brain parenchyma. The edema surrounding the contusion may result in fluctuating levels of consciousness, focal neurologic deficits, or neurologic deterioration. This patient’s imaging and timeline are more consistent with subdural hematoma.  
❌ Subarachnoid hemorrhage:
Incorrect: Subarachnoid hemorrhage occurs secondary to rupture of a saccular aneurysm or an arteriovenous malformation. Patients often complain of the “worst headache of my life.” On head CT,  SAH appears as hyperdense material filling the subarachnoid space. This patient’s imaging and timeline are more consistent with subdural hematoma.  
✅ Subdural hematoma:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Vascular dementia:
Incorrect: Vascular dementia refers to a stepwise decline in cognitive function and memory impairment caused by multiple arterial infarcts and/or chronic ischemia. On imaging, multiple cortical and/or subcortical infarcts are observed. This patient’s imaging and timeline are more consistent with subdural hematoma.

questions.text: A 4-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department for acute onset left elbow pain. She was playing in her sandbox when her parent pulled her by the arm to take her inside. Vitals are within normal limits. Examination reveals a young girl who keeps her hand in a pronated and extended position. Any manipulation of the arm causes the girl to cry. There is no swelling or deformity. The physician hyperpronates the forearm, resulting in a click with immediate cessation of pain and resumption of the patient using her arm. Which of the following best describes the etiology of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This young girl presents with classic history and presentation of radial head subluxation (or “nursemaid’s elbow”), which refers to subluxation of the radial head from the annular ligament. The usual mechanism of injury is an upward force on the arm, such as pulling a toddler upward by the hand or wrist. The radial head in children younger than 6 years has a more cylindrical shape, allowing it to slip more easily from the annular ligament which normally holds the bone in place.

The affected arm is often held in extension and pronation, and the child may refuse to move the arm secondary to pain. Tenderness is typically present at the radial head, and the patient will resist forearm pronation, supination, flexion, and extension. Without a concomitant injury, ecchymosis, erythema, edema, or signs of trauma will be absent. The diagnosis is clinical, and imaging is not required unless additional injuries are suspected. A plain radiograph of the affected arm will be normal.

Treatment of radial head subluxation involves closed reduction via hyper-pronation or supination/flexion at the elbow. A successful reduction results in immediate cessation of pain, and most children will use their arm again within minutes.  

Option Analysis

✅ Radial head subluxation   :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Incomplete fracture   :
Incorrect: Incomplete fractures (Greenstick fractures) are fractures that extend only partway through the width of bone following an angular or bending force. Greenstick fractures result in point tenderness at the site of the fracture with evidence of overlying swelling. A fracture would not spontaneously resolve, making this diagnosis less likely.   
❌ Brachial plexus injury   :
Incorrect: Brachial plexus injuries typically result from birth trauma due to excessive traction on the neonate’s head, neck, or arm. These injuries may also occur secondary to excess traction on the arm (e.g. from a fall). Neurological injury, however, would not spontaneously resolve, making this diagnosis less likely.   
❌ Complete fracture   :
Incorrect: Complete fractures of the arm are common in children. Clinical presentation includes an obvious deformity of the arm, along with localized ecchymosis, swelling, and pain. However, a fracture would not spontaneously resolve, making this diagnosis less likely.   
❌ Tendinitis:
Incorrect: Tendonitis can affect the upper extremities but is much more common in patients with a history of chronic overuse (e.g., athletes, construction workers). This patient’s history and presentation are more consistent with radial head subluxation.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department due to progressive upper abdominal pain and fever for the past 2 days. She states she has felt persistently nauseous over this time period and has vomited 5 times. Medical history is noncontributory. Temperature is 38.6°C (101.4°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. Examination reveals a patient in acute distress. Physical examination reveals yellow discoloration of the sclera. The abdomen is tender to palpation in the right upper quadrant. There is no rebound tenderness. No hepatomegaly is observed. Laboratory studies show the following:  
 
 Laboratory value  Result 
 Hemoglobin  14 g/dL 
 Leukocyte count  17,000 mm3 
 Platelet count    240,000 mm3 
 Mean corpuscular volume  87 μm3 
 Serum  
 Creatinine   0.8 g/dL 
 BUN  12 mg/dL 
 Bilirubin   
 Total   3.8 mg/dL 
 Direct  2.5 mg/dL 
 Alanine aminotransferase   190 U/L 
 Aspartate aminotransferase  210 U/L 
 Amylase  57 U/L 
 Lipase  65 U/L 
 Alkaline phosphatase   412 U/L 

Abdominal ultrasound shows dilation of the intra- and extrahepatic ducts. IV fluids and antibiotics are administered. Six hours later, the patient becomes disoriented. Temperature is 38.6°C (101.4°F), pulse is 101/min, and blood pressure is 95/60 mmHg. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s presentation?

choices.text: Bacteria infiltrating into the biliary system
Inflammation of the gallbladder without obstruction

questions.solution:
This patient presents with signs of biliary obstruction including fever, abdominal pain, jaundice (Charcot triad), and abnormal liver tests. Later, her condition deteriorates, as indicated by the hypotension and altered mental status (Reynolds pentad). She most likely has ascending cholangitis due to bacteria invading the biliary system.  

Ascending cholangitis, also known as acute cholangitis, is an inflammation of the biliary system, usually due to bacterial infection ascending from the duodenum. Most cases occur secondary to partial obstruction of the bile duct by gallstones, which disrupts normal barrier mechanisms. It can also occur following gastrointestinal surgeries involving biliary tract manipulation (e.g., biliary cyst removal, endoscopic sphincterotomy, biliary stent insertion). Laboratory tests typically reveal leukocytosis and a cholestatic pattern of liver test abnormalities (e.g., elevations in the serum alkaline phosphatase, gamma-glutamyl transpeptidase, and mainly, conjugated bilirubin). Treatment consists of supportive care, antibiotics, and biliary drainage, usually via endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP).  

Diagnostic criteria
Evidence of systemic inflammation with one of the following:    
  • Fever and/or shaking chills.
  • Laboratory evidence of an inflammatory response (e.g., leukocytosis, elevated, CRP, etc). 
and both of the following:

  • Cholestasis evidence: Bilirubin ≥2 mg/dL or abnormal liver chemistries. 
  • Imaging showing biliary dilation or evidence of the underlying etiology (e.g., stricture, stone, or stent).

Option Analysis

❌ Biliary leak:
Incorrect: A biliary leak is a complication of bile duct injury, usually following laparoscopic cholecystectomy. Patients often present with fever, abdominal pain and/or bilious ascites and signs of peritonitis. On abdominal imaging, a loculated collection in the gallbladder fossa or around the liver can be seen. This patient has not had any recent abdominal surgery.   
✅ Bacteria infiltrating into the biliary system :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Obstruction of the cystic duct:
Incorrect: The obstruction of the cystic duct is a cause of acute cholecystitis. Patients with acute cholecystitis also present with fever and abdominal pain. However, cholecystitis will not manifest with significantly elevated bilirubin or alkaline phosphatase, since obstruction of bile flow is limited to the gallbladder. Additionally, abdominal imaging in acute cholecystitis will likely show a normal common bile duct, gallbladder wall thickening, free pericholecystic fluid, and a positive sonographic Murphy sign.  
❌ Gallstone obstructing the pancreatic duct:
Incorrect: Gallstones lodged in the biliary tract can trigger acute pancreatitis by obstruction of the flow from the pancreatic duct or by obstructing the ampulla of Vater. Patients with acute pancreatitis typically experience acute epigastric pain radiating to the back, elevation of serum amylase or lipase to 3x upper limit of normal, and/or characteristic enlargement of the pancreas on CT with contrast. This patient’s presentation and laboratory results favor another diagnosis.   
❌ Inflammation of the gallbladder without obstruction:
Incorrect: Inflammation of the gallbladder without obstruction describes acalculous cholecystitis, an acute necroinflammatory disease of the gallbladder in the absence of gallstones. It is commonly seen in critically ill patients and is thought to occur due to gallbladder stasis and ischemia, which leads to a local inflammatory response of the gallbladder wall. This patient was previously healthy, making this diagnosis unlikely.

questions.text: A 46-year-old female with a history of depression, anxiety, and hyperthyroidism presents to the emergency department with muscle spasms. She states, “I have had trouble sleeping for the past two weeks because my legs keep twitching.” She has also had worsening thoughts of self-harm and has rarely left her house. The patient recently underwent a thyroidectomy and is taking escitalopram for management of the depression. During the interview, she begins seizing. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 82/min, respirations are 8/min, and blood pressure is 120/74 mmHg. On physical exam, the patient is noted to have a well-healing surgical scar over the midline of the neck. She has contractions of the upper and lower extremities bilaterally. Contraction of the ipsilateral facial muscles are elicited when the muscles just anterior to the ear are tapped. Which of the following best describes the etiology of this patient's presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient has tetany, seizures, and worsening psychiatric symptoms after undergoing a recent thyroidectomy. The physical exam is notable for a positive Chvostek sign (facial muscle spasms after tapping CN VII). Given these findings, the patient likely has hypocalcemia secondary to accidental removal/damage of the parathyroid glands during surgery and subsequent reduction in parathyroid hormone (PTH) secretion.  

Extracellular calcium ions regulate numerous biological processes including coagulation, muscle contraction, and cardiac conduction. Serum calcium concentration is carefully maintained via hormonal regulation by parathyroid hormone (up-regulates calcium) and calcitonin (down-regulates calcium).  

Hypocalcemia has many causes, which are divided into disorders associated with low PTH levels, high PTH levels, and medication side effects. Disorders associated with low PTH levels include abnormal parathyroid gland development, post-surgical neck complications, autoimmune disorders, and infiltrative disorders. Diseases associated with high PTH levels include vitamin D deficiency, PTH resistance, and renal disease. Certain drugs are known to cause hypocalcemia, including bisphosphonates, chelation agents, and phenytoin.  

Regardless of etiology, the symptoms of hypocalcemia are similar and include muscle tetany, paresthesias, seizures, and psychiatric symptoms (e.g., emotional instability, anxiety, depression). Moreover, hypocalcemia can cause cardiovascular compromise, resulting in QT interval prolongation on ECG, which can degenerate into torsade de pointes. Physical exam findings include Chvostek sign and Trousseau sign (carpal spasms triggered by inflation of a sphygmomanometer).  

Option Analysis

✅ Decreased production of parathyroid hormone:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Activating antibodies targeting calcium-sensing receptors:
Incorrect: Autoantibodies targeting calcium-sensing receptors on the surface of the parathyroid glands can cause receptor activation, reduced parathyroid hormone production, and hypocalcemia. However, this patient has a recent history of thyroidectomy and more likely has hypocalcemia secondary to accidental damage or removal of the parathyroid glands.
❌ Low vitamin D stores:
Incorrect: Low stores of vitamin D due to gastrointestinal disorders or decreased sun exposure may result in chronic symptomatic hypocalcemia. Although this patient has risk factors for vitamin D deficiency, these symptoms are acute and occured over the past two weeks in the setting of a recent thyroidectomy. As a result, accidental damage or removal of the parathyroid glands is a more likely explanation for the hypocalcemia. 
❌ Parathyroid hormone resistance :
Incorrect: Pseudohypoparathyroidism refers to a group of heterogeneous disorders defined by unresponsiveness to parathyroid hormone (PTH) due to an alteration in the postreceptor PTH signaling pathway. It generally presents in children with elevated PTH levels and hypocalcemia.
❌ Decreased renal production of 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D :
Incorrect: Chronic kidney disease is the most common etiology for decreased production of vitamin D and subsequent hypocalcemia. This patient has no history or findings concerning for chronic kidney disease.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man presents to the office because of perineal pain for the past 4 months. He states that the pain is dull, constant and has been interfering with daily activities. He also reports mild pain during urination but denies urinary frequency, urgency or straining. Past medical history is significant for migraine headaches. Family history is unremarkable. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination including digital rectal examination is normal. There is no suprapubic pain on palpation. Urinalysis shows no abnormality. Expressed prostatic secretion shows 2 leukocytes/hpf, but culture does not grow a pathogenic organism. What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation with chronic perineal pain, mild dysuria and normal physical examination and laboratory evaluation is consistent with chronic abacterial prostatitis, a type of chronic prostatitis.    

Chronic prostatitis can be bacterial or abacterial. Chronic bacterial prostatitis usually occurs secondary to previous urinary tract infection (UTI) whereby bacteria migrate from the urinary tract into the prostate through intraprostatic reflux of urine. It can also sometimes present as a complication of acute prostatitis following incomplete treatment.    

Chronic abacterial prostatitis, also known as chronic prostatitis/chronic pelvic pain syndrome (CP/CPPS), is defined as chronic pelvic pain (perineal, testicular, suprapubic or penile) for at least three months in the absence of another identifiable cause that is often associated with urinary symptoms and/or sexual dysfunction. It may be due to inflammation secondary to trauma or due to normal prostate flora, autoimmunity, neurogenic pain, and the interplay of somatic and psychological factors. Digital rectal examination (DRE) shows a mildly tender prostate, though it is not always present. Diagnosis is aided by urinalysis and expressed prostatic secretions.



Option Analysis

❌ Benign prostatic hyperplasia:
Incorrect: Benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) usually manifests with lower urinary tract symptoms like frequency, urgency, nocturia, dribbling, and a non-tender, enlarged prostate on DRE. A normal DRE and the absence of lower urinary tract symptoms makes this diagnosis unlikely.   
❌ Acute prostatitis:
Incorrect: Acute prostatitis usually presents with sudden-onset dysuria, urinary frequency, fever, chills and a warm, tender and boggy prostate on DRE. This patient’s normal DRE and urinalysis, a sterile culture of prostatic secretions, and chronic symptoms make this diagnosis less likely.
❌ Chronic bacterial prostatitis:
Incorrect: Although chronic bacterial prostatitis can present with chronic perineal pain and dysuria, prostatic secretions containing <12 leukocytes/hpf and no growth of organisms on culture are atypical.
✅ Chronic abacterial prostatitis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Cystitis:
Incorrect: Cystitis usually presents with dysuria, urinary frequency, urgency, and suprapubic pain. Urinalysis often reveals pyuria and positive leukocyte esterase and/or nitrites.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old woman comes to the clinic due to progressive fatigue, weight loss, and ankle swelling for the past two months. Physical examination shows 2+ pitting edema around the ankles. Cardiovascular and respiratory examinations are non-contributory. Laboratory results show a serum creatinine level of 3.1 mg/dL, albumin of 2.2 g/dL, and total cholesterol concentration of 290 mg/dL. Urinalysis results show 3+ proteinuria without hematuria or red cell casts. Renal biopsy is performed, and the results are shown below:  


Reproduced from: Wikipedia    

Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with pitting edema, proteinuria, hypoalbuminemia, and biopsy findings revealing Kimmelstiel-Wilson lesions. She most likely has diabetic glomerulonephropathy.

Diabetic glomerulonephropathy is the most common cause of end-stage renal disease in the United States. The condition presents with symptoms of nephrotic syndrome, including massive proteinuria (>3.5 g/day), hypoalbuminemia, edema, and hyperlipidemia. Of note, the hyperlipidemic state is thought to be a method of compensating for the reduction in plasma oncotic pressure due to protein loss via urine.  

The condition arises since hyperglycemia secondary to diabetes mellitus causes nonenzymatic glycation, which leads to mesangial expansion, basement membrane thickening, and podocyte damage. The increased permeability causes glomerular hyperfiltration, which eventually progresses to glomerular hypertrophy and scarring (glomerulosclerosis).  

Biopsy will reveal eosinophilic nodular glomerulosclerosis (Kimmelstiel-Wilson lesions), which arise due to mesangial matrix expansion. These lesions are Periodic acid–Schiff (PAS) stain positive.    

Option Analysis

❌ Light chain nephropathy:
Incorrect: Light chain nephropathy, which can be seen in patients with multiple myeloma, is a cause of nephrotic syndrome. It occurs when light chains precipitate with uromodulin (formerly termed Tamm-Horsfall mucoprotein) and obstruct the renal tubular lumen. On light microscopy, these casts can be seen as amorphous material within the renal tubular lumen. However, light chain nephropathy would not manifest with the Kimmelstiel-Wilson lesions seen on this patient’s biopsy. 
❌ Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis:
Incorrect: Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in patients of Hispanic and African-American descent. It can be a primary condition or arise secondary to HIV, sickle cell disease, obesity, or interferon treatment. Biopsy results under light microscopy will show segmental sclerosis and hyalinosis. In other words, only part of the glomerulus is affected. However, the condition would not lead to the formation of Kimmelstiel-Wilson lesions, which are seen on this patient’s biopsy. 
❌ Diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis:
Incorrect: Diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis is a condition that often presents concurrently with both nephrotic and nephritic syndrome. It is associated with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). The condition can lead to nephrotic range proteinuria (i.e. >3.5 g/day) and clinical features of nephritic syndrome (e.g., hematuria, RBC casts in the urine). A biopsy under light microscopy will show wire looping of capillaries. In contrast, this patient has neither hematuria nor wire looping.
✅ Diabetic glomerulonephropathy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Amyloidosis:
Incorrect: Amyloidosis is a cause of nephrotic syndrome. It is associated with systemic amyloidosis and chronic conditions that lead to amyloid deposition (e.g. rheumatoid arthritis). Kidney biopsy will reveal amyloid deposits, which present with an apple-green birefringence under polarized light following Congo red staining.
❌ Membranous nephropathy:
Incorrect: Membranous nephropathy is a cause of nephrotic syndrome. Primary disease can be due to antibodies against phospholipase A2 receptors. Secondary disease can be due to drugs (e.g., NSAIDs, penicillamine), infections (e.g., HBV, HCV, syphilis), systemic lupus erythematosus, and solid tumors. Biopsy results under light microscopy will show diffuse capillary and glomerular basement membrane thickening. However, the condition would not manifest with the Kimmelstiel-Wilson lesions seen on this patient’s biopsy.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old nulliparous woman comes to the office because of chronic intermittent dull pelvic pain for 7 months. The pain usually begins a day before menses and resolves 1-2 days after the menstruation stops. She also complains of crampy pain with defecation. Menarche was at age 13. Her cycles are regular but are associated with heavy bleeding for 5 days. She is not sexually active, and there is no history of sexually transmitted disease. Family history is remarkable for ovarian cancer in her maternal grandmother. Vitals are within normal limits. BMI is 33 kg/m2. Abdominal examination shows no abnormalities. Pelvic examination shows a fixed anteverted uterus and palpable right-sided adnexal mass. Transvaginal ultrasound of the right ovary is shown below.  


Reproduced from: radiopedia.org   

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation with chronic intermittent pelvic pain, dysmenorrhea, heavy menstrual bleeding, right-sided adnexal mass and fixed uterus, together with ultrasonographic evidence of a unilocular round hypoechoic density (endometrioma), is consistent with the diagnosis of endometriosis.  

Endometriosis is defined as implantation of endometrial glands and stroma outside the endometrium that grow and trigger an inflammatory response. It can involve the ovaries when the ectopic tissue in the ovary bleeds (in response to cyclic hormonal stimulation) and results in the formation of a hematoma surrounded by ovarian parenchyma (endometrioma), giving it a chocolate-like cyst appearance on gross examination. Subsequently, it can lead to nearby fibrosis and adhesion formation, causing infertility. On ultrasonography, endometrioma appears as a round hypoechoic density with homogenous contents (ground-glass appearance).   

Surgical resection provides a definitive diagnosis, symptom relief, and exclusion of malignancy. Other locations that can be involved in endometriosis include the anterior and posterior cul-de-sac (deep dyspareunia, dyschezia [pain with defecation]), broad ligaments, uterosacral ligaments, fallopian tubes, bladder (urinary frequency, urgency), and bowel (diarrhea, constipation).  

Option Analysis

❌ Polycystic ovary syndrome:
Incorrect: Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) usually presents with hyperandrogenic symptoms (hirsutism, acne) and irregular menstrual cycles. Diagnosis requires ultrasonographic evidence of 12 or more follicles measuring 2 to 9 mm in diameter in the ovary. In contrast, this patient’s ultrasonography shows a single unilocular cyst.  
❌ Ovarian cystic teratoma:
Incorrect: Teratomas are benign germ cell tumors and are asymptomatic in most cases. However, an increase in size of the mass can cause ovarian torsion that presents with acute abdomen. On ultrasonography, it appears as a complex mass with hyperechoic contents and sometimes calcifications.
✅ Endometriosis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Epithelial ovarian carcinoma:
Incorrect: Epithelial ovarian carcinoma usually manifests in postmenopausal women with bloating, abdominal distention (due to ascites), constipation or pelvic mass. Ultrasonography shows a complex multilocular mass. It is unlikely in this young patient with a unilocular mass.
❌ Corpus luteal cyst:
Incorrect: Corpus luteal cyst is a physiological cyst that forms when the corpus luteum fails to involute after ovulation. On ultrasound, it appears as a simple or complex cyst with thick walls and internal debris (if hemorrhagic). It does not cause dysmenorrhea and dyschezia.

questions.text:
A 3-day-old female infant is brought to the emergency department due to difficulty breathing. She was born at term through normal vaginal delivery to a 30-year-old woman who had full prenatal care. The mother reports that the patient was fine after birth and recently started developing blue-colored skin and rapid breathing at home. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 155/min, respirations are 65/min, and blood pressure is 80/50 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry shows an oxygen saturation of 80% on room air. Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows PO2 of 30 mm Hg. Physical examination shows central cyanosis and retractions of the rib cage. 100% oxygen through a nasal cannula and PGE1 are administered. The patient’s airway is stable, and a chest radiograph is obtained (shown below). Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?  


Reproduced from: Radiopaedia
questions.solution:
This previously healthy infant who was born to a mother who had prenatal care is now presenting several days after birth with central cyanosis, hypoxemia, and tachypnea, which imply the condition is patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) dependent. Along with the chest x-ray findings showing classic “egg on a string” appearance and increased pulmonary markings, the most likely diagnosis is D-transposition of the great vessels (D-TGA). 

D-TGA is a congenital heart defect in which the aorta arises from the right ventricle and the pulmonary artery from the left ventricle, resulting in 2 parallel circulations. The condition is not well understood but is thought to occur due to failure of the aorticopulmonary septum to spiral. Due to this parallel circuitry, blood from the right ventricle leaves through the aorta to the body, and then flows back to the right atrium and ventricle (blood never becomes oxygenated). Then, blood from the left ventricle leaves through the pulmonary artery to the lungs, where it flows through to the pulmonary veins, left atrium and left ventricle (the oxygenated blood never gets delivered to the organs).    

The postnatal clinical features are dependent on the degree of mixing between the two circulations and the presence of other cardiac anomalies. For the condition to be compatible with life, a mixing of the blood must be allowed. This can occur if there is a patent foramen ovale, ventricular septal defect, or PDA. The PDA typically closes in the first few days of life, resulting in cyanosis if the congenital heart defect is PDA-dependent, as seen here. Prostaglandin E1 (PGE1), also known as alprostadil, can be administered to help keep the PDA open while waiting for surgery. If left uncorrected, most infants die within the first year of life.  





Option Analysis

❌ Persistent truncus arteriosus:
Incorrect: Persistent truncus arteriosus (TA) is another cause of cyanotic heart disease of the newborn in which there is a failure of the aorticopulmonary septum to form resulting in a common arterial trunk. Chest radiography in TA typically shows cardiac enlargement and increased pulmonary vascular markings, rather than the “egg on a string” appearance seen in this patient. TA is associated with DiGeorge syndrome (22q11.2 deletion) and other exam features would be expected. Additionally, TA is not patent ductus arteriosus dependent (See Main Explanation).
✅ D-transposition of the great vessels:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Tricuspid atresia:
Incorrect: Tricuspid atresia is another cause of cyanotic heart disease of the newborn and is characterized by congenital agenesis or absence of the tricuspid valve. On chest radiograph in a newborn with tricuspid atresia, the smooth convexity of the right heart border is absent, and the right heart border does not cross beyond the spine. Additionally, tricuspid atresia results in decreased pulmonary flow, leading to decreased pulmonary markings on chest radiograph, rather than increased, as seen here.
❌ Tetralogy of Fallot:
Incorrect: Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) is also characterized by early cyanosis. The presentation is variable and depends on the degree of the right ventricular outflow tract obstruction. Chest radiograph in a newborn with TOF will likely show a “boot-shaped” heart and decreased pulmonary markings, unlike here, as the right ventricular outflow obstruction leads to decreased pulmonary flow. Additionally, the condition is characterized by “tet spells,” which are cyanotic episodes triggered by crying, feeding or physical activity, rather than progressive cyanosis. 
❌ Total anomalous pulmonary venous return :
Incorrect: Total anomalous pulmonary venous return (TAPVR) is another cause of early cyanosis in which the four pulmonary veins fail to make their normal connection to the left atrium and instead drain into the right atrium. A chest radiograph in a newborn with TAPVR chest radiograph may show a classic “snowman” appearance. Additionally, TAPVR is not patent ductus arteriosus dependent (See Main Explanation).

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman comes to the physician due to irregular menses for the past 3 months. She states that previously her menses occurred every 28-30 days and lasted 4-5 days. She also notes excessive fatigue and recent weight gain of 9-lb in 2 months. She uses topical betamethasone for treatment of vitiligo, and she recently started taking laxatives several times a week to help with bowel movements. Temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 52/min, blood pressure is 122/82 mm Hg, and BMI is 27 kg/m2. Physical examination shows dry skin and a slightly distended abdomen. She has delayed tendon reflex relaxation in the lower extremities. There is 2+ non-pitting edema in the bilateral lower extremities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s edema?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with irregular menses, fatigue, weight gain, constipation, and delayed deep tendon reflexes. She most likely has hypothyroidism. Although the cause is currently unknown in this patient, chronic autoimmune thyroiditis (Hashimoto thyroiditis) is the leading cause of hypothyroidism in the United States and is most commonly seen in patients with other autoimmune conditions (e.g., vitiligo, type I diabetes mellitus).  

In autoimmune thyroiditis, and other cases of primary hypothyroidism, the reduced production of T3 and T4 from the thyroid gland results in increased anterior pituitary secretion of thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH). A secondary effect of high levels of TSH is that it stimulates fibroblasts in the skin and soft tissues. The stimulated fibroblasts begin depositing glycosaminoglycans in the interstitium, resulting in pretibial non-pitting edema and/or periorbital edema.   




Option Analysis

✅ Hormonal stimulation of fibroblasts:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Decreased serum protein content:
Incorrect: Decreased serum protein content can be seen in cases of hypoalbuminemia and is either the result of decreased production (e.g. liver cirrhosis) or increased excretion (e.g. nephrotic syndrome). Albumin makes up ~80% of plasma colloid pressure, which normally counterbalances hydrostatic pressure. Patients with nephrotic syndrome typically have frothy urine, whereas patients with liver cirrhosis will have jaundice and hepatosplenomegaly. This patient’s clinical features are more consistent with a different underlying diagnosis. 
❌ Incompetence of venous valves:
Incorrect: Chronic venous insufficiency is the result of incompetent venous valves, which causes reflux of blood into superficial veins, elevation of venous pressure, and formation of varicose veins. Varicose veins are characterized by lower extremity pain and pruritus, especially after prolonged standing, and usually leads to yellow-brown skin pigmentation. This patient’s clinical features are consistent with a different underlying diagnosis. 
❌ Impaired right-sided cardiac function:
Incorrect: In patients with right-sided heart failure (RHF), there is an impaired ability of the right ventricle to send blood forward into the pulmonary system. RHF is often due to either increased pulmonary resistance (e.g. pulmonary hypertension) or decreased left-ventricular function, leading to backup of blood into the lungs (e.g. cardiogenic pulmonary edema). Patients with right-sided heart failure typically have jugular venous distension and signs of hepatic venous congestion (e.g. hepatomegaly), neither of which are seen in this patient.
❌ Increased venous capillary permeability :
Incorrect: Increase capillary permeability can result in leakage of fluid into the interstitial space, resulting in localized pitting edema. Capillary permeability can be increased in cases of inflammation, burns, or allergic reactions. This patient’s clinical features are consistent with a different underlying diagnosis.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes to the clinic due to progressive dizziness for the past month. The patient states the dizziness typically occurs several seconds after standing up from a seated position. The patient states he also has had nocturia, urinary urgency, and erectile dysfunction for the past few months. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), and pulse is 80/min. Blood pressure is 125/85 mmHg when the patient is in a recumbent position and 90/70 mmHg when standing. Ocular movements are normal. There is increased rigidity of both arms and legs. On gait evaluation, the patient strides in small steps and fails to fully lift his feet from the floor. The Mini-Mental State Examination result is 26/30. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with orthostatic hypotension, erectile dysfunction, incontinence, and diffuse rigidity, all favoring the diagnosis of multiple system atrophy (MSA).  

MSA refers to a group of neurodegenerative syndromes (including Shy-Drager syndrome) that share similar brain pathology and are characterized by autonomic dysfunction, cerebellar abnormalities, parkinsonism, and corticospinal degeneration in varying combinations. MSA can be further divided into two subtypes: MSA with predominant parkinsonism (MSA-P) and MSA with predominant cerebellar ataxia (MSA-C). At the early stages of the condition, Parkinson disease can be difficult to distinguish from MSA. However, in contrast to Parkinson disease, MSA patients typically have preserved cognitive function. The levodopa responsiveness test can help to establish the diagnosis; while Parkinson patients tend to have an excellent response to levodopa-carbidopa, MSA patients have a poor response to levodopa therapy.  

The diagnosis of MSA is based upon clinical features, and no laboratory or imaging studies are diagnostic. Neuroimaging is often non-revealing or equivocal but can assist in excluding other conditions. When present, atrophy can be seen in the basal ganglia circuit (e.g., putamen, globus pallidus). Treatment is dependent on the signs and symptoms. In general, despite the poor response to levodopa, patients do better with levodopa treatment than without it. Chronic orthostatic hypotension is managed with fludrocortisone acetate.  


 

Option Analysis

❌ Multiple sclerosis:
Incorrect: Many features seen in this patient can be explained by multiple sclerosis (MS); however, it is rare for MS to present after the age of 50, and other characteristic features such as visual disturbances and paresthesias would be expected. Additionally, rigidity (a velocity-dependent increase in tonic stretch, meaning that it is more noticeable with fast movements) is rare in MS, and most patients instead exhibit spasticity (non-velocity-dependent increase in resistance to passive movement, meaning that it does not vary with speed of movement of muscle groups involved).  
❌ Parkinson disease:
Incorrect: Although this patient is presenting with some of the classic signs of Parkinson disease, the predominance of autonomic symptoms favors the diagnosis of multiple system atrophy. 
✅ Multiple system atrophy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Normal-pressure hydrocephalus:
Incorrect: Normal-pressure hydrocephalus (NPH) is an idiopathic condition characterized by the expansion of ventricles and distortion of the corona radiata fibers. Patients typically present with a classic triad of urinary incontinence, gait apraxia (typically described as a “magnetic gait”), and cognitive dysfunction. However, in this case, the predominance of autonomic symptoms and the preserved cognition (>24 on mini-mental status exam) favor the diagnosis of multiple system atrophy. Lastly, diffuse rigidity is not typically seen in NPH.
❌ Progressive supranuclear palsy:
Incorrect: Progressive supranuclear palsy (PSP) is a neurodegenerative disease characterized by personality and behavior changes, parkinsonism, loss of balance and vertical eye palsy. Although some of the features seen in this patient can also be seen in PSP, the absence of vertical eye palsy and the signs of autonomic dysfunction favor another diagnosis.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man comes to the physician’s office due to a recent fall and the feeling of unsteadiness. The patient fell 2 days ago when going down the stairs but did not experience any head trauma. The patient’s partner reports that the patient has been acting differently for the past several months and is often anxious. The patient is healthy with no significant past medical history, and he does not take any medications. Vital signs are within normal limits. On physical examination, there is mild hyperkyphosis, and the patient is walking slowly. The muscle tone is increased bilaterally. There is a mild tremor on the right hand during rest which disappears on a finger-to-nose test. The patient is started on appropriate therapy. Which of the following is most likely to be found on examination of a patient’s brain with this condition?

choices.text: Atrophy of putamen and caudate nucleus
Eosinophilic sphere-shaped inclusions within the neuron's cytoplasm
Basophilic fibrillary structures within the neuronal cytoplasm

questions.solution:
This patient has hyperkyphosis, postural instability, hypokinesia (small steps), resting tremor, and personality changes (anxiety or depression), a presentation consistent with Parkinson disease (PD).  

Eosinophilic sphere-shaped inclusions in the cytoplasm of neurons are consistent with Lewy bodies, which are considered the pathological hallmark of PD, along with degeneration of dopaminergic neurons of the substantia nigra. In PD, dopamine depletion in the substantia nigra and nigrostriatal pathway ultimately results in excess inhibition of the thalamus and decreased excitatory input to the motor cortex, which manifests as bradykinesia and other signs of parkinsonism.  

The cardinal signs of PD include a pill-rolling tremor at rest, rigidity, akinesia/bradykinesia, and postural instability (this can be remembered with the mnemonic TRAP). Other common signs are hypomimia (reduced degree of facial expression, also known as masked facies), dysphagia, micrographia, stooped posture/kyphosis, shuffling gait, and dementia later on in the disease course.

PD has no cure, and treatment is aimed to control symptoms and delay disease progression. The pharmacologic treatment is individualized based on the patient's characteristics and the disease progression. The main drug classes include MAO-B inhibitors (selegiline), amantadine (increases dopamine release), dopamine agonists, and levodopa/carbidopa. Anticholinergic drugs are also used mainly for tremor relief.    

 

Option Analysis

❌ Atrophy of putamen and caudate nucleus :
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with Huntington disease, which typically presents with personality changes, such as aggression, depression, and dementia, as well as movement disorders, including chorea and athetosis. Imaging or autopsy of the brain typically shows ex vacuo ventriculomegaly, meaning the ventricles look enlarged when in reality the brain itself is atrophied. 
❌ Multiple cortical and subcortical infarcts:
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with vascular dementia, a condition caused by multiple infarcts and/or chronic ischemia.  The condition is typically seen in patients with longstanding cardiovascular conditions (e.g., hypertension, hyperlipidemia, diabetes), which this patient lacks. Common presenting symptoms include a stepwise decline in cognitive ability and late-onset memory impairment. 
✅ Eosinophilic sphere-shaped inclusions within the neuron's cytoplasm:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Basophilic fibrillary structures within the neuronal cytoplasm:
Incorrect: This answer depicts neurofibrillary tangles, a common finding in Alzheimer disease (AD). These tangles are made of accumulated hyperphosphorylated tau protein. Alzheimer disease typically presents with early memory loss and dementia. While motor signs (e.g., pyramidal, extrapyramidal) do occur in patients with AD, these are usually late-stage findings.
❌ Round inclusions of hyperphosphorylated proteins:
Incorrect: Round inclusions of hyperphosphorylated tau proteins or ubiquitinated TDP-43 can be seen in frontotemporal dementia, which is characterized by early changes in personality and behavior in addition to aphasia. On imaging, frontotemporal lobe degeneration is often seen.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman comes to the clinic due to 2 months of headaches and an irritating sound in her left ear. The patient states the sound is similar to a ‘whooshing,’ and she has noticed that it matches the timing of her own heartbeat. Past medical history is significant for asthma. Current medications include albuterol and inhaled corticosteroids as needed. Temperature is 37.0 °C (98.6 °F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 165/95 mmHg. Body mass index (BMI) is 32 kg/m2. On physical exam, cardiac and lung examination is within normal limits. A systolic bruit is heard below the left ear. Abdomen is soft and nontender, and bowel sounds are present. There is a bruit present over the abdomen on auscultation. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to reveal which of the following?

choices.text: Elevated urinary 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid (5‑HIAA) in the urine

questions.solution:
This young woman, who is presenting with overt hypertension, subauricular and abdominal bruits as well as pulsatile tinnitus, most likely has fibromuscular dysplasia (FMD). FMD is a nonatherosclerotic, noninflammatory disorder that results in arterial occlusion, stenosis, aneurysm, dissection, and arterial tortuosity. The exact etiology of FMD remains unknown, but a genetic origin is highly suspected. The findings are widely spread throughout the body but most frequently involve the renal and internal carotid arteries, followed by the vertebral, visceral, and external iliac arteries. A subauricular bruit is highly suggestive of FMD, since young patients should not have symptomatic carotid atherosclerosis until much older. Approximately 90% of the cases are seen in women. Symptoms of FMD are variable and depend on the location, severity, and type of FMD. Common signs and symptoms are:

  •  Hypertension (typically caused by renal artery FMD) 
  •  Headache, especially migraines (more common in carotid or vertebral artery FMD) 
  •  Pulsatile tinnitus, which patients describe as hearing a ‘swishing’ or ‘whooshing’ sound in their ears that matches the timing of their own heartbeat (more common in carotid or vertebral artery FMD) 
Secondary hypertension is the most common manifestation of FMD. The renal artery stenosis results in decreased renal perfusion which activates the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system, resulting in elevated renin. This has direct effects on sodium excretion, sympathetic nerve activity, intrarenal prostaglandin concentrations, and nitric oxide production, which ultimately lead to renovascular hypertension.



Option Analysis

❌ Elevated CO2 on pulse oximetry:
Incorrect: Elevated CO2 level on pulse oximetry can be seen in obesity hypoventilation syndrome (OHS). This condition can occur in obese individuals with body mass index [BMI] >30 kg/m2. The excess weight leads to reduced mobility of the diaphragm, as well as reduced relative inspiratory muscle strength. OHS can cause pulmonary hypertension and subsequently right ventricular failure. Although this patient’s BMI meets the criteria for obesity, the bruits and overt hypertension favors another diagnosis. 
❌ Elevated plasma metanephrines level:
Incorrect:  Elevated plasma metanephrines level can be seen in pheochromocytoma, the most common tumor of the adrenal medulla in adults. The tumor is derived from chromaffin cells (neural crest) and can secrete epinephrine, norepinephrine, and dopamine. Symptoms occur in “spells” characterized by elevated blood pressure, headache, diaphoresis, palpitations and pallor. This patient’s bruits and overt hypertension favors another diagnosis. 
❌ Elevated urinary 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid (5‑HIAA) in the urine:
Incorrect: Elevated urinary 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid (5‑HIAA) in the urine can be seen in carcinoid syndrome caused by carcinoid tumors. These tumors are derived from neuroendocrine cells and can arise in the lung or intestines. They secrete serotonin (5-HT) and present as recurrent diarrhea, cutaneous flushing, asthmatic wheezing, and right sided valvular heart disease. This patient’s presentation favors another diagnosis. 
❌ Elevated free cortisol on 24-hour urinalysis:
Incorrect: Elevated free cortisol on 24-hour urinalysis can be seen in Cushing syndrome, a condition associated with multiple entities (e.g., external steroid use, primary adrenal adenoma, ACTH-secreting pituitary adenoma, small cell lung cancer). Cushing syndrome is characterized by hypertension, weight gain, changes in physical appearance (e.g., moon facies, truncal obesity, buffalo hump), and hirsutism. Cushing syndrome is more common in the setting of chronic oral corticosteroid usage, but it would be highly unlikely with this patient’s use of a corticosteroid inhaler. Additionally, this patient’s bruits on physical examination favor another diagnosis. 
✅ Elevated renin levels :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of fatigue and a cough that is productive of blood-tinged sputum. His symptoms began four months ago. Past medical history is notable for emphysema and hypertension. He has a 40-pack-year smoking history. Physical examination reveals 4/5 strength in the bilateral upper and lower extremities. Ecchymoses and striae are noted on the abdomen. Laboratory testing reveals a fasting blood glucose of 147 mg/dL. Chest X-ray shows a mass in the perihilar region of the left lung. A 24-hour urine sample reveals an elevated cortisol level. A high-dose dexamethasone test is subsequently ordered as part of the patient’s work-up. Which of the following ACTH levels would be expected before and after the high-dose dexamethasone is administered?
questions.solution:
This patient has Cushing syndrome secondary to ectopic ACTH secretion by a lung malignancy.  

The first step in the work-up is to measure free cortisol in a 24-hour urine sample. Alternatively, blood or saliva tests at midnight can help check if there is a normal daily rise and fall of cortisol levels. Another option is the low-dose dexamethasone suppression test. During the test the individual is given a low dose of dexamethasone, an exogenous steroid that suppresses pituitary ACTH production. In healthy individuals, this would cause a decrease in serum cortisol levels.  

If any of the aforementioned tests yield abnormal results, the next step is to determine the exact cause of excess cortisol production. This involves measuring plasma ACTH levels. Low ACTH levels are seen in adrenal adenomas, adrenal carcinomas, and exogenous glucocorticoid use. In contrast, high ACTH levels are seen in patients with Cushing disease (ACTH-secreting pituitary adenoma) and ectopic ACTH production. The patient in this vignette has ectopic ACTH production by a lung malignancy. So his ACTH measurement will be elevated.  

In patients with high ACTH levels, the next step is to give a high-dose injection of dexamethasone. If there is no decline in ACTH levels, it means there is an ectopic site of ACTH production. If levels of ACTH fall after the high-dose dexamethasone test, then Cushing disease is the cause. Since this patient has ectopic ACTH secretion, his levels will remain elevated after administering high-dose dexamethasone.  

Option Analysis

❌   Before High-Dose Dexamethasone  After High-Dose Dexamethasone  Decreased  Decreased :
Incorrect: Patients with hypercortisolism due to exogenous corticosteroid use or adrenal overproduction will present with decreased ACTH levels. Administration of high-dose steroids will prompt additional negative feedback, causing further decreases in ACTH secretion. However, the X-ray findings, in combination with a history of blood-tinged sputum production, suggest that an ACTH-secreting lung malignancy is the most likely cause of his presentation.
❌   Before High-Dose Dexamethasone  After High-Dose Dexamethasone  Decreased  Increased:
Incorrect: Patients with hypercortisolism due to exogenous corticosteroid use or adrenal overproduction will have decreased ACTH levels. High-dose dexamethasone administration would only increase the negative feedback to the pituitary gland, thus further decreasing ACTH production.
❌   Before High-Dose Dexamethasone  After High-Dose Dexamethasone  Increased Decreased :
Incorrect: These findings are seen in patients with an ACTH-secreting pituitary adenoma. After the high-dose dexamethasone is administered, sufficient negative feedback will be present to decrease pituitary ACTH secretion. However, the X-ray findings and patient’s history suggest that an ACTH-secreting lung malignancy is the most likely cause of his presentation. High-dose dexamethasone cannot suppress ectopic ACTH production. 
✅   Before High-Dose Dexamethasone  After High-Dose Dexamethasone  Increased Increased:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌   Before High-Dose Dexamethasone  After High-Dose Dexamethasone  Normal Decreased :
Incorrect: These findings would be observed in a healthy individual. Administration of the high-dose dexamethasone would result in elevated serum corticosteroid levels. This would cause negative feedback on the pituitary gland and would therefore decrease ACTH production. However, healthy individuals would not present with muscle weakness, ecchymoses, and abdominal striae. All of these are symptoms of hypercortisolism, which is consistent with this patient’s elevated urine cortisol level.

questions.text:
A 2-year-old boy is brought to the clinician by his parents due to easy fatigability and growth delay. They recently immigrated to the United States. The mother did not receive any prenatal care in her home country. The child was born at term by a normal vaginal delivery. He is at the 30th percentile for length and below the 10th percentile for weight. Temperature is 37.2°C (98.9°F), pulse is 115/min, respirations are 25/min, and blood pressure is 85/60 mmHg. Abdominal examination shows hepatosplenomegaly. Hematological tests and hemoglobin electrophoresis are obtained:  
 
 Laboratory value  Result 
 Hemoglobin (Hb)  10.8 g/dL 
 Hematocrit (Hct)  32% 
 Erythrocyte count  5.7 million/mm3 
 Hemoglobin A2 (HbA2)   6.5% 
 Fetal hemoglobin (HbF)  60% 
 Hemoglobin A (HbA1)  None 
 Hemoglobin S (HbS)  None 

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with growth delay, fatigability, and hepatosplenomegaly (indicating extramedullary hematopoiesis). He also has laboratory investigations showing a low hemoglobin and absent HbA1 on hemoglobin electrophoresis. As a result, he most likely has β-thalassemia major.  

β-thalassemia major (homozygous) occurs when both genes coding for the β-globin chains on chromosome 11 are mutated, leading to absent (or minimal) β-chain production. Microcytic anemia typically develops during the first year of life, usually after six months of age. This is because in the first six months of life, the major hemoglobin is fetal hemoglobin (HbF), which uses γ-chains instead of β-chains.  

Clinical features of β-thalassemia major include symptoms and signs of severe anemia due to ineffective erythropoiesis and extravascular hemolysis such as fatigability, failure to thrive, high-output heart failure, and pallor. There may also be jaundice and dark urine from extravascular hemolysis. Patients may have evidence of extramedullary hematopoiesis including hepatosplenomegaly and craniofacial abnormalities such as thickened facial bones (“chipmunk facies”). Skull radiographs may show a translucent medullary space with hair-like projections (“hair on end” or “crew cut” appearance).  


Hemoglobin electrophoresis for β-thalassemia major will show HbA2 > 5%, HbF up to 95%, and no HbA1. Since β-chains are absent, no HbA1 can be made. The body increases HbA2 and HbF (neither of which contain β-chains) production to compensate for the absence of normal HbA1.  



Option Analysis

❌ α-thalassemia major:
Incorrect: α-thalassemia major (also termed hemoglobin Barts disease) is a cause of severe anemia that manifests in utero. The condition is incompatible with life, and infants present with hydrops fetalis at birth. α-thalassemia major occurs when all four genes coding for the α-globin chain on chromosome 16 are mutated. As a result, there is no production of α-globin, and instead, the excess γ-globin forms γ4 hemoglobin. Electrophoresis demonstrates absent HbF, HbA, and HbA2.
❌ Hemoglobin H disease:
Incorrect: Hemoglobin H (HbH) disease is also a cause of moderate microcytic hypochromic anemia. The condition occurs when three out of four genes coding for the α-globin chain on chromosome 16 are mutated. Although the condition is compatible with life, newborns with HbH disease present with moderate hemolytic anemia and jaundice. Also, laboratory panels in HbH disease will show the presence of some HbA1. In contrast, this patient has no HbA1, making HbH disease unlikely.
❌ β-thalassemia minor :
Incorrect: β-thalassemia minor (heterozygote) is another cause of microcytic hypochromic anemia and is usually asymptomatic. It occurs when one of the β-globin chain genes is mutated, leading to β-chain underproduction. Diagnosis is confirmed by identifying HbA2 (> 3.5%) and HbF (up to 5%) on electrophoresis. This patient is symptomatic, and HbF levels are higher than expected, hence making the diagnosis of β-thalassemia minor unlikely. 
✅ β-thalassemia major:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Sickle cell trait :
Incorrect: Sickle cell trait (heterozygous) occurs when a point mutation causes a single amino acid replacement in the β-chain, resulting in the production of mutated hemoglobin S (HbS). The condition is mostly asymptomatic; patients are not anemic and have a normal life expectancy. Electrophoresis is likely to show HbA1 ∼50-60%, HbA2 <3.5%, HbS ∼30%, and HbF <2%. This patient has no HbS at all, making this diagnosis very unlikely.
❌ Sickle cell disease:
Incorrect: Sickle cell disease (homozygous) is an autosomal recessive disorder that occurs when a point mutation causes a single amino acid replacement in the β-chain, producing mutated hemoglobin S (HbS). Low O2, high altitude, or acidosis precipitates sickling (deoxygenated HbS polymerizes), leading to vaso-occlusive disease as well as extravascular and intravascular hemolysis. Patients are asymptomatic at birth due to the presence of high HbF and low HbS. Electrophoresis is likely to show absent HbA1, HbA2 <3.5%, HbS ∼90%, and HbF ∼10%. This patient has no HbS at all, and no other features of sickle cell disease, making this diagnosis unlikely.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman, gravida 3 para 2, is admitted to the labor and delivery unit with active contractions every 3-5 minutes. Her previous births were via cesarean sections. One hour later, she gives birth to a healthy child. Thirty minutes after delivery, the placenta has still not been delivered. Manual extraction of the retained placenta is performed and leads to profuse bleeding. The patient’s temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 120/min, and blood pressure is 85/60 mmHg. Oxygen saturation is 95% on room air. On physical examination, the uterus is firm and nontender. Hemoglobin is 9 g/dL and platelet count is 220,000/mm3. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism for this patient’s bleeding?

choices.text: Profound activation of the coagulation cascade
Placental implantation near the cervical os
Abnormal trophoblast invasion into the uterine wall
Abnormal implantation of the fetal vessels

questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with postpartum hemorrhage and hypotension after manual extraction of the placenta, favoring the diagnosis of placenta accreta spectrum (PAS).  

PAS refers to an abnormal trophoblastic invasion into the myometrium of the uterine wall due to placental implantation at an area of faulty decidualization. This abnormal implantation is typically caused by pre-existing damage to the uterine wall, such as prior cesarean section. PAS includes placenta accreta (attaches to the myometrium rather than decidua), increta (penetrates the myometrium), and percreta (through the myometrium to the uterine serosa/adjacent organs). Risk factors include prior cesarean section, uterine procedures, maternal age > 35 years, multiparity, history of pelvic irradiation, and postpartum endometritis. PAS often present with profuse, life-threatening hemorrhage that occurs during manual placental separation. Management typically includes supportive care, and in most cases, hysterectomy is indicated.



Option Analysis

❌ Profound activation of the coagulation cascade :
Incorrect: Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) is a systemic condition in which coagulation and fibrinolysis are abnormally activated, leading to thrombosis and hemorrhage. This complication can occur during postpartum hemorrhage; however, DIC leads to prolonged aPTT and PTT, elevation of fibrin degradation products and D-dimer, and consumption of platelets. This patient has a normal platelet count. Also, manifestations of DIC include petechiae, as well as blood oozing from wound sites (e.g. intravenous lines) and mucosal surfaces. 
❌ Placental implantation near the cervical os :
Incorrect: Placenta previa refers to placental tissue implementation over or in proximity to the cervical os. Placenta previa should be suspected in any pregnant woman who presents with painless vaginal bleeding after 20 weeks gestation. Diagnosis is made via ultrasound, and a cesarean section is usually indicated. This patient's presentation and ultrasound findings favor another diagnosis.   
✅ Abnormal trophoblast invasion into the uterine wall  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Premature placental separation :
Incorrect: Placental abruption is the premature separation of the placenta from the uterine wall that occurs after 20 weeks gestation. Typical presentation includes acute onset of abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding, uterine contractions, and uterine tenderness. However, placental abruption occurs before delivery, not after.   
❌ Abnormal implantation of the fetal vessels:
Incorrect: Vasa previa is a condition in which the fetal blood vessels that implant into the placenta cover the internal os of the uterus. Clinical presentation includes a classic triad of rupture of membranes, painless vaginal bleeding, followed by fetal bradycardia. This patient presents with postpartum hemorrhage after manual extraction of the placenta, favoring another diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 64-year-old woman comes to the physician complaining of pain in the right knee for the past day. The patient reports associated joint swelling, warmth, and redness. She says this has happened before in her knees and hips, but those episodes lasted for only a few hours and resolved spontaneously. She also reports feeling fatigued during the past several months, but attributes this to frequently waking up at night to urinate. The patient has also had to strain more than usual when having a bowel movement and frequently takes laxatives to help. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals swelling, erythema, and warmth of the right knee joint. It is tender to palpation with decreased active and passive range of motion. Laboratory studies show the following:



Arthrocentesis of the right knee is performed. Gram stain is negative. Polarized light microscopy shows rhomboid-shaped, weakly positively birefringent crystals. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following?

choices.text: Osteophyte formation and subchondral sclerosis of joints
Tophi formation on cartilage and tendons

questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with joint pain, fatigue, polyuria, and constipation, as well as laboratory studies showing hypercalcemia and elevated parathyroid hormone. She most likely has a parathyroid adenoma. Hyperparathyroidism is a significant risk factor for the development of calcium pyrophosphate crystal deposition (CPPD), which presents as gout-like joint pain (which explains why CPPD is also called “pseudogout”) that classically affects the knee, although any joint can be affected. The polarized light microscopy findings of this patient's synovial fluid confirms the diagnosis; rhomboid-shaped, positively birefringent crystals are characteristic of CPPD. A particularly characteristic finding of chronic CPPD is chondrocalcinosis, which is deposition of calcium pyrophosphate crystals in various cartilage tissues across the body. The menisci of the knee is a common location for cartilage calcification, and the phenomenon is illustrated in the knee radiograph below (white arrows).



Option Analysis

✅ Calcification of cartilage in joints:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Increased serum uric acid:
Incorrect: Monosodium urate crystal deposition occurs in acute gout attacks due to increased serum uric acid. Although this patient is presenting with gout-like episodes, the polarized light microscopy findings suggest a different diagnosis. 
❌ Osteophyte formation and subchondral sclerosis of joints:
Incorrect: Osteophyte formation and subchondral sclerosis of joints is a common, pathologic finding of osteoarthritis. Osteoarthritis classically presents as pain in weight-bearing joints (e.g., hips, knees) that worsens throughout the day and improves upon rest. Although this patient is presenting with joint pain, the polarized light microscopy findings make osteoarthritis unlikely. 
❌ Positive rheumatoid factor antibodies:
Incorrect: Positive rheumatoid factor antibodies can be detected in patients with rheumatoid arthritis (RA). RA classically manifests as pain that is worse in the mornings and improves with joint use. Although this patient is presenting with joint pain, the polarized light microscopy findings make this diagnosis unlikely.
❌ Tophi formation on cartilage and tendons:
Incorrect: Tophi formation occurs in chronic, uncontrolled gout. Chronic deposition of monosodium urate crystals results in tophi formation. Although this patient is presenting with joint pain, the polarized light microscopy findings make this diagnosis unlikely.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department following a motor vehicle accident. At the scene, she was in severe pain and pointed to her chest. Soon after arrival, the patient loses consciousness. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 120/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 75/55 mmHg. On physical examination, there are multiple lacerations over the torso and face. Significant bruising is noted over the chest. Neck veins are distended. On chest auscultation, lung fields are clear bilaterally and heart sounds are weak. Echocardiography is obtained and shows a large pericardial effusion. Which of the following sets of hemodynamic parameters are most likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient has cardiac tamponade, most likely due to proximal aortic dissection within the pericardial sac. The very low blood pressure raises concern for shock. 

Shock is defined as a state of cellular and tissue hypoxia caused by reduced oxygen delivery and/or increased oxygen consumption or poor oxygen utilization. Initially, shock may be reversible, but it can become life-threatening if not treated promptly. Shock is divided according to the etiology: cardiogenic, hypovolemic, obstructive, and distributive.  

Cardiac tamponade is a form of obstructive shock, in which the heart is compressed due to increased volume within the pericardial sac. Although the heart is functioning normally, the external compression by the accumulated fluid impedes the volume that can be ejected from the ventricles, and as a result, cardiac output is decreased. In an attempt to compensate for the low cardiac output, systemic vascular resistance rises, which in turn increases preload. A characteristic finding seen in cardiac tamponade is the equalization of the right atrial pressure, right and left ventricular diastolic pressures, and pulmonary arterial diastolic pressures due to this extrinsic compression of the heart.    

In all types of shock, it is important to determine the underlying cause as each has a different treatment. In cardiac tamponade, the only definitive treatment is to relieve the obstruction with pericardiocentesis.  

 

Option Analysis

❌   Cardiac output (CO)  Preload   Systemic vascular resistance (SVR)  ↓  ↓  ↑ :
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with hypovolemic shock (e.g., bleeding), in which low volume results in low cardiac output and low preload. The SVR rises in an attempt to compensate for the low volume. 
✅   Cardiac output (CO)  Preload   Systemic vascular resistance (SVR)  ↓  ↑ ↑ :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌   Cardiac output (CO)  Preload   Systemic vascular resistance (SVR) ↑ ↓   ↓ :
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with distributive shock seen in sepsis or anaphylaxis. In patients with distributive shock, the SVR drops from massive vasodilation, and as a result, the preload decreases as well. In an attempt to compensate for the low blood pressure, cardiac output rises. 
❌   Cardiac output (CO)  Preload   Systemic vascular resistance (SVR)  ↓  ↓   ↓  :
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with distributive neurogenic shock seen in CNS injuries (brain and/or spinal cord). The injury disrupts the autonomic pathways, resulting in decreased vascular resistance, myocardial depression, and altered vagal tone.

questions.text:
A 36-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department after being found intoxicated on the sidewalk. She is arousable and reports she had several alcoholic drinks earlier that evening followed by multiple episodes of vomiting containing small amounts of blood. The patient reports stabbing epigastric and right upper quadrant abdominal pain for the past hour. She has no significant past medical history or previous surgeries but is currently on oral contraceptive therapy. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 101/min, respirations are 18/min and blood pressure is 149/82 mmHg.  Physical examination shows tenderness to palpation in the epigastrium without rebound or guarding. Laboratory findings are as follows:  
 
Laboratory value  Result
CBC, Serum 
Hemoglobin  14.5  g/dL 
 Hematocrit  43.5% 
 Leukocyte count  10,100 /mm3 
 Platelet count  249,000/mm3 
 MCV                        92 fL 
 RDW                    11.5-14.5% 
 Serum
               Sodium  134 mEq/L 
           Potassium  4.2 mEq/L 
              Chloride  98 mEq/L 
                 BUN                    18 mg/dL  
             Creatinine  .85 mg/dL 
              Albumin  3.7  g/dL 
               Lipase  90 U/L (N = 12-70 U/L) 
Which of the following best describes the pathophysiology of this disease process?

choices.text: Epithelial breakdown without penetration of the muscularis mucosa
Full thickness breakdown of the gastric mucosa

questions.solution:
This patient, who is presenting with acute abdominal pain following an episode of binge drinking with near normal laboratory values and epigastric pain, likely has acute gastritis. Gastritis or gastric erosions are described as gastric mucosal epithelial breakdown without full penetration into the muscularis mucosa. In contrast, gastric ulcers are noted to have full thickness breakdown of the mucosal epithelium with penetration into the muscularis mucosa.

Acute gastritis is typically caused by agents with a direct toxic effect on the gastric mucosa, which includes alcohol and NSAIDs. These agents work by decreasing bicarbonate secretion, mucous production, and epithelial hyperplasia, all of which ultimately contribute to mucosal epithelial breakdown. Typically, acute gastritis presents with acute onset of non-specific abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and occasionally metabolic derangements, whereas gastric ulcers usually present with progressive, intermittent abdominal pain, often with anemia due to chronic bleeding into the gastrointestinal tract.  

Option Analysis

❌ Ingestion of an enteral toxin  :
Incorrect: Staphylococcal food poisoning is caused by an enteral toxin with symptoms occurring approximately 6-10 hours after ingestions. Symptoms typically include nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and low-grade temperature. This diagnosis is less likely given the patient’s history of recent alcohol ingestion.   
✅ Epithelial breakdown without penetration of the muscularis mucosa:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Full thickness breakdown of the gastric mucosa :
Incorrect: Full thickness breakdown of the gastric mucosa describes the pathophysiology of gastric ulcers. A gastric ulcer is unlikely in this patient without a previous history of progressive epigastric pain and with laboratory results showing a normal blood count. The blood in the vomitus is likely reflective of gastric erosion in the setting of acute gastritis.
❌ Hypertrophy of Brunner's glands :
Incorrect: Gastrin-secreting tumors (Zollinger-Ellison syndrome) result in hypertrophy of the Brunner glands. This is less likely in a young patient with no presenting signs of malignancy. 
❌ Hyperstimulation of pancreatic acinar cells:
Incorrect: Alcohol has a direct stimulant effect on pancreatic acinar cells, which is thought to be the underlying pathophysiology of pancreatitis in patients with chronic alcohol abuse. While the patient’s lipase is mildly elevated, a formal diagnosis of pancreatitis can typically only be made when the lipase is greater than three times the upper limit of normal. Pancreatitis would not explain the blood in the vomitus.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her parents due acute onset of abdominal pain that started 2 hours ago. Over the past month, the patient has experienced progressive abdominal pain and swelling. She has never been sexually active. Temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 110/min, and blood pressure is 102/58 mmHg. On physical examination, the patient is in acute distress due to pain. Abdominal examination shows rebound tenderness and guarding. An abdominal ultrasound reveals fluid in the peritoneal cavity and a right-sided adnexal mass. The patient undergoes an emergent salpingo-oophorectomy and her condition stabilizes. Histopathological analysis reveals a lobulated mass composed of large, undifferentiated, germ cells with abundant clear cytoplasm. Which of the following markers pattern will most likely be found in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with signs of hemoperitoneum due to an adnexal mass rupture. The histological findings are consistent with the diagnosis of dysgerminoma.  

Dysgerminomas are a type of malignant ovarian germ cell tumor that is commonly seen in adolescents and young adults but can occur at any age. Dysgerminomas are characterized by rapid growth; consequently, patients may present with increased abdominal girth and pain due to torsion or rupture with hemoperitoneum. Grossly, dysgerminoma appears as a firm, pale tan, lobulated mass. Histology shows undifferentiated germ cells with clear cytoplasm resembling "fried eggs." Occasional granulomas and lymphocytes can also be seen. Dysgemrnomas may produce hCG, LDH and estradiol. Surgery is used for definitive diagnosis, staging, and primary treatment. Dysgerminomas are the ovarian counterparts of testicular seminoma in males; histologically, they have a similar appearance.  



Option Analysis

❌ Alpha fetoprotein (AFP)hCGLactate dehydrogenase (LDH)InhibinTestosterone---+-:
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with a granulosa cell tumor, a type of potentially malignant ovarian sex cord tumor. Histology shows granulosa cells arranged around collections of eosinophilic fluid, known as Call-Exner bodies, which resemble primordial follicles. These tumors often produce estrogen and/or progesterone, leading to symptoms of hyperestrogenism; older women experience abnormal uterine bleeding and breast tenderness, whereas young females may experience sexual precocity. 
✅ Alpha fetoprotein (AFP)hCGLactate dehydrogenase (LDH)InhibinTestosterone-++--:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Alpha fetoprotein (AFP)hCGLactate dehydrogenase (LDH)InhibinTestosterone+-+--:
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with a yolk sac tumor (endodermal sinus tumor), a malignant ovarian germ cell tumor typically seen in young women.
