Patients commonly present with symptoms related to the presence of a pelvic mass. Alpha fetoprotein (AFP) is the most commonly elevated tumor marker. Histologically, the tissue in these tumors resembles yolk sac tissue. The hallmark of yolk sac tumors is marked by the presence of papillary invaginations that surround a central vessel, known as Schiller-Duval bodies.
❌ Alpha fetoprotein (AFP)hCGLactate dehydrogenase (LDH)InhibinTestosterone----+:
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with a Sertoli-Leydig tumor, a type of rare sex cord-stromal tumor. It is usually seen in women in the 2nd and 3rd decades of life. On histology, it is composed of tubules lined with Sertoli cells and surrounded by stroma interspersed with Leydig cells. The tumor commonly produces androgens, resulting in virilization (e.g., hirsutism, clitoromegaly). Estrogen production and subsequent side effects have also been observed, but this phenomenon is less common.

questions.text:
An 8-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician by his parents because of petechiae on the inside of the mouth. Past medical history is notable for frequent episodes of epistaxis as well as prolonged bleeding after sustaining a laceration. Temperature is 37.2°C (98.9°F), pulse is 96/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 114/68 mmHg. Physical exam shows buccal petechiae. Cardiac, pulmonary, and abdominal exams are noncontributory. Laboratory testing is obtained, and the results are shown below.  
 
 Laboratory value  Results 
 Hematologic  
 Platelet count  230,000/mm3  
 Hemoglobin  15 g/dL 
 Coagulation studies  
 Prothrombin time (PT)  12 seconds 
 Activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT)  35 seconds 
 Bleeding time*  16 minutes 
*Reference Range: 2-7 minutes  

A sample of the patient’s blood is collected. Administration of risotectin to the sample induces platelet aggregation. Administration of desmopressin does not improve the patient's bleeding time. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient has buccal petechiae, prolonged bleeding time, and a normal ristocetin test in the setting of a history of recurrent epistaxis and prolonged bleeding. He most likely has Glanzmann thrombasthenia.   

Glanzmann thrombasthenia is a rare autosomal recessive platelet disorder caused by abnormal glycoprotein IIb/IIIa (Gp2b3a), which is a receptor for fibrinogen. This mutation impairs the binding of fibrinogen to platelets, thus impairing platelet aggregation. Laboratory testing will reveal normal platelet levels and morphology, elevated bleeding time, and normal ristocetin test (administration of ristocetin successfully induces platelet aggregation). Moreover, in contrast to von Willebrand disease, desmopressin (DDAVP) administration does not improve bleeding time in patients with Glanzmann thrombasthenia.  

Patients with Glanzmann thrombasthenia do not require any particular treatment, but preventative measures and therapies exist for specific bleeding episodes. Dental hygiene lessens gingival bleeding. Avoidance of antiplatelet agents, NSAIDs, and anticoagulants helps to avoid worsening symptoms of the condition. Iron or folate supplementation may be necessary if anemia is present. Antifibrinolytic drugs may be useful in controlling a bleeding episode.  



Option Analysis

❌ Bernard-Soulier syndrome:
Incorrect: Bernard-Soulier syndrome is caused by a deficiency of GpIb, which is the receptor for von Willebrand factor. As a result, there is impaired adhesion between platelets and vWF. The condition is associated with an abnormal ristocetin test. In other words, addition of ristocetin to the patient’s blood sample does not induce platelet aggregation.
❌ Hemophilia A:
Incorrect: Patients with hemophilia A typically present with excessive bruising and bleeding into joints. Laboratory testing would reveal an elevated activated thromboplastin time (aPTT). 
❌ von Willebrand disease:
Incorrect: Von Willebrand disease (vWD) is associated with mild bruising and mucocutaneous bleeding. Individuals with the condition have an abnormal ristocetin test. Moreover, in patients with vWD, desmopressin administration increases von Willebrand factor release from endothelial cells and improves the bleeding time.
❌ Hemophilia B:
Incorrect: Patients with hemophilia B typically present with excessive bruising and bleeding into joints. Laboratory testing would reveal an elevated activated thromboplastin time (aPTT). In contrast, this patient has a normal aPTT.
✅ Glanzmann's thrombasthenia:
Correct: See Main Explanation

questions.text:
A 38-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with chest pain for the past two days. The pain started gradually and is located in the center of her chest. It is slightly better when she sits up straight, and it is not affected by exertion or rest. The patient also reports feeling fatigued, achy, and feverish for the past few months. She takes no medications, and family history is non-contributory. The patient does not drink alcohol or smoke cigarettes. The patient’s temperature is 38.6°C (101.5°F), pulse is 104/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 153/97 mmHg. She appears anxious and uncomfortable. Physical examination shows conjunctival pallor and bilateral pitting ankle edema, and a scratching extra heart sound between the apex and sternum is heard on auscultation. Laboratory studies show the following:  
 
 Laboratory value  Result 
 Sodium   132 mEq/L 
 Potassium   4.2 mEq/L 
 Chloride   95 mEq/L 
 Hemoglobin   7.2 g/dL 
 Reticulocyte count  4.5% 
 Aspartate aminotransferase  20 U/L 
 Alanine aminotransferase  18 U/L 
 Bilirubin, Total  3.4 
 Bilirubin, Direct  0.3 
 Lactate dehydrogenase  368 U/L 
ECG shows the following:


Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons    
Which of the following additional laboratory findings is most likely to be present in this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation is most consistent with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). The classic presentation of SLE is a reproductive-age woman with arthralgias, fevers, and rash; however, because autoantibodies can attack and damage any organ system in the body, there are a wide range of symptoms and laboratory findings that can suggest a diagnosis of SLE, as seen with this patient. This patient’s chest pain is most likely due to pericarditis, as evidenced by the constant nature, improvement with sitting up, and pericardial friction rub on auscultation. The laboratory studies demonstrate a hemolytic anemia as suggested by the reticulocytosis, elevated lactate dehydrogenase, and unconjugated (indirect) hyperbilirubinemia.  

 In general, the possible clinical manifestations of SLE include: 
  •  Fever 
  •  Hematologic 
  •  Neuropsychiatric 
  •  Mucocutaneous 
  •  Serosal 
  •  Musculoskeletal 
  •  Renal 
 


This patient exhibits 1) fever, 2) hematologic involvement, 3) serosal involvement (pericarditis), and likely 4) renal involvement, given her edema, which would be evidenced by proteinuria and a low serum protein level. Together, these findings make SLE the most likely diagnosis.  

Option Analysis

❌ Elevated fasting blood glucose:
Incorrect: Although diabetes can cause renal damage over time, it would not explain this patient’s pericarditis or hemolytic anemia. Elevated blood sugar level  is not associated with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).  
❌ Neutropenia:
Incorrect: Although SLE may cause leukopenia and lymphopenia, a low neutrophil count (neutropenia) in isolation is not specifically associated with SLE. 
✅ Proteinuria:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Thrombocytosis:
Incorrect: Hematologic effects of SLE include leukopenia, thrombocytopenia, and autoimmune hemolysis. SLE is not associated with increased hematologic cell counts, including platelets.
❌ Uremia:
Incorrect: Although increased serum urea nitrogen might result from a decreased glomerular filtration rate in the setting of lupus nephritis, elevated urea nitrogen itself is not associated with SLE.
❌ Elevated cardiac troponin T:
Incorrect: Any patient with concerning chest pain should have an ECG done and cardiac troponin drawn to rule out an acute coronary syndrome. However, this patient’s ECG shows diffuse PR depressions and ST elevations without reciprocal changes that are most consistent with pericarditis, which does not elevate troponin levels.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman comes to the office due to a neck lump she noticed while showering. The patient generally feels fine, and medical history is unremarkable. She has not had weight loss, dysphagia, or palpitations. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 125/80 mmHg. On physical examination, a nontender nodule occupying the right thyroid lobe is noted. The rest of the physical examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory results show normal TSH levels. Ultrasound of the neck reveals a 2 cm homogenous, anechoic nodule with an absence of internal flow. Fine need aspiration reveals cells with nuclear atypia. The lesion is surgically excised and sent to histology, which shows a spherical lesion with an intact capsule. The cells are arranged in uniform follicles with colloid. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This previously healthy and asymptomatic patient presents with a thyroid nodule, which can be due to benign or malignant causes. The TSH levels are normal which excludes a hyperfunctioning nodule. The absence of internal flow on ultrasound implies that the lesion is not malignant, as malignant lesions are usually vascular. Lastly, the FNA results show cells arranged in uniform follicles that contain colloid, favoring the diagnosis of thyroid adenoma.  

Thyroid adenoma is a benign growth derived from follicular epithelium. Follicular thyroid adenoma is the most common type and consists of differentiated follicular cells. A typical thyroid adenoma presents as a solitary, well-circumscribed lesion that is separated from the adjacent tissue by a well-defined, intact capsule. Rarely, adenomas can cause hyperthyroidism via autonomous production of TSH. Follicular thyroid adenoma can be distinguished from follicular carcinoma via the presence of an intact capsule. However, this differentiation can only be made by surgery and not FNA. The management of a thyroid nodule is as follows:  




Option Analysis

❌ Papillary carcinoma:
Incorrect: Papillary thyroid carcinoma is the most common cancer of the thyroid. On histology, it is characterized by cells with nuclear clearing (“Orphan Annie eyes”), nuclear grooves, and psammoma bodies.
❌ Anaplastic carcinoma:
Incorrect: Anaplastic carcinoma is characterized by undifferentiated malignant cells invading local structures. This highly malignant and aggressive tumor, often seen in elderly patients, invades local structures and presents with compressive symptoms such as dysphagia, hoarseness, and respiratory compromise.
❌ Toxic adenoma:
Incorrect: Toxic adenoma is focal or diffuse hyperplasia of thyroid follicular cells that occurs due to an activating mutation of the TSH receptor. This mutation allows the thyroid to produce hormones independent of TSH stimulation. It typically presents with hyperthyroidism and low TSH levels. This patient had no signs of hyperthyroidism and had normal TSH levels.
✅ Thyroid adenoma:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Subacute granulomatous thyroiditis:
Incorrect: Subacute granulomatous thyroiditis, also known as de Quervain thyroiditis, is a self-limited condition that often follows an upper respiratory infection. Patients typically present with a diffusely or asymmetrically enlarged and painful thyroid. Patients may have hyperthyroidism early in the course followed by hypothyroidism. On histology, granulomatous inflammation is expected. Laboratory tests show elevated ESR. In contrast, this patient’s nodule is nontender, and she has normal TSH levels.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old man comes to the office because of progressive weakness and a dragging sensation in the abdomen for the past 3 months. The patient is a retired farmer. Past medical history is noncontributory. He does not smoke or use illicit drugs. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 96/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 125/80 mmHg. Physical examination shows mucosal pallor, petechiae on the lower extremities, and splenomegaly crossing the midline. Laboratory results are as follows:  
 
 Laboratory value  Result 
 Complete blood count 
 Hemoglobin   9.3 g/dL 
 Platelets   70,000/mm3 
 Leukocytes   6,000/mm3 
Peripheral blood smear is shown:


Reproduced from:Wikimedia Commons 

Which of the following genes is most likely to be mutated in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient with progressive weakness and massive splenomegaly, along with laboratory findings of pancytopenia and hairy cells on peripheral smear, most likely has hairy cell leukemia (HCL).  

HCL is a chronic progressive B cell lymphoproliferative disorder that results in infiltration of bone marrow and reticuloendothelial system. It constitutes about 2% of all leukemias and appears to be more common in males. Median age of incidence is 55 years. In most cases, it results from an activating point mutation in BRAF (serine/threonine), leading to self-sustained activation of RAF-MEK-ERK signaling pathway, which causes the accelerated proliferation of lymphocytes in the bone marrow. It eventually causes bone marrow fibrosis, resulting in a dry tap on aspiration and leading to pancytopenia (fever, fatigue, weakness and recurrent infections). The neoplastic cells also infiltrate the red pulp of the spleen, leading to splenomegaly, which can present as a dragging sensation in the abdomen (as in this patient), as well as early satiety due to compression of the stomach.  

Peripheral blood smear shows lymphocytes with cytoplasmic projections (irregular cytoplasm outline). Additionally, the stain for tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase (TRAP) is characteristically positive in HCL. Diagnosis is established by flow cytometry specific for B-cell markers (CD20, CD22, CD25). Treatment options include various chemotherapeutic agents, and the overall prognosis is excellent. Tumors with an underlying BRAF mutation that fail conventional therapy have strong responses to BRAF inhibitors.  

Option Analysis

❌ RB1:
Incorrect: RB1 is a tumor suppressor gene that encodes for retinoblastoma protein. Inactivating mutations in RB1 is associated with the development of retinoblastoma and osteosarcoma, not hairy cell leukemia.  
✅ BRAF:
Correct: See Main Explanation  
❌ RET:
Incorrect: Multiple neuroendocrine neoplasia 2 (MEN2) results from germ-line mutations in RET proto-oncogene. MEN2 mutations are associated with pheochromocytoma, medullary thyroid cancer, parathyroid hyperplasia and mucosal neuromas. Pancytopenia and peripheral cells with hairy cytoplasmic projections suggests a leukemic disorder.
❌ HER2:
Incorrect: HER2 overexpression is involved in the pathogenesis of invasive breast cancers and is unlikely to be mutated in this patient presenting with classic signs and symptoms of hairy cell leukemia.
❌ VHL:
Incorrect: Loss of function mutations in VHL are seen in renal cell carcinoma (presenting with abdominal mass and hematuria) or von Hippel-Landau syndrome (associated with hemangioblastomas, pheochromocytomas, and bilateral renal cell carcinomas). This patient’s presentation is suggestive of a leukemic disorder.

questions.text:
A 38-year-old woman comes to the clinic complaining of pain in her hands for several months. The pain is characterized by an intermittent aching in both of the wrists and the bases of the fingers that lasts for hours at a time. The patient also feels warm at night and has not had much of an appetite recently. The patient’s temperature is 37.6 C (99.6 F), pulse is 77/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 145/85 mmHg. Physical examination shows mild symmetric swelling of the wrists, metacarpophalangeal, and proximal interphalangeal joints bilaterally, without tenderness on palpation. There are no skin lesions. Laboratory studies show the following:  
 
Laboratory value  Result
 Hemoglobin  14.0 g/dL 
 Platelets  100,000/mm3 
 Leukocytes   3,500/mm3 
Further evaluation with urinalysis shows proteinuria and red blood cell casts.    

Which of the following is the most common cause of death in patients with this condition?
questions.solution:
This patient has fevers, arthralgias, leukopenia and thrombocytopenia, with evidence of glomerulonephritis on urinalysis. Together, these findings suggest the diagnosis of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE): a systemic, relapsing and remitting autoimmune disease.  

Patients with SLE have overall mortality rates 2-5x higher than the general population. A general high yield fact to remember is that end-stage renal disease, necessitating hemodialysis, is the number one cause of overall morbidity and mortality among individuals with SLE. This is followed by the next two major contributors to mortality: cardiovascular disease and infection.

The cytotoxic agents given to treat lupus as well as the often heavy doses of glucocorticoids used can cause complications like glucocorticoid-induced avascular necrosis of the hips and knees, osteoporosis, and cognitive dysfunction. SLE itself tends to attack the kidneys and slowly, or sometimes in flares, causes decreases in kidney function, eventually leading to kidney failure and the need for dialysis. Once patients are on dialysis (ESRD), they acquire the same mortality risks from dialysis as patients with ESRD from other causes, including life-threatening infection from vascular site access, dangerous electrolyte derangements, and accelerated calcific atherosclerotic disease leading to strokes and heart attacks.  

Option Analysis

❌ Renal cell carcinoma:
Incorrect: Meta-analyses have not shown an association between SLE and higher mortality from malignancies, with the exception of non-Hodgkin lymphoma, which is significantly increased among patients with SLE.  
❌ Coronary artery disease:
Incorrect: Ischemic cardiovascular disease is increased in patients with SLE over time. Overall, however, complications from kidney failure cause more deaths.  
❌ Pulmonary fibrosis:
Incorrect: Although SLE may cause pleuritis and pleural effusions, it does not cause pulmonary fibrosis. Respiratory effects from SLE do not contribute to increased mortality.
❌ Community acquired pneumonia:
Incorrect: In early SLE (within the first decade), the leading causes of death are central nervous system disease, acute renal failure, and infection due to immunosuppression. Overall, however, complications from kidney failure are responsible for the majority of deaths.  
✅ End-stage renal disease:
Correct: See Main Explanation

questions.text:
A 54-year-old woman comes to the clinic for an annual wellness examination. Since the last visit, she reports that she has been bothered by bilateral achy knee pains with walking which have left her sedentary and reliant on canned and premade foods for nutrition. She reports a 9.1 kg (20 lbs) weight gain over the past year, and she feels thirsty all the time. Medical history is significant for osteoarthritis, obesity, and essential hypertension. Medications include amlodipine and naproxen sodium. The patient’s father recently suffered a heart attack. The patient’s temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 85/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 140/85 mmHg. BMI is 40 kg/m2. Physical examination shows dry mucous membranes and decreased skin turgor. Fasting laboratory studies reveal the following:  
 
Laboratory value  Result 
 Sodium   134 mEq/L 
 Potassium   4.2 mEq/L 
 Chloride   95 mEq/L 
 Bicarbonate   24 mEq/L 
 Blood urea nitrogen  24 mg/dL 
 Creatinine  0.8 mg/dL 
 Glucose  128 mg/dL 
Which of the following conditions does this patient most likely have?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with progressive weight gain, polyuria, and signs of volume depletion (dry mucous membranes). Given the patient’s age (> 40 years old) and sedentary lifestyle, there is an inreased risk for type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM). Diabetes is diagnosed by quantifying the amount of glucose present in the blood at various points in time. In the clinic, a common screening test for diabetes is the fasting glucose level; this blood work is done after the patient has had no calories to eat or drink for at least eight hours. A level of 126 mg/dL or higher, in the presence of symptoms (including polyuria), is diagnostic of diabetes.  

A non-fasting (random) glucose test can be done at any time, with 200 mg/dL or higher being diagnostic of diabetes if the individual has symptoms. Another test is called an oral glucose tolerance test, where a person is given a glucose tab (usually 75 mg), and then blood samples are taken at timed intervals to determine how well the glucose is being cleared from the blood. A glucose level over 200 mg/dL after 2 hours indicates diabetes.  

When blood glucose levels get high, the glucose molecules can also attach to proteins that are present in the blood or in cells. Hemoglobin A1c (HgA1c) values indicate the proportion of hemoglobin in red blood cells that has glucose attached to it; HbA1c levels of 6.5% or higher indicate diabetes, while levels from 5.7% to 6.4% indicate pre-diabetes. The proportion of glycated hemoglobin varies minimally day to day, so a high yield fact is that this test gives a sense for whether the blood glucose levels have been high over the past 3 months, which is the lifespan of a typical red blood cell.  

Option Analysis

❌ Impaired fasting glucose:
Incorrect: Impaired fasting glucose is defined as a plasma glucose value of 100 to 125 mg/dL while fasting. Fasting is defined as having no food or caloric intake for the past 8 hours.  
❌ Impaired glucose tolerance:
Incorrect: Impaired glucose tolerance is defined as a two-hour plasma glucose value of 140 to 199 mg/dL during a 75 g oral glucose tolerance test.   
❌ Diabetes insipidus:
Incorrect: Diabetes insipidus is caused by insufficient antidiuretic hormone (ADH) secretion from the hypothalamus, leading to polyuria, nocturia, and elevated serum sodium levels.    
❌ Prediabetes:
Incorrect: Prediabetes is a generalized term that refers to an abnormally elevated glucose level that is below the threshold for diabetes but raises future risk of diabetes. By definition, a patient with prediabetes has either a diagnosis of impaired fasting glucose or impaired glucose tolerance.  
✅ Diabetes mellitus:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman comes to the clinic due to palpitations and diarrhea. Medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus, insomnia and anxiety, for which she takes metformin diazepam. During the past year, she had a few episodes of chest pain and pressure, and two weeks ago, she underwent coronary angiography and stenting. Current temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 110/min and irregular, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. On physical examination, the patient appears nervous and diaphoretic. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with signs of hyperthyroidism (e.g., palpitations, sweating, diarrhea) two weeks after iodine contrast solution administration via coronary angiography. Given the patient’s history of insomnia and anxiety, in the context of these recent symptoms and physical exam findings, the most likely diagnosis is iodine-induced hyperthyroidism.  

Iodine-induced hyperthyroidism, or Jod-Basedow phenomenon, describes thyrotoxicosis that occurs following exposure to increased amounts of iodine (e.g. iodine contrast material). Thyrotoxicosis occurs in patients with autonomous areas within the thyroid gland, such as those with subclinical hyperthyroidism (undiagnosed Graves disease, toxic adenoma, or toxic multinodular goiter). When the body’s iodine supply suddenly increases, these autonomous areas produce large amounts of thyroid hormone independent of normal regulatory mechanisms. In this case presentation, it is likely that this patient with anxiety and insomnia in fact had subclinical hyperthyroidism, thus predisposing her to the thyrotoxicosis.  

Iodine-induced hyperthyroidism should be suspected in patients with an exposure history to iodine (e.g., coronary angiography, radiographic contrast) and signs and symptoms of hyperthyroidism. The diagnosis is confirmed with thyroid function tests showing low serum TSH, high free T4 and/or T3. Patients may present weeks or even months after iodine administration. Iodine-induced hyperthyroidism is usually a self-limited condition, lasting 1 to 18 months. Management includes discontinuation of iodine, avoidance of further exposure, and beta-blockers for symptomatic control.  

Of note, in healthy individuals with no autonomous regions within the thyroid gland, sudden exposure to excess serum iodide instead inhibits iodine organification and new thyroid hormone synthesis. This phenomenon is termed the Wolff-Chaikoff effect.   

Option Analysis

❌ Contrast material allergic-like reaction:
Incorrect: Signs and symptoms of allergic-like reactions to contrast material may include urticaria, pruritus, erythema, sneezing, conjunctivitis, rhinorrhea, facial edema, hoarseness or stridor, repetitive cough, wheezing, chest tightness, and anaphylactic shock. This patient has none of these symptoms.
❌ Acute hemolytic transfusion reaction:
Incorrect: Acute hemolytic transfusion reaction is a type II hypersensitivity reaction due to ABO blood group incompatibility. The presentation includes fever, hypotension, tachypnea, tachycardia, flank pain, hemoglobinuria, and jaundice after a blood transfusion. This patient did not receive any blood products.
✅ Iodine-induced hyperthyroidism:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Serum sickness:
Incorrect: Serum sickness is a type of immune complex disease (Type III hypersensitivity) in which antibodies to foreign proteins are produced around 1-2 weeks after exposure. Antibody-antigen complexes form and deposit in tissues, lead complement activation, inflammation, and tissue damage. The presentation includes fever, urticaria, arthralgia, proteinuria, and lymphadenopathy. It can be seen after administration of protein antigens from a nonhuman species (e.g. rabies vaccine), therapeutic fibrinolytic proteins (e.g. streptokinase), and immune and cell metabolism modulators (e.g. rituximab). This patient’s presentation and history favors another diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 13-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department complaining of blurry vision. The patient says that over the past few months she has noticed gradual vision changes in both eyes, which have gotten worse over the past few weeks. The patient recently started the new school year and is finding it difficult to read the homework assignments, and she says she accidentally ran into a tree without seeing it yesterday. The patient has a history of corrected congenital hip dysplasia. The patient’s mother has autoimmune thyroiditis. The patient’s temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 88/min, respirations are 25/min, and blood pressure is 105/64 mmHg. Physical examination shows a well-appearing adolescent in no acute distress with severe bilateral cataracts and a normal thyroid gland. Laboratory studies show the following:  
 
Laboratory value  Result
 Sodium  132 mEq/L 
 Potassium  4.2 mEq/L 
 Bicarbonate  16 mEq/L 
 Glucose  532 mg/dL 
Which of the following is the most likely mechanism of this patient’s vision loss?
questions.solution:
This patient is presentnig with the gradual onset of cataracts at a young age. A cataract is an opacity of the lens of the eye that may cause vision loss, normally associated with advanced age. This patient’s laboratory results reveal a markedly elevated glucose with acidosis (decreased serum bicarbonate), suggestive of ketogenesis. This, together with a family history of autoimmune disease, suggest a diagnosis of type 1 diabetes mellitus. Upon further questioning, this patient would likely endorse frequent urination and thirst due to glycosuria.  Along with chronic complications (atherosclerosis, neuropathy, nephropathy), diabetes can also cause cataracts from osmotic cellular damage.   

In the eye, glucose enters the cell and is immediately converted to sorbitol by aldose reductase. However, these cells (as well as the pericytes in the retina, Schwann cells, and renal epithelial cells) have reduced levels of the enzyme that converts sorbitol to fructose: sorbitol dehydrogenase. Relative to glucose and fructose, sorbitol is a more polar molecule that is unable to diffuse out of the cell. As it builds up, it osmotically pulls in water and increases intracellular osmotic pressure. This swelling leads to collapse and liquefaction of lens cells, resulting in cataracts.  



Option Analysis

❌ Fructose accumulation:
Incorrect: Fructose is formed in the cells of the lens as the product of sorbitol and sorbitol dehydrogenase. In patients with hyperglycemia, sorbitol is formed faster than it can be converted to fructose. Sorbitol, unlike fructose, is unable to diffuse out of the cells, thereby causing osmotic pressure damage.  
❌ Galactose accumulation:
Incorrect: Galactosemia is a rare autosomal recessive disorder wherein levels of galactokinase or galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase are absent, leading to the accumulation toxic levels of galactose or galactose-1-phosphate, respectively, when lactose is ingested. These molecules can cause cataracts, although most cases of galactosemia are detected in infancy through newborn screening.
❌ Glucose accumulation:
Incorrect: Glucose is quickly converted to sorbitol by aldose reductase upon its entry into cells of the lens. Therefore, it is sorbitol that drives the damage seen in diabetic cataracts. Non-enzymatic glycosylation (glucose binding directly to cells and causing damage) occurs in arteries and is instead responsible for macrovascular disease (coronary disease, strokes) in patients with diabetes.
❌ Maltose accumulation:
Incorrect: Maltose is an exogenous carbohydrate formed in malt through the process of allowing grain to soften in water and germinate. In humans, maltose is broken down to produce two glucose molecules. Complete maltose intolerance in humans is extraordinarily rare.  
✅ Sorbitol accumulation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 27-year-old male is brought to the emergency room after sustaining multiple gunshot wounds. He is currently agitated and moaning in pain. The patient's primary survey is notable for decreased breath sounds over the right chest with hyperresonance to percussion. Secondary survey reveals three gunshot wounds to the right chest and one graze wound to the left flank. Temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 130/min, and blood pressure is 70/40 mmHg. Respirations are 26/min, and the patient has an oxygen saturation of 86% on room air. Which of the following best describes the pathophysiology of this patient’s clinical condition?

choices.text: Rapid accumulation of air within the pleural cavity and compression of mediastinal structures
Rapid accumulation of fluid within the pericardium
Penetrating injury to the aortic arch
Hemorrhage into the pleural cavity from injured lung parenchyma
Bruising of the lung parenchyma followed by alveolar edema and hemorrhage

questions.solution:
This patient has decreased breath sounds, hyperresonance to percussion, and signs of hemodynamic instability in the setting of penetrating chest trauma. He most likely has a tension pneumothorax.  

A tension pneumothorax refers to progressive air accumulation within the pleural cavity, which can then compress or displace mediastinal structures. In this patient, the tissue flaps surrounding the bullet wounds act as one-way valves, allowing air to enter the pleural cavity but preventing air from exiting. Over time, the accumulated air increases in pressure and can shift the mediastinum to the opposite hemithorax, resulting in obstructive shock.  

Tension pneumothorax, as with other pneumothoraces, can present with dyspnea, pleuritic chest pain, reduced breath sounds over the affected lung, and hyperresonance to percussion. In severe cases, patients can develop tracheal deviation. Patients can also have hypotension and elevated jugular venous pulsations secondary to compression of the heart and vena cava.  

Emergent treatment involves the placement of a large bore angiocatheter (usually a 14G or 16G) at the second intercostal space, midclavicular line, followed by tube thoracostomy. With correct technique, a rapid gush of air is often audible.



Option Analysis

✅ Rapid accumulation of air within the pleural cavity and compression of mediastinal structures:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Rapid accumulation of fluid within the pericardium:
Incorrect: Pericardial tamponade can occur with penetrating trauma to the chest and can present with hypotension, jugular venous distension, and muffled heart sounds. It would not cause absent breath sounds or hyperresonance on percussion.
❌ Penetrating injury to the aortic arch:
Incorrect: Penetrating injuries to the aortic arch are generally lethal. Most individuals die in the field before reaching a hospital. Individuals that do make it to a hospital are usually pulseless and have profound hemodynamic compromise. However, this patient’s physical exam findings of reduced breath sounds in the right chest and hyperresonance on percussion make tension pneumothorax a more likely explanation for the presentation.
❌ Hemorrhage into the pleural cavity from injured lung parenchyma:
Incorrect: Hemothorax can occur in the setting of penetrating trauma and cause hemodynamic instability. The condition would result in dullness to percussion over the affected area. In contrast, this patient has hyperresonance to percussion over the right chest.
❌ Bruising of the lung parenchyma followed by alveolar edema and hemorrhage:
Incorrect: Pulmonary contusions are a common complication of blunt trauma to the chest. They present with many of the same clinical features as a pneumothorax, such as dyspnea, reduced breath sounds, and hemodynamic instability. However, pulmonary contusions would not typically cause hyperresonance to percussion on physical examination.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of progressive shortness of breath and chest pain for the past three weeks. Medical history includes type II diabetes mellitus, hyperlipidemia, and a myocardial infarction six years ago. Temperature is 37.1°C (98.9°F), pulse is 80/min, blood pressure is 135/87 mmHg, and respirations are 20/min. Physical examination reveals 2+ pitting edema in the bilateral lower extremities. Respiratory examination is notable for dullness to percussion and decreased breath sounds at the bilateral lung bases. Cardiac auscultation reveals a heart sound occurring immediately after the S2 sound. A chest x-ray is obtained and shows blunting of the costophrenic angles bilaterally. The patient’s serum protein level is 7 g/dL, and serum lactate dehydrogenase is 280 U/L. If a thoracentesis were performed, which of the following laboratory findings would most likely be present in this patient’s pleural fluid?
questions.solution:
This patient likely has bilateral transudative pleural effusions secondary to congestive heart failure (CHF) exacerbation. The pleural effusions are responsible for the patient’s respiratory distress, pleuritic chest pain, and physical exam findings (e.g., decreased breath sounds, dullness to percussion). The pitting edema, S3 heart sound, and history of myocardial infarction point to CHF as the likely underlying cause.  

Transudative pleural effusions result from imbalances in hydrostatic and oncotic pressure. Potential causes include CHF, hypothyroidism, liver failure, and renal failure. In CHF, failure of the left heart to effectively pump blood into the systemic circulation causes blood to accumulate in the pulmonary circulation. This increases capillary hydrostatic pressure and causes fluid to shift into the pleural space. The pH of a transudative pleural fluid is between 7.40 to 7.55.  

Exudative pleural effusions are caused by inflammation, which leads to leaky capillaries. Potential causes include infection, malignancy, immunologic response, and trauma. Most exudative effusions have a pH between 7.30 to 7.45 because of increased acid production from bacteria or decreased ion efflux due to pleuritis.    

Thoracocentesis can be used to obtain a sample of the effusion and allow for therapeutic drainage of the pleural space. Light's criteria can then be used to distinguish between transudative and exudative pleural effusions. Meeting any of Light’s criteria indicates the presence of an exudative effusion.  


Option Analysis

✅ pH of 7.50:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Elevated amylase levels:
Incorrect: High amylase levels in the pleural fluid can be seen in pancreatitis or esophageal rupture. This patient's presentation is more consistent with congestive heart failure, which would cause a transudative pleural effusion.
❌ High triglyceride levels  :
Incorrect: High triglyceride levels can be seen chylothorax, such as in the case of a thoracic duct rupture. This patient's presentation of pitting edema, S3 heart sound, and history of myocardial infarction is more consistent with congestive heart failure (CHF). CHF would give rise to a transudative pleural effusion with normal triglyceride levels.
❌ Protein level of 5 g/L:
Incorrect: A protein level of 5 g/L would yield a pleural fluid protein/serum protein ratio of 5/7 = 0.71. This value is greater than 0.5, which would be diagnostic for an exudative effusion. However, this patient has physical exam findings of congestive heart failure, which typically gives rise to a transudative effusion.
❌ Lactate dehydrogenase level of 250 U/L  :
Incorrect: A lactate dehydrogenase level of 250 U/L would give a pleural fluid LDH/serum LDH ratio of 250/280 = 0.89, which is greater than 0.6. This finding may be present in an exudative pleural effusion. However, this patient most likely has congestive heart failure, which would give rise to a transudative pleural effusion.  
❌ Glucose level < 60 mg/dL:
Incorrect: A pleural fluid glucose of less than 60 mg/dL can be seen in conditions such as complicated parapneumonic effusion, rheumatoid arthritis, tuberculosis, and malignancy. This patient's presentation is more consistent with congestive heart failure leading to a transudative pleural effusion.

questions.text:
A 47-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of altered mental status. The patient is disoriented and unable to provide her history. Review of the electronic medical record reveals a history notable for alcohol use disorder and hepatitis C infection. She lost her insurance several years ago, and since then, she has not seen a physician. Her temperature is 37.4°C (99.3°F), blood pressure of 155/90 mmHg, and pulse of 71/min. Physical examination shows scleral icterus and diffuse jaundice of the skin. Abdominal exam reveals the following:  

 
Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons  

Which of the following laboratory findings will most likely be present in this patient?
questions.solution:
The patient in this vignette has jaundice, scleral icterus, and ascites (as seen from the distended abdomen). Given her history of chronic alcohol use and hepatitis C, the most likely cause of her condition is liver cirrhosis.  

Liver cirrhosis, along with hepatitis, causes mixed hyperbilirubinemia, because these conditions impair both bilirubin conjugation and canalicular excretion of bile. In advanced cirrhosis, glucuronyl conjugation of unconjugated bilirubin and biliary excretion of conjugated bilirubin are markedly impaired, and jaundice appears. This decrease in bilirubin conjugation and increase in systemic circulation of conjugated bilirubin due to impaired excretion results in a mixed hyperbilirubinemia. The concentration of bilirubin in serum, therefore, is a good prognostic marker for patients with decompensated liver cirrhosis.  



Option Analysis

❌  Unconjugated bilirubin Conjugated bilirubin Urine hemoglobin ↑  Normal  ↑ :
Incorrect: Conditions that increase hemolysis, such as glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency or hereditary spherocytosis, can cause unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. In addition, hemolysis causes increased quantities of hemoglobin to be released, much of which is excreted via urine. However, this patient most likely has liver cirrhosis, which causes elevations in both unconjugated and conjugated bilirubin levels.
✅  Unconjugated bilirubin Conjugated bilirubin Urine hemoglobin ↑  ↑Normal:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌  Unconjugated bilirubin Conjugated bilirubin Urine hemoglobin Normal ↑  ↑ :
Incorrect: Conjugated hyperbilirubinemia can be caused by impaired bilirubin excretion or biliary tract obstruction. Potential causes range from Crigler-Najjar syndrome to primary sclerosing cholangitis. However, this patient’s history of chronic alcohol use and hepatitis C infection makes liver cirrhosis the most likely underlying etiology, and liver cirrhosis causes mixed hyperbilirubinemia.
❌  Unconjugated bilirubin Conjugated bilirubin Urine hemoglobin ↑ ↑  ↑ :
Incorrect: Patients with mixed hyperbilirubinemia have elevated conjugated and unconjugated bilirubin levels. Potential causes are hepatitis and liver cirrhosis. However, neither condition causes increased erythrocyte hemolysis. Hence, urine hemoglobin would be normal in these individuals. 
❌  Unconjugated bilirubin Conjugated bilirubin Urine hemoglobin Normal  Normal Normal:
Incorrect: These findings would be seen in a healthy individual. However, this patient has jaundice and scleral icterus, which are concerning for elevated bilirubin levels.

questions.text:
A 26-year-old man is evaluated in the emergency department for epigastric pain that began an hour ago. He reports that the pain radiates to the back and is 9 out of 10 in severity. The patient consumes a diet rich in fresh fruits and vegetables. He drinks 2-3 glasses of wine per week on social occasions. Family history is notable for recurrent episodes of pancreatitis in his father and paternal uncle. His temperature is 37.7°C (99.9°F), blood pressure is 125/83 mmHg, and pulse is 96/min. Physical examination is notable for tenderness on light palpation of the epigastric region. Abdominal exam also reveals hepatosplenomegaly and the following finding:  


Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons  

Xanthomas are found on the patient’s bilateral elbows. Which of the following set of laboratory findings would be most likely expected in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient has type IV familial hyperlipidemia (also termed familial hypertriglyceridemia), an autosomal dominant condition caused by hepatic overproduction of VLDLs. In addition, lipoprotein lipase activity is decreased, which prevents the breakdown of VLDLs and chylomicrons. Since VLDLs and chylomicrons both contain mainly triglyceride, serum triglyceride levels are markedly elevated.  

This condition is characterized by premature atherosclerosis and an increased risk of developing acute pancreatitis, such as in this patient, who is presenting with the classic pain distribution (e.g., epigastric pain radiating to the back) and the skin findings consistent with Cullen’s sign (periumbilical ecchymosis). The high concentration of serum triglycerides can activate pancreatic cells, causing them to release lipase which breaks the triglycerides down into free fatty acids; excess free fatty acids can subsequently injure the pancreas.  

Option Analysis

❌  Serum Triglyceride Serum Cholesterol Serum Lipase ↑  Unchanged  ↑ :
Incorrect: Patients with type I familial hyperlipidemia present with elevated triglyceride levels and normal cholesterol levels. These patients are at increased risk of pancreatitis, which causes elevated serum lipase levels. However, type I familial hyperlipidemia is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern. In contrast, this patient’s father has similar symptoms, suggesting that an autosomal dominant condition is the underlying cause.
❌   Serum Triglyceride  Serum Cholesterol  Serum Lipase Unchanged  ↑ Unchanged:
Incorrect: This patient has epigastric pain radiating to the back and skin findings consistent with Cullen’s sign (periumbilical ecchymosis). All of these findings are suggestive of pancreatitis, which presents with an elevated serum lipase.
❌  Serum Triglyceride Serum Cholesterol Serum Lipase ↑   ↑ Unchanged:
Incorrect: The patient in this vignette has epigastric pain radiating to the back and periumbilical bruising, termed Cullen’s sign. These findings are highly suggestive of pancreatitis, and an elevated lipase is expected.
✅   Serum Triglyceride  Serum Cholesterol  Serum Lipase  ↑   ↑  ↑ :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌  Serum Triglyceride Serum Cholesterol Serum Lipase Unchanged  Unchanged  ↑ :
Incorrect: Individuals with normal cholesterol and triglyceride levels can also develop pancreatitis, which presents with an elevated serum lipase level. Potential causes include obstructive gallstones, abdominal trauma, or alcohol abuse. However this patient’s xanthomas and family history of pancreatitis raise concerns for familial dyslipidemia, which causes elevated triglycerides and/or cholesterol.

questions.text:
A 26-year-old female presents to the emergency department for evaluation of sudden onset palpitations. She is otherwise healthy and does not take any medications. The patient has had similar episodes in the past, and they self-resolved without treatment. However, the symptoms today have persisted for longer than usual. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 172/min, respirations are 21/min, and blood pressure is 110/71 mmHg. Initial electrocardiogram is demonstrated below:  

 
 
Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons  

Which of the following features of this patient's electrocardiogram can be used to localize the anatomic origin of this arrhythmia?
questions.solution:
This young, otherwise healthy patient presents with sudden-onset palpitations and an electrocardiogram that demonstrates a regular, narrow complex tachycardia with absent P-waves. These findings are most consistent with a diagnosis of paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia. In general, the distinguishing feature of supraventricular tachycardias is the presence of narrow QRS complexes.  

Supraventricular tachycardias refer to a subset of fast arrhythmias that originate above the ventricles, or above the bundle of His. Supraventricular arrhythmias are classified into several main types: those of sinus origin, reentrant tachycardias, ectopic rhythms, and pre-excitation syndromes (e.g. Wolff-Parkinson White).  

With the exception of Wolff-Parkinson White, supraventricular arrhythmias are characterized by narrow QRS complexes (<100 ms). This electrocardiographic finding is reflective of rapid depolarization of the ventricles. In contrast, ventricular arrhythmias will have wide QRS complexes due to slower depolarization. Differentiation between supraventricular and ventricular arrhythmias remains an important diagnostic consideration, as the treatment and risk of degeneration into ventricular fibrillation or cardiac arrest rises substantially with arrhythmias of ventricular origin.  



Option Analysis

✅ QRS complex duration:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ QT interval :
Incorrect: The QT interval can provide information regarding the presence of concomitant metabolic disturbances, medication side effects, and inherited QT channelopathy. It can also predict a patient’s risk of developing torsades de pointes. However, the QT interval does not provide meaningful information regarding an arrhythmia’s anatomic site of origin.
❌ PR interval   :
Incorrect: The PR interval provides information regarding interventricular conduction, metabolic disturbance, or presence of an accessory bypass tract. 
❌ P wave morphology :
Incorrect: The presence of P-waves can help differentiate between supraventricular and ventricular arrhythmias, with the latter more likely to not present with P-waves. However, evaluating for the presence of P-waves is not as useful as measuring QRS complex width when determining an arrhythmia’s site of origin.
❌ Axis :
Incorrect: The axis of a patient’s electrocardiogram can be used to differentiate between left and right heart strain or hypertrophy. It does not provide meaningful information about an arrhythmia’s site of origin.

questions.text:
A 34-year-old woman at 32 weeks gestation presents to the clinic with malaise, fatigue, and fevers. She reports she arrived from Egypt last week to visit family here. She reports she is otherwise healthy, does not smoke, use illicit drugs, or consume alcohol. The pregnancy has otherwise been uncomplicated. She has never received blood products in the past. Temperature is 37.8 °C (100°F), pulse is 83/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 137/72 mmHg. Physical examination is notable for scleral icterus. The liver is palpated 3 cm below the right costal margin. Laboratory findings are demonstrated below:


This patient is at risk of developing which of the following pathologic conditions?
questions.solution:
This pregnant patient in the third trimester who recently immigrated from a different country presents with fatigue, jaundice, hepatomegaly, and laboratory markers consistent with active infection with hepatitis E. Of the choices listed, hepatitis E carries the highest risk of developing fulminant hepatitis, especially in pregnant women.  

Hepatitis E is a member of the herpes virus family and is an overall rare form of hepatitis in developed countries. However, in certain parts of the world—India, Africa, Southeast Asia—the disease carries a significant burden of disease, causing nearly 20 million infections on a yearly basis. It is spread via fecal-oral transmission, usually through contaminated seafood or water, and carries a short incubation period. Prior to symptom onset, patients will typically have increased levels of HEV RNA but negative titers for anti-HEV (IgM). Once a patient develops symptoms, typically two weeks after exposure, they will develop anti-HEV (IgM) antibodies. Most patients experience full recovery and will develop anti-HEV (IgG antibodies). It is important to note that hepatitis E does not confer a carrier state.    

At risk patients include pregnant patients, especially those in the third trimester, as well as patients with underlying liver disease. In these individuals, infection with hepatitis E carries a high risk of developing fulminant hepatitis—which refers to massive necrosis of liver parenchyma and atrophy. Treatment is largely supportive, and there is currently no vaccine against hepatitis E.

Option Analysis

✅ Massive necrosis of liver parenchyma:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Hepatocellular carcinoma:
Incorrect: Hepatitis B, C, and D increase the risk of developing hepatocellular carcinoma, while hepatitis E does not.
❌ Pyogenic liver abscess:
Incorrect: Pyogenic liver abscess is a rare entity associated with underlying liver or biliary disease or recent biliary tract manipulation. In developing countries, these abscesses are more commonly caused by parasitic infections, whereas in the United States they are most commonly caused by bacterial infection. It does not typically present with marked elevations in liver enzymes.  
❌ Membranous glomerulonephritis:
Incorrect: Active hepatitis B carries an increased risk of developing membranous glomerulonephritis and membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis. However, this patient’s viral hepatitis panel shows antibodies for the hepatitis B surface antigen, indicating immunity.
❌ B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma:
Incorrect: Hepatitis C carries an increased risk for developing B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma, as well as ITP, and autoimmune hemolytic anemia. This pregnant patient with no risk factors for acquiring hepatitis C (e.g., intravenous drug use, blood product recipient) is likely infected with a different hepatitis virus, as indicated by the viral panel.

questions.text:
A 57-year-old male undergoes coronary artery bypass grafting due to severe symptomatic coronary artery disease. The surgery is uncomplicated, and the patient is admitted to the cardiothoracic intensive care unit for hemodynamic monitoring. Overnight, a rapid response is called after a tachyarrhythmia was noted on the patient’s telemetry strip. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 140/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 134/72 mmHg. He has incisional chest pain but is otherwise asymptomatic. The patient’s electrocardiogram is demonstrated below:  


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons  

Based on this patient's clinical presentation, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response

questions.solution:
This patient presents after cardiac surgery with an electrocardiogram demonstrating characteristic flutter waves with a 3:1 and 4:1 AV nodal block. These findings are most consistent with atrial flutter.  
 
Atrial flutter is a common tachydysrhythmia that usually arises due to a reentry circuit near the tricuspid annulus. It results in an atrial rate of approximately 300 beats per minute with subsequent ventricular depolarizations of approximately 150 beats per minute. Identifying atrial flutter is dependent on the recognition of characteristic "flutter waves," which are most commonly found in the inferior leads and take on a saw-tooth appearance. Atrial flutter will also demonstrate an atrio-ventricular conduction ratio, meaning that every X number of atrial beats results in a single ventricular depolarization. For example, a 3:1 conduction ratio indicates three atrial beats for every one ventricular beat.  

Etiologies of atrial flutter include underlying metabolic disturbance, structural heart disease, pulmonary embolism, pericarditis, and recent cardiac surgery. When symptomatic, patients typically present with shortness of breath, chest pain, palpitations, and light-headedness. Treatment is targeted at correcting the underlying etiology and achieving rate control. Atrial flutter is often more resistant to rate controlling medications, and thus many patients will need to undergo catheter directed ablation.  

 

Option Analysis

✅ Atrial flutter  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia:
Incorrect: Paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia is defined as a regular rhythm with a rate ranging between 150 to 250 beats per minute, a narrow QRS complex, and absent P-waves. In contrast, P-waves are seen on this patient’s electrocardiogram .
❌ Multifocal atrial tachycardia :
Incorrect: Multifocal atrial tachycardia (MAT) is defined by an irregularly irregular rhythm with varying intervals and at least 3 distinct P-wave morphologies in the same lead. Patients with underlying pulmonary disease are predisposed to this tachyarrhythmia. However, this patient’s electrocardiogram demonstrates a “sawtooth pattern,” which is more consistent with atrial flutter.
❌ Atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response:
Incorrect: Atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (RVR) is defined as an abnormally fast heart rate with irregularly irregular QRS complexes and absent P-waves. In contrast, P-waves are seen on this patient’s electrocardiogram.
❌ Sinus tachycardia:
Incorrect: Sinus tachycardia is characterized by a fast (>100 beats per minutes) rate, regular rhythm, and an identifiable P-wave before every QRS complex. It would not, however, manifest with the “sawtooth pattern” seen on this patient’s electrocardiogram .

questions.text:
A 62-year-old man presents with a worsening cough and shortness of breath for the past 5 months. He reports he used to be able to walk four blocks before becoming short of breath but now can only walk a half-a-block. He has a past medical history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He smokes 5-10 cigarettes per day and does not use alcohol or illicit substances. He has worked as a bird breeder for over 15 years. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 62/min, respirations are 17/min, blood pressure is 138/94 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 94% on room air. Physical examination is notable for a thin, cachectic male with coarse breath sounds bilaterally and digital clubbing. Chest CT scan is demonstrated below:  


Reproduced from: Radiopaedia    
Lung biopsy is performed and reveals aggregates of epithelioid macrophages with multinucleated giant cells. This patient is most likely to demonstrate which of the following respiratory parameters?
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of working as a bird breeder, presents with worsening dyspnea on exertion, malaise, and has a CT scan of the chest demonstrating diffuse ground glass opacities. His history and clinical findings are consistent with chronic hypersensitivity pneumonitis, a restrictive lung disease.  

Hypersensitivity pneumonitis is a granulomatous disorder in which the lungs become inflamed in response to inhaled microorganisms, plant and animal proteins, or chemicals. The disease was colloquially referred to as bird fancier disease, as antigens in pigeon or bird droppings were the common offending agent. It is divided into an acute and chronic form. Acute disease often presents with fevers, cough, and shortness of breath within hours of exposure to the antigen and then subsequent resolution of symptoms after removal of the exposure. Chronic hypersensitivity pneumonitis presents similarly, but with a more insidious onset over years of exposure. These patients often have sustained shortness of breath, weight loss, a pattern of restrictive lung disease, and, in its worse case, respiratory failure.    

Diagnosis of the disease rests on compatible clinical, radiographic, physiologic, and histopathologic findings. Radiographic findings include diffuse bilateral ground glass opacities on CT-scan as well as numerous, poorly defined small opacities throughout both lungs—sparring the apices and the bases. Spirometry will demonstrate a restrictive lung physiology, characterized by decreased FEV1/FVC ratio and bronchiolar lavage samples will often have increased lymphocytes and mast cells. Lung biopsy will typically demonstrate noncaseating granulomas (aggregates of epithelioid macrophages with multinucleated giant cells) as well.  

One of the key tests performed is called an inhalation challenge, where the patient physically inhales the suspected antigen and is monitored for developing symptoms. If diagnosed early, the disease process can be reversed. Most cases are treated by simply instructing the patient to avoid the exposure, while more severe cases require treatment with steroids.  





Option Analysis

✅ Increased FEV1/FVC:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Decreased FEV1/FVC:
Incorrect: Obstructive lung diseases such as emphysema or asthma will demonstrate an decreased FEV1/FVC ratio. While this patient does smoke, the chest CT-findings are inconsistent with emphysematous changes, which would instead demonstrate hyperinflation and hyperlucency of the lung fields. Pulmonary examination would also demonstrate reduced breath sounds. 
❌ Decreased A-a gradient :
Incorrect: Restrictive lung diseases like hypersensitivity pneumonitis tend to present with an increased A-a gradient due to the impaired diffusion of gases across the inflamed and fibrosed alveolar-capillary membrane. 
❌ Increased residual volume:
Incorrect: Increased residual volume are findings consistent with obstructive lung disease such as emphysema. This patient’s CT findings do not have evidence of hyperinflated lung fields. 
❌ Normal diffusing capacity for CO:
Incorrect: A normal diffusing capacity for carbon monoxide may be seen in restrictive lung diseases where there is no parenchymal damage, such as scoliosis or morbid obesity. However, in the case of hypersensitivity pneumonitis, inflammation and damage to the alveolar capillary interface results in impaired diffusing capacity for CO.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male is brought to the emergency department after being involved in a high speed motor vehicle collision. Per paramedics, the patient was the restrained driver and was rear-ended by another vehicle traveling approximately 60 miles per hour. The patient endorses difficulty moving his arms and legs, and endorses pain to the back of his neck. He is otherwise healthy and does not take any medications. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 42/min, respirations are 17/min, blood pressure is 80/60 mmHg, and O<sub>2</sub> saturation is 97% on room air. On physical exam, the patient has a large bruise over the anterior chest wall and abdomen. Cardiopulmonary exam is otherwise unremarkable. He is unable to move his arms or legs to command and has absent reflexes below the C6 level. Which of the following best describes the underlying pathophysiology resulting in this patient’s clinical presentation?

choices.text: Inadequate perfusion due to loss of intravascular volume
Compression of mediastinal structures and impaired cardiac outflow
Blunt cardiac injury and excess fluid between the heart and pericardium

questions.solution:
This trauma patient presents after a high speed motor vehicle collision with absent reflexes and paralysis below the C6 level. His vitals demonstrate signs of autonomic dysfunction consistent with neurogenic shock, which is due to impaired sympathetic outflow.  

Neurogenic shock is a type of distributive or “warm” shock characterized by inadequate tissue perfusion in the setting of autonomic instability from injury to the central nervous system. Neurogenic shock is most commonly caused by cervical or thoracic spine injuries, but it can also be caused by intracranial hemorrhage, traumatic brain injuries, or inflammatory neuropathies. Most commonly, damage to axons and neural membranes in the intermediolateral nucleus, lateral grey matter, and anterior roots leads to disrupted sympathetic tone and subsequent unopposed parasympathetic outflow. Unopposed parasympathetic tone can cause systemic vasodilation, bradycardia, and bradypnea.  

Ultimately, this manifests with a decreased systemic vascular resistance, decreased pulmonary capillary wedge pressure, and decreased cardiac output. Hence, it is the only type of shock that does not appropriately respond with reflex tachycardia to hypotension. Patients typically present with flushing, warm extremities, autonomic instability, and decreased or absent reflexes below the level of the injury.


Option Analysis

✅ Impaired sympathetic outflow:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Inadequate perfusion due to loss of intravascular volume:
Incorrect: Hypovolemic shock should always be considered in an unstable trauma patient. While intra-abdominal injury and subsequent hemoperitoneum is possible, it is unlikely given his relative bradycardia. Hypovolemic shock presents with compensatory reflex tachycardia due to ongoing volume losses.
❌ Compression of mediastinal structures and impaired cardiac outflow:
Incorrect: Tension pneumothorax presents with absent unilateral breath sounds, tracheal deviation, and jugular venous distension. It is unlikely that this patient, who has a normal cardiopulmonary exam and oxygen saturation of 97% on room air, has a tension pneumothorax.
❌ Impaired parasympathetic outflow:
Incorrect: Impaired parasympathetic outflow would result in hypertension, tachycardia, and tachypnea.  Sympathetic, not parasympathetic, outflow is disrupted in neurogenic shock.  
❌ Blunt cardiac injury and excess fluid between the heart and pericardium:
Incorrect: Pericardial tamponade, a form of obstructive shock, presents with Beck triad: muffled heart tones, jugular venous distension, and low blood pressure. In contrast, this patient's cardiopulmonary exam is normal.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his partner due to altered mental status. He is disoriented and unarousable, but his partner is able to provide medical information. The patient has not seen a physician in several years, but he has noticed increased abdominal distension and leg swelling in the last year. Past medical history is notable for IV drug use and chronic hepatitis C infection, which was diagnosed 30 years ago. However, the patient has not used intravenous drugs in over 10 years. Physical examination reveals gynecomastia and multiple spider angiomata. His abdomen is significantly distended, with visible paraumbilical veins; shifting dullness to percussion is present. Splenomegaly is noted. The patient has 3+ pitting edema of the lower extremities. Which set of laboratory findings is most consistent with this patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient has symptoms of cirrhosis (e.g., gynecomastia, spider angiomata, splenomegaly) and altered mental status. He likely has hepatic encephalopathy due to underlying cirrhosis brought about by chronic hepatitis C infection.  

Cirrhosis is an irreversible condition caused by recurrent hepatocellular damage (e.g., alcohol intake, viral infection) and repair, ultimately resulting in diffuse fibrosis and impaired hepatic function. Prothrombin time (PT) is a measure of the extrinsic coagulation pathway; since coagulation factors of the extrinsic system are mainly synthesized by the liver, an abnormally elevated PT can indicate liver dysfunction.  

Additionally, since albumin, a major constituent of serum proteins, is exclusively made in the liver, cirrhosis and declining liver function can result in reduced total albumin. This change contributes to decreased intravascular oncotic pressure and leads to fluid extravasation and peripheral edema.  

As the liver becomes fibrotic, blood flow through the organ is impaired, resulting in backflow of blood into the portosystemic anastomoses and subsequent elevation of portal pressure. This phenomenon is termed portal hypertension and can manifest with engorged paraumbilical veins (caput medusae) and splenomegaly.  

In contrast, hepatic steatosis and acute hepatitis are milder conditions that can be reversed if the underlying trigger for hepatocellular injury is removed. Furthermore, these conditions do not typically present with abnormalities in clotting parameters or serum albumin levels.  


Option Analysis

✅ :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ :
Incorrect: These findings can be seen in patients with acute hepatitis, since the synthetic function of the liver is mainly intact. However, this patient has gynecomastia, spider angiomata, pitting edema, and abdominal ascites, which are suggestive of liver failure due to cirrhosis. Patients with cirrhosis typically have elevated PT and decreased total protein levels due to impaired hepatic synthetic function.
❌ :
Incorrect: This set of laboratory findings is not consistent with the patient’s underlying cirrhosis. The impaired synthetic function of the liver would cause a decrease in total serum proteins, not increase.
❌ :
Incorrect: This set of laboratory findings is not consistent with the patient’s underlying cirrhosis; the impaired synthetic function of the liver would cause a decrease in total serum proteins, not increase. Additionally, this patient’s portal pressure is likely elevated given there is clinical evidence of portal hypertension (e.g., enlarged paraumbilical veins, splenomegaly).
❌ :
Incorrect: This patient has clinical symptoms of liver cirrhosis and likely has impaired hepatic synthetic function. Given that the liver is involved in the synthesis of clotting factors and serum proteins (e.g. albumin), patients with cirrhosis will have an elevated PT and decreased total protein level.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man presents to his primary care physician with progressive shortness of breath over the past year. He reports he is otherwise healthy and does not take any medications daily. He works as an accountant and smokes two to three cigarettes on the weekend. The patient is lost to follow-up, and several years later, the patient requires a bilateral lung transplantation. Pathologic evaluation of the patient’s lungs reveals a honeycomb pattern with fibrotic walls most prominent in the subpleural and perilobular regions. Which of the following best describes the underlying pathophysiology of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Recurrent episodes of lung injury and disordered healing

questions.solution:
This patient presents with progressive dyspnea and undergoes bilateral lung transplantation with his native lungs demonstrating a honeycomb pattern with fibrotic walls most prominent in the subpleural and perilobular regions. In the absence of other known causes, this patient's presentation is most consistent with idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis—a disease of unknown etiology thought to be due to repeated cycles of lung injury and wound healing with increased collagen deposition.  

Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis is a restrictive lung disease of unknown etiology. It is identified in patients as a diagnosis of exclusion—once other types of restrictive lung diseases are ruled out. The known risk factors for disease include male gender, smoking, and old age. While the precise precipitant of disease is unknown, lung injury results in destruction of type I pneumocytes and subsequent overproliferation of type II pneumocytes and myofibroblasts that do not undergo apoptosis. Increased collagen deposition by these cells leads to stiffening of the lungs, resulting in traction bronchiectasis, where fibrosis pulls apart the parenchyma, resulting in irreversible dilation of the bronchi and bronchioles.  

Patients with this disease are usually asymptomatic in the early stages, but as the disease progresses, patients typically develop a dry cough or shortness of breath. At later stages, patients may develop cyanosis, digital clubbing, or respiratory failure. The disease is diagnosed by first excluding other causes of pulmonary fibrosis, spirometry, and radiography. Pulmonary function testing will typically reveal a restrictive pattern, and chest CT will demonstrate a honeycomb pattern. Treatment involves supplemental oxygen, the antifibrotic medication pirfenidone (inhibits transforming growth factor beta), and lung transplantation.   

Option Analysis

✅ Recurrent episodes of lung injury and disordered healing:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Deficiency of a proteinase inhibitor:
Incorrect: Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency is instead associated with emphysematous changes in the lung tissue and obstructive lung disease. 
❌ Proliferation of undifferentiated neuroendocrine cells :
Incorrect: Small cell carcinoma of the lung results in an amorphous mass usually arising from central bronchi. 
❌ Mixed type III/IV hypersensitivity reaction :
Incorrect: Hypersensitivity pneumonitis results in diffuse reticulonodular fibrosis due to a mixed type III/IV hypersensitivity reaction. Patients will typically have a history of repeated exposure to an offending antigen, history of working on a farm, or history as a bird breeder. 
❌ Multisystem granulomatous disorder:
Incorrect: Sarcoidosis results in a granuloma formation in the lungs with hilar adenopathy. This patient lacks other history associated with this disease process including uveitis, Bell's palsy, or arthritis.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician's office for evaluation of pain and stiffness in fingers and low back for six months. The pain is worse early in the morning and gradually improves over the course of the day. She also has soreness of the heels bilaterally. The patient has been taking acetaminophen with only partial relief. Past medical history includes myocardial infarction with stent placement one year ago. Physical examination shows point tenderness over the bilateral Achilles tendons, as well as effusion and joint line tenderness of 3rd and 4th distal interphalangeal joints of the bilateral hands. The patient’s left thumb is demonstrated below.  


Retrieved fromWikimedia Commons  

Which of the following clinical findings is associated with this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Erythematous pruritic papules and vesicles on extensor surfaces
Well-defined silvery scales and plaques on extensor surfaces
Pruritic tense bullae on flexural surfaces, groin and axilla
Hyperkeratotic, hyperpigmented plaques on axilla, groin and neck
Dense rope-like bands in skin with strictures and edema

questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation of pain, tenderness, and stiffness of distal interphalangeal (DIP) joints (distal arthritis) and spine, along with point tenderness of the Achilles tendon (enthesitis), and nail pitting, is consistent with psoriatic arthritis (PsA).   

PsA is a seronegative chronic inflammatory arthropathy that presents with pain and stiffness of affected joints. It is associated with psoriasis, a chronic inflammatory skin condition that presents as a well-demarcated, silvery, erythematous rash mainly on the extensor surfaces of extremities. Though most patients present with cutaneous symptoms, joint involvement precedes the onset of the rash in about 7% of the cases.  

Psoriatic arthritis is clinically divided into five subtypes:

  •  Asymmetric oligoarticular arthritis: <3 joints are affected, most common presentation 
  •  Symmetric polyarticular arthritis: >5 joints are affected, resembles rheumatoid arthritis 
  •  Spondylitis presentation: sacroiliitis and spondylitis 
  •  Distal arthritis: DIP joints are affected 
  • Arthritis mutilans: deforming and destructive arthritis   
Generally, psoriatic arthritis manifests as a peripheral arthritis worse in the morning and improves with activity, enthesitis (inflammation at the tendon or ligament insertion site), dactylitis (sausage digits) and nail lesions (e.g., nail pitting, onycholysis). Plain radiographs may show the characteristic ‘pencil in cup’ deformity that occurs secondary to erosion and new bone formation within the same joint.  


Retrieved from Radiopedia

Option Analysis

❌ Erythematous pruritic papules and vesicles on extensor surfaces:
Incorrect: Erythematous pruritic papules and vesicles on extensor surfaces are typical of dermatitis herpetiformis which is an autoimmune dermal reaction to dietary gluten observed in patients with celiac disease.
✅ Well-defined silvery scales and plaques on extensor surfaces:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Pruritic tense bullae on flexural surfaces, groin and axilla:
Incorrect: Pruritic tense bullae on flexural surface, groin and axilla are characteristic of bullous pemphigoid, an autoimmune blistering disorder. It has been found in association with dementia, Parkinson disease, and bipolar disorder, but not psoriatic arthritis. 
❌ Hyperkeratotic, hyperpigmented plaques on axilla, groin and neck:
Incorrect: Hyperkeratotic hyperpigmented plaques on axilla, groin and neck are typical of acanthosis nigricans, which is strongly associated with insulin resistance. It has no association with psoriatic arthritis.   
❌ Dense rope-like bands in skin with strictures and edema:
Incorrect: Dense rope-like bands in skin with strictures and edema occur as a complication of hidradenitis suppurativa, which is a chronic inflammatory disease that results from occlusion of pilosebaceous subunits. It is common in patients with obesity and diabetes or those with a positive family history. An association with arthritis is not well-established.

questions.text:
A 54-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her partner due to altered mental status for the last 2 days. According to her husband, the patient has become increasingly lethargic, disoriented, and agitated. The patient has a history of chronic hepatitis C infection that was diagnosed 14 years ago. She refused all treatment at that time. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 98/min, and blood pressure is 104/74 mmHg. On examination, the patient is lethargic and oriented only to self. When her hands are outstretched in front of her and extended at the wrist, they exhibit a flapping tremor. The abdomen is nontender and mildly distended; shifting dullness to percussion is present. There is no nuchal rigidity. Stool occult blood is positive. Laboratory testing reveals the following findings:



The patient is started on emergent therapy for her symptoms. Which of the following best explains the pathophysiology of this patient’s current condition?

choices.text: Increased absorption of nitrogenous substances by the gut
Occlusion of the anterior cerebral artery

questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with symptoms hepatic encephalopathy (e.g., asterixis, confusion, lethargy) in the setting of liver cirrhosis and an underlying gastrointestinal bleed, given the positive fecal occult blood test. Hepatic encephalopathy (HE) occurs since liver dysfunction results in insufficient elimination and subsequent accumulation of metabolic products (e.g. ammonia). As ammonia accumulates, it is able to cross the blood-brain-barrier, resulting in astrocyte swelling, dysfunction, and impaired neurotransmitter synthesis.  

Anything that increases ammonia production or reabsorption in the gut can trigger HE. These include gastrointestinal bleeding, constipation, or infections. Decreased ammonia elimination via the kidneys can also be a trigger. Finally, transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunting (TIPS) used to treat portal hypertension can also be a trigger since ammonia-rich blood from the intestines bypasses the liver completely.  

Hepatic encephalopathy presents with symptoms like insomnia or hypersomnia, mood changes, along with confusion, and even coma in some cases. Asterixis, a flapping tremor of the hand that appears when the wrist is extended, is commonly seen.  

Treatment typically involves administering antibiotics (e.g. rifaximin) to kill ammonia-producing bacteria and lactulose to decrease ammonia absorption in the bowel. Lactulose is converted to lactic acid by colonic bacteria resulting in acidification of the intestinal environment, leading to increased conversion of ammonia (NH3) to ammonium (NH4+). Ammonium is non-absorbable by the intestines and therefore excreted via feces.





Option Analysis

✅ Increased absorption of nitrogenous substances by the gut:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Bacterial infection of the meninges:
Incorrect: Meningitis, which is caused by bacterial infection of the meninges, can also result in fever and altered mental status. However, meningitis characteristically causes neck stiffness (nuchal rigidity), along with photophobia, which this patient lacks.
❌ Inflammation of brain parenchyma:
Incorrect: Encephalitis is inflammation of the brain parenchyma, and it typically presents with a prodromal phase of fever, headache, and altered mental status. Acute encephalitis can cause seizures and behavioral changes. However, encephalitis itself would not explain the jaundice, shifting dullness to percussion, and asterixis as seen in this patient.
❌ Microbial infection of ascitic fluid:
Incorrect: Spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP) is an infection of the ascitic fluid that is characterized by fever, abdominal pain, and varying degrees of altered mental status. However, this patient’s asterixis and occult blood in the stool is suggestive of a different inciting condition.
