❌ Occlusion of the anterior cerebral artery:
Incorrect: A stroke involving the anterior cerebral artery (ACA) would present as contralateral paralysis and sensory loss affecting primarily the lower extremities as well as urinary incontinence. However, this patient’s asterixis and occult blood in the stool is suggestive of a different inciting condition.

questions.text: A 56-year-old male presents to his primary care physician with worsening fatigue, decreasing exercise tolerance and a 15 pound weight loss over the past two months. The patient additionally has a chronic cough, low grade fevers, and cravings for salty foods. He currently lives in Ohio but recently immigrated from Vietnam where he worked as a nurse. He has a history of type II diabetes mellitus and a ten pack year smoking history, but he does not use alcohol or other illicit substances. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6 °F), pulse is 65/min, respirations are 16/min, blood pressure is 100/72 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 95% on room air. Physical examination demonstrates a thin, fatigued male in no acute distress with facial hyperpigmentation. A screening PPD test is positive. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient’s clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with worsening fatigue, low grade fevers, weight loss, and skin hyperpigmentation. In addition, he has a history of working as a nurse in a country endemic to Mycobacterium tuberculosis, which is the most common etiology of primary adrenal insufficiency in the developing world. His screening PPD test is positive, which further supports this diagnosis.  

Primary adrenal insufficiency refers to decreased production of both mineralocorticoids and glucocorticoids due to adrenal gland dysfunction. This disease is further divided into acute and chronic forms, with acute disease characterized by refractory shock due to adrenal hemorrhage from acute infectious etiologies, thrombosis, or trauma.  

Chronic adrenal insufficiency is characterized by indolent symptoms that commonly include fatigue, weight loss, salt craving, and non-specific gastrointestinal complaints. Patients will frequently have signs of hypotension, skin hyperpigmentation, and electrolyte abnormalities of hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, and metabolic acidosis. Etiologies of chronic adrenal insufficiency are divided into autoimmune causes, infectious etiologies, drugs, and metastatic disease. In the developed world, autoimmune adrenalitis is the most common cause of primary adrenal insufficiency, whereas in the developing world the most common etiology is chronic Mycobacterium tuberculosis infection.



Option Analysis

✅ Chronic mycobacterial infection:
Correct: See main explanation.
❌ Infection with a gram-negative diplococci  :
Incorrect: Infection with Neisseria meningitidis can result in Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome and bilateral adrenal hemorrhage. Clinically, this complication presents with acute disseminated intravascular coagulation and refractory shock, which are absent in this patient.
❌ Disseminated histoplasmosis:
Incorrect: Disseminated histoplasmosis can cause primary adrenal insufficiency. However, it is not the most common etiology of adrenal insufficiency in patients from developing countries. Furthermore, disseminated histoplasmosis rarely manifests in immunocompetent patients.  
❌ Presence of HLA-B8:
Incorrect: Autoimmune adrenalitis is associated with the HLA-B8 serotype. Given the patient’s risk factors and clinical features consistent with Mycobacterium tuberculosis infection, this diagnosis is less likely.  
❌ Metastatic lung malignancy:
Incorrect: Metastatic malignancies can cause primary adrenal insufficiency when tumor burden spreads to the adrenal glands. Although this patient does smoke, his positive PPD test makes mycobacterial infection a more likely cause of his adrenal insufficiency.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old male is evaluated post-operatively after a transsphenoidal pituitary tumor resection two days ago. He appears groggy and is unable to provide any clinical history. Past medical history is notable for Cushing disease, for which he underwent resection of the aforementioned pituitary tumor. The surgery was uncomplicated, and he is not on any medications. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 101/min, respirations are 14/min, blood pressure is 110/60mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. Physical examination is notable for truncal obesity and striae. Initial laboratory findings are demonstrated below:



Which of the following laboratory findings is most representative of this patient’s clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient has a history of Cushing disease secondary to an ACTH secreting pituitary tumor. After undergoing surgical resection of the tumor, loss of ACTH production results in loss of cortisol production, which manifests with a glucocorticoid crisis and tertiary adrenal insufficiency.  

Tertiary adrenal insufficiency is characterized by hypothalamic dysfunction and decreased CRH production. Overall, the most common etiology is the sudden withdrawal of chronic glucocorticoid therapy, since exogenous steroid use suppresses CRH release. When steroids are abruptly withdrawn, the now dysfunctional hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis can no longer produce endogenous cortisol. Abrupt removal of an ACTH producing tumor, as in the case of this patient, can also result in tertiary adrenal insufficiency via a similar mechanism. Other etiologies of tertiary adrenal insufficiency include suprasellar lesions, trauma, hypothalamic/pituitary tumors, and abrupt removal of CRH or cortisol producing tumors.  

Laboratory testing will reveal reduced CRH, ACTH, and cortisol levels. Aldosterone levels will be normal since adrenal gland synthetic function is unaffected.  

Diagnosis is achieved through obtaining levels of CRH, ACTH, and cortisol in association with clinical features. Most patients with tertiary adrenal insufficiency will have a stable blood pressure, no hyponatremia or hyperkalemia, due to normal aldosterone production. However, they will tend to have more features of hypoglycemia. Treatment involves glucocorticoid replacement therapy.  



Option Analysis

✅ :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ :
Incorrect: These values are reflective of decreased ACTH production in the setting of secondary adrenal insufficiency. However, this patient has a history of Cushing disease and is now presenting with signs of hypocortisolism after resection of a pituitary adenoma, which is more concerning for tertiary adrenal insufficiency.
❌ :
Incorrect: Primary adrenal insufficiency is characterized by decreased aldosterone and cortisol production from the adrenal gland itself. It is further characterized by increased levels of CRH and ACTH due to absence of feedback suppression. This patient’s history, however, is more concerning for tertiary adrenal insufficiency.
❌ :
Incorrect: Ectopic CRH releasing tumors are rare but are associated with medullary thyroid carcinoma, pheochromocytoma, and prostate cancer. In contrast, this patient with a history of Cushing disease is now presenting with signs of hypocortisolism after resection of a pituitary adenoma, which is more concerning for tertiary adrenal insufficiency.
❌ :
Incorrect: These findings are suggestive of primary hypercortisolism, such as in the case of an adrenal adenoma or carcinoma. In contrast, this patient’s patient’s hypercortisolism was due to an ACTH secreting pituitary adenoma, which has since been surgically removed.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old woman begins complaining of dyspnea while recovering in the post-anesthesia care unit. Earlier in the day, the patient underwent a laparoscopic cholecystectomy for treatment of symptomatic gallstones. Past medical history is unremarkable. Her temperature is 37.7°C (99.9°F), pulse is 93/min, respiratory rate is 24/min and blood pressure is 125/72 mmHg. Physical examination shows the patient in distress with shallow breaths, using accessory muscles. In addition, the patient is observed to have drooping of the eyelids and corners of the mouth bilaterally. Pupils are 3 cm bilaterally and reactive to light. An arterial blood gas measurement reveals the following findings:
 
Laboratory Value  Result
 pH  7.31 
 PaCO2  56 mmHg 
 PaO2  71 mmHg 
 Bicarbonate  25 mmol/L 

The patient’s condition improves with administration of edrophonium chloride. Which of the following best describes the cause of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Lodging of blood clot in the pulmonary vasculature

questions.solution:
This patient with significant respiratory distress (dyspnea, rapid, shallow breath, use of accessory muscles) and respiratory acidosis (↓pH, ↑pCO2, ↓O2, normal HCO3), together with examination findings of ptosis and facial drooping, is most likely in myasthenic crisis.

Myasthenic crisis is a life-threatening complication of myasthenia gravis (MG) that occurs due to weakness of the respiratory muscles (e.g., diaphragm, intercostal muscles). It can be triggered by infections, surgery/anesthesia, pregnancy, and medications such as beta-blockers. The condition manifests with dyspnea and respiratory insufficiency, which can quickly progress to respiratory failure.  

It is important to distinguish a myasthenic crisis from a cholinergic crisis, which occurs due to overtreatment of MG by acetylcholinerase inhibitors (e.g. pyridostigmine). In a cholinergic crisis, too much acetylcholine is present at the neuromuscular junction. Both cholinergic crisis and myasthenic crisis manifest with similar symptoms, so an edrophonium test is needed to distinguish the two. Administration of edrophonium briefly blocks the breakdown of acetylcholine, temporarily increasing its levels at the neuromuscular junction. In myasthenic crisis, the increased acetylcholine levels are enough to overcome the symptoms caused by the decreased number of available receptors, so muscle weakness improves. If symptoms get worse, a cholinergic crisis should be suspected.  



Option Analysis

❌ Cholinomimetic drug overdose:
Incorrect: Overdose of cholinomimetic medications can result in a cholinergic crisis. The condition can cause cramping, muscle weakness, and paralysis, which can lead to respiratory failure. However, patients experiencing a cholinergic crisis will also have miosis and muscle weakness that worsens after edrophonium administration. In contrast, this patient has normal-sized pupils and weakness that improved after edrophonium administration.
❌ Deflation of lung alveoli :
Incorrect: This answer choice describes atelectasis, a condition that can arise in postoperative patients. Postoperative pain, retained airway secretions, and reduced spontaneous breathing secondary to anesthesia are all precipitating factors in the development of atelectasis. However, this patient also has ptosis and bulbar muscle weakness, which raise concern for myasthenic crisis instead.
✅ Respiratory muscles weakness:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Lodging of blood clot in the pulmonary vasculature:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes pulmonary embolism, which can manifest with dyspnea and tachycardia. Recent surgery and associated immobilization can predispose patients to developing this condition. However, pulmonary embolism would not account for the extraocular and facial muscle weakness noted on the physical exam.
❌ Pulmonary edema secondary to inflammation:
Incorrect: Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) is characterized by a severe inflammatory reaction that damages the lungs, increases vessel permeability, and causes fluid to accumulate in the lungs. The condition is often triggered by conditions such as sepsis, pneumonia, and pancreatitis. In contrast, the patient in this vignette does not have any of these risk factors.

questions.text: A 57-year-old man comes to his primary care provider for evaluation of muscle weakness. The symptoms began four months ago. The patient reports the weakness is most prominent in the thighs. Past medical history is notable for hypertension and type I diabetes mellitus, for which he takes daily amlodipine and insulin injections. Social history is notable for a 40-pack-year smoking history. In the office, his temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 71/min, and blood pressure is 152/83 mmHg. Physical examination shows weakness in the quadriceps bilaterally and 3/5 patellar reflexes. The patient is asked to walk back-and-forth several times across the examination room. Repeat testing reveals 5/5 patellar reflexes. No sensory deficits are observed. Cardiac, pulmonary, and abdominal exams are noncontributory. Laboratory testing reveals a creatinine kinase of 80 U/L and erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 12 mm/h. Which of the following best describes the pathophysiology of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Formation of antibodies against acetylcholine receptors
T-cell mediated damage of muscle tissue
Impaired release of acetylcholine from motor end plate
Formation of antibodies against voltage-gated calcium channels

questions.solution:
This patient has Lambert Eaton myasthenic syndrome (LEMS), an autoimmune condition characterized by the formation of auto-antibodies against presynaptic voltage-gated calcium channels. It is a type II hypersensitivity reaction.  

The antibodies bind and block the channels, leaving only a few that are viable. As a result, only small quantities of calcium can enter the neuron, which is not enough to trigger acetylcholine release into the neuromuscular junction and induce muscle contractions. With repeated stimulation by electrical impulses from the brain, enough calcium will finally make it through the few free calcium channels, resulting in acetylcholine release and muscle contraction.

Hence, patients with LEMS exhibit the “warming-up phenomenon,” which is muscle weakness that temporarily improves after repeated use (as in this patient). The disease most commonly leads to symmetrical weakness of the proximal muscles, such as those in the shoulders and hips. The lower limbs are more frequently affected. As a result, patients may endorse difficulty climbing stairs, standing up from a sitting position, and lifting their arm to brush their hair.

In addition, patients can have reduced tendon reflexes and autonomic symptoms, such as dry mouth, constipation, and blurry vision.



Option Analysis

❌ Formation of antibodies against acetylcholine receptors:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes myasthenia gravis, which most often affects the oculobulbar muscles. The condition manifests with muscle weakness that is exacerbated by repeated use. In contrast, this patient has weakness most prominent in the proximal leg muscles and decreased tendon reflexes that improve with repeated muscle use. These symptoms are more consistent with Lambert Eaton myasthenic syndrome.
❌ T-cell mediated damage of muscle tissue:
Incorrect: Polymyositis is characterized by cell-mediated autoimmune damage of muscle tissue. The condition causes proximal muscle weakness. However, polymyositis would manifest with an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate, due to its inflammation, and elevated creatinine kinase, due to muscle damage.  
❌ Impaired release of acetylcholine from motor end plate:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes botulism, which can manifest with a flaccid descending paralysis, diplopia, and dysarthria/dysphagia. In adults, the condition is often caused by the consumption of canned foods contaminated by botulinum toxin or infection of a wound by Clostridium botulinum spores. However, it would be atypical for botulism to present with muscle weakness most prominent in the thighs or reduced deep tendon reflexes that improve with activity.  
✅ Formation of antibodies against voltage-gated calcium channels:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Autoimmune damage of Schwann cells:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes Guillain-Barre syndrome (GBS), which causes an ascending flaccid paralysis and reduced deep tendon reflexes. The condition also typically causes reduced sensation in the hands and feet. In contrast, this patient has no sensory deficits. Moreover, it would be atypical for GBS to present with reduced tendon reflexes that improve after repeated stimulation.

questions.text:
A 20-year-old male comes to his primary care physician for evaluation of neck pain and headaches. His symptoms have been progressively worsening over the past several months, and his headache is located primarily at the occipital region. The patient is otherwise healthy and does not consume alcohol, tobacco, or illicit substances. He is not taking any medications. Vitals are within normal limits. On physical examination, the patient is noted to have down beating nystagmus. MRI imaging of the brain reveals the following findings:  

 Image reproduced from Radiopaedia  

 Which of the following findings is most often associated with this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Cystic cavity within the spinal cord

questions.solution:
This patient presents with a chronic, worsening headache, nystagmus, and evidence of tonsillar ectopia on the sagittal view of his brain MRI. These findings are consistent with symptomatic Chiari I malformation, which is most commonly associated with a syrinx, or cystic cavity, within the spinal cord.    

A Chiari I malformation is a congenital condition characterized by abnormally shaped cerebellar tonsils that are displaced below the level of the foramen magnum. Most cases of Chiari I malformation are asymptomatic and discovered incidentally. When symptomatic, patients typically present during adolescence or early adulthood with chronic occipital headaches, cranial nerve palsies, paresthesias, ataxia, or nystagmus.    

Furthermore, nearly half of all cases are associated with a syringomyelia in the spinal cord. If this cystic cavity enlarges, it can compress the anterior white commissure, resulting in a "cape-like," bilateral, symmetrical loss of pain and temperature sensation in upper extremities but with preservation of fine touch. Other causes of syringomyelia include trauma and tumors.  

Figure 1: Cerebellar tonsils (white arrow) seen herniating below foramen magnum (white line)

Option Analysis

✅ Cystic cavity within the spinal cord:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Lumbosacral myelomeningocele:
Incorrect: Chiari II malformations are associated with lumbosacral myelomeningoceles. Chiari II malformations are due to downward displacement of both the cerebellar vermis and tonsils. The condition is almost universally discovered at birth since it leads to significant motor and sensory deficits. 
❌ Presence of a monoventricle:
Incorrect: Holoprosencephaly refers to the failure of the embryonic forebrain to separate into two distinct compartments during fetal development. The condition results in a monoventricle. However, this patient’s symptoms are most consistent with those of a Chiari I malformation, which would not lead to the presence of a monoventricle. 
❌ Non-communicating hydrocephalus :
Incorrect: This patient’s imaging shows a herniated cerebellar tonsil, which is concerning for a Chiari I malformation. Non-communicating hydrocephalus can occur due to Chiari I malformations. However, it is overall a rare complication and more likely to occur in patients with Chiari II malformations.  
❌  Morbid obesity  :
Incorrect: Idiopathic intracranial hypertension (IIH) can manifest with headaches and visual disturbances. The condition is associated with morbid obesity. However, IIH is not associated with Chiari I malformation, which is characterized by herniated cerebellar tonsils on neuroimaging.

questions.text: A 5-month-old female infant is brought to her pediatrician for a well-child visit. The mother describes that the patient “hasn’t been breathing well lately, and I’ve noticed that she doesn’t have a very loud cry.” The patient’s temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 130/min, respirations are 22/min, blood pressure is 90/54 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 93% on room air. Her physical exam is notable for flaccid upper extremities and an inability to sit unsupported. Reflexes are diminished in the upper and lower extremities. Which of the following best describes the underlying genetic pathophysiology of this disease process?

choices.text: Loss of function of mutation of superoxide dismutase 1

questions.solution:
This infant presents with signs of lower motor neuron disease including an inability to sit unsupported, diminished deep tendon reflexes, and flaccid upper extremities. In the infantile period, this constellation of symptoms raises concern for spinal muscular atrophy (SMA) type I, which is also termed Werdig-Hoffman disease.  

SMA type 1 is due to an autosomal recessive mutation in SMN1. This gene encodes a protein referred to as survival motor neuron protein, which functions in transcriptional regulation, telomerase regeneration, cellular trafficking, as well as neuronal trafficking and differentiation. In this disease, microdeletions disrupt this protein and result in congenital degeneration of the anterior horns of the spinal cord.    

This degeneration produces symptoms of lower motor neuron disease including weakness, fasciculations (especially of the tongue), and hypotonia. In infants, additional findings include the inability to sit unsupported, poor cry, difficulty feeding, and recurrent aspiration. Most infants die before the age of two years due to respiratory failure and recurrent pneumonia.  


Option Analysis

✅ Autosomal recessive mutation in SMN1   :
 Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Loss of function of mutation of superoxide dismutase 1:
Incorrect: Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (also termed Lou Gehirg’s disease) is a combined upper and lower motor neuron disease. It is associated with loss of function mutations in SOD1 and tends to present in middle or older aged individuals. This patient does not have clinical features of upper motor neuron disease (e.g., spasticity, hyperreflexia), making this diagnosis unlikely.  
❌ TSC2 mutation on chromosome 16  :
Incorrect: Tuberous sclerosis is a multiple organ disease resulting in hamartomas in multiple organ systems including the brain. It tends to present with seizures and intellectual disability rather than signs of lower motor neuron disease. 
❌ Autosomal dominant PMP22 gene duplication:
Incorrect: Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease is an autosomal dominant polyneuropathy that results in both motor and sensory dysfunction. Associated clinical features include hammer toes and pes cavus. In contrast, this patient does not have sensory deficits. 
❌ Autosomal dominant CAG repeat expansion:
Incorrect: Huntington disease is a trinucleotide repeat expansion disease that results in symptoms of chorea, athetosis, and aggression. It does not typically present with features of lower motor neuron disease, and it presents in adults, as opposed to children.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman goes to her primary care physician for an annual wellness examination. She has no acute complaints. Past medical history is notable for type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension, for which she is currently taking metformin and lisinopril, respectively. She frequently engages in outdoor exercise and eats a diet rich in protein and vegetables. Laboratory studies show a serum creatinine within normal limits. A dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry test is ordered, and the results show that the patient’s T-score is more than three standard deviations below the mean. Which of the following best explains the pathophysiology of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Osteoporosis in postmenopausal females is characterized by increased bone resorption and decreased bone deposition, which results in porous and weak bones. The patient in this vignette has two risk factors: advanced age and reduced estrogen levels secondary to menopause. Estrogen normally decreases osteoclast resorption of bone; therefore, decreased estrogen levels leave the patient vulnerable to breakdown of bone. In addition, the rate of bone deposition by osteoblasts decreases with age. A combination of the two factors accounts for the pathophysiology behind this patient’s reduced bone mineral density, which is quantified using the T-score. A T-score of 2.5 SD or more below the young adult mean (more than -2.5 SD) indicates the presence of osteoporosis.  

Additional risk factors include hypocalcemia, low weight, alcohol consumption, smoking, and drugs like corticosteroids. Moreover, there is a genetic element to the disease, which explains why some individuals develop osteoporosis earlier than others. Physical inactivity can also lead to osteoporosis because it causes decreased bone deposition. Lastly, some diseases that can predispose to osteoporosis include Turner syndrome, hyperprolactinemia, Klinefelter syndrome, and hyperparathyroidism.  



Option Analysis

❌ Decreased mineralization of osteoid seam:
Incorrect: This answer describes osteomalacia, a condition wherein osteoid can be deposited but cannot subsequently be mineralized. Mineralization abnormalities occur as a consequence of hypocalcemia or hypophosphatemia. Patients often present with bone pain, difficulty walking, and fractures. In contrast, the patient in this vignette presents with none of these symptoms. 
❌ Reduced osteoclast bone resorption:
Incorrect: Reduced osteoclast resorption of bone occurs in osteopetrosis. Patients present with thickened bones that are prone to fractures. In contrast, this patient’s low T-score indicates decreased, not increased, bone density.
✅ Increased osteoclast bone breakdown:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Overproduction of parathyroid hormone:
Incorrect: Hyperparathyroidism can stimulate osteoclast activity and result in bone breakdown. However, patients with hyperparathyroidism often have symptoms of hypercalcemia, such as kidney stones, bone pain, constipation, and altered mental status. In contrast, this patient has none of these symptoms.
❌ Impaired activation of vitamin D:
Incorrect: Chronic kidney disease (CKD) impairs vitamin D activation, which in turn reduces calcium uptake, predisposing patients to osteoporosis. The patient’s history of diabetes mellitus places her at risk of developing CKD. However, she has no symptoms of CKD (e.g., edema, oliguria), and her normal serum creatinine makes this etiology less likely.

questions.text:
A 20-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of pain in his right forearm and pelvis. Symptoms began 2 hours ago when the patient tripped and fell from standing height while cleaning his garage. Temperature is 37.4°C (99.3°F), blood pressure is 128/77 mmHg, and pulse is 74/min. Physical examination is notable for tenderness to palpation in the distal right forearm. Radiographs of the hands, forearm, and hip are ordered. The forearm X-ray confirms the presence of a radial fracture. The hip x-ray is shown below:  

 
Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons  

Which of the following best describes the underlying pathophysiology of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
Osteopetrosis is a rare genetic disorder characterized by decreased bone resorption. The condition is associated with mutations in at least nine genes, including carbonic anhydrase II, which ultimately impair the ability of osteoclasts to generate the acidic environment necessary for bone resorption. Without functional osteoclasts, old bone is not broken down as new bone is formed. The net result is dense and structurally abnormal bones that are fracture-prone.  

Diagnosis is established by x-ray. Some findings characteristic of osteopetrosis include: (1) diffuse sclerosis, which presents as widespread radiopacity, (2) “bone-in-bone” appearance wherein there is an even radiopaque area surrounded by a rim of radiolucent tissue, and (3) “sandwich” vertebrae where the superior and inferior margins of the vertebrae are opaque and the middle radiolucent. Laboratory testing may show normal or low calcium levels. In severe cases, growth of cortical bone into the marrow can impede hematopoiesis and cause pancytopenia.


Osteopetrosis can be divided into two subtypes. Infantile malignant osteopetrosis presents in infancy, has a severe clinical course, and definitive treatment involves bone marrow transplantation. Autosomal-dominant osteopetrosis type II presents in early adulthood, has a milder clinical course, and treatment entails symptomatic management (e.g. surgical repair of fractures).  



Option Analysis

❌ Increased bone resorption:
Incorrect: Increased bone resorption occurs in type I “postmenopausal” osteoporosis. The condition most often affects eldery postmenopausal females and presents with increased bone lucency on x-ray. In contrast, this patient is young and has x-ray results showing increased bone density.  
❌ Decreased bone mineralization:
Incorrect: This answer describes osteomalacia. The condition can present with fractures, bone pain, and difficulty walking. However, this patient presents with diffuse sclerosis of the pelvis. These findings would be atypical for osteomalacia.
✅ Reduced bone resorption:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Increased bone deposition:
Incorrect: This may be seen in the later stages of osteitis deformans (also termed Paget disease). The condition typically affects elderly men and presents with bone pain, cranial nerve deficits, skull enlargement, and pathological fractures. X-ray will most likely reveal a combination of sclerotic and osteolytic lesions. In contrast, this patient’s x-ray reveals no osteolytic lesions.
❌ Reduced bone deposition:
Incorrect: This may be seen in type II “senile” osteoporosis, which affects both men and women. However, osteoporosis presents with increased bone radiolucency, whereas this patient’s x-ray shows increased radiodensity.

questions.text:
A 9-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician by his parents because of bone pain and an abnormal gait pattern. The patient and his family recently immigrated to the United States from India. Prior to immigrating, the patient’s diet consisted mostly of rice and salted vegetables due to food shortages. Vitals are within normal limits. He is below the 10th percentile for height and weight. Radiographic imaging reveals the following findings:  


Image reproduced from Radiopedia  

Which of the following set of laboratory findings will be most likely present in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient has rickets, a condition that causes inadequate mineralization of the cartilaginous growth plates in children. Rickets is usually diagnosed with laboratory tests, which show abnormally low vitamin D levels, low serum calcium, and elevated serum alkaline phosphatase. Bone specific alkaline phosphatase isoenzyme is elevated as a result of increased osteoblastic activity. As a result of low calcium, there may also be high parathyroid hormone, which causes low serum phosphate.   

 Imaging can also be used to diagnose rickets, and several findings may be present: 
  •  Looser zones: bands of low bone density that form on the surface bones. Since they resemble fractures on x-ray, they are also termed pseudofractures.  
  •  Metaphyseal cupping: the edges of the metaphysis widen laterally, and the metaphysis itself drops inwards, hence resembling a cup.  
  • Metaphyseal fraying: instead of the metaphyseal surface appearing smooth, it appears fuzzy and irregular.
Treatment for rickets and osteomalacia involves oral vitamin D supplementation and treating the underlying cause, which could be any condition affecting the organs responsible for vitamin D activation. Moreover, preventive measures include vitamin D supplementation during pregnancy and administering vitamin D drops to neonates and infants.  



Option Analysis

❌  Calcium  Phosphate Alkaline Phosphatase ↓  Normal Normal:
Incorrect: These findings are seen in patients with osteopetrosis. The condition manifests during infancy or young adulthood and will present with increased radiodensity on imaging due to diffuse bone sclerosis. In contrast, this patient’s imaging reveals increased radiolucency. 
❌   Calcium  Phosphate Alkaline Phosphatase Normal  Normal  ↑:
Incorrect: Patients with Paget disease of the bone (also termed osteitis deformans) will present with these findings. This condition most often affects elderly men. It causes bone pain secondary to microfractures, warmth/erythema over affected areas, skull changes, and cranial nerve impingement. In contrast, it would be atypical for Paget disease of the bone to present with long-bone bowing in a young child. 
❌   Calcium  Phosphate  Alkaline Phosphatase ↑ ↓ ↑:
Incorrect: Hyperparathyroidism will cause elevated serum calcium and reduced serum phosphate levels. Bone turnover due to high parathyroid hormone levels will result in an elevated alkaline phosphatase. Patients with hyperparathyroidism often have symptoms of hypercalcemia (e.g. renal stones, bone pain, constipation). While this patient has bone pain, his history of a poor diet makes rickets a more likely explanation.
✅   Calcium  Phosphate  Alkaline Phosphatase  ↓  ↓ ↑:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌   Calcium Phosphate Alkaline Phosphatase Normal  Normal  Normal :
Incorrect: These findings are seen in patients with osteoporosis. Osteoporosis can cause pathological fractures, which may lead to bone pain. However, it would be atypical for osteoporosis to present in a patient this young or cause bowing of the legs.

questions.text:
A 53-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of abdominal pain and distention. The patient has had several episodes of emesis prior to arrival. Past medical history is notable for rheumatoid arthritis and gallstones treated with laparoscopic cholecystectomy. Temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), pulse is 96/min and blood pressure is 140/83 mmHg. Physical examination reveals diffuse tenderness to palpation of the abdomen and high-pitched bowel sounds on auscultation. Laboratory testing reveals the following findings:

 
 Laboratory value  Result 
 Sodium  145 mmol/L 
 Potassium  3.7 mmol/L 
 Chloride  102 mmol/L 
 Bicarbonate  30 mmol/L 

Imaging reveals obstruction of the small intestine. The patient is taken to the operating room, undergoes endotracheal intubation, and surgical adhesiolysis is performed. Three hours later, neurological examination reveals areflexia and impaired sensation in all extremities. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for the neurological defects?
questions.solution:
This patient has cervical spine subluxation, which is when the cervical vertebrae become misaligned secondary to rheumatoid arthritis. If the misalignment is severe, patients can develop spinal cord compression, neurological deficits, and even tetraplegia, which is paralysis of all four limbs and torso.

The condition arises since rheumatoid arthritis affects the C1-C2 joint, also termed the atlantoaxial joint, which is the only synovial joint in the spine. When it is affected, patients can experience neck pain. Sometimes, extension of the neck during endotracheal intubation or trauma can exacerbate the subluxation, leading to acute compression of the spinal cord or vertebral arteries. Since subluxation is not always symptomatic, radiographic studies of the cervical spine are needed for all patients with rheumatoid arthritis scheduled to undergo surgery requiring manipulation of the neck for either anesthesia or the surgical procedure.



Option Analysis

❌ Osmotic demyelination syndrome:
Incorrect: Osmotic demyelination syndrome occurs when there is rapid correction of serum osmolality (from hyponatremia to normal). Patients with hypernatremia are at increased risk. In contrast, this patient’s preoperative sodium levels are within normal range.
❌ Diabetic neuropathy:
Incorrect: Diabetic neuropathy can cause sensory (and sometimes motor) loss in the distal extremities. This patient has a history of type II diabetes mellitus. However, the patient’s history of rheumatoid arthritis and recent intubation makes cervical spine subluxation a more likely explanation for her symptoms.
❌ Hyperglycemic hyperosmolar syndrome:
Incorrect: This condition can be seen in patients with type II diabetes mellitus. Patients can develop weakness, altered mental status, and coma. However, it would be atypical for this condition to cause areflexia or impaired sensation in the extremities.
✅ Cervical spine subluxation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Guillain-Barre Syndrome:
Incorrect: Guillain-Barre syndrome (GBS) can cause ascending muscle weakness and loss of reflexes. It occurs after an infection by pathogens such as Campylobacter jejuni. However, this patient has no history of recent infection, and her development of symptoms promptly following surgery makes another etiology more likely.

questions.text: A 3-week-old infant boy is brought to the emergency room for evaluation of non-bilious vomiting that is precipitated by feeding. He was born at 38-weeks gestational age to a 23-year-old, gravida 1 para 1, woman via a vaginal delivery. During pregnancy, the patient’s mother was diagnosed with Chlamydial cervicitis and prescribed azithromycin, which successfully treated the infection. Physical exam is notable for sunken anterior and posterior fontanelles. Abdominal exam is notable for a firm mass palpated in the right upper quadrant. Laboratory testing is ordered. Which of the following findings will most likely be present?
questions.solution:
This patient has pyloric stenosis, which is when an infant’s pyloric sphincter hypertrophies and causes gastric outlet obstruction. First-born males and maternal use of macrolide antibiotics while pregnant are risk factors.

Patients with hypertrophic pyloric stenosis have a normal gut function at birth. However, symptoms develop around two to six weeks of life. Patients can develop projectile vomiting after feeding. Of note, the vomitus is non-bilious, since bile is secreted into the duodenum, which is distal to the pyloric sphincter.    

Laboratory testing will reveal hypochloremic hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis. This pattern is because the loss of stomach acid (hydrochloric acid) leads to hypochloremia and dehydration. Dehydration activates the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS). This activation causes the kidneys to retain sodium and excrete potassium, resulting in hypokalemia. Hypokalemia causes the movement of potassium out of cells and hydrogen ions into cells, as well as secretion of hydrogen ions and reabsorption of bicarbonate ions in the kidneys. The net result is metabolic alkalosis.    

Patients will have an “olive-shaped” mass in the right upper abdominal quadrant. Ultrasound is used to confirm the condition. Treatment involves pyloromyotomy, which is when the pylorus muscle is surgically cut.

Option Analysis

✅   Serum pH  Serum Potassium   Serum Chloride  7.50  3.3  90  :
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌   Serum pH  Serum Potassium   Serum Chloride  7.50  5.3  90  :
Incorrect: Vomiting of gastric contents can cause volume depletion and activate the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone-system. This system increases sodium reuptake and potassium excretion in the kidney’s collecting tubules. The net result is hypokalemia.
❌  Serum pH  Serum Potassium   Serum Chloride  7.40  4.0  100 :
Incorrect: These are normal lab findings, which may be seen in patients with mild vomiting. However, this patient most likely has severe vomiting given he has signs of dehydration (e.g., sunken fontanelles). As a result, a hypochloremic hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis would most likely be present.
❌  Serum pH  Serum Potassium   Serum Chloride  7.30  3.3  90  :
Incorrect: Conditions such as diarrhea may cause bicarbonate loss and result in a metabolic acidosis. However, the patient in this vignette has repeated vomiting, which will most likely cause a metabolic alkalosis due to gastric acid loss and activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone-system.
❌  Serum pH  Serum Potassium   Serum Chloride  7.30  5.3  90  :
Incorrect: Vomiting contributes to volume depletion and subsequent activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone-system. Aldosterone increases sodium uptake and potassium excretion in the kidney’s collecting tubules, resulting in hypokalemia. Aldosterone also increases hydrogen ion excretion by the kidneys, resulting in a metabolic alkalosis.

questions.text: An 11-month-old girl is brought to the pediatrician for a routine visit. The parents have no acute complaints, and the patient has been meeting developmental milestones. Family history is notable for hypertension in her father and an atrial septal defect in her older brother. The rest of the history is noncontributory. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination is notable for a III/VI harsh, holosystolic murmur most prominent at the left lower sternal border. Pulmonary and abdominal examination is unremarkable. Review of the patient’s medical record reveals that no murmur was heard at the time of birth. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s findings?

choices.text: Impaired growth of the septum primum
Failure of the ductus arteriosus to close
Anterosuperior displacement of the interventricular septum
Incomplete development of the interventricular septum
Incomplete closure of the mitral valve during systole

questions.solution:
This infant with examination finding of harsh, holosystolic murmur most prominent at the left lower sternal border without accompanying symptoms (e.g. cyanosis) most likely has a ventricular septal defect (VSD).  

Ventricular septal defects arise due to impaired development or fusion of the two portions of interventricular septum. One is a membranous portion, which is the upper one-third, and the other is a muscular portion, which is the lower two-thirds. Defects usually occur in the membranous portion. Most VSDs are small and close on their own.    

Individuals with VSDs are asymptomatic at birth but can develop symptoms several weeks later. This delay is because after delivery, there is a gradual decline in pulmonary vascular resistance which results in a decrease in right ventricular pressure. Blood is then able to pass more readily from the left heart through the VSD into the right heart, producing a holosystolic murmur.  

On auscultation, the murmur can be heard at the left lower sternal border. Of note, the smaller the defect, the louder the murmur. This finding is because when blood rushes through a narrower opening, it produces more turbulence and hence more noise. In addition, because the defect allows oxygenated blood to move into the right heart, cardiac catheterization will show increased oxygen saturation in the right ventricle and pulmonary artery.  

Option Analysis

❌ Impaired growth of the septum primum :
Incorrect: This answer describes an atrial septal defect (ASD). ASDs present with a fixed-split S2 sound and a murmur loudest at the left upper sternal border. In contrast, this patient has a harsh, holosystolic murmur that is most prominent at the left lower sternal border. 
❌ Failure of the ductus arteriosus to close :
Incorrect: This answer describes a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA), which usually presents with a continuous machine-like murmur most prominent at the left infraclavicular area. It would be atypical for PDA to instead cause a holosystolic murmur at the left lower sternal border. 
❌ Anterosuperior displacement of the interventricular septum :
Incorrect: This pathology would result in Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF). One finding in TOF is a ventricular septal defect with a right-to-left shunt. Patients with TOF can have episodes of cyanosis triggered by crying or exercise. Although this patient’s murmur is consistent with that of a VSD, she lacks the other history and physical examination findings of TOF or a right-to-left shunt.  
✅ Incomplete development of the interventricular septum :
Correct: See Main Explanation 
❌ Incomplete closure of the mitral valve during systole :
Incorrect: This pathology results in mitral regurgitation, which causes a systolic murmur loudest over the cardiac apex (5th intercostal space at the midclavicular line) that radiates to the axilla. In contrast, this patient’s murmur is loudest over the left lower sternal border.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl is brought to the pediatrician for evaluation of leg pain that is exacerbated by exercise. The patient reports having difficulty keeping up with her classmates while playing soccer at school. She has not started having menses. Her mother had menarche at the age of 12. The patient’s temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 14/min. Upper extremity blood pressure is 140/81 mmHg, and lower extremity blood pressure is 118/70 mmHg. Physical examination reveals a low posterior hairline, Tanner stage I breasts and webbed neck.  Which of the following additional examination findings will most likely be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient with symptoms of claudication and hypotension in lower extremities most likely has coarctation of aorta (CoA). The history of primary amenorrhea, together with examination findings of  low posterior hairline, Tanner stage I breasts and webbed neck strongly suggest Turner syndrome, which is associated with increased risk of developing CoA.  

CoA can be divided into two types: preductal and postductal. The preductal type occurs when aortic narrowing occurs before the ductus arteriosus. This type causes right-to-left shunting of blood, which usually presents with differential cyanosis between the upper and lower extremities. The postductal type occurs when aortic narrowing occurs after the ductus arteriosus. This type does not cause shunting and thus is acyanotic.  

Both types of CoA can cause upper extremity hypertension. In addition, if too little blood reaches the legs, patients can develop claudication that is exacerbated by exercise. Another finding is rib notching. This finding arises because the anterior intercostal arteries come from the internal thoracic artery, a branch of the right subclavian, and the posterior intercostals come from the descending aorta. This anatomy can thus provide a collateral circulation to bypass the aortic narrowing. However, the problem is these intercostal arteries are now under high pressure, resulting in dilation. These dilated arteries rub up against the ribs, and over time, the ribs can develop notches that are visible on chest x-ray. 

Option Analysis

✅ Rib notching :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Thymic aplasia :
Incorrect: DiGeorge syndrome arises from defects in the 3rd and 4th branchial arches. It can cause thymic aplasia. However, the condition is not associated with CoA. 
❌ Upslanting palpebral fissures :
Incorrect: This feature is seen in trisomy 21 (Down syndrome). Cardiovascular anomalies that are associated with trisomy 21 include endocardial cushion defects (e.g., atrial or ventricular septal defect), patent ductus arteriosus and tetralogy of Fallot. However, trisomy 21 is not associated with CoA. 
❌ Pectus carinatum :
Incorrect: This condition is a rare malformation characterized by protrusion of the sternum and ribs. It is associated with connective tissue disorders such as Marfan or Ehlers-Danlos syndrome. However, these conditions are not associated with CoA, which is the most likely underlying cause of the patient’s leg pain and upper extremity hypertension.  
❌ Smooth hypoplastic philtrum :
Incorrect: A smooth hypoplastic philtrum is seen in fetal alcohol syndrome. The condition can cause cardiac defects ranging from ventricular septal defects to patent ductus arteriosus. However, it is not associated with CoA.

questions.text: A 51-year-old man comes to his physician for a routine preventative examination. The patient’s past medical history is significant for coronary artery disease and hypertension. His current medications include hydrochlorothiazide, atorvastatin, and daily aspirin. His diet consists mainly of processed red meats with minimal vegetables and fruits. He consumes 1 glass of wine with his dinner daily. In the office, his blood pressure is 126/84 mmHg, pulse is 80/min, respiratory rate is 17/min, and body mass index (BMI) is 34 kg/m2. The patient’s sister recently died from colorectal cancer, and he wants to know what is his own risk of developing this disease. Which of the following in this patient’s current lifestyle is protective against colorectal cancer?
questions.solution:
Colorectal cancer (CRC) is the third most common cancer worldwide. It most commonly affects individuals over 50-years-old, and in 25% of cases, there is a positive family history. The condition most commonly manifests in the rectosigmoid region, then ascending colon, and rarely the descending colon.  

Risk factors for colorectal cancer include hereditary factors (e.g. familial adenomatous polyposis) as well as the presence of adenomatous and serrated polyps on colonoscopy. Lifestyle factors, such as obesity, smoking, alcohol consumption, physical inactivity, and dietary factors, which include high consumption of processed red meat and decreased consumption of fiber, are associated with increased risk of CRC.    

Increased cyclooxygenase-2 (COX-2) activity is also linked to some forms of colon adenocarcinoma. The proposed theory is that COX-induced prostaglandin production leads to epithelial proliferation. Therefore, frequent use of COX enzyme inhibitors, such as NSAIDs and aspirin, can lower the risk of developing colorectal cancer. Furthermore, is associated with a decreased risk of CRC. This association is due to butyrate, a substance with antineoplastic properties which is synthesized by the gut microbiota as dietary fiber transits through the colon.  



Option Analysis

✅ Daily aspirin intake:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Low-fiber diet:
Incorrect: Increased fiber consumption is associated with a decreased risk of developing colorectal cancer. This patient consumes minimal fruits and vegetables (high fiber-containing foods), which increases his risk of developing colorectal cancer. 
❌ Consumption of red meat:
Incorrect: Long-term consumption of red meat or processed meats is associated with an increased risk of colorectal cancer. The proposed reason is that high temperature cooking (e.g., barbecuing, pan-frying) produces polyaromatic hydrocarbons and other carcinogens. 
❌ Obesity:
Incorrect: Obesity and type II diabetes mellitus are associated with an increased risk of colorectal cancer. Insulin is an important growth factor for colonic mucosal cells and stimulates colonic tumor cells. Patients with insulin resistance are likely to have increased serum insulin levels and hence an increased risk for colorectal cancer. 
❌ Statin use:
Incorrect: Statins are lipid-lowering drugs used to treat conditions such as coronary artery disease and hyperlipidemia. However, statins have not been shown to reduce the risk of colorectal cancer.

questions.text:
A pathologist is examining brain biopsies from a patient who died from a neurodegenerative condition following an episode of aspiration pneumonia. A tissue sample from the patient is demonstrated below:



Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

Further staining reveals patchy red plaques that become yellow when viewed under polarized light. Which of the following clinical courses was most likely seen in this patient?

choices.text: Early memory loss followed by behavioral changes
Early behavioral changes followed by memory loss
Rapidly progressive memory loss and behavioral changes

questions.solution:
The brain biopsy shows numerous plaques that stain with Congo red and demonstrate birefringence when viewed under polarized light. As a result, this biopsy sample was likely from a patient who had Alzheimer disease (AD). In AD, deposition of extracellular beta-amyloid protein plaques (yellow circles) and intracellular neurofibrillary tangles causes neuronal degeneration. Most patients are in their 70-80s when symptoms develop. The disease typically has three phases:

  1.  The asymptomatic phase is when the molecular pathology of AD is present in the brain, but clinical symptoms have not yet manifested. 
  2.  The predementia phase is characterized by mild cognitive impairment. There is a gradual onset of memory impairment without significant deficits in other cognitive domains or daily functioning. This phase differs from normal aging because the memory impairment is greater than expected for the individual’s age.
  3. The dementia phase is when individuals develop significant memory loss, followed by slow, gradual loss of the other cognitive functions (e.g, language, visuospatial skills, executive functions). There are two main types of memory: episodic memory (memory of events) and semantic memory (memory of words and vocabulary). Early on, episodic memory is impaired and semantic memory remains intact. With disease progression, both episodic and semantic memory become impaired. Behavioral changes also occur in advanced stages, resulting in apathy, agitation, irritability, and aggression. 




Option Analysis

✅ Early memory loss followed by behavioral changes:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Early behavioral changes followed by memory loss:
Incorrect: This clinical course is characteristic of frontotemporal dementia. Initial neuronal degeneration in the frontal lobe results in social disinhibition and behavioral changes. As neuronal damage and loss progresses, there are profound memory deficits. However, histopathology in patients with frontotemporal dementia would demonstrate Pick bodies (cytoplasmic inclusions of aggregated tau proteins) and hyperphosphorylated TDP-43, which are not present in this patient’s tissue sample.
❌ Rapidly progressive memory loss and behavioral changes:
Incorrect: Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CFD) is caused by prions and results in a rapidly progressive dementia. Histopathology would demonstrate spongiform degeneration as a result of neuronal loss and the formation of numerous vacuoles.
❌ Mild decline in cognitive functioning:
Incorrect: A mild decline in cognitive functioning is seen as a result of normal aging. Patients may have mild cortical atrophy, but the histopathological findings in this patient are more consistent with those of Alzheimer disease.
❌ Stepwise deterioration in cognition:
Incorrect: A stepwise decline in cognition is typically observed in patients with vascular dementia. The condition arises due to cerebral tissue ischemia and can be due to atherosclerosis, thrombosis, or vasculopathy.

questions.text: A heterosexual couple comes to the genetic counselor’s office for prenatal counseling. The woman has no significant past medical history, and her family history is not notable for any cancers. The man has a history of prophylactic colectomy at the age of 16 after a colonoscopy revealed hundreds of polyps. His father died at the age of 39 due to colorectal cancer, but his mother has been healthy. The couple is worried their children may also inherit this condition. What is the probability that this couple’s first child will inherit the disease?
questions.solution:
The male patient in this case had a prophylactic colectomy as a teenager and a first-degree relative who developed colon cancer at a young age. As a result, he most likely has familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP). FAP is an autosomal dominant disorder marked by the appearance of hundreds of colorectal adenomas by the teenage years. If untreated, most patients will die from colorectal cancer by the 4th decade of life.    

FAP is caused by mutations of the adenomatous polyposis coli (APC) gene located on chromosome 5. APC is a tumor suppressor protein that plays a central role in Wnt signaling by regulating the degradation of β-catenin. Normally, in the presence of wild-type APC protein, β-catenin is degraded. However when APC is mutated, β-catenin and its target genes (e.g. c-myc) are overexpressed, resulting in uncontrolled cellular proliferation and eventual progression to cancer. Therefore, patients with FAP should receive annual screening colonoscopies and, if polyps are found, undergo prophylactic colectomy.  

Since FAP is inherited in an autosomal dominant fashion, only 1 mutant copy of the APC gene is sufficient to cause the disorder. This man’s father likely passed on a mutant copy of APC to him, whereas his mother was unaffected, and thus passed on a normal copy of APC. A heterozygous parent, such as this man, has a 50% chance of transmitting the condition. Therefore, his future child has a 50% chance of inheriting FAP.
 

Option Analysis

✅ 50%:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ 25%:
Incorrect: Autosomal recessive diseases occur when an offspring inherits two copies of the mutated gene (one from each parent). If both parents are carriers, there is a 25% chance the child would inherit the condition. The man in this case likely has familial adenomatous polyposis, which is an autosomal dominant disease. 
❌ 0%:
Incorrect: This man likely has familial adenomatous polyposis, which is inherited in an autosomal dominant fashion. Therefore, there is significant probability that this couple’s future child will also have a similar condition. 
❌ 75%:
Incorrect: This man likely has familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP), which is caused by mutations in the APC gene and is inherited in an autosomal dominant fashion. The woman has a noncontributory family history and does not have the mutated gene. As a result, this couple’s child has a 50% chance of inheriting the mutated APC gene from the man and developing FAP.
❌ 100%:
Incorrect: If the man in this case had been homozygous for the autosomal dominant trait, there would be a 100% chance the offspring would inherit the condition. However, homozygosity is exceedingly rare. In addition, the man’s mother did not display symptoms of the disease, meaning he likely only inherited one mutant copy of the APC gene from his father.

questions.text: A 71-year-old woman is brought to the clinic by her partner due to worsening insomnia and cognitive impairment for the past 3 months. According to the husband, the patient had previously been able to drive to the grocery store and play racquetball. However, she is no longer able to complete these activities on her own. The patient has no history of psychiatric conditions, but her mother died from Alzheimer disease in her 80s. In the office, the patient’s temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 88/min, respirations are 13/min, and blood pressure is 122/84 mmHg. Physical exam reveals ataxic gait and an inability to follow multi-step instructions.  When a nearby door is shut loudly, the patient is startled, causing her arms to clench involuntarily. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to reveal which of the following findings?

choices.text: Elevated 14-3-3 protein in the cerebrospinal fluid
Enlarged ventricles with normal sulci on MRI of the brain
Diffuse 3-Hz spike and wave discharges on electroencephalography
Metabolic disorders in the frontal and temporal lobes on PET scan
Atrophy of the mammillary bodies on MRI of the brain

questions.solution:
Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD) is a rapidly progressive neurodegenerative illness that causes death within 1 year of symptom onset. Patients typically experience a prodromal phase characterized by vague, nonspecific symptoms, such as headaches, fatigue, and sleep disorders. Neuropsychiatric symptoms are consistently seen and manifest as dementia, behavioral abnormalities, and deficits involving higher cortical function (e.g. aphasia). Additionally, a characteristic physical exam finding seen in patients with CJD is startle myoclonus, wherein jerking or clenching movements of a muscle group are triggered by a loud sound (e.g. door slamming shut). Work-up of CJD involves several different modalities, including the following:  

  •  MRI imaging is the best initial test. Brain MRI excludes other potential causes of dementia and also can identify findings suggestive of CJD. On brain MRI, CJD classically presents with enhancement of the basal ganglia and thalamus. 
  •  Periodic sharp wave complexes are the hallmark EEG finding of CJD. The fusion of dendritic membranes of affected neurons results in increased electrotonic coupling and synchronized bursting activity. 
  •  Detection of protein 14-3-3 in cerebrospinal fluid is classically seen in patients with CJD, and it occurs due to acute neuronal damage. 
Ultimately, definitive diagnosis requires a post-mortem brain biopsy demonstrating spongiform encephalopathy.  



Option Analysis

✅ Elevated 14-3-3 protein in the cerebrospinal fluid:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Enlarged ventricles with normal sulci on MRI of the brain:
Incorrect: Normal pressure hydrocephalus is characterized by the triad of “wet, wacky and wobbly,” which describes the urinary incontinence, dementia, and gait disorder seen in this condition. Although this patient exhibits a gait disorder and dementia, her other clinical features (e.g., rapidly progressing dementia, startle myoclonus) suggest a different etiology. 
❌ Diffuse 3-Hz spike and wave discharges on electroencephalography:
Incorrect: Diffuse 3-Hz spike and wave discharges on electroencephalography (EEG) are characteristic of absence seizures, which are usually seen in pediatric patients. This condition is characterized by multiple, short periods of impaired consciousness with intact body tone. 
❌ Metabolic disorders in the frontal and temporal lobes on PET scan :
Incorrect: Frontotemporal dementia classically presents with early personality changes (e.g., apathy, disinhibition, irritability) followed by reduced cognitive functioning. MRI typically shows atrophy of the frontal and/or temporal lobes, as well as frontotemporal hypoperfusion or hypometabolism, which can be visualized on a PET scan.
❌ Atrophy of the mammillary bodies on MRI of the brain:
Incorrect: Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome is seen in patients with a history of chronic alcohol use disorder or severe malnourishment. The condition occurs due to destruction and atrophy of the mammillary bodies. Patients typically present with confusion, ataxia, ophthalmoplegia, and in severe cases, permanent amnesia.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman comes to the clinic for evaluation of painless swelling around the right side of the labia minora. The patient is in good health and does not use tobacco, alcohol, or illicit substances. Two-years ago, the patient was treated for a Chlamydia trachomatis infection. The patient’s temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 75/min, and blood pressure is 115/70 mmHg. Examination of the vulva reveals a 1 cm area of swelling and mild erythema on the posterior aspect of the labia majora. The affected area is located at the eight o'clock position with respect to the vaginal orifice. Which of the following structures is most likely affected in this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with localized, non-painful swelling on the posterior aspect of the labia minora at the eight o'clock position, which is suggestive of a greater vestibular gland cyst.    

The greater vestibular glands, also known as Bartholin glands, are pea-sized glands found on the posterior aspect of the labia majora at approximately 4 and 8 o'clock positions with respect to the vaginal orifice. These glands secrete mucus to lubricate the vagina. Bartholin gland cysts occur due to obstruction of the duct opening. These cysts may evolve into abscesses. Vulvar abscesses are usually due to mixed polymicrobial infections, consisting mainly of methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA), enteric gram-negative aerobes, and anaerobes.    

Patients with a Bartholin cyst typically present with a painless and asymptomatic mass. Larger cysts may lead to discomfort during sexual intercourse, sitting, or ambulating. Abscesses, however, are usually painful and may present with fever.  

Diagnosis is based on clinical presentation, and physical exam may reveal the presence of a mass in the lower medial labia minora or vulvar vestibule. Management of a Bartholin gland mass depends on its size and whether it is a cyst or abscess. In general, larger cysts or abscesses (≥3 cm) are an indication for incision and drainage, while smaller lesions may be treated with conservative therapy such as warm compresses or sitz baths. Antibiotics may be added for abscess treatment.


Option Analysis

❌ Hair follicle:
Incorrect: Hair follicle infections are common sites of infection and abscess formation. The mons pubis and labia majora are covered with hair but not the labia minora. While hair follicle infection is common, this patient’s lesion is located in the posterior aspect of the labia minora, which favors another diagnosis.  
❌  Paraurethral glands  :
Incorrect: Paraurethral glands (also known as the lesser vestibular glands or Skene glands) are located on the anterior vaginal wall, around the lower end of the urethra. These glands are responsible for the secretion of fluid that helps lubricate the urethral opening. In contrast, this patient’s lesion is located posterior to the vaginal opening, which instead raises greater concern for a Batholin gland cyst. 
✅ Greater vestibular glands:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Urethral mucosa:
Incorrect: A urethral diverticulum refers to the localized outpouching of the urethral mucosa. Patients may present with the classic triad of postvoid dribbling, dysuria, and dyspareunia. In addition, patients may experience recurrent urinary tract infections, hematuria, and increased urinary frequency. On physical examination, an anterior vaginal wall mass is often found. In contrast, this patient lacks the symptoms characteristic of a urethral diverticulum and has a lesion posterior to the vaginal opening. 
❌  Sebaceous glands  :
Incorrect: Sebaceous gland cysts, also known as epidermal inclusion cysts, are caused by an accumulation of the squamous epithelium below the epidermis due to obstruction of the pilosebaceous ducts or secondary to trauma. They are often found on the vulva. The cysts vary in size, are typically round, and are skin-colored, yellow, or white. This patient’s lesion and location favor another diagnosis.

questions.text: A 41-year-old woman comes to her primary care physician for a follow-up visit. At her prior visit several months ago, the patient had persistent hypertension, with a blood pressure measured at 153/89 mmHg. Laboratory testing showed an elevated aldosterone-to-renin ratio. Abdominal imaging revealed an adrenal adenoma located in the zona glomerulosa of the adrenal cortex. The patient’s blood pressure at this current visit is 156/87 mmHg. This patient most likely has which of the following additional symptoms?

choices.text: Pitting edema of the lower extremities

questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with persistent hypertension and an elevated aldosterone-to-renin ratio. Imaging reveals an adrenal tumor in the zona glomerulosa. In combination, these findings are concerning for an aldosteronoma.

Hyperaldosteronism secondary to an aldosterone-secreting adrenal adenoma is termed Conn syndrome. The most important clinical consequence of hyperaldosteronism is hypertension. The high levels of aldosterone will lead to hypokalemia, hypernatremia, and metabolic alkalosis. Significant hypokalemia may occur in some affected individuals, resulting in muscular aches and weakness, muscle spasms, numbness, and heart palpitations.

Additionally, Conn syndrome does not usually cause edema because of an “aldosterone escape” mechanism. The mechanism occurs since the surge in blood volume secondary to hyperaldosteronism stimulates the atria of the heart to release high levels of atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP). The ANP then leads to compensatory diuresis and “escape” from edema and severe hypernatremia.





 

Option Analysis

✅ Muscle weakness:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Episodic palpitations and diaphoresis:
Incorrect: Pheochromocytomas are neoplasms of chromaffin cells in the adrenal medulla that overproduce catecholamines (e.g., epinephrine, norepinephrine). Although pheochromocytomas can also cause hypertension, they are associated with paroxysmal episodes of hypertension, diaphoresis, and palpitations. In contrast, this patient has persistent hypertension.
❌ Scattered ecchymoses:
Incorrect: Cushing syndrome, which can arise due to an adrenal tumor in the zona fasciculata (not zona glomerulosa), would result in hypercortisolism. Cushing syndrome can also present with hypertension. Moreover, the excess cortisol would cause weight gain, muscle atrophy, and collagen loss resulting in thin, fragile skin that is easily bruised. However, this patient has a tumor in the zona glomerulosa, which is more concerning for an aldosteronoma.
❌ Pitting edema of the lower extremities:
Incorrect: Hyperaldosteronism does not usually cause edema due to the “aldosterone escape” mechanism. The mechanism occurs since a surge in blood volume secondary to hyperaldosteronism stimulates the atria of the heart to release high levels of atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP). The ANP then leads to compensatory diuresis and “escape” from edema and severe hypernatremia.
❌ Bitemporal hemianopsia:
Incorrect: Pituitary tumors can compress the optic chiasm and result in bitemporal hemianopsia. However, this patient has an elevated aldosterone-to-renin ratio and CT imaging showing an adrenal mass. As a result, his symptoms are more likely due to an aldosterone-producing adrenal tumor.

questions.text: A 66-year-old man comes to the emergency department for evaluation of sensory disturbance to the right half of his body. The patient was gardening when he suddenly developed right arm and leg numbness. He does not have weakness, urinary incontinence, or loss of vision. His past medical history includes hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and a 25 pack year smoking history. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 92/min, and blood pressure is 178/98 mmHg. The patient reports 50% sensation to light touch of the right upper extremity and right lower extremity when compared to 100% sensation to light touch in the left upper and left lower extremity. Strength testing is intact throughout. Noncontrast head CT shows no abnormalities. This patient's clinical presentation reflects pathology to which of the following vascular structures?
questions.solution:
This patient with uncontrolled hypertension presents for evaluation of right-sided numbness and absent motor deficits -- suggesting a stroke of the thalamus, supplied by the lenticulostriate arteries. Acutely, these strokes are difficult to visualize on CT-imaging, and clinical suspicion should guide the physician towards advanced imaging via MRI.

Strokes of the basal ganglia, also called lacunar strokes are most commonly caused by ischemia of the lenticulostriate arteries -- a collection of small perforating arteries supplying the basal ganglia and arising from the anterior circle of Willis. After a lacunar stroke, the damaged brain tissue develops fluid-filled cysts, which look like little lakes (“lacunae”).

Lacunar strokes are most commonly initiated by atherosclerosis and arteriosclerosis from untreated hypertension, diabetes, and smoking. These conditions result in a type of arteriosclerosis called hyaline arteriolosclerosis where the arteriole walls fill with protein, reducing the size of the lumen, and causing ischemia to downstream tissue. Symptoms of lacunar strokes can vary based on anatomic location, as seen in the chart below.



Option Analysis

❌ Middle cerebral artery:
Incorrect: An ischemic stroke of the middle cerebral artery (MCA) is characterized by contralateral motor and/or sensorimotor deficits, with the upper limbs being more affected than the lower limbs. If the dominant lobe is affected, the patient may demonstrate aphasia, whereas if the non-dominant lobe is affected, the patient may demonstrate hemineglect.
✅ Lenticulostriate arteries:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Anterior cerebral artery:
Incorrect: An ischemic stroke of the anterior cerebral artery (ACA) is characterized by contralateral motor and/or sensorimotor deficits, with the lower limbs being more affected than the upper limbs. Patients often present with concomitant urinary incontinence, limb apraxia, and emotional disturbance.
❌ Basilar artery:
Incorrect: An ischemic stroke of the basilar artery has a range of clinical presentations; some patients may present with vertebrobasilar insufficiency (e.g., vertigo, drop attacks, tinnitus), whereas others may present with locked-in syndrome (e.g. loss of movement of the extremities) if the pons is affected.
❌ Posterior inferior cerebellar artery:
Incorrect: An ischemic stroke of the posterior inferior cerebellar artery artery results in Wallenberg syndrome, which is characterized by ipsilateral Horner syndrome, dysphagia, hemiataxia, and contralateral sensory disturbances.

questions.text: A 77-year-old right-handed woman is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of increasing confusion and altered mental status. The patient has a history of transient ischemic attack last year without residual deficits, as well as hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and diabetes mellitus. Vital signs are within normal limits. The patient is alert and oriented to self and place only. When asked to write her name, the patient is unable to do so. Non-contrast CT-brain is performed, which demonstrates an acute  infarct in the inferior left parietal lobe. Which of the following associated clinical findings is most likely to be observed in this patient?
questions.solution:
This elderly patient with multiple risk factors for acute stroke is found to have an acute infarct of the inferior left parietal lobe in the region of the angular gyrus. If the dominant parietal hemisphere is affected, Gerstmann syndrome develops, which is characterized by a tetrad of symptoms (known as the four A’s), including:

  •  Finger agnosia refers to the patient unable to recognize different fingers on their own or another person’s hands. 
  •  Agraphia, or inability to write. 
  •  Alexia, or inability to read.
  •  Acalculia, or inability to do simple calculations. 

If the non-dominant parietal hemisphere is affected, hemispatial neglect syndrome occurs, wherein agnosia, or reduced awareness of the contralateral side of the body, ensues.


Option Analysis

✅ Acalculia and finger agnosia:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Emotional lability and aggressive behavior:
Incorrect: Emotional lability and aggressive behavior are associated with damage to the prefrontal cortex (e.g., trauma, frontotemporal dementia) not the posterior parietal lobe. 
❌ Homonymous hemianopsia:
Incorrect: Homonymous hemianopia occurs with lesions affecting the occipital lobe, not the parietal lobe.
❌ Expressive aphasia:
Incorrect: The Broca speech area is located in the inferior frontal gyrus of the dominant hemisphere (left in this patient, based on her handedness). When damaged, the result is Broca aphasia, also known as motor aphasia, due to the inability to express thoughts in a meaningful manner, while comprehension remains intact.
❌ Upper visual quadrantanopia:
Incorrect: A lesion to the inferior bank of the calcarine sulcus will cause upper quadrantanopia, not a lesion to the inferior parietal lobe.

questions.text: A 10-year-old girl is brought to the pediatrician due to progressive vaginal pruritus and painful defecation that began one-month ago. The itching often awakens her at night. She is generally healthy and has reached all childhood developmental milestones. She has not yet had a menstrual period. In the office, her temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 71/min, and blood pressure is 110/72 mmHg. On physical examination, the patient is Tanner stage 1. Vaginal examination shows multiple white, atrophic papules and plaques that cover the labia minora and extend to the perineum. Multiple hemorrhagic foci are also noted. Rectal examination reveals an anal fissure. This patient’s condition is associated with which of the following?
questions.solution:
This premenarchal girl is presenting with vaginal pruritus, multiple white, atrophic, papules and plaques over the labia major, and an anal fissure. She most likely has lichen sclerosis.  

Lichen sclerosis is a benign, chronic dermatologic disorder typified by inflammation, epithelial thinning, and dermal changes. Patients may present with vulvar pruritus, anal discomfort (anal fissure or painful defection), dyspareunia, and dysuria. The lesions are usually white, atrophic papules that may fuse into plaques. The lesions are sometimes described as porcelain-white paper-like plaques. The lesions commonly affect the labia minora and/or labia majora and may extend to the perineum. Scratching can cause secondary hemorrhage and hyperkeratosis.    

The condition may occur at any age but usually follows a bimodal distribution; one peak is seen in prepubertal girls and a second in peri/postmenopausal women. Both of these are physiologically low-estrogen states. The condition is also associated with genetic factors (runs in families), autoimmune conditions, and local factors (skin graft). Patients with vulvar lichen sclerosis are at increased risk of developing squamous cell cancer of the vulva, and therefore diagnostic biopsy is recommended in adult patients. Treatment usually includes a highly potent topical corticosteroid ointment, such as clobetasol.   

Option Analysis

✅ Low estrogen levels :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Low fiber diet :
Incorrect: Constipation due to a low-fiber diet can result in anal fissure formation and painful defecation. However, it would not account for the vulvar itching or the plaques observed on physical examination. 
❌ Mite infestation of the skin:
Incorrect: Sarcoptes scabiei is a mite capable of infesting the skin and causing intense pruritus. The condition commonly affects the webs of the fingers, wrists, axillae, areolae, and genitalia. Typical skin findings include multiple small, erythematous, papules and burrows. This patient is presenting only with vulvar and perineal lesions, which makes scabies less likely. Moreover, a scabies infection would likely spread to other members of her household, and they would experience similar symptoms.  
❌ Chronic irritation :
Incorrect: Lichen simplex chronicus refers to non-neoplastic hyperplasia of vulvar squamous epithelium caused by chronic irritation. It typically presents as leathery, thick vulvar skin from scratching. This patient’s lesion is atrophic, which favors another diagnosis. Moreover, lichen simplex chronicus is usually a diagnosis of exclusion.  
❌ Viral infection:
Incorrect: Condylomata acuminata, also known as anogenital warts, is caused by human papillomavirus (HPV) infection. The most common strains are HPV types 6 and 11. The lesions typically manifest as soft cauliflower-shaped, white/skin-colored/erythematous growths on the external genitalia. In contrast, it would be atypical for anogenital warts to manifest as atrophic papules and plaques.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old man comes to the office because of watery diarrhea and right lower quadrant pain. The symptoms started 3 months ago and are not relieved by over-the-counter antidiarrheals. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. Physical examination shows tenderness to deep palpation in the right lower quadrant.
