There is no rebound tenderness. Rovsing sign is negative. Colonoscopy reveals focal ulcerations adjacent to areas of normal appearing mucosa along with nodular mucosal changes in the colon. Biopsy findings of the involved tissue sample are shown.


 Retrieved from: Wikimedia Commons  

Which of the following cell types are the most involved in the formation of this lesion?
questions.solution:
The clinical manifestations of chronic watery diarrhea and right lower quadrant pain, together with colonoscopy findings of skip lesions (focal ulcerations adjacent to areas of normal appearing mucosa) and biopsy evidence of a noncaseating granuloma, are diagnostic of Crohn disease, an inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) mainly mediated by Th1 cells.

Crohn disease is characterized by immune-mediated transmural inflammation that can occur anywhere in the gastrointestinal (GI) tract from the mouth to anus, though it usually involves the terminal ileum and colon. The damage is primarily mediated by Th1 cells, which secrete large amounts of interferon-gamma (IFN-γ) and interleukin-2 (IL-2), and macrophages, which release tumor necrosis factor alpha (TNF-ɑ) and other cytokines (e.g., IL-6, IL-12), likely in response to self-antigens. Macrophages help in Th1 cell differentiation, while Th1 cells promote further T-cell response, activation of macrophages, and differentiation of macrophages into giant cells. The end-result is formation of noncaseating granulomas containing epithelioid macrophages, which may fuse to form multinucleated giant cells, surrounded by a band of lymphocytes, as seen in the biopsy image. Although these granulomas are actually only seen in a minority of patients with CD, when they are present, they are highly suggestive of the diagnosis.



Option Analysis

✅ T helper 1 (Th1) cells:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ T helper 2 (Th2) cells:
Incorrect: Th2 cells are mainly involved in the pathogenesis of ulcerative colitis (UC) by producing IL-5 and IL-13 which contribute to inflammation and damage of the intestinal mucosa. Enhanced Th2 (humoral) immunity in UC is evidenced by high levels of immunoglobulins and autoantibodies.
❌ Neutrophils:
Incorrect: Neutrophils are mainly involved in phagocytosis, and as such they instead play an active role in nonspecific inflammatory processes in response to injury or infection.
❌ B-lymphocytes:
Incorrect: B-lymphocytes transform into plasma cells which actively secrete antibodies that are involved in humoral immunity. However, noncaseating granulomas are mainly formed by cell-mediated immunity.
❌ Eosinophils:
Incorrect: Eosinophils mediates defense reactions against helminthic infections. They are also implicated in the pathogenesis of hypersensitivity reactions, eosinophilic vasculitis and a few types of Hodgkin lymphoma, but they are not actively involved in pathogenesis of IBD.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of shortness of breath and a cough productive of blood-tinged sputum for 3 days. She had a similar episode several weeks ago and was prescribed antibiotics by her family doctor with minimal improvement. Over the past 2 months, she has experienced mild fever, malaise, and weight loss as well as persistent red-tinged rhinorrhea. She does not smoke cigarettes or use illicit drugs. Temperature is 38.0°C (100.4°F), pulse is 92/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 110/68 mm Hg. Physical examination shows nasal crusting and multiple ulcer formations in the nasal cavity. Laboratory studies show an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR). Urinalysis shows dysmorphic red cells and red blood cell casts. Which of the following antibodies is most likely to be found in the patient's serum?
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of fatigue, weight loss, and persistent bloody rhinorrhea is now presenting with shortness of breath and a productive bloody cough. Her presentation, in conjunction with the urinalysis results and unresponsiveness to antibiotic therapy, is consistent with granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA). GPA, formerly referred to as Wegener granulomatosis, is a systemic autoimmune disorder that belongs to the antineutrophil cytoplasmic autoantibody (ANCA)-associated vasculitides (together with microscopic polyangiitis and eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis). It mainly affects small- and medium-sized vessels throughout the body.    

Classic signs and symptoms are involvement of 3 systems: the upper respiratory tract (e.g. saddle nose deformity, nasal mucosal ulceration, otitis media), lower respiratory tract (e.g.. hemoptysis, lung nodules), and the kidneys (glomerulonephritis, hematuria). Lung involvement that does not resolve with antibiotic therapy should raise a suspicion of a non-infectious etiology.    

Patients with vasculitis have circulating antibodies that react with neutrophil cytoplasmic antigens termed “antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies” (ANCAs). ANCAs are a heterogeneous group of autoantibodies directed against neutrophil primary granules elements (mainly enzymes). Anti-proteinase-3 (PR3-ANCA), previously called c-ANCA, is a neutrophil azurophilic granule component that shares similar structure with numerous microbial peptides, possibly explaining the generation of these antibodies. PR3-ANCAs are associated with granulomatosis with polyangiitis.




Option Analysis

❌ Anti-centromere antibodies:
Incorrect: Anti-centromere antibodies are associated with limited scleroderma, which classically presents with CREST syndrome; CREST is an acronym for Calcinosis, Raynaud phenomenon, Esophageal dysmotility, Sclerodactyly, and Telangiectasia, none of which are seen in this patient. 
❌ Anti-myeloperoxidase antibodies:
Incorrect: Anti-myeloperoxidase antibodies (MPO-ANCA) are associated with microscopic polyangiitis. It is an autoimmune condition characterized by a systemic, pauci-immune, necrotizing, small-vessel vasculitis without evidence of necrotizing granulomatous inflammation. Presentation is similar to granulomatosis with polyangiitis; however, ear-nose-throat involvement is more common in the latter.  
✅ Anti-proteinase-3 antibodies:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Anti-dsDNA antibodies:
Incorrect: Anti-dsDNA is associated with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), an autoimmune condition with a vast range of manifestations. Common symptoms include systemic signs (fever, fatigue), painful and swollen joints, mouth ulcers, lymphadenopathy, characteristic malar rash on the face, and photosensitivity. The kidneys are often involved in SLE; however, ear-nose-throat involvement, as seen in this patient, is not expected.     
❌ Anti-mitochondrial antibodies:
Incorrect: Anti-mitochondrial antibodies are associated with primary biliary cirrhosis. This condition is an autoimmune pathology characterized by progressive destruction of the small bile ducts of the liver. Patients often present with fatigue, pruritus, and jaundice.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old man comes to the clinic due to fatigue, cough and episodic blood in his urine during the past 6 months. He states he “hasn’t been feeling like myself lately.” Over the past 2 months, he has had a chronic cough which he attributed to an upper respiratory infection. His medical history is insignificant, and he does not smoke or use illicit drugs. On physical examination, wheezing is heard diffusely over the lung fields. Examination of the lower extremities reveals diffuse palpable purpura. Laboratory studies are obtained and shown below:  
 
 Laboratory value  Result 
 Serum 
 Antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody (ANCA)  Positive 
 Urine  
 Protein   2.5 g/24-hr 
 Creatinine  1.9 mg/dL 
 Erythrocytes  10/hpf 
 
Arterial biopsy of an affected region reveals focal transmural necrotizing lesions without granulomatous inflammation. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presenting with constitutional symptoms, lung involvement, and nephritic syndrome, in association with a positive test for antineutrophil cytoplasmic autoantibody (ANCA) and biopsy showing vasculitis without granulomas, most likely has microscopic polyangiitis (MPA). It is a type of small-vessel necrotizing vasculitis characterized by fatigue, fever, weight loss, arthralgias, rhinosinusitis, cough, dyspnea, renal insufficiency, purpura, and neurologic dysfunction.  

MPA is a subtype of ANCA-associated vasculitides which include granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA), microscopic polyangiitis (MPA), and eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (EGPA). Presentation of ANCA-associated vasculitides can be similar, and biopsy can assist in establishing the diagnosis. Biopsy showing necrotizing vasculitis without granulomas supports the diagnosis of MPA. Other distinguishing factors include nasopharyngeal involvement (e.g. nasal septum) seen mostly in GPA, and atopic history seen in eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis. ANCA-associated vasculitides are often termed pauci-immune due to the absence of immune complexes under immunofluorescence and electron microscopy.

Option Analysis

❌ Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis:
Incorrect: Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis is another antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody-associated vasculitis that presents with similar symptoms as seen in this patient. However, patients typically have atopic history (e.g., asthma, allergy), and granulomas are usually seen on biopsy. 
❌ Immunoglobulin A vasculitis:
Incorrect: Immunoglobulin A vasculitis (Henoch-Schönlein purpura) is usually seen in children due to IgA immune complex deposition following an upper respiratory tract infection. Typical presentation includes palpable purpura, arthralgias and abdominal pain. This condition is not associated with antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies. 
❌ Acute postinfectious glomerulonephritis:
Incorrect: Acute postinfectious glomerulonephritis is a cause of nephritic syndrome usually seen after streptococcal throat infection or skin infection. The condition is usually limited to the kidneys and presents with hypertension and edema, rather than pulmonary symptoms. Additionally, it is not associated with antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies. 
❌ Granulomatosis with polyangiitis :
Incorrect: Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener granulomatosis) is another antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody-associated vasculitis that can present with similar symptoms as seen in this patient. However, granulomas would be seen on biopsy, and patients usually present with nasopharyngeal involvement.  
❌ Behçet syndrome:
Incorrect: Behçet syndrome is a type of small-vessel immune complex vasculitis. Presentation includes recurrent aphthous ulcers, genital ulcerations, uveitis, and erythema nodosum. The condition is associated with HLA-B51, not antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies. 
✅ Microscopic polyangiitis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Giant cell arteritis:
Incorrect: Giant cell (temporal) arteritis is a large-vessel vasculitis usually seen in patients over the age of 50. It typically involves the branches of the carotid artery and presents with unilateral headache, possible temporal artery tenderness, and jaw claudication. It is not associated with antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies, and renal involvement is not common.

questions.text:
A 48-year-old woman presents to the emergency department for evaluation of intractable vomiting for the past 24 hours. Last night she ate a hamburger from a local restaurant, and since then she has had multiple episodes of bilious emesis. Past medical history is significant for osteoarthritis and hypertension. Current medications include ibuprofen and lisinopril. Her temperature is 36.6°C (97.8° F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 21/min, and blood pressure is 101/62 mm Hg. Physical examination demonstrates decreased skin turgor and dry oral mucosa. A liver function assay is within normal limits. The remainder of the laboratory studies are shown below.  

 Laboratory value  Result 
 Complete blood count 
 Hemoglobin  13 g/dL 
 Leukocytes  10,000 /mL 
 Platelets  330,000/mm3 
 Serum chemistry 
 Sodium  136 mEq/L 
 Potassium  2.8 mEq/L 
 Chloride  85 mEq/L 
 Bicarbonate  29 mEq/L 
 Creatinine  1.7 mg/dL 
 Blood urea nitrogen (BUN)  40 mg/dL 
 Urinalysis 
 Erythrocytes  1-2/hpf 
 Leukocytes  1-2/hpf 
 Fractional excretion of sodium (FENa)  <1% 
 Urine osmolality  650 mOsm/kg 
 Sediment  None 
   
Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient's clinical condition?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation of tachycardia, hypotension, and volume depletion due to intractable vomiting, together with the BUN:Cr >20, is strongly suggestive of prerenal acute kidney injury (AKI). Acute kidney injury refers to an abrupt decline in renal function, resulting in a decrease in glomerular filtration rate, and subsequent accumulation of nitrogenous waste products.  

AKI is divided into three categories dependent on the site of injury: prerenal AKI (e.g., bleeding, volume depletion, sepsis), intrarenal AKI (e.g., acute tubular necrosis, glomerulonephritis, or interstitial nephritis) or post-renal AKI (e.g., BPH, stones, malignancy). The etiology of renal injury can be determined via clinical history as well as via assessment of urine osmolality, urine sodium, FENa, and the serum BUN/Cr.
 
 Patients with prerenal AKI have reduced renal perfusion, and in an attempt to conserve the glomerular filtration rate (GFR), the kidney reabsorbs more sodium (leading to a FeNa<1%) and urea. Creatinine, however, is not reabsorbed, and thus the BUN/Cr ratio is >20. Since the kidney absorbs water to maintain GFR, the urine becomes highly concentrated, with osmolality >500 mOsm/kg. Irrespective of etiology, untreated AKI can lead to several complications including anemia, pericarditis and encephalopathy. 

Option Analysis

❌ Hemolytic uremic syndrome:
Incorrect: Hemolytic uremic syndrome occurs in response to shiga-like toxin-producing organisms and presents with a triad of acute kidney injury, hemolytic anemia and thrombocytopenia 1-2 weeks following a diarrheal illness. Although this patient’s serum chemistry is indicative of acute kidney injury, there is no evidence of anemia or thrombocytopenia.  
✅ Prerenal azotemia:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Hepatorenal syndrome:
Incorrect: Hepatorenal syndrome refers to acute kidney injury secondary to portal hypertension and  chronic liver disease. Although this patient’s serum chemistry is indicative of acute kidney injury, a normal liver function assay makes this diagnosis unlikely. 
❌ Renal papillary necrosis:
Incorrect: Although renal papillary necrosis can occur in the setting of chronic analgesic use, urinalysis usually demonstrates hematuria and proteinuria. Moreover, this patient’s increased BUN:Cr (>20) in the setting of volume depletion, suggests a prerenal (not intrarenal) cause of acute kidney injury. 
❌ Acute interstitial nephritis:
Incorrect: Acute interstitial nephritis refers to acute inflammation of the renal interstitium. It is commonly induced by drugs (mainly antibiotics) or autoimmune disease, and it presents with fever, rash, pyuria, hematuria and costovertebral angle tenderness.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old man comes to the office for evaluation of scaliness and redness over his forehead for the past few months. It sometimes causes a stinging sensation on the affected area. Review of systems is noncontributory. He has been working as a lifeguard at the beach for the past 25 years. Past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus that is well-controlled with metformin. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 78/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 126/75 mmHg. Physical examination reveals a sandpaper-like texture of the forehead on palpation. An image of the lesion is shown below:


Retrieved fromWikimedia Commons

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation with multiple erythematous papules on his forehead with a sand-paper like texture on physical examination and a history of prolonged sunlight exposure (lifeguard) is strongly suggestive of actinic keratosis (AK).

AK is a pre-malignant cutaneous lesion that is associated with multiple signs on pathological examination, including:

  •  Parakeratosis: retention of nuclei in the stratum corneum 
  •  Hyperkeratosis: hyperplasia of stratum corneum 
  • Atypical keratinocytes: pleomorphic nuclei and multiple mitoses.
Major risk factors include excessive sun exposure, fair skin, advanced age and male gender. It usually presents with erythematous macules or papules with or without scaling and pigmentation on sun-exposed areas. Physical examination shows a sandpaper-like rough texture on palpation. Commonly affected areas include a balding scalp, forehead, dorsum of hands, lateral forearms and neck. It can progress to squamous cell carcinoma (SCC), and the risk is proportional to the degree of epithelial dysplasia. Isolated lesions are treated with cryotherapy or surgical procedures, whereas multiple lesions require topical treatment with 5-fluorouracil or imiquimod.  
 

Option Analysis

❌ Atopic dermatitis:
Incorrect: Atopic dermatitis usually presents in adults as lichenified plaques in flexural creases. Forehead involvement with scaly erythematous papules in relation to excessive sun exposure is atypical.
❌ Seborrheic keratosis:
Incorrect: Seborrheic keratoses are a result of benign proliferation of immature keratinocytes that clinically appear as well-demarcated, round or oval lesions with a dull, verrucous surface and a typical stuck-on appearance. Although scaling may occasionally be present, this patient’s examination findings are suggestive of an alternate diagnosis.
✅ Actinic keratosis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Molluscum contagiosum:
Incorrect: Molluscum contagiosum is a pox virus infection that presents with intensely pruritic papules with umbilicated centers, which are not observed in this patient.
❌ Psoriasis:
Incorrect: Psoriasis is a hyperkeratotic skin disorder that presents as a sharply defined erythematous plaque with silver-scaling and pruritus. Common areas of involvement include the scalp, extensor surfaces (e.g., elbows, knees), and the gluteal cleft. Forehead involvement is uncommon.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old man presents to the office because of an outgrowth on the dorsum of his right hand. The patient states that the lesion was initially small but then rapidly increased in size over the last 3 weeks. He is a farmer and has smoked 2 packs of cigarettes per day for the past 35 years. Past medical history is significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia treated with lisinopril and atorvastatin, respectively. Physical examination shows a dome-shaped 2-cm papule with a central keratinous plug on the dorsum of the right hand, as shown in the image below:


Retrieved fromWikimedia Commons

Which of the following best describes the progression of this lesion?
questions.solution:
The examination finding of a dome-shaped 2-cm papule with a central keratinous plug on sun-exposed skin (dorsum of hand) that recently rapidly increased in size is highly suggestive of keratoacanthoma (KA).

KA is a low-grade cutaneous tumor that originates from pilosebaceous glands and grows rapidly over a few weeks before regressing spontaneously. Modification of the factors responsible for epidermal cell proliferation, cell survival, and adhesion play an important role in its development. Common risk factors include fair skin, prolonged sun-exposure, trauma, and tobacco smoking. It usually presents on sun-exposed areas of skin (eyelids, nose, cheek, lower lip, neck, hands, and arms). The evolution of KA is divided into three phases:

  •  Proliferation phase, in which rapid progression of a small macule to papule occurs that subsequently forms a 1-2-cm circumscribed nodule with a central keratinous plug. It lasts 6-8 weeks. 
  •  Maturation phase, in which growth ceases, and the nodule may show signs of fragmentation. 
  • Involution phase, in which the nodule regresses. The central keratin plug is expelled, and the lesion becomes atrophic. It usually lasts 4-6 weeks.

KA is considered a benign variant of squamous cell carcinoma by some histopathologists, but definitive criteria to differentiate between the two has not been established.




Option Analysis

✅ Spontaneous resolution:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Formation of bullae :
Incorrect: Formation of bullae is characteristic of bullous pemphigoid, an autoimmune blistering disease.  A pre-bullous prodrome, however, presents as urticarial or eczematous lesions (not dome-shaped papule with a keratinous plug).
❌ Progression to basal cell carcinoma :
Incorrect: Keratoacanthoma, as seen in this patient, is considered a less aggressive variant of squamous cell carcinoma by some studies, but no relationship with basal cell carcinoma has been established.
❌ Keloid formation:
Incorrect: Keloid formation is characterized by fibroblast proliferation and excessive production of collagen which results from tissue response to dermal injury. Keratoacanthoma usually resolves spontaneously with an atrophic or hypopigmented scar. Keloid formation is unlikely.
❌ Ulceration:
Incorrect: Ulceration is one of the differentiating features between keratoacanthoma (KA) and squamous cell carcinoma. KA usually resolves and does not ulcerate.

questions.text: A 26-year-old man comes to the emergency department for evaluation of acute testicular pain. The pain has been progressively worsening over the past five days. He has no pain with urination, but there is significant tenderness with manipulation of the scrotum. He is sexually active with two partners and does not use barrier protection. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 94/min, and blood pressure is 125/80 mmHg. Physical examination reveals pain with palpation of the right testis posteriorly. Stroking of the right inner thigh results in elevation of the right testis. Which of the following additional clinical findings will most likely be observed in this patient?

choices.text: Relief of pain with manual elevation of the right testis
Transverse lie of the right testis
Edematous and tender prostate on digital rectal examination
Tender nodule with blue discoloration on the upper pole of the right testis

questions.solution:
Epididymitis refers to an infection of the epididymis. In males less than 35 years old, this infection is most commonly associated with sexually transmitted organisms including Chlamydia trachomatis and, less commonly, Neisseria gonorrhoeae. In males older than 35 years, and those without sexual partners, the most common organisms are gram-negative bacteria, predominantly Escherichia coli. In some patients, the infection can spread to the testicle, resulting in orchitis. Isolated cases of orchitis are rare and are more often seen with viral etiologies (e.g. mumps).

It is important to differentiate epididymitis from testicular torsion, which is another cause of testicular and scrotal pain. The Prehn sign is a helpful differentiating physical examination maneuver that is typically positive in patients with epididymitis. The exam is considered positive when elevation of the affected testis results in relief of pain, whereas in testicular torsion, any testicular manipulation exacerbates the pain. Additionally, patients with epididymitis have an intact cremaster reflex, whereas patients with testicular torsion have an absent reflex.  

Option Analysis

✅ Relief of pain with manual elevation of the right testis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ High-riding right testis:
Incorrect: A high-riding testis occurs when the testis moves to a more superior scrotal position. This phenomenon occurs due to shortening of the spermatic cord with testicular torsion. This diagnosis is unlikely in this patient who is presented with testicular pain in the posterior testis, as well as an intact cremaster reflex.
❌ Transverse lie of the right testis:
Incorrect: Transverse lie of the testis can be seen in patients with testicular torsion. This diagnosis is unlikely in this patient who is presenting with testicular pain in the posterior testis, as well as an intact cremaster reflex.
❌ Edematous and tender prostate on digital rectal examination:
Incorrect: This answer describes prostatitis, which more often presents with fevers, chills, dysuria, and pelvic or perineal pain. This patient has none of these symptoms.
❌ Tender nodule with blue discoloration on the upper pole of the right testis:
Incorrect: This answer describes torsion of the appendix testes. Torsion of the appendix testis rarely occurs in adults. The pain in this condition is localized to the anterosuperior aspect of the testis.

questions.text: A 67-year-old woman comes to the clinic due to a productive cough mixed with blood, weight loss, and fatigue for the past 2 months. Her medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus and smoking 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years. A chest radiograph shows a single nodule in the right lung field. A biopsy of the suspected lesion is performed, which reveals dark blue cells that stain positive for chromogranin A on histopathology, confirming the diagnosis of a malignancy. The doctor informs the patient that this type of cancer is often initially very responsive to chemotherapy. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
From the options above, only small cell lung cancer is highly responsive initially to chemotherapy, and thus chemotherapy is the preferred initial treatment. While the other lung cancers may also involve chemotherapy as part of the treatment plan, small cell carcinoma carries the best response (though prognosis is still often poor). Biopsy and histopathological examination of small cell carcinoma of the lung typically reveals dark blue cells (neuroendocrine cells) that stain positive for chromogranin A, neuron-specific enolase, and synaptophysin on histopathology.

Small cell (“oat cell”) carcinoma is an undifferentiated, very aggressive tumor. Limited-stage disease is mainly treated with a combination of chemotherapy and radiation therapy because the addition of radiation therapy has been demonstrated to prolong survival compared with chemotherapy alone. Surgery is generally not used, with the rare exception of solitary pulmonary nodules without distant metastases or regional lymph node involvement.  

Option Analysis

❌ Adenocarcinoma:
Incorrect: Adenocarcinoma is the most common primary lung cancer. It is more common in women than men, and it is most likely to arise in nonsmokers. As with other types of non-small cell lung cancer, surgical resection offers the best opportunity for long-term survival and cure, if the tumor is indeed resectable. Depending on the cancer staging, adjuvant chemotherapy, radiation, and immunotherapy may be followed or used instead.
❌ Squamous cell carcinoma:
Incorrect: Squamous cell carcinoma usually presents as a hilar mass arising from the bronchus. It is also associated with smoking. As with other types of non-small cell lung cancer, surgical resection offers the best opportunity for long-term survival and cure if the tumor is indeed resectable. Depending on the cancer staging, adjuvant chemotherapy, radiation, and immunotherapy may be followed or used instead.
❌ Large cell carcinoma:
Incorrect: Large cell carcinoma is a highly anaplastic, undifferentiated tumor that carries a poor prognosis. It is associated with smoking. As with other types of non-small cell lung cancer, surgical resection offers the best opportunity for long-term survival and cure if the tumor is indeed resectable. Depending on the cancer staging, adjuvant chemotherapy, radiation, and immunotherapy may be followed or used instead.
❌ Bronchial carcinoid tumor:
Incorrect: Bronchial carcinoid tumor is a neuroendocrine tumor that may secrete serotonin. It usually carries an excellent prognosis, and metastases are rare. Currently, there is no optimal approach for treatment, but most are treated with surgical resection with/without adjuvant chemotherapy depending on the staging.
✅ Small cell carcinoma:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man comes to the physician’s office due to a 2-month history of pain and numbness in his right shoulder and arm. The patient describes the pain as dull and deep, and it often awakens him at night. He tried some over-the-counter pain medications with minimal relief. The patient's medical history is significant for hypertension, cholelithiasis, and gastroesophageal reflux disease. He smoked 1 pack of cigarettes per day since he was 25 years old but quit 2 years ago. On physical examination, 3/5 strength is noted on the right upper extremity, and hypoesthesia is present along the distribution of C8-T1 dermatomes. Eye examination reveals left side ptosis and miosis. Which of the following is most likely responsible for this patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation with a smoking history, Horner syndrome and shoulder pain that often awakens him at night, with associated weakness is most likely secondary to a superior sulcus tumor causing local compression.

Superior sulcus tumors, also called Pancoast tumors, are neoplasms that arise at the apical pleuropulmonary groove, adjacent to the subclavian vessels. The majority of superior sulcus tumors are non-small cell lung cancers (NSCLCs), with a predominance of adenocarcinomas. Pancoast tumors may present as shoulder and arm pain (along C8, T1, and T2 dermatomes), Horner syndrome, and weakness and atrophy of the muscles of the hand. This constellation of symptoms is referred to as Pancoast syndrome. Horner syndrome consists of ipsilateral ptosis, anhidrosis, and miosis (remembered with the mnemonic PAM). It is caused by compression of the paravertebral sympathetic chain and the inferior cervical (stellate) ganglion. Since the tumor is located in the periphery, pulmonary symptoms such as cough, hemoptysis, and dyspnea are uncommon until late in the disease, as seen in this patient. Other findings may include supraclavicular lymph node enlargement, weight loss, phrenic, or recurrent laryngeal neuropathy or superior vena cava syndrome.

 



Option Analysis

❌ Cervical rib:
Incorrect: A cervical rib is a possible cause of thoracic outlet syndrome, which presents as atrophy of intrinsic hand muscles, ischemia, pain, and edema due to compression of the lower trunk of the brachial plexus and subclavian vessels. This patient’s smoking history and Horner syndrome (ptosis, anhidrosis, miosis) favor another diagnosis.
❌ Symptomatic gallstones:
Incorrect: Gallstones may cause biliary colic, which presents as episodic pain, typically after food ingestion when the gallbladder contracts. The pain can radiate to the right shoulder or underneath the scapula. This patient’s smoking history and Horner syndrome (ptosis, anhidrosis, miosis) favor another diagnosis.
❌ Antibodies against presynaptic Ca2+ channels:
Incorrect: Antibodies against presynaptic Ca2+ channels can be seen in Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome, a condition often associated with small cell (oat cell) carcinoma. It often presents with proximal muscle weakness and autonomic symptoms (dry mouth, erectile dysfunction). Lambert-Eaton does not cause unilateral weakness, and the presence of other symptoms (unilateral ptosis, miosis) favors another diagnosis.
✅ Superior sulcus tumor:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Pleural effusion:
Incorrect: Pleural effusion can cause diaphragmatic irritation and, as a result, referred shoulder pain. However, it will not cause arm weakness and numbness or Horner syndrome (ptosis, anhidrosis, miosis).
❌ Cervical disc herniation:
Incorrect: Cervical disc herniation can present as shoulder pain and numbness along specific dermatomes as seen in this patient. However, this patient’s smoking history, Horner syndrome (ptosis, anhidrosis, miosis), and pain that awakens him at night favor another diagnosis.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman comes to the clinic for the evaluation of irregular periods. For the last three years, the patient has had about four periods a year. She recently began shaving her upper lip and chin due to excessive hair growth. Review of systems is significant for 30 lbs weight gain in the last 7 months. Past medical history is unremarkable. She has a family history of breast cancer in her mother at age 49 and myocardial infarction in her father at age 52. Temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 74/min, respirations are 13/min, and blood pressure is 124/72 mmHg. Physical examination shows terminal hair on the upper lip and nipples. The abdomen is obese and nontender with no masses or tenderness. Development is Tanner stage V. A transvaginal ultrasound shows polycystic ovaries bilaterally. Serum TSH is within normal limits. Which of the following sets of hormonal changes will most likely be observed in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient has clinical evidence of the hyperandrogenism (hirsutism), irregular menses, and obesity typical of polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS). The ultrasound finding of polycystic ovaries further supports the diagnosis.

PCOS is caused by dysfunction in the hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian (HPO) axis. The anterior pituitary makes too much LH (the mechanism is not well known), which can exceed twice the level of FSH. Excessive LH causes the theca cells to produce excess amounts of androstenedione, which is converted into estrone by aromatase in the adipose tissue, and reduced levels of sex-hormone binding globulin. High estrone levels cause high pulses of GnRH from the hypothalamus. The high pulses of GnRH produce an imbalance of LH/FSH release from the pituitary which results in a lack of LH surge. This leads to the failure of follicle maturation and oocyte release. As a result, ovulation does not occur. However, an elevated LH-to-FSH ratio is not a criterion for the diagnosis of PCOS, as their levels fluctuate throughout the menstrual cycle.

High levels of androstenedione from polycystic ovary syndrome can cause hirsutism. It can also lead to male-pattern baldness, as well as acne on the face, chest, and back. Lack of ovulation causes amenorrhea or oligomenorrhea, both of which can cause infertility.  

Option Analysis

❌   GnRH  FSH  Estrogen ↓↓↓:
Incorrect: Functional hypothalamic amenorrhea (FHA) is caused by the decreased amplitude and/or frequency of gonadotropin pulses from the hypothalamus, leading to decreased levels of LH, FSH and estradiol. It can occur in females who maintain a very low calorie diet.
✅  GnRH FSH  Estrogen ↑Normal↑:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌   GnRH  FSH  Estrogen ↑↑↓:
Incorrect: This set of findings is usually seen in patients with primary ovarian insufficiency, which is the cessation of ovarian function at age <40. It is characterized by oligomenorrhea or amenorrhea in combination with symptoms of estrogen deficiency (e.g. hot flashes and vaginal dryness).
❌  GnRH FSH  Estrogen NormalNormalNormal:
Incorrect: Normal hormonal levels are indicative of normal ovulation and is unlikely in this patient with irregular menstrual cycle and signs of hyperandrogenism. Such levels can also be seen in patients with imperforate hymen who present with cyclic abdominal pain and a vaginal bulge, neither of which is seen in this patient.
❌   GnRH  FSH  Estrogen ↓↓↑:
Incorrect: Exogenous estrogen administration decreases serum GnRH and FSH levels via negative feedback. It is unlikely in this patient.

questions.text:
A 13-year-old girl is brought to her pediatricians office for evaluation of shortness of breath and cough. She has had two episodes of pneumonia over the last two years and an episode of bloody diarrhea six months ago requiring hospitalization. Two years ago, the patient was without any significant health complications. Her only past medical history is asthma. Family history is noncontributory. Her immunizations are up to date. Temperature is 38.7 C° (101.7 F°), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 25/min, and blood pressure is 100/60 mmHg. Height and weight are currently at the 5th percentile for age. Physical examination reveals faint rales over the right lower lung field. No enlarged lymph nodes are palpated on neck examination. Laboratory results are shown.

 
 Laboratory value  Result 
 Complete blood count 
 Hemoglobin  12  g/dL  
 Leukocyte count  10,100 /mm3 
 Platelet count  200,000/mm3 
Immunoglobulins 
IgG  250mg/dL 
 IgA  24 mg/dL 
 IgM  15 mg/dL 
 IgE  undetectable 
 CD4/CD8 ratio  2 (normal, 1-4) 

Chest x-ray reveals a right lower lobe infiltrate. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with evidence of recurrent pneumonia and a history of bloody diarrhea, in the setting of hypogammaglobulinemia, which is suggestive of common variable immunodeficiency (CVID).

This disorder results from a defect in B-cell differentiation, impaired lymphocyte activation, and hypogammaglobulinemia. Function of toll-like receptors (TLR) 7 and 9 on both B cells and dendritic cells becomes impaired, which is normally required for B cell activation, cytokine secretion, proliferation, and survival against viral and bacterial DNA, respectively.

CVID typically presents in adolescents (around puberty) or young adults (age 20-40) with recurrent sinopulmonary infections (especially encapsulated bacteria/mycoplasma), chronic respiratory diseases (e.g., asthma and bronchiectasis), gastrointestinal infections (e.g., Campylobacter jejuni, Salmonella or Giardiasis) and failure to thrive. Other commonly reported infections include septic arthritis, meningitis (both bacterial and viral), and bacteremia. Diagnosis is based on decreased serum IgG levels and markedly decreased IgM/IgA in the absence of other defined immunodeficiency states. Lymphocyte and B cell concentrations are typically normal. Treatment includes lifelong intravenous infusion of immunoglobulin. Patients with CVID are at increased risk of associated autoimmune disease and malignancies, regardless of treatment.  

Option Analysis

❌ Severe combined immunodeficiency syndrome:
Incorrect: Severe combined immunodeficiency syndrome is a life-threatening condition that results from mutations that impair B and T cell development and function. It presents in infancy with failure to thrive and severe viral and bacterial infections as maternal immunity wanes. This patient’s T cell count is normal.
❌ Chronic granulomatous disease:
Incorrect: Chronic granulomatous disease results from a defect in NADPH oxidase which leads to  decreased production of reactive oxygen species and respiratory burst. Affected patients are susceptible to infections with catalase positive organisms (e.g. Staphylococcus and Pseudomonas aeruginosa). Immunoglobulin levels are normal in these patients.
❌ DiGeorge syndrome:
Incorrect: DiGeorge syndrome classically presents with cardiac defects (conotruncal abnormalities [eg, tetralogy of Fallot, truncus arteriosus]), abnormal facies, thymic hypoplasia causing T-cell deficiency (recurrent viral/ fungal infections), and hypocalcemia. Immunodeficiency occurs secondary to thymic hypoplasia. Immunoglobulin levels are within normal limits. This patient has normal T cell count and hypogammaglobulinemia.
✅ Common variable immunodeficiency:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Job syndrome:
Incorrect: Job syndrome (autosomal dominant hyper-IgE syndrome) results in impaired recruitment of neutrophils to the site of infection. Affected patients present with cold (noninflamed) staphylococcal abscesses, retained baby teeth, coarse facies, eczema and elevated serum IgE levels (normal levels of other immunoglobulin, unlike this patient).

questions.text: A 56-year-old man presents to a urology clinic for evaluation of an ulcerated penile lesion. The lesion has been present on the glans of the penis for eight weeks. He completed a course of penicillin, doxycycline, and fluconazole without improvement of the lesion. Past medical history includes psoriasis treated with topical corticosteroids. The patient immigrated from Sri Lanka in his twenties and is unsure of his vaccination status. He has had multiple sexual partners and occasionally uses condoms for protection. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates a circumcised penis with a 2-cm painless ulcer noted on the dorsal aspect of the glans without surrounding swelling or erythema. Several verrucous, cauliflower-like growths are also noted at the base of the penis. Bilateral inguinal lymphadenopathy is noted. Which of the following is the strongest risk factor predisposing this patient to the development of this ulcerative lesion?
questions.solution:
This middle-aged man presents for evaluation of a chronic penile ulcer resistant to antibiotic therapy. The patient also has a history of multiple sexual partners, marked inguinal lymphadenopathy, and condyloma accuminata, suggesting underlying squamous cell carcinoma of the penis.

There are several risk factors for the development of penile cancer, including:

  •  Phimosis  
  •  History of sexually transmitted infections (STIs), especially human papillomavirus (HPV) and HIV 
  •  Tobacco use 
  •  Lichen sclerosus 
  • Poor hygiene
HPV DNA is identified in 30-50% of all penile carcinomas. Further evidence of HPV infection includes the presence of condyloma accuminata (genital warts), which are soft papillomatous growths associated with human papillomavirus (HPV) infection. Although these lesions rarely undergo malignant transformation, immunosuppression can augment this process. Overall, HPV-associated squamous cell carcinoma of the penis is most associated with infection from subtypes 16, 18, 31, 33, 35, and 39.  

Option Analysis

✅ Infection with a DNA virus:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Infection with a spirochete:
Incorrect: Bacterial infection (such as with Treponema pallidum) can result in a painless chancre on the penis. Over time, the papule can ulcerate, resulting in a 1 to 2 cm ulcer with raised, indurated margins. This patient was treated for underlying syphilis with penicillin.
❌ Candida infection:
Incorrect: Penile balanitis can be caused by fungal infections (e.g. Candida). Symptoms include pain, tenderness, or pruritus with erythematous lesions on the glans and/or the foreskin. This patient received adequate antifungal therapy and also has verrucous growths and inguinal lymphadenopathy, making another etiology more likely.
❌ History of circumcision:
Incorrect: Circumcision is protective against the development of penile cancers, as it eliminates the closed preputial environment that induces chronic inflammation.
❌ History of psoriasis:
Incorrect: Psoriasis is not a known risk factor for the development of squamous cell carcinoma of the penis.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of new onset confusion. She was recently diagnosed with neurocysticercosis and was discharged from the hospital two days ago with new prescriptions for albendazole and acetazolamide. Her family says up until today, the patient’s headache had been improving, but this morning, they found her unable to remain awake or state her own name. She has a history of opioid use disorder in remission. Her temperature is 36.4°C (97.5° F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 36/min, and blood pressure is 100/70 mmHg. She appears lethargic and is difficult to arouse, exhibiting rapid, shallow breaths. Physical examination shows symmetric pupils and normal reflexes in all four extremities. Which of the following sets of values is most likely to be found on arterial blood gas analysis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with a history of acetazolamide use, tachypnea, and altered mental status--suggestive of metabolic acidosis. Acetazolamide is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor that secretes bicarbonate (HCO3-) in the proximal tubule of the kidney, while also stimulating the choroid plexus to reduce the production of cerebrospinal fluid. This patient’s headache was likely secondary to increased intracranial pressure from neurocysticercosis (an infection of the central nervous system with the tapeworm Taenia solium), for which she was being treated with albendazole and acetazolamide.

The loss of bicarbonate caused by acetazolamide causes the buffer reaction to shift to the right, lowering the body’s pH, as shown:

 

A low bicarbonate with a low pH represents a metabolic acidosis and can happen either from the accumulation of acid in the bloodstream (increased production or ingestion) or from an inability to remove acid via loss of the bicarbonate buffer (excessive bicarbonate loss from the kidneys or gastrointestinal tract). In either case, bicarbonate levels will be low, usually less than 20mEq/L.



 
In an attempt to maintain a neutral pH, the body compensates via hyperventilation to eliminate carbon dioxide (CO2) and reduce hydrogen ion production. Because the body cannot completely compensate for metabolic acidosis through hyperventilation, the pH in metabolic acidosis still remains low (pH ≤ 7.5). The low pH leads to changes in enzymatic activity which, along with a rapid respiratory rate, predisposes to confusion and mental status changes. Stopping acetazolamide and reversing its effects with sodium bicarbonate will normalize this patient’s acid-base status.

Option Analysis

❌  Arterial pH  Arterial PaCO2  (mmHg)  Arterial HCO3–  (mEq/L)  7.30  50  24 :
Incorrect: Low pH with high PaCO2 and normal HCO3 is consistent with acute respiratory acidosis. As examples, respiratory acidosis can occur in patients with COPD exacerbations or respiratory depression from opioid administration. Opioid toxicity depresses the respiratory rate (usually less than 12 breaths per minute).
✅  Arterial pH  Arterial PaCO2  (mmHg)  Arterial HCO3–  (mEq/L)  7.35 10  6:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌  Arterial pH  Arterial PaCO2  (mmHg)  Arterial HCO3–  (mEq/L) 7.40 40 24 :
Incorrect: These values represent a normal acid-base status.
❌  Arterial pH  Arterial PaCO2  (mmHg)  Arterial HCO3–  (mEq/L) 7.45 50 32:
Incorrect: High pH with a high PaCO2 and high HCO3 is consistent with concurrent respiratory acidosis and metabolic alkalosis. As an example, this pattern could occur in the setting of ingesting a toxic central nervous system depressant that causes both diarrhea and respiratory depression.
❌  Arterial pH  Arterial PaCO2  (mmHg)  Arterial HCO3–  (mEq/L) 7.5030 24 :
Incorrect: High pH with a low PaCO2 and high HCO3 is consistent with acute respiratory alkalosis. As examples, respiratory alkalosis can occur in patients with sepsis, stroke, or pulmonary embolism.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man comes to the emergency department for evaluation of dyspnea, dizziness, and associated chest pain. He became more concerned when he was walking up stairs and suddenly “passed out.” His medical history includes type 2 diabetes mellitus, for which he takes metformin. He smoked one pack per day for forty years but does not use excessive alcohol or illicit drugs. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 139/75 mmHg. On physical examination, a systolic murmur is appreciated over the right sternal border, which decreases with sustained hand grip. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with classic features of symptomatic aortic stenosis (AS), including dyspnea, decreased exercise tolerance, dizziness, syncope and a systolic murmur over the right sternal border. The most common cause of aortic stenosis in adults over the age of 60 is age-related calcification.

Common clinical findings of AS include exertional dyspnea, decreased exercise tolerance, dizziness, syncope, exertional angina, and arrhythmias. During exertion, left ventricular dysfunction ensues as the heart pumps against a stenotic valve--thus limiting ejection fraction and blood flow to both peripheral tissues and coronary arteries. On physical examination, AS is heard as a crescendo-decrescendo systolic ejection murmur over the right 2nd right intercostal space. Additional physical findings include a  soft S2, an ejection click, and a weak carotid pulse with a delayed peak (“Pulsus parvus et tardus”).






The most common cause of aortic stenosis (AS) in individuals above the age of 60 is age-related calcification. In patients under the age of 60, AS is associated with a bicuspid aortic valve or rheumatic heart disease. Clinical manifestations include signs of left ventricular outflow obstruction, such as exertional dyspnea, dizziness, syncope, and angina. AS leads to a crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur over the right sternal border. 

Option Analysis

❌ Bicuspid aortic valve:
Incorrect: Bicuspid aortic valve is associated with early-onset calcification in patients under the age of sixty. This patient’s constellation of findings is suggestive of more dangerous cardiac pathology.
❌ Untreated group A streptococcus infection:
Incorrect: Untreated group A strep infection is most commonly associated with mitral regurgitation--less so aortic or tricuspid regurgitation. Aortic regurgitation, if present, is almost always seen concurrently with mitral insufficiency. This patient’s findings are consistent with isolated aortic stenosis.
❌ Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease :
Incorrect: Pulmonary arterial hypertension may occur as a result of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease; however, it usually presents with signs of right-sided heart failure, such as dyspnea, hepatic congestion, and peripheral edema.
✅ Age-related valve calcification:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Myxomatous valve degeneration:
Incorrect: Myxomatous valve degeneration is a cause of primary mitral valve prolapse and is characterized by non-inflammatory abnormal tissue deposition (glycosaminoglycan) around cardiac valves. Mitral valve prolapse presents with a late-systolic, crescendo murmur and a midsystolic click appreciated over the cardiac apex.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman comes to the clinic due to shortness of breath on exertion and occasional chest pain. Her medical history is significant for a “heart sound” that was diagnosed as a child after having a prolonged illness. She does not use tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drugs. She immigrated from Peru two years ago with her family. Her temperature is 36.4°C (97.5° F), pulse is 115/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 130/60 mm Hg. Physical examination shows pulsations of the nail bed. Cardiac examination shows an abnormal heart sound over the left sternal border on auscultation (see image below). Which of the following maneuvers will likely decrease the intensity of this heart sound?
questions.solution:
This woman recently immigrated from Peru, where she was diagnosed with a “heart sound” after a prolonged illness. She is now presenting with some of the classic signs of aortic regurgitation (AR), which is most likely due to untreated rheumatic fever. In developed countries, AR is most often due to congenital bicuspid aortic valve, aortic root dilation, and endocarditis. Symptoms of AR include exertional dyspnea, angina, and palpitations, and the condition can eventually lead to left heart failure.

Aortic insufficiency leads to blood return to the left ventricle during diastole and an increase in the end diastolic volume. In an attempt to compensate for the increase in wall stress, the left ventricle undergoes eccentric hypertrophy, leading to an increased stroke volume. This increased stroke volume increases the systolic pressure, while the regurgitation leads to a rapid fall in diastolic pressure and collapse of the arteries -- which, in combination, results in a wide pulse pressure (systolic pressure minus diastolic blood pressure). The resulting wide pulse pressure is responsible for a number of characteristic physical findings including: head bobbing (de Musset sign), capillary pulsations of the fingertips or lips, and abrupt distention and collapse of the arterial pulse (water hammer sign). In addition, patients may describe palpitations from forceful contractions of the heart.

On auscultation, a high-pitched “blowing” early diastolic decrescendo murmur is expected at the left sternal border. Anything that decreases venous return to the heart, and therefore the preload, will cause a decrease in the intensity of the AR murmur. This includes abrupt standing and valsalva.

 

Option Analysis

❌ Passive leg raising:
Incorrect: Passive leg raising leads to an increase in venous return, which causes the aortic regurgitation murmur to intensify (also MR & VSD). In contrast, the murmur of hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy becomes softer, and the murmur of mitral valve prolapse shortens.
❌ Sustained hand grip:
Incorrect: Sustained hand grip leads to constriction of the arteries of the hand, causing an increase in afterload and backflow pressure. This maneuver will cause murmur intensity to increase, not decrease.
✅ Abrupt standing:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Rapid squatting:
Incorrect: Rapid squatting leads to an increase in venous return, increase in preload, and increased afterload. Squatting causes the aortic regurgitation murmur to intensify. In general, most murmurs intensify with squatting with the exception of hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy, which softens, and the murmur onset in mitral valve prolapse is delayed.

questions.text:
A 3-year-old boy is brought to the office by his parents because of difficulty keeping up with other children at daycare. The parents report that he has difficulty climbing stairs and seems more tired and less interested in active play. The patient has a history of upper respiratory tract infections twice in the last year. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 70/min, respirations are 19/min and blood pressure is 100/60 mmHg. Physical examination shows enlarged and nontender calves bilaterally. The rest of the examination is unremarkable. A genetic condition is suspected. The patient’s family pedigree with respect to this condition is shown with the red arrow indicating his position within the family.



Assuming that the genetic condition demonstrates complete penetrance, which of the following inheritance patterns is most likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
The pedigree shows that only males are affected by the disease. Specifically, male offspring of unaffected parents are affected and there is no evidence of male-to-male transmission. This pattern is most likely suggestive of X-linked recessive inheritance from an asymptomatic carrier female in the first generation. In X-linked recessive disease:

  •  If the female is a carrier,  50% of her sons will end up having the mutation and 50% of daughters will be carriers for the mutation. 
  •  Affected males will always produce unaffected sons and carrier daughters. 
This patient is most likely suffering from Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD). About 2/3rds of the time, the affected patient’s mother is a carrier, and the other 1/3rd of the time the disease is sporadic, which means it is caused by a new mutation. Patients with DMD may experience a gradual and relentless deterioration, and most patients lose ambulation before the age of 12 years. Most patients with DMD die in their 20s or 30s. Therefore, it is important to counsel the parents regarding the risk of having another child with a similar mutation.  

Becker muscular dystrophy (BMD) is similar to DMD but manifests later in life. It is also an X-linked recessive disease. BMD patients typically have a milder clinical course than those with DMD, and remain ambulatory into adult life. They usually survive beyond the age of 30 years and have a mean age of death in the mid-40s.  



Option Analysis

❌ X-linked dominant:
Incorrect: In X-linked dominant inheritance, at least one parent (of either sex) is affected.
✅ X-linked recessive:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Autosomal dominant:
Incorrect: In autosomal dominant inheritance, more than one generation is affected; therefore, at least one parent should also be affected. Both male and females can have the disease.
❌ Autosomal recessive:
Incorrect: Autosomal recessive conditions usually affect only one generation, and both parents of the affected child should at least be a carrier of the disease. With two carrier parents, only 25% of the children will be affected, and both males and females can be affected by the mutation.
❌ Mitochondrial:
Incorrect: Diseases that have mitochondrial inheritance are transmitted only by females, and all of the affected female’s offspring are likely to show the signs of the disease.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man comes to his primary care provider for evaluation of “fullness in the groin,” which started 3 weeks ago. The discomfort is present in both testicles and has not improved with over-the-counter ibuprofen. On review of systems, the patient endorses a decreased appetite, 7-kg (15-lb) weight loss over the past 2 months, and occasionally wakes up at night drenched in sweat. Past medical history is notable for hypertension, peripheral vascular disease, and chronic venous insufficiency. Temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 71/min and blood pressure is 147/82 mmHg. Physical examination reveals a thin man with diffuse muscle wasting. Bilateral testicular enlargement is present. The masses do not decrease in size when the patient lies flat. The testes are nontender to palpation. No erythema or rashes are noted over the scrotum. Which of the following best describes the pathophysiology of this patient’s testicular findings?

choices.text: Abnormal proliferation of antibody-producing cells within the testes
Accumulation of venous blood in the scrotum
Retrograde flow of Gram-negative pathogens found in urine
Uncontrolled proliferation of sex cord stromal cells

questions.solution:
This older male is presenting with bilateral testicular enlargement as well as B-symptoms, including weight loss and night sweats. These findings are concerning for testicular lymphoma.

Testicular lymphoma is a rare disease that accounts for only 5-9% of all testicular malignancies. However, it is the most common testicular malignancy in individuals over 50-years-old. The most common type of testicular lymphoma is diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL).

Although testicular lymphomas can arise as a primary tumor of the testes, it is more commonly a result of metastasis from a different site within the body. Testicular lymphomas are aggressive with a high relapse rate and poor prognosis. Clinically, the malignancy presents unilaterally in around 84% of cases and bilaterally in 16% of cases. Patients usually present with swelling, and sometimes pain, of the testes. Patients can also have systemic symptoms such as fever, night sweats, and weight loss, which are collectively termed B-symptoms.

Option Analysis

✅ Abnormal proliferation of antibody-producing cells within the testes:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Malignant transformation of germ cells:
Incorrect: Germ cell tumors of the testes include seminomas, yolk sac tumors, choriocarcinomas, teratomas, and embryonal carcinomas. These tumors most often occur as a unilateral mass in young men. The presence of B-symptoms (e.g., weight loss, night sweats), in combination with the presence of bilateral testicular involvement, is more concerning for testicular lymphoma.
❌ Accumulation of venous blood in the scrotum:
Incorrect: This patient has a history of venous insufficiency, which can cause blood to accumulate within the pampiniform plexus, resulting in varicoceles. Varicoceles can be bilateral and present with a sense of scrotal fullness. However, the presence of bilateral varicoceles would not account for the changes in appetite, weight loss, and night sweats, which are concerning for an underlying malignancy. Additionally, varicoceles typically regress in size when patients lay flat, which is not seen in this patient.
❌ Retrograde flow of Gram-negative pathogens found in urine:
Incorrect: Retrograde flow of contaminated urine, as in the case of a urinary tract infection, can lead to epididymitis. Patients will develop testicular pain and scrotal erythema. However, it would not account for the weight loss or night sweats experienced by this patient.
❌ Uncontrolled proliferation of sex cord stromal cells:
Incorrect: Sex cord stromal tumors include Leydig and Sertoli cell tumors. These tumors typically manifest as a unilateral testicular mass and can be hormonally active, meaning they can manifest with symptoms of hyperestrogenism or hyperandrogenism. They would not, however, account for the B-symptoms (e.g., weight loss, night sweats) experienced by this patient.

questions.text: A 29-year-old primigravid woman at 34 weeks gestation comes to the clinic for a routine prenatal examination. She has noticed regular fetal movements and does not have complaints of vaginal bleeding, leaking or abdominal pain. She had an upper respiratory infection and hyperemesis in the first trimester that have since resolved. The patient uses illicit drugs including heroin, cocaine and marijuana. She does not use tobacco. Prior to conceiving, she would consume alcohol with her friends on the weekends. Temperature is 98°F (36.6°C), pulse is 110 bpm, blood pressure is 100/70 mmHg. Ultrasound reveals a biparietal diameter of 32 weeks and abdominal circumference of 28 weeks. Which of the following complications should be anticipated at the time of delivery?
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of cocaine use presents with evidence of intrauterine fetal growth restriction (discordance between gestational age and fetal growth parameters). Fetal growth restriction is defined as an estimated fetal weight less than 10% for gestational age.

Fetal growth restriction is associated with uteroplacental insufficiency resulting from cocaine use, hypertension, or tobacco use. Cocaine is a potent psychostimulant that acts by blocking the reuptake of biogenic amines like norepinephrine, serotonin and dopamine and can promote vasoconstriction and thrombus formation. Vasoconstriction of the placental vessels is the predominant mechanism for cocaine-induced maternal and fetal complications. In addition, cocaine use during pregnancy is also associated with complications such as preterm delivery, abruptio placenta, and miscarriage.

Option Analysis

✅ Abruptio placenta:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Placenta previa:
Incorrect: Risk factors for placenta previa include previous cesarean deliveries, multiple gestation and previous placenta praevia. Patients with intrauterine growth restriction and cocaine use are not at a higher risk to develop placenta praevia.
❌ Fetal hypoglycemia:
Incorrect: Fetal hypoglycemia can result from maternal hyperglycemia, fetal pancreatic hyperplasia and fetal hyperinsulinemia.
❌ Uterine rupture:
Incorrect: Uterine rupture is an obstetric emergency that results in the rupture of all the uterine layers. Risk factors include previous cesarean delivery and recent blunt abdominal trauma.
❌ Fetal macrosomia:
Incorrect: Macrosomia (birth weight >4500g) is a consequence of gestational diabetes mellitus secondary to maternal hyperglycemia and fetal hyperinsulinemia. Cocaine use is typically associated with preterm delivery and low birth weight.

questions.text: A 24-year old man is brought to the emergency department by the police after being found wandering the streets screaming at bystanders. He resisted arrest and became physically aggressive. While a nurse attempts to place an IV, the patient screams and attempts to hit her. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.6°F), respirations are 20/minute, heart rate is 120/minute, and blood pressure is 155/95 mmHg. The patient is subsequently provided with intramuscular haloperidol. Urine toxicology confirms the use of a drug that exerts its effects by binding to and antagonizing N-methyl-D-aspartate (NMDA) receptors. Which of the following physical exam findings is highly associated with this drug?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with characteristic features of phencyclidine (PCP) intoxication--an analgesic and anesthetic drug that exerts its effects by antagonizing the N-methyl-D-aspartate (NMDA) receptors found in the hypothalamus, basal ganglia, and neocortex.

Mechanistically, PCP is classified as a dissociative anesthetic. It is most commonly inhaled, with a rapid onset of effects including dysphoria, agitation, and diminished pain perception. Aggressive combative behavior is usually seen in patients taking PCP and may lead to serious injuries to self or others. When consumed in excess, patients may suffer from seizures as well.

On physical examination, patients with PCP intoxication have evidence of hypertension, tachycardia, hyperventilation, and hyperthermia. Nystagmus is almost always observed on physical examination, often with associated miosis.



Option Analysis

✅ Nystagmus:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Conjunctival injection:
Incorrect: Conjunctival injection is common to cannabis intoxication. Cannabis exerts its effects by binding to the cannabinoid binding receptors 1 and 2 (CB1 and CB2).
❌ Mydriasis:
Incorrect: Miosis is more commonly observed with PCP intoxication, not mydriasis.
❌ Respiratory depression:
Incorrect: Respiratory depression is a well-known complication of heroin overdose, which exerts its effects by binding to the opioid receptors, not NMDA receptors.
❌ Prinzmetal angina:
Incorrect: Prinzmetal angina is associated with overdoses of vasoconstrictive agents like cocaine. Cocaine does not exert its effects on NMDA receptors.

questions.text:
A 77-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician for a routine check-up. She has been feeling well and has been taking medications as prescribed. The patient lives at a senior apartment complex and is able to complete activities of daily living. Past medical history is notable for hypertension and hyperlipidemia, for which she takes lisinopril and atorvastatin. The patient does not consume alcohol or tobacco products. Vital signs are within normal limits. On ophthalmologic evaluation, intraocular pressures are measured to be 25 mmHg in the right eye and 27 mmHg in the left eye. Fundoscopic examination reveals the following:


Image reproduced from Flickr

 If untreated, this patient will most likely develop which of the following findings?

choices.text: Small shadows in the visual field

questions.solution:
This patient has a painless elevation of intraocular pressure (>20 mmHg) and enlarged cup-to-disc ratio. These findings are concerning for open-angle glaucoma, which, if untreated, can cause peripheral vision loss.

Glaucoma is an eye disease that results in damage to the optic nerve and subsequent vision loss, often in the setting of increased intraocular pressure. The pathophysiology of glaucoma can be understood by tracing the normal flow of aqueous humor through the eye. Aqueous humor is produced by the ciliary body and exits the posterior chamber via the pupil into the anterior chamber. Next, aqueous humor exits the eye either via the trabecular network and canals of Schlemm to aqueous veins, or via the uveo-scleral pathway.

Open-angle glaucoma can be idiopathic or due to reduced aqueous humor flow through the trabecular meshwork. Closed-angle glaucoma occurs when the iridocorneal angle is narrowed, thus impeding aqueous humor outflow.

In both conditions, impaired aqueous humor outflow can result in increased intraocular pressure, optic disc atrophy, and progressive peripheral vision loss. Open-angle glaucoma is usually discovered incidentally, since the majority of patients are asymptomatic in the early stages of disease. In contrast, closed-angle glaucoma results in acute attacks characterized by a unilateral, painful eye with a non-reactive and dilated pupil.

 

Option Analysis

✅ Peripheral vision loss:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Loss of central vision:
Incorrect: This patient presents with elevated intraocular pressures and an enlarged cup-to-disc ratio, which are concerning for glaucoma. Although glaucoma can ultimately result in central vision loss, peripheral vision loss tends to occur first and is a more common clinical finding.
❌ Amaurosis fugax:
Incorrect: Amaurosis fugax describes a painless temporary loss of vision in one or both eyes. The condition is usually caused by imapired blood flow to the eye, such as in the case of retinal artery occlusion. In contrast, this patient more likely has glaucoma, which is initially asymptomatic but overtime can lead to peripheral vision loss.
❌ Difficulty seeing in dim light:
Incorrect: Retinitis pigmentosa is a form of inherited retinal degeneration that leads to progressive vision loss. The first symptoms are often night blindness due to degeneration of the rods in the retina.
❌ Small shadows in the visual field:
Incorrect: Floaters, which are little “cobwebs” or “specks” that float in the visual field, arise due to the presence of objects (e.g. leukocytes, erythrocytes) within the vitreous fluid. Floaters can develop in the setting of vitreous detachment, intraocular bleeding, and uveitis, but not typically glaucoma.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman, gravida 2 para 1, at 12 weeks gestation, presents to the emergency department because of sloughing off of the skin and pain in and around the oral cavity. For the past four days, these symptoms were preceded by fever, joint pain, and malaise. She reports mouth and throat pain during swallowing both solids and liquids. She has a history of generalized tonic-clonic seizures and was recently switched to a different medication. She works as a postal carrier and traveled to Massachusetts two months ago to visit her aunt. Temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 102/60 mmHg. Physical examination shows an ill-appearing woman with extensive erosions of the oral mucosa and sloughed skin of the face and chest that is tender to touch. Which of the following is most likely associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
This patient with tender, peeling skin of her face and chest, oral pain, and mucosal erosions following a prodrome of an influenza-like illness is most likely suffering from Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS). It was likely triggered by a new medication (such as lamotrigine) for her seizures.

SJS is a severe mucocutaneous type IV hypersensitivity reaction that results from cytotoxic T-cell-mediated destruction of keratinocytes expressing foreign antigens, leading to mucocutaneous erosions, necrosis, and detachment at the basement membrane. Toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN) is  considered a continuum of SJS. TEN differs in terms of the severity and percentage of the body surface area (BSA) affected:  

  •  SJS affects <10% of the BSA 
  •  SJS-TEN overlap when the affected region is 10-30% of the BSA 
  •  TEN >30% of the BSA 
SJS typically presents 4-28 days after exposure to a trigger, most commonly a drug (e.g., allopurinol, lamotrigine, carbamazepine, sulfonamides, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs). Other associated factors include Mycoplasma pneumoniae infection, vaccinations (rarely), and graft-versus-host disease. The onset is characterized by a prodrome of an influenza-like illness (fever, joint pain, malaise) followed by signs and symptoms of systemic toxicity (e.g., high-grade fever, tachycardia, hypotension, altered level of consciousness) and mucocutaneous eruption. The latter presents as erythematous macules, vesicles, and bullae which rapidly progress to skin sloughing and necrosis and mucosal erosions. Diagnosis is clinical, and management is supportive care with adequate fluid hydration.  

Option Analysis

❌ Herpes simplex virus infection  :
Incorrect: Viral infection caused by herpes simplex virus can lead to erythema multiforme, usually presenting with asymptomatic targetoid lesions. Herpetic vesicles instead of influenza-like symptoms (fever, malaise, joint pain) usually precede the onset of these lesions. This patient has no such rash.  
✅ Medication side-effect  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Sun exposure:
Incorrect: Excessive sun exposure can cause sunburn, which presents with tender, blanching erythema, blister formation, and peeling skin. Mucosal erosions, however, are not usually seen.  
❌ Tick bite  :
Incorrect: Ixodes tick bite can lead to the development of erythema migrans (EM), the earliest manifestation of Lyme disease. EM typically presents with a painless “bull’s eye” rash 1-2 weeks after the bite. Although this patient has a history of travel to a Lyme endemic area, her painful and tender mucocutaneous lesions and hemodynamic instability suggest an alternative diagnosis.  
❌ Pregnancy  :
Incorrect: Although pregnancy can precipitate inflammatory dermatoses, this usually occurs in the third trimester. The lesions are usually papular or eczematous and start from stretch marks in the periumbilical region. Tenderness and mucosal erosions are not commonly seen.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy presents to his family physician accompanied by his parents. The patient’s parents are concerned about the patient’s behavior. Over the past six months, the patient has been repeatedly arguing with his parents and performing poorly in school. The patient regularly gets into fights, resulting in several suspensions. Six months ago, the patient did not make the varsity football team, as he usually had every year prior. The patient states, “All I need from you is acne medication, not lessons in how to live my life!” The patient refuses assessment of his vitals. On initial physical assessment, the patient has severe acne, is extremely muscular, and has evidence of male pattern baldness. Which of the following best describes this patient’s expected laboratory findings?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation of extreme irritability, robust muscular build, severe acne, and male pattern baldness is suggestive of exogenous steroid abuse. High levels of circulating testosterone suppress the hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal axis, resulting in extremely low levels of circulating GnRH, FSH and LH (also known as hypogonadotropic hypogonadism). Additional laboratory findings include a low TSH and prolactin levels.

Once the exogenous steroids have been discontinued, patients continue to have hypogonadism due to testicular atrophy. However, the hypothalamic-pituitary axis now senses the low levels of testosterone and responds by attempting to stimulate the atrophied testes by producing increased GnRH, FSH and LH. This phenomenon is termed hypergonadotropic hypogonadism.  



Option Analysis

✅ Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Hypergonadotropic hypogonadism  :
Incorrect: In the case of discontinued exogenous anabolic steroids, the testes have not been producing normal amounts of testosterone and have subsequently atrophied. Upon discontinuation of the exogenous steroids, there is a reflexive increase in luteinizing hormone (LH) and follicle stimulating hormone (FSH) via gonadotropin releasing hormone (GnRH) secretion.  
❌ Normal hormonal panel  :
Incorrect: This patient’s behavior is beyond normal for an irritable teenager, and his physical exam findings are suggestive of exogenous steroid abuse.  
❌ Hypothalamic hypogonadism  :
Incorrect: This patient’s presentation points towards an excess of circulating testosterone, which instead causes hypogonadotropic hypogonadism.  
❌ High dihydrotestosterone levels  :
Incorrect: Dihydrotestosterone (DHT) is the biologically active, more potent form of testosterone. This patient, based on his history of irritability, physical musculature and male pattern baldness, is likely to have high amounts of exogenous testosterone, not DHT.

questions.text: A 64-year-old individual undergoes further evaluation by a nephrologist after being found to have elevated blood pressure and proteinuria. The patient underwent successful kidney transplantation two years ago and has been taking tacrolimus daily. Past medical history is significant for type II diabetes mellitus complicated with diabetic nephropathy and end-stage renal disease. The patient tells the physician that they are not completely adherent to their medication as they sometimes forget to take it. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 92/minute, and blood pressure is 160/95 mmHg. The patient has not had hypertension in the past. Laboratory evaluation shows elevated serum creatinine in addition to proteinuria. A biopsy is taken from the transplanted kidney and shows arteriosclerosis of the transplanted organ vessels in addition to parenchymal fibrosis and tubular atrophy. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient is most likely having chronic renal transplant rejection. Chronic transplant rejection is one of the most common causes of graft rejection, and it typically develops one year after transplantation. The pathophysiology of chronic graft rejection involves both the cellular and humoral immune responses:  

  •  Antibody-mediated injury (type II hypersensitivity reaction) occurs due to development of donor specific antibodies against HLA and non-HLA antigens. These antibodies induce graft endothelial damage both directly and indirectly via complement activation and recruitment of other immune inflammatory cells.  
  • Cell-mediated injury (type IV hypersensitivity reaction) occurs when antigen-presenting cells (APC) present the graft antigens to the T-cells, leading to T-cell activation. After T-cells are activated, they begin secreting several cytokines, including interferon-gamma (IFN-γ) and transforming growth factor-beta (TGF-beta). This cytokine release eventually induces an immune response, leading to graft rejection.
Histologically, chronic transplant rejection is characterized by interstitial fibrosis, tubular atrophy, arteriolar hyalinosis, and hyaline arteriolar thickening (arteriosclerosis). However, chronic transplant rejection is organ-specific depending on the transplanted organ. Some organ-specific examples of chronic transplant rejection include:

  1.  Bronchiolitis obliterans is a form of chronic lung transplant rejection.
  2.  Vanishing bile duct syndrome is a form of chronic liver transplant rejection and is characterized by a decreased number of bile ducts and obliteration of small arteries.  
  3. Chronic allograft nephropathy is a form of chronic kidney transplant rejection.

Option Analysis

✅ Chronic transplant rejection:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Acute transplant rejection :
Incorrect: Acute transplant rejection usually occurs between three months to one year following transplant. Histologically, it is characterized by vasculitis and dense lymphocytic interstitial infiltration. This patient most likely has chronic, not acute, rejection.
❌ Hyperacute transplant rejection:
Incorrect: Hyperacute transplant rejection happens minutes to hours after transplant due to preformed antibodies against the graft antigens. It does not occur two years after transplant. 
❌ BK virus nephropathy:
Incorrect: Although BK virus nephropathy can lead to kidney transplant failure, histology typically reveals viral inclusions (i.e. intranuclear cytoplasmic inclusions) within kidney cells. 
❌ Calcineurin inhibitor toxicity:
