Incorrect: Calcineurin inhibitors (e.g., tacrolimus, cyclosporine) are highly nephrotoxic immunosuppressants. However, the histological findings in this patient instead suggest chronic renal transplant rejection.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of an acute-onset, severe headache. The patient was preparing dinner when she suddenly lost consciousness and fell to the floor. Upon awakening, the patient endorsed “the worst headache of my life.” Her medical history is notable for a ventricular septal defect repaired during childhood. She is nauseated and has vomited twice. Temperature is 36.2°C (97.1°F), pulse is 100/min, and blood pressure is 150/90 mmHg. On physical examination, the patient appears in acute distress due to pain. Her pupils are equal and reactive to light. A non-contrast CT is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient's clinical presentation?  


Retrieved from: ">Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
This previously healthy woman presents with a sudden onset, severe headache and loss of consciousness. The CT demonstrates a hyperdense collection within the Circle of Willis, confirming the diagnosis of subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH).

SAH refers to the pooling of blood in the subarachnoid space. Major causes include rupture of a pre-existing saccular “berry” aneurysm (most common) or, less commonly, bleeding from an arteriovenous malformation, tumor or traumatic injury. Patients often present with the “worst headache of my life” (thunderclap headache) or a headache that reaches maximum intensity within seconds to minutes.

Common findings include a brief loss of consciousness, vomiting, neck pain/stiffness, and focal neurologic deficits. Diagnosis is performed with a non-contrast CT-brain that will reveal blood in the subarachnoid space. If inconclusive, lumbar puncture is indicated, which may show bloody or yellow cerebrospinal fluid called xanthochromia (as a result of the broken down blood products in the CSF). Treatment of SAH involves surgical clipping or coiling of the ruptured aneurysm.

 

Option Analysis

❌ Hypertensive encephalopathy:
Incorrect: Hypertensive encephalopathy refers to the altered mentation observed in patients with a hypertensive emergency. Other manifestations of hypertensive emergency include stroke, retinal hemorrhages and exudates, papilledema, myocardial infarction, heart failure, kidney injury, and microangiopathic hemolytic anemia. The presence of a hyperdense collection around the Circle of Willis seen on this CT favors another diagnosis.
❌ Intracerebral hemorrhage  :
Incorrect: Intracerebral hemorrhage may present with headache, vomiting, and altered mentation that typically develop when the hemorrhage becomes large enough. Other signs and symptoms depend on the location and size of the bleeding. In contrast to subarachnoid hemorrhage, the symptoms associated with intracerebral hemorrhage typically develop gradually over hours. The presence of a hyperdense collection around the Circle of Willis seen on this CT favors another diagnosis.  
❌ Cluster headache:
Incorrect: Cluster headaches are characterized by a severe unilateral headache with associated  autonomic symptoms ipsilateral to the pain. Episodes generally occur at the same time of the day or multiple times per day, lasting 15 minutes to 3 hours. However, CT findings are normal in patients presenting with cluster headaches.  
✅ Berry aneurysm:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Paradoxical emboli:
Incorrect: Paradoxical embolism refers to a systemic venous embolism that passes to the systemic arterial circulation through an atrioventricular septal defect and lodges in the brain vessels. While this patient did have a ventricular septal defect, it has been repaired, and thus she is no longer at risk of a paradoxical embolism. In addition, embolic events are unlikely to be visualized on a non-contrast CT-brain.

questions.text: A 47-year-old man is brought to the office by his son due to increased forgetfulness and fatigue for the past three months. He has also been frequently stumbling and experienced several near-falls while climbing stairs. Review of systems is also notable for abdominal pain and numbness in the patient’s hands and feet. Past medical history is unremarkable, and he does not take any medications. He has been working as an automobile mechanic for the last 20 years. Vitals are within normal limits. The abdomen is soft, nontender, and without organomegaly on physical examination. Neurological examination reveals weakness and reduced pinprick sensation in the bilateral hands and feet. Upper and lower limb reflexes are 2/5. Laboratory testing is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient has multiple symptoms suggestive of lead poisoning. These include:

Gastrointestinal symptoms: abdominal pain, constipation
Neurological symptoms: forgetfulness, peripheral neuropathy
Hematologic symptoms: microcytic anemia

Furthermore, chronic poisoning can also lead to nephropathy and hypertension.

Lead is absorbed through the lungs, skin, and GI tract. It then binds to erythrocytes where it interferes with enzymes involved in the heme pathway, leading to decreased hemoglobin synthesis. Common causes of lead toxicity in adults include occupational exposures, such as exposure to lead paint, batteries, and ammunition. Children can develop lead poisoning from ingesting lead-containing paint chips, which may be found in homes built before 1978.

Capillary blood tests are used for lead poisoning screening. However, the test can give false positives. Therefore, the diagnosis should be confirmed with venous lead levels. A complete blood count can be obtained to evaluate for microcytic anemia, and a peripheral blood smear may show basophilic stippling. Treatment involves removal of the lead source and chelation therapy with agents such as dimercaptosuccinic acid (also called succimer), dimercaprol, and calcium disodium edetate.  

Option Analysis

❌ Arsenic poisoning:
Incorrect: Arsenic toxicity often occurs due to occupational exposure or consumption of contaminated water or food. Arsenic binds to sulfhydryl groups and impairs cellular respiration. Symptoms include peripheral neuropathy, skin hyper/hypopigmentation, hyperkeratosis, pancytopenia, and transaminitis. This patient’s symptoms are instead more consistent with lead poisoning.  
❌ Vitamin B12 deficiency:
Incorrect: Vitamin B12 deficiency can result in subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord–manifesting with gait disturbance and impaired vibration sense. However, this condition is associated with a macrocytic, not microcytic, anemia.  
✅ Lead poisoning:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Iron overdose:
Incorrect: Iron toxicity most commonly occurs in children due to accidental ingestion of iron tablets. Local toxicity presents with abdominal pain, vomiting, diarrhea, and bleeding. Patients may develop systemic toxicity, which can cause distributive and cardiogenic shock as well as liver necrosis. Laboratory testing will reveal an anion gap metabolic acidosis. However, this patient has peripheral neuropathy, forgetfulness, and microcytic anemia, which are more concerning for lead poisoning.  
❌ Parkinson disease:
Incorrect: Patients with Parkinson disease present with a shuffling gait, resting tremors, and muscle rigidity. Peripheral neuropathy and microcytic anemia are not usually associated with Parkinson disease.

questions.text: A 58 year-old female comes to her primary care physician for evaluation of urinary leakage that has persisted for several months. The patient reports that these episodes occur when she coughs or sneezes. She denies dysuria or urgency. Past medical history is notable for 4 spontaneous vaginal deliveries and type 2 diabetes mellitus. She is currently taking metformin. Speculum exam reveals atrophic vaginal walls. Testing with a Q-tip is positive. Bladder postvoid residual volume is 50 ml and her most recent HbA1c was 6.8%. Which of the following best describes the pathophysiology of this patient’s symptoms?

choices.text: Infection of the urinary tract by gram-negative bacteria
Hypermobile urethra secondary to pelvic floor muscle weakness
Abnormal connection between the bladder and vagina
Excessive urine production secondary to osmotic diuresis

questions.solution:
This patient has stress incontinence, which presents as urinary incontinence triggered by events that increase intra-abdominal pressure (e.g., coughing, sneezing, laughing). A common cause is a hypermobile urethra, which causes increases in abdominal pressure to be transmitted more to the bladder and less to the urethra. As a result, pressure within the bladder will exceed that within the urethra, resulting in urine expulsion. Other causes of stress incontinence include weak pelvic floor muscles and reduced urethral sphincter tone.  

Stress incontinence can be diagnosed by performing a history & physical exam. During the physical exam, urethral mobility can be assessed using a Q-tip. In addition, a bladder stress test, which involves observing for urine leakage while the patient coughs or performs the Valsalva maneuver, can be done. A urinalysis can help rule out UTIs, and an ultrasound can measure the post-void residual volume. Urodynamic studies, which involve using a small catheter to fill the bladder, are more invasive and reserved for unclear/complex cases.  

Lifestyle and behavioral modifications, including weight loss, caffeine restriction, and strengthening of pelvic floor muscles via Kegel exercises, are the first-line treatment. Vaginal pessaries, devices that restore normal anatomy by physically elevating the urethra, can be utilized in female patients. If the aforementioned conservative methods fail, surgical intervention such as placement of a midurethral sling may be necessary.  


Option Analysis

❌ Infection of the urinary tract by gram-negative bacteria:
Incorrect: This describes a urinary tract infection (UTI), which may cause urinary incontinence. UTIs can range from being asymptomatic to causing fever, dysuria, and urge incontinence. However, this patient’s history of urine leakage when coughing and sneezing is most consistent with stress incontinence. It is atypical for UTIs to cause stress incontinence.  
✅ Hypermobile urethra secondary to pelvic floor muscle weakness:
 Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Abnormal connection between the bladder and vagina:
Incorrect: This describes a vesicovaginal fistula. In patients with this condition, urine from the bladder can pass through the fistula, resulting in continuous incontinence. Pooling of urine in the vagina may be seen on a speculum exam. Risk factors include pelvic radiation and pelvic surgery. In contrast, the patient in this vignette has a normal speculum exam and none of the aforementioned risk factors.    
❌ Neuropathy causing impaired detrusor contractility:
Incorrect: Poorly controlled diabetes can cause autonomic neuropathy and an underactive detrusor muscle, resulting in overflow incontinence. The condition may present clinically as frequent urinary dribbling or a sense of fullness in the lower abdomen. However, this patient’s blood glucose is well-managed, as reflected through her HbA1c value. Moreover, the patient’s normal postvoid residual volume suggests that detrusor function is intact, and the bladder is able to empty normally.   
❌  Excessive urine production secondary to osmotic diuresis:
Incorrect: Patients with poorly-controlled diabetes mellitus can have elevated blood and urine glucose levels. This may impair water reabsorption in the renal tubules and result in polyuria. However, patients with polyuria would more likely present with symptoms of urge incontinence rather than the symptoms of stress incontinence described in this vignette.

questions.text:
A 46-year-old man comes to his primary care provider regarding mouth discomfort and bleeding for the past several weeks. He noticed bleeding after brushing his teeth. The patient's medical history is notable for HIV infection, and he says that he has been poorly compliant with his antiretroviral medication. Physical examination shows an intraoral dark-brown lesion with an overlying plaque which is easily scraped. Biopsy of the lesion shows significant lymphocyte infiltration and the presence of spindle cells. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?  



Reproduced from from: Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
The patient most likely has Kaposi sarcoma (KS). KS is a low-grade vascular tumor caused by human herpesvirus virus 8 (HSV-8), which is transmitted via sexual contact. Although KS can involve virtually any part of the body, cutaneous disease is the most common initial presentation. The lesions of KS are elliptical pink, red, purple, or brown, and they are often found on the lower extremities, face, oral mucosa, and genitalia. The lesions are not painful and do not produce necrosis of overlying skin.  

Diagnosis is based upon the characteristic appearance, but sometimes biopsy is required for confirmation. Histologic examination of the lesions will likely show whorls of spindle-shaped cells with lymphocytic infiltration and aberrant proliferation of small vessels. While this condition is most often associated with HIV infection and immunosuppressed individuals, it can also rarely occur elderly men of Mediterranean or Sub-Saharan African descent.  



Retrieved from: Wikimedia Commons  

Option Analysis

❌ Bacillary angiomatosis:
 Incorrect: Bacillary angiomatosis is caused by Bartonella species, a gram-negative bacillus transmitted to humans, most commonly via scratch from an infected cat. Immunodeficient individuals may present with fever, fatigue, anorexia and characteristic vascular pedunculated skin lesions. Neutrophilic infiltrate, as opposed to this patient’s lymphocytic infiltrate, is found on biopsy.   
✅ Human herpesvirus infection  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Hairy leukoplakia:
Incorrect: Hairy leukoplakia is a benign squamous cell proliferation that presents as irregular, white, painless plaques on the lateral tongue. It is Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) mediated and typically occurs in immunodeficient individuals. In contrast to candidiasis thrush (scrapable), leukoplakia cannot be scraped off.   
❌ Human papillomavirus infection:
Incorrect: Human papillomavirus infections mostly cause no symptoms and resolve spontaneously. In some, they persist and result in warts or precancerous lesions. The precancerous lesions increase the risk of cancer of the cervix, vulva, vagina, penis, anus, mouth, or throat. Nearly all cervical cancers are due to strains HPV-16 and HPV-18. Papilloma lesions typically grow exophytically in finger-like fronds. Histopathologic examination typically shows hyperparakeratosis and koilocyte-like cells. This patient’s lesion favors another diagnosis.   
❌ Erythroplakia :
Incorrect: Erythroplakia is an uncommon oral lesion that carries a high risk of malignant transformation. It presents as a red, velvety, asymptomatic patch most commonly located on the tongue, floor of the mouth, and soft palate, and it is typically found in individuals who consume tobacco and alcohol. On histopathologic examination, erythroplakia shows dysplasia of variable grade, carcinoma in situ, or features of invasive squamous cell carcinoma.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents to his primary care physician due to changes in his bowel habits. The patient reports he has been experiencing alternating episodes of loose stools and constipation over the past several months, with associated cramping abdominal pain. The patient’s past medical history is significant for hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and diabetes. His past surgical history is notable for an appendectomy at age 18. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 18/min and blood pressure is 137/94 mmHg. BMI is 36 kg/m2. Physical examination shows a distended abdomen without focal tenderness, rebound, or guarding. A fecal occult blood test is positive. The patient undergoes a colonoscopy that demonstrates outpouchings of the colonic mucosa and submucosa in the descending colon. Which of the following best describes the pathophysiology of this disease process?

choices.text: Increased intraluminal pressure at points of vascular penetration
Failure of involution of the vitelline duct
Telescoping of a proximal colon segment into a distal segment
Erosion of adjacent loops of bowel due to full thickness granulomatous inflammation
Outpouchings surrounding a vestigial lymphoid structure

questions.solution:
The patient in this vignette presents with alternating constipation, diarrhea, and colickly abdominal pain with a colonoscopy that reveals outpouchings of the mucosa and submucosa. Together, these findings are consistent with a diagnosis of diverticulosis. Diverticulosis is the presence of multiple false diverticula, or pseudodiverticula, which occur only when the mucosa and submucosa outpouch. They are thought to be due to prolonged increased intraluminal pressure from diets poor in fiber at the weakest points of the gastrointestinal tract, where the vasa recta perforate the muscularis externa. Diverticula may also bleed intermittently, resulting in anemia or a positive fecal occult blood test, or they may become infected, resulting in diverticulitis.  

In contrast to false diverticula, true diverticula, such as a Meckel's diverticulum or inherited diverticula of the appendix, contain all layers of the bowel wall. True diverticula are much less common in comparison to false or pseudodiverticula.  



Option Analysis

✅ Increased intraluminal pressure at points of vascular penetration:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Failure of involution of the vitelline duct:
Incorrect: This answer describes the pathophysiology of a Meckel's diverticulum, which contains all layers of the colonic wall, not just the mucosa and submucosa. Meckel’s diverticulum is a remnant of the omphalomesenteric (vitelline) duct, and it is the most common congenital malformation of the gastrointestinal tract. It usually presents in pediatric patients with painless hematochezia, or it is discovered incidentally during colonoscopy at the terminal ileum.  
❌ Telescoping of a proximal colon segment into a distal segment  :
Incorrect: This answer describes the pathophysiology of intussusception, which occurs when a lead point (such as a Meckel's diverticulum, lymphoid tissue, or tumor) causes the proximal end of bowel to peristalse into the more distal end. Intussusception can present with colicky abdominal pain in both pediatric patients and adults, although it is much more common in the pediatric population. Intussusception is unlikely in this patient without an identifiable lead point visualized on colonoscopy.   
❌ Erosion of adjacent loops of bowel due to full thickness granulomatous inflammation:
Incorrect: This answer describes fistula formation due to Crohn's disease, which results in full thickness inflammation of all layers of the colon or small bowel. While Crohn’s disease can present with hematochezia or a positive fecal occult blood test, it is generally associated with additional constitutional symptoms such as weight loss, arthralgias and fever.   
❌ Outpouchings surrounding a vestigial lymphoid structure  :
Incorrect: Diverticula can form around the appendix resulting in an increased risk of obstruction and subsequent appendicitis; however this patient’s appendix has been removed, and his diverticula are noted in the more distal colon, away from the site of the appendix.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old woman begins complaining of chest pain in the post-anesthesia care unit after undergoing an upper endoscopy for evaluation of esophageal varices. She states the pain radiates to the back. She also complains of dyspnea, nausea, and she has produced blood-tinged vomitus. Past medical history is notable for chronic alcohol use disorder and liver cirrhosis. Her temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), blood pressure is 107/61 mmHg, and pulse is 82/min. Physical examination shows a woman in acute distress. Crackles are heard while auscultating over the heart. Abdominal exam is notable for hepatosplenomegaly. CT imaging reveals the following:  



Reproduced from: Radiopedia  

Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s presentation?

choices.text: Aspiration of gastric contents while unconscious

questions.solution:
This patient has an esophageal perforation, which can cause chest pain radiating to the back, vomiting, hematemesis, and melena. In addition, once esophageal perforation has occurred, it can lead to mediastinitis (inflammation of the mediastinum), pneumomediastinum (air surrounding the heart), and subcutaneous emphysema (presence of air in the subcutaneous tissue). Specifically, in this patient’s case, air has left the esophagus and accumulated in the mediastinum. This explains why crackles were heard during heart auscultation and why mediastinal air pockets are seen on CT (Figure 1).    

The causes of esophageal perforation can be divided into iatrogenic and non-iatrogenic causes. Perforation during endoscopic procedures is the most common iatrogenic cause. Non-iatrogenic causes include spontaneous rupture, trauma, foreign body ingestion, and malignancy.  

Diagnosis of esophageal rupture can be made using x-ray, which will show air that has escaped the esophagus, followed by a contrast esophagram, which will confirm the diagnosis, as well as determine the size and location of the perforation. A CT scan can be used in cases when a contrast esophagram cannot be performed (e.g. if a patient is hemodynamically unstable or uncooperative) or if the results come back inconclusive. Most cases typically require surgical management of the perforation.  

Image 1: Esophageal perforation with annotations (white arrows)  



Reproduced from: Radiopedia 

Option Analysis

❌ Anesthetic side-effect  :
Incorrect: Anesthetic agents may cause postoperative nausea and discomfort. However, anesthesia would not account for the crackles that were auscultated on physical exam or pneumomediastinum found on CT scan.  
✅ Iatrogenic perforation of the esophagus:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Laceration of the esophageal mucosa:
Incorrect: It is possible for an endoscope to lacerate and cause bleeding from the esophageal mucosa. This would account for the patient’s blood-tinged vomitus. However, even if the mucosa were lacerated, the esophagus would still be surrounded by connective tissue and muscle. As a result, a mucosal laceration would not explain why this patient has air in the mediastinum.  
❌ Rupture of dilated esophageal veins:
Incorrect: Rupture of esophageal varices can cause upper GI bleeding, which can lead to nausea and vomiting. However, this mechanism would not account for the patient’s pneumomediastinum, which would occur only if a full-thickness esophageal perforation had occurred.  
❌ Aspiration of gastric contents while unconscious:
Incorrect: Anesthetized patients are at increased risk of aspiration pneumonia, in part due to reduced laryngeal protective reflexes. Patients may present with chest discomfort, dyspnea, cough, and fever. However the patient’s physical exam findings and imaging findings, which suggest the presence of air in the mediastinum, raise greater concerns for esophageal perforation.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman comes to the clinic complaining of episodes of dizziness for the past month. The patient reports that the dizziness usually occurs when she gets up from bed, gets up from a seated position, or turns her head, and it lasts for approximately 30 seconds. During these episodes, she feels as though the room is spinning around her, which is accompanied by nausea. Medical history is significant for hypertension, which is treated with hydrochlorothiazide. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows right-beating and torsional nystagmus. Hearing is intact, and the rest of the physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is most likely responsible for this patient's presentation?

choices.text: Inflammation of the vestibulocochlear nerve (CN VIII)
Excessive build-up of the endolymph fluid

questions.solution:
This patient, who presents with isolated complaints of vertigo that occurs mainly with head rotation and position changes, most likely has benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV). The diagnosis of BPPV can be confirmed by the Dix-Hallpike maneuver, in which the physician extends the patient's neck and turns it to one side while the patient is sitting, followed by rapidly placing them in a supine position so that their head hangs over the edge of the bed. On a positive test there will be nystagmus or vertigo.  

BPPV is one of the most common causes of peripheral vertigo; it is characterized by episodes of spinning sensation provoked by head rotation and position changes which last approximately 30 seconds. The condition is attributed to calcium debris within the semicircular canals, known as canalithiasis. This debris likely represents loose calcium carbonate crystals originating from the utricular sac. Under normal conditions, the semicircular canals detect angular head accelerations. Debris accumulation in the canal causes inappropriate movement of the endolymph with linear accelerations, creating a false sensation of spinning when the head shifts. While symptoms can be disabling, the disorder typically responds to treatment with particle-repositioning maneuvers (Epley maneuver) in the office upon diagnosis.  

 

Option Analysis

❌ Depletion of body fluids:
Incorrect: This answer choice refers to orthostatic hypotension, which is diagnosed when a person's blood pressure falls upon standing or sitting. Although hydrochlorothiazide use does increase the risk for orthostatic hypotension, this phenomenon would not cause nystagmus or vertigo.   
❌ Arterial insufficiency:
Incorrect: Rotational vertebral artery syndrome refers to a phenomenon of symptomatic posterior circulation ischemia from the compression of the vertebral arteries by bony elements of the spine (usually at CI-C2) which occurs upon head rotation. Patients may present with recurrent syncope, vertigo, nystagmus, ataxia, diplopia, nausea, dysarthria, or dysphagia. Although some of this patient’s symptoms overlap with rotational vertebral artery syndrome, standing would not cause the symptoms.   
❌ Inflammation of the vestibulocochlear nerve (CN VIII):
Incorrect: Inflammation of the eighth cranial nerve causes vestibular neuritis or labyrinthitis. It is thought to be a viral or post-viral inflammatory disorder which leads to inflammation of the vestibular portion of the nerve. Patients often present with severe vertigo and possibly hearing loss and tinnitus. It typically occurs as an acute attack that lasts for days. This patient’s presentation and duration of symptoms favor another diagnosis.  
✅ Debris within the semicircular canal  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Excessive build-up of the endolymph fluid:
Incorrect: Excessive build-up of the endolymph fluid, also known as endolymphatic hydrops, describes the hypothesis behind Ménière disease. The condition is characterized by episodic vertigo, tinnitus, and hearing loss. It is thought to occur due to an abnormality in the flow of endolymph or in the resorption of endolymph. The increased volume of the endolymph can lead to damage of the cochlea and the vestibular system of the inner ear. This patient’s presentation and intact hearing favor another diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 37-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with acute onset shortness of breath. The patient reports she was on a walk when she suddenly had sharp chest pain worse with inspiration. The patient reports she is otherwise healthy. Her only medication is a combined oral contraceptive pill, which she recently started taking for birth control. She is a current smoker, she drinks 3-4 beers daily and she occasionally uses cocaine. The patient reports she was recently incarcerated. While in the ED, she is noted to have an episode of hemoptysis. Her temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 107/min, respirations are 22/min, blood pressure is 108/80 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation is 90% on room air. Her chest x-ray and ECG and shown below. Which of the following best describes the pathophysiology of this disease process?  



Reproduced from: Radiopaedia



Reproduced from: Wikipedia

choices.text: Vasospasm of a large coronary artery
Intimal dissection of the ascending aorta

questions.solution:
This patient presents with acute onset pleuritic chest pain, tachypnea, tachycardia, hypoxemia in the setting of recent initiation of oral contraceptive pills, which is concerning for a pulmonary embolism. Additionally, her chest x-ray reveals a wedge-shaped infarct known as Hampton's hump (indicated by the red circle below) and an electrocardiogram with an S1Q3T3 pattern, which is consistent with right heart strain.   

Oral contraceptive pills, particularly those with a higher concentration of estrogen, are known to increase the risk of venous thromboembolism (VTE) as high as five-fold. The mechanism is still poorly understood, but it is thought to be due to an estrogen-induced increase in clotting factor synthesis. VTE risk may be compounded by thrombophilic disorders, active malignancies, prolonged immobilization, and recent surgery or trauma. These risk factors contribute to venous stasis, endothelial injury, and a hypercoagulable state -- also known as Virchow’s triad.  

Typically, pulmonary emboli originate in the deep veins of the leg, dislodge, and migrate upward via the vena cava to the right side of the heart. As the right heart beats, the clot propels into the pulmonary arteries, causing a ventilation-perfusion (VQ) mismatch which results in respiratory alkalosis, pleuritic chest pain, hypoxemia and a low pCO2. If the clot becomes large, the right heart may fail due to the increased strain, resulting in cor pulmonale and cardiogenic shock.  

 

Option Analysis

❌ Subacute infection with a mycobacteria:
Incorrect: This patient has risk factors for tuberculosis infection, including recent incarceration. Her chest x-ray demonstrates a wedge shaped infarct known as Hamptons sign, whereas tuberculosis typically presents with bilateral infiltrates in the apical-posterior segments of the upper lobes, along with associated symptoms of weight loss, malaise, and night-sweats.   
✅ Hormone-induced thrombophilia:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Vasospasm of a large coronary artery:
Incorrect: Cocaine-induced vasospasm may demonstrate characteristic symptoms of acute coronary syndrome, including chest pain that is worse with exertion, pressure-like, and relieved with rest or nitroglycerin. Typically, patients will manifest ST-depressions or elevations as opposed to the pattern of right heart strain as seen on this patient’s ECG.   
❌ Intimal dissection of the ascending aorta  :
Incorrect: Cocaine and uncontrolled hypertension can manifest in aortic dissection, which typically presents with acute onset tearing chest pain radiating to the back. A chest x-ray will often demonstrate a widened mediastinum or a tortuous aorta, which is not observed in this case.   
❌ Rib fractures  :
Incorrect: Rib fractures can cause pleuritic chest pain; however, this chest x-ray is without evidence of rib fractures, and the patient has no history of recent trauma.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old woman comes to the clinic due to hip pain that began after she slipped and fell on her side while going down the stairs 2 hours ago. Past medical history is significant for osteoarthritis. The patient has had recent difficulty walking due to hip pain but is otherwise healthy. Vitals are within normal limits. On physical exam, the right hip is tender to touch and peripheral pulses are intact. An x-ray of the lower extremities is obtained (shown below) and no fractures or displacements are seen. Which of the following is responsible for the appearance of this patient’s femoral arteries?  



Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons

choices.text: Deposition of calcium without luminal narrowing
Separation of the media and intima

questions.solution:
This asymptomatic patient, without claudication and intact peripheral pulses, is found to have an incidental finding on x-ray of the hip, which most indicative of Mönckeberg sclerosis (medial calcific sclerosis). It is an uncommon condition caused by calcification of the internal elastic lamina and media (but spares the intima) of arteries, leading to vascular stiffening without luminal obstruction. It is often described as a “pipestem” appearance on x-ray. Typically, Mönckeberg arteriosclerosis is asymptomatic, unless complicated by atherosclerosis or calciphylaxis. The pathogenesis is not well understood, but the condition is thought to be the consequence of disordered calcium phosphate regulation in the blood vessel, leading to calcium phosphate crystals (hydroxyapatite) deposition.  

Mönckeberg sclerosis is a benign variant of arteriosclerosis, and the differences between different types of arteriosclerosis are shown in the table below:  



Option Analysis

❌ Proliferation of smooth muscle cells:
Incorrect: Proliferation of smooth muscle cells is seen in hyperplastic arteriolosclerosis (“onion skinning”), which is due to severe hypertension. This patient has no prior history of hypertension, and hyperplastic arteriolosclerosis is not likely to be seen on x-ray; instead, diagnosis requires biopsy of an artery.   
❌ Deposition of hyaline:
Incorrect: Hyaline arteriolosclerosis is seen in patients with essential hypertension or diabetes mellitus, due to protein deposition. It leads to thickening of the vessel wall and seen as homogeneous pink material under the microscope. This patient has no associated medical conditions (e.g., diabetes mellitus, hypertension), and hyaline arteriolosclerosis is not likely to be seen on x-ray; instead, diagnosis requires biopsy of an artery.   
❌ Intimal fatty streak formation:
Incorrect: Intimal fatty streak formation and buildup of cholesterol plaques is seen in atherosclerosis. Most people at the age of 55 will have some degree of atherosclerosis; however, this would not be demonstrated on x-ray imaging in this way.  
✅ Deposition of calcium without luminal narrowing  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Separation of the media and intima:
Incorrect: Separation of the media and intima can occur in aortic dissection, which presents as tearing chest pain that radiates to the back. Chest x-ray might show a widened mediastinum; however, only arteriography can recognize the layer separation. Additionally, separation of the arterial media in the femoral arteries is unlikely.   
❌ Inflammation of the media:
Incorrect: Inflammation of the arterial media can be seen in certain types of vasculitis (e.g., temporal and Takayasu arteritis); however, evidence of these conditions would be seen only on arterial biopsy and would not be detected on x-ray imaging.

questions.text: A 60-year old male comes to the clinic complaining of numbness in his toes. He cannot quite pinpoint exactly when it started, but for at least the past 3 months the patient has been unable to feel his big toes in his shoes. The patient is able to walk without any weakness in the legs, and he does not have any symptoms in the arms or fingers. The patient’s diet consists mostly of processed food and contains very few raw fruits or vegetables. Medical history includes obesity, chronic lower back pain, and type 2 diabetes. Medications include tylenol and metformin. The patient’s temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. Physical examination reveals the patient to be comfortable, and the extremity exam demonstrates bilaterally diminished ankle reflexes and loss of monofilament sensation over the forefront of both plantar surfaces. Laboratory studies show a normal complete blood count and a hemoblogin A1c of 10.5%. Which of the following mechanisms is most likely contributing to this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with classic symptoms of diabetic neuropathy. Diabetic neuropathy refers to the gradual loss of function of large and small myelinated and unmyelinated nerve fibers, starting distally, leading to symptoms of numbness, weakness, tinging, and pain. The process starts in the feet first, and typically once it reaches halfway up the calves, it begins in the fingers, leading to a “stocking-glove” distribution. Diabetic neuropathy should be suspected in patients with type 1 diabetes 5 years after diagnosis and in all patients with type 2 diabetes, and it is screened for by monofilament testing.  

The chronic hyperglycemia of diabetes damages nerves through multiple mechanisms, but an especially important mechanism is through osmotic cellular damage. Normally, when glucose enters cells, it can be converted to sorbitol by the enzyme aldose reductase. Sorbitol is an osmotic agent, meaning it attracts water into the cells. As a protective mechanism, cells are able to convert sorbitol to fructose with the enzyme sorbitol dehydrogenase; however, the cells of the lens, the pericytes in the retina, Schwann cells and renal epithelial cells lack this enzyme. Therefore, in these cells, sorbitol accumulates, causing osmotic swelling and cell membrane damage, which leads to demyelination in the case of Schwann cells.  

The loss of sensation makes affected body parts more prone to injury and drives the development of diabetic foot ulcers. Then, hyperglycemia impairs ulcer healing, which can progress and cause osteomyelitis. Strict glycemic control can stop the progression of diabetic neuropathy.  



Option Analysis

❌ Fructose excess:
Incorrect: Fructose is produced from sorbitol by the enzyme sorbitol dehydrogenase. In the setting of hyperglycemia from diabetes, excess glucose is metabolised to sorbitol and then to fructose in the cells that contain sorbitol dehydrogenase. High intracellular fructose does not damage neurons.  
❌ NADPH excess:
Incorrect: In the setting of hyperglycemia, excess glucose is metabolised to sorbitol by aldose reductase. This reaction uses NADPH and produces NADP+, which leads to a decreased concentration of NADPH. With less NADPH, other reactions like the synthesis of myo-inositol (which is crucial for nerve function) are reduced, which can lead to neuropathy.  
❌ Aldose reductase deficiency  :
Incorrect: Aldose reductase converts glucose to sorbitol, utilizing NADPH as a cofactor. Normally, glucose is phosphorylated by hexokinase, but in the setting of hyperglycemia, hexokinase becomes saturated, and aldose reductase begins to metabolize the excess glucose.   
✅ Sorbitol dehydrogenase deficiency:
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Protein kinase C deactivation:
Incorrect: Elevated glucose levels lead to increased glycolysis and the creation of diacylglycerol. Diacylglycerol activates protein kinase C, which produces vasoconstriction and nerve hypoxia, leading to damage. It is one of the mechanisms responsible for causing diabetic neuropathy.

questions.text:
A 4-week-old newborn boy is brought to the emergency department by his parents due to irritability and difficulty feeding over the past few days. He was born through normal vaginal birth and delivery to a 24-year-old primigravida woman who did not receive prenatal care. The patient’s family history is unremarkable. The patient’s temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 70/min, respirations are 40/min, and blood pressure is 120/80 mmHg. On physical examination, frontal bossing and prominent scalp veins are noted. Generalized spasticity is present in all limbs. Examination of the skin shows a hair patch over the lower back with a gap under the skin. An MRI of the brain is obtained and shown below:  



Retrieved from: Wikimedia Commons    

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This infant is presenting with signs of congenital hydrocephalus (e.g., frontal bossing, prominent scalp veins) and signs of increased intracranial pressure (evidenced by bradycardia, hypertension, and irritability). The MRI reveals a hypoplasia or agenesis of the cerebellar vermis, which is characteristic of Dandy-Walker malformation. The hair patch signifies an underlying spina bifida occulta.

Dandy-Walker is a rare congenital malformation marked by agenesis or hypoplasia of the cerebellar vermis (indicated by the red circle on the head MRI), with cystic dilatation of the 4th ventricle and extension of the posterior fossa. Clinical presentation is dependent on the severity of the anomaly. The majority of patients usually present with signs and symptoms of hydrocephalus and associated neurological symptoms in the first year of life. The condition is often associated with spina bifida (occulta, meningocele, or myelomeningocele).    







Option Analysis

❌ Chiari I malformation:
Incorrect: Chiari I malformation is a congenital brain anomaly characterized by herniation of the cerebellar tonsils into the foramen magnum. The condition is usually asymptomatic during childhood and manifests in adulthood with headaches, elevated intracranial pressure, and cranial neuropathies. It often occurs in conjunction with syringomyelia, which is a cavitation within the central canal of the spinal cord. This patient’s MRI favors another diagnosis.   
❌ Chiari II malformation:
Incorrect: Chiari II malformation is a congenital brain anomaly characterized by herniation of both the cerebellar vermis and tonsils via the foramen magnum, leading to aqueductal stenosis, and noncommunicating hydrocephalus. Chiari II is often seen with myelomeningocele and is more likely to present early in life. However, this patient’s MRI favors another diagnosis.   
✅ Dandy-Walker malformation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Lissencephaly:
Incorrect: Lissencephaly (meaning "smooth brain") is a central nervous system disorder characterized by a smooth appearance of the brain surface due to the lack of development of gyri and sulci. The pathogenesis involves defective neuronal migration, which normally occurs between the 12th to 24th weeks of gestation. This patient’s MRI favors another diagnosis.   
❌ Anencephaly :
Incorrect: Anencephaly is a type of open neural tube defect that occurs due to the failure of the rostral neuropore to close. On ultrasound or other imaging modality, anencephaly demonstrates the absence of brain and calvaria. The condition is incompatible with life, and infants die in utero or soon after birth.

questions.text: Q1. A 20-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her partner after finding the patient unconscious in her room in soiled clothes this afternoon. The partner states the patient has been under significant stress lately due to upcoming exams. Past medical history is significant for migraine, for which the patient takes topiramate. Vitals are within normal limits. The patient appears tired and confused and is unable to recall what happened. Physical examination shows a bite mark on the tongue. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s loss of consciousness?
questions.solution:
The examination findings in this patient, together with loss of consciousness and postictal state, are consistent with a diagnosis of generalized tonic-clonic seizure (GTCS). It is the most common type of generalized seizures, and it manifests as a generalized stiffness of muscles (tonic phase) that is followed by jerking and twitching (clonic phase). The patient loses consciousness during the episode and remains in deep sleep for a few minutes, followed by postictal confusion. The episode can be overlooked if the patient is alone. However, it is usually accompanied by tongue bite, urinary and/or fecal incontinence and amnesia of the event, all of which are seen in this patient. Certain triggers or precipitants tend to lower seizure threshold. These include, but are not limited to, strong emotions, flashing lights, fever, stress and lack of sleep (as in this patient).  

Option Analysis

❌ Vasovagal syncope:
Incorrect: Although emotional or orthostatic stress can be an inciting event for a vasovagal syncope in young individuals, it is not followed by postictal confusion, and the patient usually recalls a prodrome of pallor, dizziness, nausea or diaphoresis.  
❌ Medication side effect:
Incorrect: Medications that can induce or precipitate seizure activity in susceptible individuals include bupropion, isoniazid, lithium, monoamine oxidase inhibitors, tricyclic antidepressants, and several others. Topiramate is an anticonvulsant and can cause sedation, weight loss or renal calculi. It does not, however, precipitate seizures.  
❌ Migraine attack:
Incorrect: Migraine is an episodic disorder causing severe headache that is generally associated with nausea and/or light and sound sensitivity. Although it is also exacerbated by stress and sleep disturbance, it does not cause or precipitate seizure activity.  
❌ Psychogenic Non-Epileptic Seizure (PNES):
Incorrect: PNES is derived from psychological underpinnings and tends to occur in front of witnesses. Its duration is usually longer than 2 minutes and vocalization is observed during the episode. It is unlikely in this patient who was found alone with tongue bite, incontinence and postictal drowsiness and confusion.  
✅ Generalized tonic-clonic seizure (GTCS):
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes to the physician's office for a follow-up appointment after a car accident that required hospitalization. The patient was in the car accident 1 month ago, and he broke 2 ribs on the left side. During the hospitalization, a focused assessment with sonography in trauma (FAST) was obtained, and an incidental renal finding that was suspicious of a cyst was observed. The patient's medical history is unremarkable, and the patient reports that he feels well. Which of the following features if observed on imaging will favor the diagnosis of a benign lesion?

choices.text: Strong posterior wall echo on ultrasound
The presence of echoes within the mass on ultrasound
An enhancement of soft-tissue components with CT contrast
Irregular borders of the lesion on CT scan
Nodular calcification of the wall on CT scan

questions.solution:
Renal cysts can be categorized as simple or complex. Simple renal cysts are often observed in normal kidneys of healthy individuals, and the incidence increases with age (>50 years old). Simple renal cysts are benign, asymptomatic lesions that rarely require treatment. In contrast, complex cysts usually require follow-up imaging, biopsy, or surgical excision in order to exclude malignancy.  

The first step in evaluation is ultrasound, which helps to differentiate a cyst from malignancy or abscess as following:  

  •  Round mass, sharply demarcated with smooth walls. 
  •  No echoes (anechoic) within the mass. 
  •  Strong posterior wall echo, indicating good transmission through the cyst. 
If all three components of the criteria are satisfied, further evaluation is not necessary, since the likelihood of malignancy is low. If the results of the ultrasonogram are equivocal, if calcifications or septae are seen, or if multiple cysts could mask an underlying carcinoma, a CT scan should follow.  

A simple renal cyst is considered to be present if the following features are observed on CT scan:    

  •  A sharply demarcated lesion with a smooth, thin wall. 
  •  Homogeneous fluid within the cyst is, with a density of <20 Hounsfield units (similar to water).  
  •  No enhancement of the mass following the administration of contrast, indicating an avascular lesion. Enhancement implies vascularity, which is a characteristic of a malignant lesion.  
Findings suggestive of malignancy include thickened, irregular or smooth walls or septa and enhancement following contrast injection.  

 


Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons  
Simple renal cyst on ultrasound  



Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons  
Complex renal cyst on ultrasound  



Option Analysis

✅ Strong posterior wall echo on ultrasound:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ The presence of echoes within the mass on ultrasound:
Incorrect: Echoes within the mass on ultrasound are characteristic of a complex cyst, which requires further evaluation. Highly dense tissues, such as solid components, readily reflect echoes and appear bright white on an ultrasound.  
❌ An enhancement of soft-tissue components with CT contrast:
Incorrect: An enhancement of soft-tissue components with contrast indicates vascular lesion, which prompts further evaluation. Vascularity is a characteristic of a malignant lesion.   
❌ Irregular borders of the lesion on CT scan:
Incorrect: Irregular borders of the lesion are characteristic of a complex cyst that prompts further evaluation.   
❌ Nodular calcification of the wall on CT scan:
Incorrect: Nodular calcification of the wall is a feature of a complex cyst that requires further evaluation.

questions.text: A 25-year-old Caucasian woman presents to the emergency department due to difficulty breathing. Two hours ago, she suddenly felt chest pain accompanied by dyspnea. The patient denies any recent trauma, and she does not smoke or use illicit drugs. She is sexually active with her partner and uses condoms for contraception. The patient’s temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 75/min, and blood pressure is 118/73 mmHg. On physical examination, the patient appears distressed. Heart sounds are normal and the lungs are clear to auscultation. Labs show an elevated d-dimer. PT and PTT are 12 and 10 seconds, respectively. Purified protein C is added to the patient’s plasma and causes no change in the lab values. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This young patient who has no acquired risk factors for hypercoagulability (e.g., smoking, OCP use) is presenting with a pulmonary embolism, raising concerns for a hereditary cause. Factor V Leiden is the most common inherited hypercoagulability disorder in Caucasians with venous thromboembolism (VTE). Patients may be homozygous or heterozygous.  

Factor V is a procoagulant clotting factor that is synthesized as an inactive form and activated by thrombin at the wound site. Activated factor V then functions as a cofactor in the production of more thrombin from prothrombin. However, thrombin also halts its own production via a negative feedback loop. It does so by activating protein C (aPC), a protease that deactivates factor Va and factor VIIIa, thereby reducing thrombin production.    

Factor V Leiden deficiency is caused by a single point mutation in the factor V gene in which guanine is switched to adenine. The corresponding mRNA codon forms a polypeptide chain in which arginine is replaced by glutamine at position Arg506. Consequently, the cleavage site is altered and factor V can no longer be degraded by protein C.  

Patients are at increased risk for venous or arterial thromboembolism, MI, stroke, and obstetric complications. Laboratory testing often shows shortened or normal PTT. Diagnosis can be made via functional assay by demonstrating failure to prolong PTT with addition of purified protein C (protein C resistance). Definitive diagnosis is made via genetic testing.    







Option Analysis

❌ Protein S deficiency:
Incorrect: Protein S is a vitamin K-dependent protein that serves as a cofactor for activated protein C to inactivate the procoagulant factors Va and VIIIa, thereby reducing thrombin generation. Protein S also functions as a cofactor for activated protein C in augmenting fibrinolysis. Deficiency of protein S may occur due to mutations and leads to hypercoagulability, resulting in pulmonary embolism. Although protein S deficiency is difficult to distinguish from factor V Leiden deficiency, the former is far rarer and therefore less likely.   
❌ Prothrombin gene mutation:
Incorrect: Prothrombin, also known as factor II, is the precursor of thrombin, the end product of the coagulation cascade. Thrombin’s main role is to proteolytically cleave fibrinogen to fibrin, which in turn crosslinks to form a fibrin clot. It also interacts with other hemostatic components. The G20210A point mutation in the prothrombin gene results in a gain-of-function of prothrombin that leads to hypercoagulability. However, the failure to change PTT after adding purified protein C favors another diagnosis.  
❌ Antiphospholipid syndrome  :
Incorrect: Antiphospholipid syndrome (APS) refers to an autoimmune condition characterized by venous and/or arterial thrombosis due to the presence of antiphospholipid antibodies (lupus anticoagulant, anticardiolipin, anti-β2 glycoprotein I antibodies). It is most commonly associated with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). Patients with APS often show prolonged PTT. In contrast, this patient shows no features of SLE and has reduced PTT.   
❌ Antithrombin deficiency:
Incorrect: Antithrombin (AT, previously called AT III) deficiency may be acquired or inherited in an autosomal dominant fashion with variable penetration. Antithrombin is a natural anticoagulant that inhibits thrombin (factor IIa), factor Xa, and other factors in the coagulation cascade. A variety of mutations have been recognized. AT has no direct effect on the PT, PTT, or thrombin time. Instead, it diminishes the increase in PTT following heparin administration. This phenomenon exists since heparin, an indirect inhibitor of thrombin and factor Xa, requires functional AT to be effective.  
✅ Factor V Leiden deficiency:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man comes to the clinic due to progressive back pain for the past 2 months. The pain is dull, 3/10, and often wakes him at night. The patient denies any trauma, weight loss, or history of radiation. The patient has been smoking 1 pack of cigarettes per day for 40 years and drinks 2 beers every night. Vital signs are within normal limits. Laboratory tests show elevated alkaline phosphatase, calcium level is 7 mg/dL, PTHrP is not detected, and hemoglobin is 8 g/dL. Imaging of the spine shows sclerotic lesions at the L3-4 vertebrae. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with progressive back pain, anemia, elevated ALP and low calcium levels. In light of the sclerotic lesions seen on x-ray, the most likely diagnosis is vertebral metastases due to prostate cancer. While metastases to the bone usually cause hypercalcemia, prostate cancer is more commonly associated with hypocalcemia, since it causes osteoblastic lesions. Patients with prostate cancer are often asymptomatic at the time of diagnosis. Signs of metastatic disease may include weight loss, weakness or pain due to spinal cord compression, pathologic fractures, fatigue, anemia, hematuria, and signs of chronic renal failure due to bladder outlet obstruction. On imaging, the metastatic lesions are sclerotic (osteoblastic), as seen in this patient.  

The bones are the third most common organ affected by metastases, following the lung and liver. It is also a common location of distant relapse for solid tumors, especially lung, breast, and prostate cancer. The most common locations for metastatic disease are the proximal femurs, vertebral column, sacrum, and pelvis.    



Option Analysis

❌ Multiple myeloma:
Incorrect: Multiple myeloma is a malignant proliferation of plasma cells that produce monoclonal immunoglobulins. The condition is characterized by renal failure, bone pain, hypercalcemia, normocytic anemia, and lytic bone lesions. This patient has osteoblastic bone lesions.   
✅ Prostatic cancer metastasis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Paget disease of the bone:
Incorrect: Paget disease of bone is a disorder that interferes with normal bone metabolism and leads to accelerated bone remodeling. Bone lesions may be single or multiple and can be lytic, mixed, or blastic depending on the stage. Laboratory findings in Paget disease include normal serum calcium, phosphorus, and PTH levels, while ALP is elevated. Also, Paget disease would not explain the patient’s anemia.   
❌ Osteosarcoma :
Incorrect: Osteosarcoma is the most common primary bone tumor. It follows a bimodal age distribution, with a first peak seen in persons younger than 20 years of age and a smaller peak in older adults. In adolescents, it often arises in the metaphyseal regions of the distal femur and proximal tibia. Radiographs usually show destructive, mixed lytic and sclerotic mass with reactive subperiosteal bone formation. In adults, risk factors of developing osteosarcoma include prior irradiation or chemotherapy, Paget disease, and fibrous dysplasia.   
❌ Osteoporosis:
Incorrect: Osteoporosis is a condition characterized by loss of trabecular (spongy) and cortical bone mass despite normal bone mineralization. Osteoporosis is usually asymptomatic but may present with fractures after minimal trauma. Laboratory tests will show normal calcium, phosphate, and ALP levels, unlike this patient. On radiography, osteoporosis leads to loss of cortical bone and trabecular bone, rather than sclerotic lesions.

questions.text: A 44-year-old man comes to the office because of persistent dyspepsia. The patient has been taking a high dose of omeprazole for two months with some improvement in the symptoms, but he still complains of mild, burning epigastric pain alleviated by eating. As a result, he has gained 6.8-kg (15-lb) over this period of time. In addition, he complains of foul smelling, non-bloody diarrhea 1-2 times daily. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 86/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 142/62 mmHg. Physical examination is unremarkable. The patient undergoes esophagogastroduodenoscopy, which reveals multiple ulcers in the proximal and distal duodenum. Biopsies of the ulcers are negative for Helicobacter pylori. Which of the following findings is diagnostic of this patient’s underlying condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presentation of proton pump inhibitor-resistant peptic ulcer disease, negative H. pylori biopsy, and findings of multiple ulcers on endoscopy is concerning for Zollinger-Ellison syndrome (ZES) due to an underlying gastrinoma. Gastrinomas are pancreatic or duodenal tumors that secrete excess gastrin, resulting in hyperplasia of parietal cells and hypersecretion of gastric acid. Over time, the excess acid exceeds the neutralizing capacity of pancreatic bicarbonate secretions, resulting in multiple peptic ulcers. Additionally, the low pH of intestinal contents inactivates pancreatic digestive enzymes, resulting in malabsorption and steatorrhea.  

Once ZES is suspected, initial testing includes measurement of serum gastrin and gastric pH. A serum gastrin concentration of >1,000 pg/mL, in addition to gastric pH <2 is diagnostic of ZES and highly suggestive of a gastrinoma; however, gastrinomas have been discovered at gastrin concentrations as low as 150 pg/mL. If the serum gastrin concentration is equivocal, a secretin stimulation test should be administered. In the setting of ZES, this typically will then show a gastrin concentration of >1,000 pg/mL in addition to gastric pH <2, confirming the diagnosis of ZES. Treatment of ZES involves medical management with a high dose proton pump inhibitor, octreotide, as well as resection of the gastrinoma for localized disease.    

Option Analysis

✅ Elevated serum gastrin levels  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Elevated CEA levels:
Incorrect: Elevated CEA levels are used in monitoring for recurrence of colorectal cancer. CEA is not implicated in testing for Zollinger-Ellison syndrome.   
❌ Elevated serum chromogranin A levels:
Incorrect: Chromogranin A levels are commonly elevated in patients with gastrinomas; however, the finding is non-specific and can be seen in other conditions as well, including pheochromocytoma, pancreatic cancer, and additional neuroendocrine tumors.  
❌ Elevated serum cancer antigen 19-9 levels:
Incorrect: CA19-9 is a tumor marker for pancreatic cancer, which more commonly presents with painless jaundice and weight loss, which this patient does not have.   
❌ Genetic analysis of RET:
Incorrect: Gastrinomas are associated with mutations in MEN 1, but they are not seen in patients with MEN 2A or 2B, which are caused by mutations in the RET proto-oncogene.

questions.text: A 70-year-old African-American woman, gravida 3 para 3, comes to the clinic due to a breast mass found on self-examination. She is generally healthy and does not smoke or use illicit drugs. She drinks 2-3 glasses of wine per week and 4-5 cups of coffee per day. Menarche was at age 12 and first pregnancy at age 22. Family history is significant for breast cancer in her maternal aunt at age 55. The patient’s father had colon cancer at age of 60. The patient has never been very physically active. Vitals are within normal limits. On physical examination, a fixed, palpable firm mass is noted in the left breast. Mammogram shows a suspicious mass with calcifications. Core needle biopsy is performed and confirms the diagnosis of ductal carcinoma in situ. While discussing treatment options, the patient asks the doctor why she developed this condition. Which of the following confers the most significant risk factor for the development of breast cancer in this patient?
questions.solution:
Breast cancer is the most commonly diagnosed malignancy in biological females and the leading cause of cancer death in females worldwide. In the United States, it is the most frequent malignancy in biological females and the 2nd leading cause of death. Risk factors can be further divided into modifiable (e.g. smoking) and non modifiable (e.g. age). Among the answers above, the patient’s age is associated with the most significant increase in risk for breast cancer. At age 70 and older, 1 in 15 women develops breast cancer. Risk factors for developing breast cancer are depicted in the table below.    



Option Analysis

✅ Patient's age:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Patient's race:
Incorrect: White women have the highest rate of breast cancer, while black women are more likely to present with regional or advanced disease. However, this patient has another, more significant risk factor for the development of breast cancer.    
❌ Patient's physical activity:
Incorrect: Currently, there is no evidence that lack of physical activity increases the risk for breast cancer. On the other hand, regular physical exercise does appear to provide protection against breast cancer, espcially in postmenopausal women. However, this patient has another, more significant risk factor for the development of breast cancer.  
❌ Patient's family history:
Incorrect: Positive family history of breast cancer in a first-degree relative is strongly associated with increased risk, especially if the relative was diagnosed before the age of 30. The risk is also affected by the number of first-degree relatives diagnosed with breast cancer. Instead of a first-degree relative, this patient’s maternal aunt had breast cancer, making family history a less significant risk factor in this patient. Additionally, this patient has another, more significant risk factor for the development of breast cancer.    
❌ Patient's obstetric history:
Incorrect: Multiparity confers a protective effect against breast cancer, which is theorized to occur due to the decreased levels of estrogen during pregnancy and lactation. Nulliparous women are at increased risk for breast cancer.

questions.text:
A 72-year-old man is brought to the clinic from a nearby homeless shelter due to fatigue and progressive dyspnea. The patient states he had a remote history of hemoptysis and night sweats many years ago that resolved with a prolonged course of medications received at a clinic. Temperature is 36°C (97.4°F), pulse is 122/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 120/60 mmHg. Physical examination shows 3+ edema in the lower extremities and hepatomegaly. Examination of the neck reveals jugular venous distention that fails to subside on inspiration. Cardiac monitor shows a prominent x and y descent in the jugular venous pulse tracing. A chest x-ray is obtained and shown below:  


Reproduced from: Radiopaedia

Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
This patient's presentation is consistent with constrictive pericarditis, a condition characterized by incomplete filling of the cardiac chambers due to thickening of the pericardium (seen as a line of calcifications over the heart border on the chest radiograph). This patient experiencing homelessness likely had a previous history of tuberculosis infection (hemoptysis, night sweats), a common cause of constrictive pericarditis. Other causes of constrictive cardiomyopathy include post-cardiac surgery or radiation, connective tissue disorder, and miscellaneous causes (e.g., malignancy, trauma, drug-induced, sarcoidosis, uremic pericarditis). Note that some of the causes are common to both restrictive cardiomyopathy and constrictive pericarditis.  

The fibrous thickening of the pericardium forms a rigid, noncompliant cover of the heart, resulting in progressive impairment in cardiac filling with subsequent low cardiac output. The impaired heart filling leads to progressive signs and symptoms of predominantly right heart failure (e.g., pitting edema of the lower extremities, hepatomegaly). Patients often present with fluid overload, ranging from peripheral edema to anasarca, and symptoms related to low cardiac output, such as fatigability and dyspnea on exertion. On physical examination, the majority of patients display elevated jugular venous pressure. Other less common features include pulsus paradoxus, Kussmaul sign (increase or lack of decrease in JVP during inspiration), pericardial knock, peripheral edema, ascites, and/or cachexia. Pericardial knock is a unique feature that can be heard during early diastole. The sound corresponds to the abrupt cessation of ventricular filling due to a constrictive pericardium. Jugular venous pulse tracing typically reveals prominent x and y descent, correlating with the downward displacement of closed tricuspid valves during rapid ventricular ejection and right atrial emptying, respectively.

The diagnosis of constrictive pericarditis is commonly made using echocardiography in patients presenting with high clinical suspicion. Depending on the severity, patients may be treated with medications aimed to reduce the inflammation (colchicine and NSAIDs) or pericardiectomy surgery.      

Option Analysis

❌ Cardiac myxoma:
Incorrect: Cardiac myxoma is the most common cardiac tumor in adults. Myxomas are typically described as a “ball-valve” mass found in the left atrium. Patients often present with fever, weight loss, and possible syncopal episodes. Cardiac auscultation may reveal early diastolic “tumor plop” sound. Cardiac myxoma, however, does not cause calcifications of the myocardium or jugular venous pulse changes, as seen in this patient.    
✅ Constrictive pericarditis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Dilated cardiomyopathy:
Incorrect: Dilated cardiomyopathy can also present with dyspnea, chest pain and edema. Causes of dilated cardiomyopathy include genetics, substance abuse (e.g., alcohol, cocaine), and certain infections. Dilated cardiomyopathy, however, does not cause calcifications of the myocardium or jugular venous pulse changes, as seen in this patient.   
❌ Hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy:
Incorrect: Hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy is the most common cause of death in young athletes. It is caused by hypertrophy of the myocardium. Patients often present with a harsh systolic ejection murmur and a palpable apical impulse, neither of which are seen in this patient.    
❌ Restrictive cardiomyopathy:
Incorrect: The presentation of restrictive cardiomyopathy is very similar to constrictive pericarditis, including chest pain, dyspnea, edema, fatigue, and exercise intolerance due to elevations in filling pressures. The history and physical examination may differentiate the cause. Causes of restrictive cardiomyopathy include post-radiation fibrosis, Löffler endocarditis, amyloidosis, sarcoidosis, and hemochromatosis. In contrast to constrictive pericarditis, restrictive cardiomyopathy presents with prominent y descent but blunting of the x descent in the jugular venous pulse. Additionally, an echocardiogram may reveal an increase in wall thickness, rather than the calcifications on chest radiograph seen in this patient.

questions.text:
A 52-year-old woman comes to the physician's office due to suspicious findings seen on a routine mammogram. She recalls no recent trauma or breast surgery. She is a gymnastics teacher and regularly engages in intense workout regimens. The patient’s first mammogram 2 years ago was normal. Medical history is unremarkable except hypertension treated with hydrochlorothiazide. Family history is significant for breast cancer in her mother diagnosed at age 64. On physical examination, a lump is palpated in the right breast field. Mammography results are shown below:  


Reproduced from: Radiopaedia  

 

After a discussion with the physician, the patient subsequently undergoes biopsy, and the results are shown below:  

Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons    

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with a suspicious mass showing calcifications on mammography. Her biopsy results, however, reveal fat globules and associated necrosis, confirming the diagnosis of fat necrosis.   

Fat necrosis typically occurs after trauma or surgery and presents as a firm and irregular mass. Fat necrosis from trauma is typically accompanied by skin ecchymosis. However, many patients do not have a recollection of the specific trauma, although they may often be involved in activities where trauma is likely to occur (e.g. gymnastics). On mammography and ultrasound, findings such as oil cysts (collections of liquefied fat) are often seen. Fat necrosis is often confused with malignancy on physical examination as well as on radiologic studies showing calcification. Therefore, a biopsy is often required to exclude other conditions. On histology, necrotic fat and giant cells are seen. After the diagnosis has been established, excision is not required, since there is no increased risk for cancer.  

Option Analysis

❌ Lobular carcinoma in situ:
Incorrect: Lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS) is a noninvasive lesion that arises from terminal duct lobular units of the breast. It is characterized by a solid proliferation of small cells with uniform, round nuclei, and variably distinct cell borders. LCIS is found in the majority of cases as an incidental finding that is diagnosed on a breast biopsy performed for another reason, such as fibrocystic change or fibroadenoma. This patient's presentation, imaging, and histopathology results favor another diagnosis.  

Retrieved from: Wikimedia Commons  
❌ Sclerosing adenosis:
Incorrect: Sclerosing adenosis is a subtype of fibrocystic changes, characterized by an increase in fibrous tissue and glandular cells within the lobules. While fibrocystic change is usually a benign condition, sclerosing adenosis subtype is associated with a slightly increased risk for invasive cancer. Sclerosing adenosis can present with calcifications on mammography; however, this patient’s histology results favor another diagnosis.   
✅ Fat necrosis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Ductal carcinoma in situ:
Incorrect: Ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS), refers to a localized tumor that arises from monoclonal proliferation of the terminal duct cells which fill the ductal lumen; by definition, the tumor does not cross the basement membrane. DCIS is typically recognized incidentally on mammogram screening as microcalcifications and rarely as a hard, palpable lump on physical examination. Although this patient’s mammogram shows calcifications, the biopsy results favor another diagnosis.  

Retrieved from: Wikimedia Commons 
❌ Medullary carcinoma:
Incorrect: Medullary carcinoma is an uncommon type of breast cancer, comprising about 2% of invasive breast cancers. On physical examination and imaging, it is characterized as a well-circumscribed tumor that is difficult to distinguish from benign tumors such as fibroadenoma. On histology, it is composed of large, anaplastic cells growing in sheets with adjacent lymphocytes and plasma cells. This patient’s histology results favor another diagnosis.

questions.text: A 25-year-old primigravida woman at 20 weeks of gestation comes to the obstetrician for a routine prenatal evaluation. The pregnancy has been uncomplicated, and she has been compliant with prenatal care. She takes vitamins as needed. Family and medical history are unremarkable. She did not have any prior abortions or miscarriages. Ultrasound reveals numerous cysts and no identifiable renal tissue at the location of the fetus’s right kidney. The fetus’s left kidney appears normal. Amniotic fluid index is normal. These ultrasound findings are most likely caused by which of the following?

choices.text: Congenital failure of the metanephric mesenchyme to differentiate
Congenital failure of the ureteric bud to develop
Congenital bifurcation of the ureteric bud

questions.solution:
Fetal ultrasound shows a normal amniotic fluid index, a cystic mass with absent renal tissue, and a normal left kidney, which favors the diagnosis of multicystic dysplastic kidney.   

Multicystic dysplastic kidney is the most severe form of cystic renal dysplasia. The dysplastic kidney is composed of numerous cysts intertwined with dysplastic tissue without identifiable renal tissue. The ureter may be absent or atretic. The exact pathogenesis is not entirely clear. However, it is thought to be due to failure of the ureteric bud to induce differentiation of the metanephric blastema during embryogenesis.  

The condition is predominantly non-hereditary and unilateral. If bilateral involvement occurs, Potter sequence ensues. The majority of cases do not require intervention, since the contralateral kidney is able to compensate. Observation and long-term follow-up are required to monitor for other comorbidities that may affect the healthy kidney (e.g., vesicoureteral reflux, ureteropelvic junction obstruction).    

Option Analysis

❌ Autosomal dominant hereditary condition:
Incorrect: Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD) is caused by a mutation in the PKD1 gene on chromosome 16 or PKD2 gene on chromosome 4. Patients typically present in adulthood with hypertension, hematuria, proteinuria, and impaired kidney function, as well as bilateral flank masses on imaging or physical examination. This fetus has only one nonfunctional kidney, which makes ADPKD very unlikely.   
❌ Autosomal recessive hereditary condition:
Incorrect: Autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease (ARPKD) is a genetic condition characterized by cystic dilation of the collecting ducts, biliary dysgenesis, and hepatic fibrosis. Patients often present at birth with Potter sequence, bilateral flank masses, hypertension, progressive renal insufficiency, and portal hypertension. This fetus has only one nonfunctional kidney, which makes ARPKD very unlikely.   
✅ Congenital failure of the metanephric mesenchyme to differentiate:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Congenital failure of the ureteric bud to develop:
Incorrect: Failure of the ureteric bud to develop during would cause unilateral renal agenesis. Individuals with renal agenesis would not have a kidney or ureter on the affected side. The fetal ultrasound shows cystic nonfunctional tissue, which favors another diagnosis.   
❌ Congenital bifurcation of the ureteric bud:
Incorrect: Congenital bifurcation of the ureteric bud during embryonic development would cause a duplex collecting system, resulting in 2 separate collecting systems. Patients with duplex collecting systems can be asymptomatic or present with urinary tract infections, hydronephrosis, and vesicoureteral reflux. However, fetal ultrasound shows cystic nonfunctional tissue, which favors an alternative diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 67-year-old male presents to the emergency department after a confirmed cardiac arrest in the field. Per EMS, the patient was found down by several bystanders without a pulse, and CPR was initiated immediately. The patient has no past medical history and is not on any medications. He is currently without a pulse, and CPR is ongoing. His 12 lead electrocardiogram is demonstrated below:  



Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons   

The patient is shocked multiple times and dies despite resuscitation efforts. Post-mortem analysis is most likely to demonstrate which of the following as the etiology of this patient’s clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient sustained a witnessed cardiac arrest and cardio-pulmonary resuscitation (CPR) was initiated. The electrocardiogram demonstrates findings consistent with ventricular fibrillation, of which the most common culprit is underlying coronary artery disease.  

Ventricular fibrillation represents the most lethal arrhythmia, characterized by completely disorganized electrical activity of the heart without discernable p-waves, QRS complexes, or t-waves. During ventricular fibrillation the heart is “quivering” and unable to provide meaningful cardiac output or a pulse. It is commonly preceded by ventricular tachycardia and will result in asystole and death unless immediately treated with CPR and defibrillation. Despite these interventions, the arrhythmia still carries an overall poor prognosis.

The etiologies of ventricular fibrillation are multiple, but it is most commonly due to severe coronary artery disease, plaque rupture, and subsequent myocardial infarction. Other less common etiologies include electrolyte abnormalities such as hyperkalemia, major trauma, near drowning, or associated underlying cardiac diseases such as cardiomyopathy, Brugada syndrome, myocarditis, or inherited long QT-syndromes.      

Option Analysis

✅ Multi-vessel coronary artery disease:
Correct: See main explanation  
❌ Saddle pulmonary embolism :
Incorrect: A large pulmonary embolism can trigger ventricular tachycardia and subsequent ventricular fibrillation/cardiac arrest if enough right heart strain occurs; however, it is not the most common etiology of cardiac arrest.   
❌ Dilated cardiomyopathy:
Incorrect: Dilated cardiomyopathy is a common culprit of ventricular fibrillation arrest, but it is not the most common etiology in the overall population.   
❌ Hypomagnesemia :
Incorrect: Hypomagnesemia portends to polymorphic ventricular tachycardia and torsade de pointes. These ventricular arrhythmias can degenerate into ventricular fibrillation arrest; however, underlying coronary artery disease is a more likely culprit.   
❌ Pericardial effusion:
Incorrect: Pericardial tamponade can result in obstructive shock and subsequent ventricular fibrillation arrest. Pericardial tamponade presents with muffled heart tones in the setting of a history of trauma, rheumatologic disease, malignancy, or uremia.

questions.text:
