A 26-year-old woman comes to the office because of a recurrent rash. The patient noticed the rash for the first time after going in the water at the beach one month ago. She reports that since then, she has developed similar appearing pink and itchy rashes on her arms and legs that eventually resolve on their own. The patient works as a forest ranger at a national park. Past medical history is significant for systemic lupus erythematosus and asthma. Current medications include ibuprofen and an albuterol inhaler, both as needed. The patient has seasonal allergies but no food intolerances. Temperature is 98°F (36.7°C), pulse is 70/min, respirations are 13/min, and blood pressure is 118/77 mmHg. Physical examination is significant for scattered expiratory wheezes. When ice is placed on the leg, a rash appears, as shown in the image:


Reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

Which of the following terminologies best describes the dermatological findings seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The patient’s skin finding is consistent with urticaria, a dermatologic disorder characterized by pruritic wheals that form after mast cell degranulation. Urticaria can occasionally be triggered by certain methods, such as application of an ice pack in this case; wheals can form due to cutaneous mast cell degranulation and release of proinflammatory mediators after cold exposure of the skin. Wheals are often described as pale red, raised, pruritic bumps that can occur anywhere on the surface of the skin.

Wheals should be differentiated from papules and plaques, which are solid elevated skin lesions that lack the characteristic well-defined erythematous margins observed in wheals. Moreover, wheals typically disappear on their own within 24 hours, unlike papules and plaques. The shape of wheals can vary, presenting as round, polycyclic (overlapping circles), annular (ring-shaped), or geographic (like a map) shapes.



Option Analysis

❌ Papules:
Incorrect: Papules are defined as less than one centimeter, solid, elevated skin lesions with no oozing fluid. They are characteristically seen in acne or a mole. This patient’s urticaria is suggestive of a different dermatological condition.
❌ Plaques:
Incorrect: Plaques are elevated, solid skin lesions less than one centimeter in diameter. They are most commonly seen in association with psoriasis. This patient’s urticaria is suggestive of a different dermatological condition.
✅ Wheals:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Patch:
Incorrect: A patch is a flat skin lesion greater than one centimeter in size that differs in color from surrounding skin (e.g. congenital nevus). This patient’s urticaria is suggestive of a different dermatological condition.
❌ Macule:
Incorrect: Macules are described as flat, less than one centimeter changes in skin color that are usually seen in tinea versicolor or exemplified as freckles. This patient’s urticaria is suggestive of a different dermatological condition.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy presents to his family physician accompanied by his parent due to concerns regarding delayed puberty. The patient’s parent expresses concern about a lack of secondary male sex characteristics compared to his sibling of the same age. The patient has a reserved demeanor and answers questions with one-word answers. The patient gets mostly C’s and some D’s in school. He has been picked on since starting school for his inability to smell when other students intentionally break wind in his presence. On physical examination, height and weight are near the 60th percentile for his age. The patient has absent pubic hair and small testes. A deficiency of which of the following hormones is most directly responsible for this patient’s clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
This vignette illustrates characteristic features of Kallman syndrome – a genetic disorder that prevents one from starting or finishing puberty. Kallmann syndrome falls under a subset of genetic disorders, termed hypogonadotropic hypogonadism, and patients with this disorder present with distinct reproductive and non-reproductive clinical features.

During the first 10 weeks of embryological development, gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) neurons migrate from their initial location in rostral nasopharynx, an area called the olfactory placode, through the cribriform plate and into the developing hypothalamus. Kallman syndrome is thought to arise from aberration of GnRH neuronal migration, which also affects neurons originating in the olfactory placode, leading to anosmia. The lack of GnRH in these patients ultimately leads to downstream absence of luteinizing hormone (LH) and follicle stimulating hormone (FSH), resulting in lack of secondary sexual characteristics and hair growth. Kallmann syndrome is significantly more common in males than females.  

Option Analysis

✅ Gonadotropin-releasing hormone  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Follicle Stimulating Hormone  :
Incorrect: While FSH is greatly decreased in this disorder, it is the lack of upstream GnRH which accounts for the physical manifestations of Kallman syndrome.  
❌ Luteinizing hormone  :
Incorrect: While LH is greatly decreased in this disorder, it is the lack of upstream GnRH which accounts for the physical manifestations of Kallman syndrome.  
❌ Testosterone:
Incorrect: This patient’s lack of secondary sexual characteristics is due to a lack of GnRH, not testosterone. This is further evidenced by this patient’s anosmia and hypogonadism (pathognomonic features of Kallmann Syndrome).  
❌ Corticotropin releasing hormone  :
Incorrect: Hypothalamic expression of CRH is unrelated to this patient’s hypogonadism. Corticotropin-releasing hormone stimulates cortisol secretion during times of sustained stress.

questions.text: A 66-year-old man comes to his physician for evaluation of fatigue and abdominal pain for the past several months. He has a history of peptic ulcer disease, but he has been inconsistent with treatment. Vital signs are within normal limits. Urea breath test is positive. Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy reveals a mass in the gastric antrum. Biopsy of the mass demonstrates diffuse infiltrates of small lymphoid CD20-positive cells. A CT scan of the chest and abdomen reveals enlarged regional lymph nodes. This patient’s condition is most highly associated with which of the following diseases?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with a positive urea breath test and history of peptic ulcer disease and likely has H. pylori-induced gastritis. Chronic inflammation can result in clonal expansion of B-cells and development of marginal zone lymphoma (MZL). Biopsy often demonstrates an infiltrate of small B-cells that express the B-cell markers CD19, CD20, and CD22.

MZL is an indolent variant of non-Hodgkin lymphoma. It tends to develop within tissues subjected to chronic mucosal inflammation due to primary autoimmune disorders (such as the salivary gland in Sjögren syndrome or the thyroid gland in Hashimoto thyroiditis) or due to infection (such as the stomach in H. pylori gastritis). In the case of gastric MZL, treatment with antibiotic therapy often leads to regression of the disease.  



Option Analysis

✅ Sjögren syndrome   :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Ulcerative colitis   :
Incorrect: Ulcerative colitis is associated with a substantially increased risk of developing colon cancer, not marginal zone lymphoma (MZL).   
❌ Hemochromatosis   :
Incorrect: Hemochromatosis is associated with an elevated risk of developing hepatocellular carcinoma, not marginal zone lymphoma (MZL).   
❌ Graves disease   :
Incorrect: Graves disease has not been shown to increase the risk of thyroid-related cancers. In contrast, patients with Hashimoto thyroiditis do have an increased risk of developing marginal zone lymphoma (MZL).   
❌ Systemic sclerosis   :
Incorrect: Systemic sclerosis (SS), an autoimmune disease involving the skin and viscera, may result in an elevated risk of various cancers, although the link has not been fully established. However, marginal zone lymphoma (MZL) has not been shown to be associated with SS.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man is brought to the emergency department following an altercation at a bar where he was hit over the left side of his head with a bottle. The patient subsequently lost consciousness and spontaneously awakened minutes later. He initially refused medical evaluation, but a few hours later, he began vomiting and agreed to be taken to the hospital. On arrival, the patient suddenly loses consciousness. Temperature is 36.0°C (96.8°F), pulse is 48/min, respirations are 8/min and irregular, and blood pressure is 144/40 mmHg. On physical examination, the patient does not respond to painful stimuli. The left pupil is dilated and inferolaterally abducted. A non-contrast CT is obtained and demonstrates a convex lesion with mass effect and downward displacement of the inferior temporal lobe. This patient's clinical presentation is best defined by which of the following injury patterns?

choices.text: Intra-axial injury; supratentorial; primary brain injury
Extra-axial injury; supratentorial; primary brain injury
Extra-axial injury; supratentorial; secondary brain injury
Extra-axial injury; infratentorial; secondary brain injury

questions.solution:
This patient presents with blunt head trauma and classic features of an epidural hematoma including a “lucid interval,” a lens shaped lesion, and signs of impending herniation. The physical examination demonstrates a blown, dilated pupil, indicating uncal herniation secondary to extrinsic compression of cranial nerve III. Lastly, the CT results confirm the diagnosis of an epidural hematoma, which is an extra-axial bleed, with secondary brain herniation.  

Traumatic brain injury (TBI) can be classified as primary (e.g. epidural hematoma) or secondary (e.g. brain herniation), the latter of which occurs due to mass effect and increased intracranial pressure. Another way to classify herniation is with respect to the tentorium: supratentorial herniation (cingulate, a.k.a. subfalcine), central transtentorial herniation, or infratentorial herniation (downward/cerebellar tonsillar herniation or upward cerebellar/transtentorial herniation). Finally, TBI that occurs within the brain parenchyma is classified as intra-axial (e.g. diffuse axonal injury) or extra-axial (e.g., epidural, subdural).  




Option Analysis

❌ Intra-axial injury; supratentorial; primary brain injury  :
Incorrect: Diffuse axonal injury (DAI) is an example of this injury pattern. Patients with DAI often present with deep coma without elevated intracranial pressure. DAI occurs as a result of traumatic shearing forces applied to the brain when the head is rapidly accelerated and/or decelerated affecting the gray-white junction. Another example of intra-axial injury is a focal cerebral contusion. This patient more likely has an extra-axial injury.  
❌ Extra-axial injury; supratentorial; primary brain injury  :
Incorrect: Examples of this injury pattern include epidural, subdural, and subarachnoid hematomas without signs of brain herniation. This patient has imaging and exam findings indicative of herniation, a secondary brain injury.  
✅ Extra-axial injury; supratentorial; secondary brain injury:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Extra-axial injury; infratentorial; secondary brain injury  :
Incorrect: An example of this injury pattern includes downward cerebellar/tonsillar herniation or upward cerebellar/transtentorial herniation from a tumor or hematoma secondary to trauma. This patient’s presentation is consistent with supratentorial herniation.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl comes to her pediatrician’s office for evaluation of left knee pain. The pain has been present for the past 3-4 months, and worsens with running, prolonged sitting, or when going up or down steps. The patient also mentions episodes of her left knee “buckling.” She has taken ibuprofen which occasionally alleviates the pain. Vitals are within normal limits. BMI is 19.5 kg/m<sup>2</sup>. Physical examination shows a normal gait. There is no visible knee deformity. When the patient is asked to perform squats, there is significant pain in the left knee. Which of the following best describes the etiology of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Chronic avulsion of the secondary ossification center of the tibial tuberosity
Displacement of the femoral epiphysis from the femoral neck
Abnormal formation of the acetabulum and the femoral head
Muscular imbalance and decreased stability of the patellofemoral joint
Infectious arthritis of the joint space

questions.solution:
This adolescent girl presents with poorly localized anterior knee pain and clinical features suggestive of patellofemoral pain syndrome (PFPS). The pathogenesis of this condition is poorly understood but is likely due to anatomical variants that increase chronic contact pressure between the patella and the femur, resulting in knee pain. In addition, muscular imbalance(s) between the quadriceps and hamstrings decrease the stability of the patellofemoral joint with normal weight-bearing activities. This condition is primarily related to overuse but can also occur acutely following trauma.

Clinical features of PFPS include anterior knee pain directly under or around the patella. The pain is often worsened with activity or with walking up and down stairs. It is relieved with rest, although pain may be noted after prolonged periods of knee flexion (e.g. sitting in a chair). Diagnosis of PFPS is primarily based on patient history and examination findings. The pain is often provoked by maneuvers that involve contraction of the quadriceps with the knee in flexion (e.g. squatting). PFPS is most common in adolescent females.

Nonoperative medical management and physical therapy is the most common initial treatment course. Therapy focuses on stretching and strengthening of the quadriceps muscle.  

Option Analysis

❌ Chronic avulsion of the secondary ossification center of the tibial tuberosity   :
Incorrect: Osgood-Schlatter disease (OSD) refers to a traction apophysitis of the tibial tubercle due to repetitive strain and chronic avulsion of the secondary ossification center at the tibial tuberosity. In contrast to this patient, physical examination in patients with OSD typically reveals tenderness and soft tissue or bony prominence over the tibial tubercle.   
❌ Displacement of the femoral epiphysis from the femoral neck   :
Incorrect: Slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE) results from slipping of the femoral head from the femoral neck. The typical patient is an adolescent male with obesity with a painful limp as well as pain in the groin, hip, or knee. This patient has a normal gait.   
❌ Abnormal formation of the acetabulum and the femoral head   :
Incorrect: Developmental dysplasia of the hip (DDH) results from the improper formation of the acetabulum and femoral head; the condition occurs in neonates. This adolescent patient has a different diagnosis.   
✅ Muscular imbalance and decreased stability of the patellofemoral joint   :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Infectious arthritis of the joint space   :
Incorrect: Septic arthritis is a surgical emergency which involves infectious arthritis of the joint space. This patient’s presentation, including the chronic nature of her pain and paucity of systemic findings (e.g. fever), suggests a different diagnosis.

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman, gravida 5 para 5, is brought to the emergency department due to sudden-onset colicky abdominal pain in the right upper quadrant that started 1 hour ago. She states she has been feeling nauseous for several hours since the pain started and has vomited twice. She has had several episodes of abdominal discomfort in the past, especially after consuming food. Medical history is significant for hypertriglyceridemia and obesity. Medications include fenofibrate. Temperature is 38.0°C (100.4°F), pulse is 75/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. BMI is 36 kg/m<sup>2</sup>. Abdominal examination reveals inspiratory arrest during palpation of the right upper quadrant. An abdominal ultrasound shows a thickened gallbladder wall and exquisite tenderness when the probe is applied on the right upper quadrant. A diagnosis is made, and the patient receives pain medication and IV hydration. Two weeks later, the patient undergoes elective laparoscopic cholecystectomy which reveals multiple stones within the gallbladder. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Decreased activity of HMG-CoA reductase enzyme

questions.solution:
This female patient, who is multiparous and has obesity, is presenting with right upper abdominal pain, positive Murphy sign and a thickened gallbladder on abdominal ultrasound; she most likely has acute cholecystitis due to cholesterol gallstones.   

In classic cholecystitis, gallstones obstruct the cystic duct, leading to a buildup of pressure and inflammation of the gallbladder. The typical presentation of cholecystitis includes right upper abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and occasionally fever. On physical examination, patients may demonstrate a positive Murphy sign, which is sudden inspiratory pause upon palpation of the RUQ. Similarly, a positive sonographic Murphy sign can be elicited with an ultrasound probe. Risk factors for cholesterol gallstones include female sex, pregnancy and oral contraceptive pills, obesity, and age, especially after 40. These can be remembered by the 4 F’s: female, fertile, fat, and forty.  

Bile production is the main pathway for elimination of excess cholesterol from the body, either as  bile salts or as free cholesterol. Cholesterol is secreted by the liver into the gallbladder and is rendered water-soluble within the bile by lecithins and bile salts. When cholesterol concentrations exceed the capacity of bile to solubilize it (supersaturation), cholesterol crystallizes and forms stones. Any condition that increases cholesterol and/or bilirubin, decreases bile salts, or promotes gallbladder stasis can cause gallstone formation. The enzyme 7α-hydroxylase converts cholesterol to 7-alpha-hydroxycholesterol, the rate-limiting step in bile acid synthesis. Inhibition of this enzyme (e.g. by fibrates medication) can lead to the building up of cholesterol, its supersaturation, and stone formation.  

There are 2 types of stones, cholesterol stones (80% of cases) and pigment stones (black and brown). Cholesterol stones are associated with obesity, Crohn disease, advanced age, estrogen therapy, multiparity, and rapid weight loss. The characteristics of each stone type are depicted in the table below.  

 

Option Analysis

❌ Decreased activity of HMG-CoA reductase enzyme:
Incorrect: HMG-CoA reductase is the enzyme responsible for the rate-limiting step in cholesterol synthesis. This enzyme catalyzes the conversion of HMG-CoA to mevalonate. Inhibition of this enzyme, such as by a statin, will result in decreased production of cholesterol and subsequently decreased risk for cholesterol gallstones.     
❌ Decreased activity of aromatase enzyme:
Incorrect: Aromatase is the enzyme that catalyzes the conversion of androgen to estrogen. Increased level of estrogen increases the risk for cholesterol gallstones by increasing the hepatic secretion of biliary cholesterol. Therefore, decreased activity aromatase will reduce the risk for gallstones.   
✅ Decreased activity of 7α-hydroxylase enzyme:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Increased activity of β-glucuronidase enzyme  :
Incorrect: β-glucuronidase is a brush border enzyme that converts conjugated bilirubin to an unconjugated form for reabsorption. Any process that results in increased unconjugated bilirubin in the bile will increase the potential for pigment gallstone formation. However, this patient, who is multiparous and has obesity, is much more likely to have cholesterol gallstones, rather than pigment gallstones.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman comes to the emergency department due to sudden loss of vision in the right eye that began several hours ago. The patient has intense pain with any movement of the eye. She has no significant past medical history, but she did have an episode of reduced sensation in her legs 6 months ago. This episode resolved spontaneously after several days. On neurologic examination, there is a relative afferent pupillary defect in the right eye. There is reduced adduction of the left eye with right lateral gaze. Convergence testing shows no abnormalities. Physical examination reveals decreased pain and light touch perception in both legs. Mild bilateral spasticity is observed. MRI of the brain and spine is inconclusive. Further testing is likely to demonstrate which of the following?

choices.text: Elevated nonspecific clones of IgG on CSF electrophoresis
Positive rapid plasma reagin from a sample of cerebrospinal fluid
Elevated protein levels and normal cell counts in cerebrospinal fluid analysis
Genetic testing revealing increased triplet repeats on chromosome 4

questions.solution:
This patient’s neurological dysfunctions are separated in space and time (e.g., optic neuritis, sensory symptoms, bilateral spasticity), which means the symptoms manifest at different times and affect different parts of the body. These findings are highly suggestive of multiple sclerosis.   

Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain and spine is the initial diagnostic test of choice. The presence of multiple sclerotic plaques is the most common finding in MS patients. These plaques are usually located near the ventricles (periventricular). Sclerotic plaques occur due to reactive gliosis that follows demyelination episodes. As these periventricular areas of hyperintensity stretch out perpendicularly along medullary veins, they are described as Dawson fingers (Figure 1).  

In cases wherein MRI is inconclusive, a lumbar puncture with subsequent analysis of the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) is indicated. Oligoclonal bands are found in up to 95% of patients with MS. Oligoclonal bands represent increased production of multiple, nonspecific clones of IgG within the central nervous system due to intrathecal inflammation. Additionally, since Th1 cells initiate the demyelinating episodes, lymphocytosis in the CSF is another common finding, but it is not specific for MS.  

Figure 1: Dawson’s fingers (some are marked with white arrows) seen on sagittal MRI  



Image reproduced from Radiopedia 

Option Analysis

✅ Elevated nonspecific clones of IgG on CSF electrophoresis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Positive rapid plasma reagin from a sample of cerebrospinal fluid:
Incorrect:  Positive rapid plasma reagin (RPR) of the CSF suggests neurosyphilis; syphilis can present similarly to MS with ataxia and loss of peripheral sensation. However, syphilis can be differentiated by recognition of earlier signs, such as a painless genital ulcer in primary syphilis and a disseminated rash involving the palms and soles in secondary syphilis.
❌ Decreased ceruloplasmin on laboratory studies:
Incorrect: This finding is present in patients with Wilson disease, in which there is impaired copper excretion and inadequate incorporation of copper into ceruloplasmin, resulting in systemic copper accumulation. Patients typically present with liver disease and neurological symptoms (e.g., dysarthria, parkinsonism), as well as characteristic Kayser-Fleischer rings in the periphery of the iris. 
❌ Elevated protein levels and normal cell counts in cerebrospinal fluid analysis:
Incorrect: Albuminocytologic dissociation of the CSF is present in patients with Guillain-Barré syndrome. This condition typically presents after a viral gastroenteritis (e.g. preceding diarrheal episode) with bilateral ascending, flaccid paralysis.
❌ Genetic testing revealing increased triplet repeats on chromosome 4:
Incorrect: Increased number of CAG triplet repeats in the huntingtin gene located on chromosome 4 is seen in patients with Huntington disease. Since this condition has autosomal dominant inheritance, the lack of family history makes this diagnosis unlikely. Additionally, patients with Huntington disease also have chorea, which is characterized by involuntary, irregular movements of the limbs and/or face.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman comes to the obstetrician with her partner for evaluation of infertility. The patient has had three prior pregnancies, all of which ended in miscarriages during the first trimester. She currently has monthly menstrual periods. Past medical history is unremarkable. The patient is an avid runner and takes part in several marathons each year. Temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), blood pressure is 115/78 mmHg, pulse is 72/min, and body mass index is 21 kg/m2. Speculum examination reveals a normal-appearing cervix. The abdomen is soft and nondistended, and there are no palpable masses. The remainder of the physical examination is unremarkable. Laboratory testing reveals a prothrombin time of 12 seconds and partial thromboplastin time of 37 seconds. A hysterosalpingogram is performed and shown below. Which of the following best describes the pathophysiology of this patient’s condition?

 

Image reproduced from Radiopedia

choices.text: Complete failure of Müllerian duct fusion
Proliferation of benign uterine smooth muscle tumors
Incomplete fusion of the Müllerian ducts

questions.solution:
This patient has a history of recurrent miscarriages. Laboratory testing is unremarkable and imagining reveals a bicornuate uterus. This condition arises due to incomplete fusion of the Müllerian ducts.    

Uterine anomalies describe anatomical malformations of the uterus that are present at birth.    

A septate uterus occurs when the Müllerian ducts fuse, but the septum between the ducts persists. The condition can lead to decreased fertility and increased risk of early miscarriage or pregnancy loss. Diagnosis can be made with imaging techniques (e.g., ultrasound, hysterosalpingogram, MRI) revealing the presence of a midline septum.  

A bicornuate uterus occurs due to incomplete fusion of the Müllerian ducts. As a result, the uterus develops two upper horns above the uterine body, giving it a heart shape. The finding can be observed on imaging. The condition can lead to an increased risk of complicated pregnancy, fetal malpresentation, early miscarriage, and preterm birth.    

Finally, uterus didelphys occurs due to complete failure of Müllerian duct fusion. As a result, patients will have a double uterus, double cervix, and double vagina. While pregnancy remains possible, patients are at increased risk of early miscarriage and preterm birth. Imaging will reveal two uncommunicated uteruses, each one with its own fallopian tube.  



Option Analysis

❌ Complete failure of Müllerian duct fusion:
Incorrect: Uterus didelphys occurs when there is complete failure in fusion of the Müllerian ducts. As a result, individuals will have two uteruses, two cervixes, and two vaginas. In contrast, this patient’s imaging demonstrates a single vagina and cervix but two uteruses, which is more suggestive of a bicornuate uterus.  
❌ Proliferation of benign uterine smooth muscle tumors:
Incorrect: Uterine fibroids are caused by benign proliferation of smooth muscle. The condition can lead to recurrent miscarriages. However, fibroids are neither present on physical examination nor imaging, and the patient lacks additional symptoms suggestive of fibroids (e.g., menorrhagia, back pain).  
❌ Formation of anti-β2 glycoprotein autoantibodies:
Incorrect: Individuals with antiphospholipid syndrome can form anti-β2 glycoprotein autoantibodies and are at risk for recurrent miscarriages. The condition will lead to an elevated partial thromboplastin time (PTT). In contrast, this patient’s PTT is within normal limits, making antiphospholipid syndrome unlikely. 
✅ Incomplete fusion of the Müllerian ducts:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Reduced hypothalamic hormone release:
Incorrect: Excessive exercise can lead to reduced hypothalamic secretion of GnRH, which subsequently impairs pituitary release of follicle stimulating hormone (FSH) and luteinizing hormone (LH). The condition can manifest with amenorrhea and infertility. While this patient has a history of training for marathons, her BMI is within normal limits, and she has been having monthly menstrual periods. Furthermore, imaging findings are more suggestive of a uterine abnormality as the underlying cause of her prior miscarriages.

questions.text: A 25-year-old individual is brought to the emergency department by a friend after the patient was stabbed in the abdomen in a bar fight. Upon arrival, the patient’s temperature is 36.4°C (97.5°F), pulse is 116/min and blood pressure is 108/80 mmHg.  The patient has facial pallor with a visible stab wound in the left upper quadrant of the abdomen. The patient is immediately resuscitated in the emergency department and is given 2 units of blood. Several minutes after the transfusion, the patient begins having severe itching and scattered hives all over their body. The patient’s blood pressure drops to 60/40. The transfusion is immediately stopped; the patient is given fluids, antihistamines, and intramuscular epinephrine, and the patient’s blood pressure begins to normalize. Which of the following is most likely to be found on further evaluation of this patient’s blood serum?

choices.text: Bacterial contamination of the transfused blood

questions.solution:
This patient is most likely having anaphylactic transfusion reaction, which develops due to preformed antibodies in the recipient against the donor's plasma proteins, causing mast cell and basophil activation and systemic anaphylaxis.  

Anaphylactic transfusion reactions are rare but potentially fatal and develop more commonly in patients with IgA deficiency. These patients have no IgA and thus form anti-IgA IgG and IgE antibodies that bind to the IgA in the donor's plasma and induce an anaphylaxis reaction. To avoid such life threatening reactions, patients with known IgA deficiency usually wear a medical alert bracelet/necklace indicating their status.  

Patients with IgA deficiency should be given plasma-reduced or washed blood. In washed blood, the plasma is removed and, since the IgA antigens are found in the plasma, removing those antigens will prevent the risk of anaphylactic reactions.  

 

Option Analysis

✅ Presence of Anti-IgA antibodies:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Bacterial contamination of the transfused blood:
Incorrect: Sepsis due to bacterial contamination of blood products can be life-threatening and is characterized by fever, hypotension, and shock. This patient’s fever resolved without antipyretic or antibiotic intervention, and vitals are stable, making sepsis unlikely as the cause.
❌ Circulating antibody-antigen complexes:
Incorrect: Type III hypersensitivity reactions are mediated by antibody-antigen complexes that deposit in various tissues (e.g., joints, skin) and induce an inflammatory response. Serum sickness is one common example of a type III hypersensitivity reaction. However, this patient’s anaphylaxis is a type I, not type III, hypersensitivity reaction.
❌ Presence of Anti-IgE antibodies:
Incorrect: Anaphylactic reactions to blood products are more commonly characterized by the presence of anti-IgA, not anti-IgE antibodies. 
❌ Hypocalcemia:
Incorrect: Calcium gluconate infusion is done to prevent hypocalcemia in patients receiving massive amounts of blood. However, hypocalcemia does not manifest as an anaphylactic reaction.

questions.text:
A 16-year-old girl comes to the office because of a rash on her forehead. The rash started to appear 3-4 weeks ago and has progressively spread to involve her entire forehead. She also reports being stressed about her upcoming debate competition this week. Past medical history is noncontributory. She recently became sexually active with her boyfriend and started using oral contraceptives for contraception. She does not use tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drugs. Family history is significant for type II diabetes mellitus in her father. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows multiple scattered papules on her forehead as shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?


Reproduced from Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
This adolescent girl with multiple open comedones on her forehead, in the setting of a recent stressor (upcoming debate competition), is most likely suffering from acne vulgaris, a common inflammatory skin disorder affecting hair follicles and sebaceous glands. The underlying etiology is multifactorial and involves the following changes:  
  •  Hyperkeratosis of lower follicular infundibulum 
  •  Increased sebum production from sebaceous glands, stimulated by androgens 
  •  Subsequent proliferation of Cutibacterium acnes (part of normal flora) causing inflammation and development of papules and pustules 
Common predisposing factors include genetic predisposition, hormonal imbalance, infection, medications, psychological stress, and polycystic ovarian syndrome. Treatment options depend on the severity and include retinoids, benzoyl peroxide, antibiotics, and isotretinoin. Acne vulgaris can be categorized into the following 4 types based on severity, as shown in the table below.



Option Analysis

❌ Rosacea:
Incorrect: Rosacea is an inflammatory cutaneous disorder that usually presents with persistent facial flushing, telangiectasia, papules, pustules, and ocular hyperemia. It can be exacerbated by exposure to sunlight, alcohol intake, or eating spicy foods. Rosacea is differentiated from acne vulgaris by the absence of comedones and the presence of telangiectasia in the former.

Reproduced from Wikimedia Commons
❌ Sebaceous hyperplasia:
Incorrect: Sebaceous glands enlargement is termed sebaceous hyperplasia. It presents small pale papules with umbilication mainly on the forehead and cheeks. The presence of open comedones favors the diagnosis of acne vulgaris.
 

Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons
✅ Acne vulgaris:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Hidradenitis suppurativa:
Incorrect: Hidradenitis suppurativa is an inflammatory occlusion of the pilosebaceous subunit that results in the formation of solitary, painful nodules, not papules. Moreover, it usually affects intertriginous areas (e.g., axilla, inguinal, and perineal areas)

Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons
❌ Drug-induced acne:
Incorrect: Drug-induced acne appears as monomorphic papular lesions, unlike the polymorphous lesions seen in this patient. Moreover, combined oral contraceptives do not promote acne but can improve it by inhibiting androgen synthesis. Common examples that can cause drug-induced acne include glucocorticoids, phenytoin, lithium, and isoniazid.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department following a motor vehicle crash, where she hit her head over the left temporal area with associated loss of consciousness. En route to the hospital, the patient suddenly loses consciousness again. On arrival, temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 50/min, respirations are 10/min, and blood pressure is 160/70 mmHg. On physical examination, the patient has swelling, ecchymosis, and crepitus over the left temporal skull. Non-contrast CT is most likely to demonstrate which of the following findings?

choices.text: Hyperdense collection around the Circle of Willis
Hyperdense collection within the basal ganglia
Multiple hyperdense collections at the gray-white junction

questions.solution:
This patient most likely suffered a fracture at the pterion with concomitant middle meningeal artery rupture and epidural hematoma formation. The majority of cases of epidural hematoma occur secondary to head trauma during motor vehicle crashes, falls, and assaults. The most commonly implicated vessel is the middle meningeal artery as it passes under the pterion–the confluence where the frontal, parietal, temporal, and sphenoid bones merge. On head CT, epidural bleeding creates a lens-shaped lesion as the collection is bordered by dural attachments at the cranial sutures.

Patients with epidural hematomas often experience a “lucid interval,” which refers to a temporary improvement in consciousness before rapid loss of consciousness and clinical deterioration from the expanding hematoma. Manifestations of epidural hematoma include headaches, drowsiness, confusion, aphasia, seizures, and focal neurologic deficits. Additionally, the Cushing triad (bradycardia, hypertension, and respiratory depression) may be observed secondary to elevated intracranial hypertension and brain stem compression. Treatment typically involves an emergency craniotomy and hematoma evacuation to prevent irreversible brain injury and death.



Option Analysis

✅ Biconvex hyperdense lesion:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Crescent-shaped lesion:
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with a subdural hematoma, which occurs due to rupture of the bridging veins. Subdural hematomas may be acute due to high energy trauma (e.g. motor vehicle accident) or chronic from low energy trauma (e.g., brain atrophy, chronic alcohol use). However, trauma to the pterion (temporal area) is associated with epidural hematomas, which present as a lens-shaped lesion.  
❌ Hyperdense collection around the Circle of Willis:
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) due to rupture of a saccular aneurysm or arteriovenous malformations. Patients often complain of the “worst headache of my life.” On head CT, SAH appears as hyperdense material filling the subarachnoid space.  
❌ Hyperdense collection within the basal ganglia:
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with intraparenchymal hemorrhage secondary to  Charcot-Bouchard microaneurysms and subsequent rupture of the lenticulostriate penetrating arteries, often seen in patients with chronic hypertension.  
❌ Multiple hyperdense collections at the gray-white junction  :
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with a diffuse axonal injury (DAI) from a rapid acceleration/deceleration injury. Non-contrast CT will recognize only hemorrhagic lesions at the early stages. MRI (diffusion tensor imaging) is more sensitive for detecting DAI.

questions.text: An autopsy is being performed on a 57-year-old man who was found unresponsive on the kitchen floor by his daughter. His medical history is remarkable for a 30 pack year smoking history. The pathologist notes small, red punctate lesions at the upper level of the pons. These findings are associated with which of the following cerebral pathologies?
questions.solution:
This patient’s autopsy reveals Duret hemorrhages, a complication of central transtentorial herniation involving the rupture of branches of the basilar artery (pontine arteries). The patient likely suffered a fall with subsequent head trauma, and the traumatic brain injury was ultimately fatal.

Central transtentorial herniation refers to downward displacement of the diencephalon and parts of the temporal lobes through a notch in the tentorium cerebelli. This type of herniation may result in small, fixed pupils with paralysis of upward eye movement ("sunset eyes") and diabetes insipidus due to compression of the pituitary stalk. Other features may range from altered mentation to coma. Central herniation may also result in rupture of branches of the basilar artery (pontine arteries) known as a Duret hemorrhages (a complication which is often fatal). On autopsy, these hemorrhages are described as red punctate lesions at the upper level of the pons.



Option Analysis

❌ Cerebral hypoperfusion:
Incorrect: Hypoxic-ischemic brain injury is observed in conditions such as cardiac arrest, hypovolemic shock, poisoning, or head trauma. This condition typically affects cerebral watershed areas found between cerebral vascular territories. These territories include the junction between the anterior and middle cerebral arteries, as well as between the posterior and middle cerebral arteries. This patient’s autopsy reveals Duret hemorrhages, a complication of central transtentorial herniation.
❌ Osmotic demyelination syndrome:
Incorrect: Osmotic demyelination syndrome occurs secondary to rapid correction of hyponatremia. Manifestations include acute paralysis, dysarthria, dysphagia, diplopia, loss of consciousness, or death. The red lesions seen in this patient's autopsy instead imply hemorrhage. This patient’s autopsy reveals Duret hemorrhages, a complication of central transtentorial herniation.  
✅ Transtentorial herniation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Charcot-Bouchard microaneurysm  :
Incorrect: Rupture of the lenticulostriate arteries supplying the basal ganglia (Charcot-Bouchard microaneurysms) results in intraparenchymal hemorrhage. This condition is most commonly associated with chronic hypertension. This patient’s autopsy reveals Duret hemorrhages, a complication of central transtentorial herniation.  
❌ Carbon monoxide poisoning:
Incorrect: The clinical manifestation of carbon monoxide (CO) poisoning is highly variable and includes constitutional symptoms such as headache, malaise, nausea, and dizziness. Long term sequelae includes myocardial injury and delayed neuropsychiatric syndrome. Acute intoxication manifests with  hemorrhagic infarction of the globus pallidus and, less so, the deep white matter. This patient’s autopsy reveals Duret hemorrhages, a complication of central transtentorial herniation.

questions.text:
A 14-year-old boy is brought to his primary pediatrician for evaluation of left knee pain. He plays basketball for his high school team, and the pain started four weeks following the start of the season. The pain is worsened with running and jumping and relieved with rest. He has no significant past medical history. Vitals are within normal limits. He is at the 75th percentile for height and 40th percentile for weight. Physical examination reveals anterior knee pain located at the position of the arrow, as seen in the image below. Which of the following best describes the etiology of this patient’s condition?
 

Reproduced from: ">Wikimedia Commons

choices.text: Chronic avulsion of the secondary ossification center of the tibial tuberosity
Displacement of the femoral epiphysis from the femoral neck
Abnormal formation of the acetabulum and the femoral head
Muscular imbalance and decreased stability of the patellofemoral joint
Degenerative alterations to the patellar tendon

questions.solution:
This patient presents with swelling and tenderness over the tibial tuberosity, which is consistent with the traction apophysitis Osgood-Schlatter disease (OSD). OSD is an overuse injury characterized by inflammation and microfracture of the tibial tuberosity. Repetitive strain from repetitive jumping and strong contraction of quadriceps results in chronic avulsion at the tibial tuberosity with subsequent secondary ossification and chronic pain.

OSD typically occurs in adolescent (ages 13-14) males or females who have recently undergone a rapid growth spurt. The most common presenting complaint is gradually worsening anterior knee pain that is exacerbated with physical activity (running, jumping) and relieved with rest. Physical examination typically reveals tenderness and soft tissue or bony prominence over the tibial tubercle, as indicated by the yellow arrow in the image. In contrast, pain that is more superior and just inferior to the patella would suggest patellar tendinopathy.  

Option Analysis

✅ Chronic avulsion of the secondary ossification center of the tibial tuberosity   :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Displacement of the femoral epiphysis from the femoral neck   :
Incorrect: Slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE) results from slipping of the femoral head from the femoral neck. The typical patient is an adolescent male with obesity who presents with a painful limp as well as pain in the groin, hip, or knee.   
❌ Abnormal formation of the acetabulum and the femoral head   :
Incorrect: Developmental dysplasia of the hip (DDH) results from the improper formation of the acetabulum and femoral head and occurs in neonates. This patient, who presents with pain at the tibial tuberosity, has a different diagnosis.   
❌ Muscular imbalance and decreased stability of the patellofemoral joint   :
Incorrect: Patellofemoral syndrome results from malalignment of the patella (often caused by muscular imbalance). This condition results in pain around the patella or directly below the patella.   
❌ Degenerative alterations to the patellar tendon   :
Incorrect: Patellar tendinitis is an overuse injury due to repetitive jumping. Patients with this condition present with anterior knee pain that is worsened with activity. Patellar tendinitis typically results in point tenderness at the inferior pole of the patella–not over the tibial tuberosity.

questions.text:
A 51-year-old female comes to the emergency department because of shortness of breath that began an hour ago. Three days ago, the patient returned from a business trip in Europe. Past medical history is notable for hypertension. The patient has been taking oral estrogen for management of menopausal symptoms. Her temperature is 37.8°C (100.0°F), blood pressure is 148/89, pulse is 130/min, and respiratory rate is 27/min. Oxygen saturation is 86% on room air. Physical examination reveals splenomegaly. Coagulation studies show a prothrombin time (PT) of 12 seconds and partial thromboplastin time (PTT) of 34 seconds. A peripheral blood smear shows the following:  



 Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons  

Computed tomography subsequently confirms the presence of a pulmonary embolus. Which of the following best explains the pathophysiology of this patient presentation?

choices.text: Prolonged immobility resulting in venous stasis
Medication side-effect resulting in increased clotting factor production
Neoplastic proliferation of megakaryocytes causing increased platelet production
Autoimmune disease causing production of antiphospholipid antibodies
Production of mutated Factor V that cannot be inactivated by Protein C

questions.solution:
This patient has essential thrombocythemia. It is a myeloproliferative neoplasm wherein megakaryocytes and platelets are produced in the absence of thrombopoietin, a hormone secreted by the liver and kidneys to promote platelet production. The disease is most often caused by Janus Kinase 2, MPL, or Calreticulin gene mutations.  

Patients may experience thromboembolic events or recurrent fetal loss due to a hypercoagulable state. In addition, patients may experience constitutional symptoms such as fatigue and headaches. In extreme cases, when platelet count exceeds 1.5 million/mm3, patients can be at increased risk of bleeding. This is because the platelets consume so much von Willebrand factor that not enough is available at the injury site.    

 The work-up for essential thrombocythemia includes getting a complete blood count, peripheral blood smear, bone marrow biopsy, and genetic testing. Peripheral blood smear will show an elevated platelet count. Bone marrow biopsy will show megakaryocytes proliferation and genetic testing will often confirm the presence of a mutation (e.g. JAK2).  

Patients should be given low-dose aspirin to prevent thromboembolic events. Patients at high risk for arterial or venous thrombosis should be treated with cytoreductive therapies such as hydroxyurea, anagrelide, or pegylated interferon.  


Option Analysis

❌ Prolonged immobility resulting in venous stasis:
Incorrect: Prolonged immobility, as in the case of a long plane ride, can cause stasis and increase the risk of clot formation. If one of the clots becomes dislodged and travels to the lungs, then a pulmonary embolism can occur. However, this mechanism would not account for the increased platelet count on peripheral smear or the splenomegaly on physical examination.  
❌ Medication side-effect resulting in increased clotting factor production:
Incorrect: The patient is taking oral estrogen supplementation. One side effect of this medication is that it increases production of coagulation factors, which predisposes patients to clot formation. However, it would be atypical for oral estrogen to cause thrombocythemia (as seen on the peripheral blood smear) or splenomegaly as side-effects.   
✅ Neoplastic proliferation of megakaryocytes causing increased platelet production:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Autoimmune disease causing production of antiphospholipid antibodies:
Incorrect: This describes antiphospholipid syndrome. The antiphospholipid antibodies bind and inactivate anticoagulant proteins. This produces a hypercoagulable state. However on laboratory testing, the antibodies interfere with the phospholipids used to trigger in vitro coagulation, resulting in a falsely-elevated PTT. By contrast, this patient has a normal PTT. Moreover, it would be atypical for antiphospholipid syndrome to present with the thrombocythemia seen on peripheral smear.  
❌ Production of mutated Factor V that cannot be inactivated by Protein C :
Incorrect: This describes Factor V Leiden. In this condition, a mutation causes the production of faulty Factor V that cannot be inactivated by Protein C. The condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant fashion. Laboratory testing may show a low or normal PTT. However, this patient has no history of previous clots or family history of hypercoagulability. This makes Factor V Leiden unlikely to be the underlying cause of this patient’s presentation.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman comes to the emergency department due to right-sided tingling and weakness, as well as a severe headache. She says she started experiencing problems with her vision two hours ago, followed by tingling in her right hand. After this, she began experiencing weakness in her right hand, which progressively extended to her right arm and face, as well as a severe, unilateral throbbing headache that is still ongoing. Her medical history is significant for migraines, but mentions that this time it “feels different.” She is otherwise healthy and takes no medications. Her temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 85/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. Physical examination shows 4/5 muscle strength on the right side compared to 5/5 on the left, as well as mildly reduced sensation on the right side. Ophthalmologic examination shows decreased vision and central scotoma in the right eye. Computed tomography is obtained and shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presenting with visual disturbance, paresthesias, and progressive weakness, followed by a severe throbbing unilateral headache, most likely has a hemiplegic migraine.  

Hemiplegic migraines are a rare type of migraine headache where patients experience motor aura characterized by progressive weakness (typically unilateral) that precedes or accompanies the migraine headache. Hemiplegic migraines always have at least two types of aura present, including visual, sensory, motor, aphasic, and/or brainstem symptoms. Most commonly, weakness starts in the hand, and progresses to involve the arm and face. These symptoms are fully reversible, with most lasting at least 60 minutes. In rare cases, hemiplegia may last up to 4 weeks.    

Like other types of migraines, hemiplegic migraines are more common in women than men. Management is similar to typical migraine headaches, including abortive medications during the acute phase as well as prophylactic treatment to prevent future episodes. In severe cases, patients may require hospitalization due to fever, altered consciousness, or seizures.  

Option Analysis

❌ Transient ischemic attack :
Incorrect: Both migraines and transient ischemic attacks (TIAs) can include reversible symptoms such as weakness, paraesthesia, and visual changes, and imaging in both cases shows no abnormalities. However, the symptoms of TIA are acute, not progressive as seen in this patient. Also, patients usually have additional risk factors (e.g., hypercholesterolemia, coronary artery disease, advanced age), unlike this young healthy woman.   
❌ Simple seizure:
Incorrect: Simple seizures may be preceded by visual or motor auras, however it is usually associated with “positive” symptoms (e.g., shaking, jerking, flashing lights, or visual distortion) rather than “negative” symptoms (e.g., weakness, paraesthesias). Additionally, the throbbing headache and history of migraine favors another diagnosis.   
❌ Subarachnoid hemorrhage:
Incorrect: The classic presentation of a subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) is sudden onset of a severe headache, often described as the “worst headache of my life,” brief loss of consciousness, vomiting, and neck pain or stiffness. Although this patient has an acute onset of severe headache, her computed tomography shows no abnormalities, whereas SAH should show signs of hemorrhage.   
❌ Cluster headache:
Incorrect: Cluster headaches manifest as unilateral excruciating periorbital pain with lacrimation and rhinorrhea. It is more common in men than women and usually is short in duration (15 minutes–3 hours). This patient has a progressive motor aura, throbbing headache, and lacks the autonomic signs seen in cluster headaches (e.g. lacrimation, rhinorrhea), which favors another diagnosis.   
✅ Migraine headache:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Temporal arteritis  :
Incorrect: Temporal arteritis (TA) or giant cell arteritis should be considered in patients over 50 years with the following symptoms: new headache, scalp tenderness, jaw claudication, abrupt onset of visual disturbances/transient monocular visual loss, and constitutional symptoms. This patient's young age and lack of classic TA findings favors another diagnosis.

questions.text: A 37-year-old primigravid woman at 22 weeks gestation comes to the clinic for her second-trimester fetal assessment. She has had full prenatal care, and her first-trimester assessment showed no abnormalities. This is her first pregnancy, and she is very excited about the upcoming birth of her daughter. Fetal ultrasound reveals increased nuchal translucency and a septated fluid collection that extends along the entire posterior length of the fetus. The doctor suspects a genetic abnormality. Which of the following is most likely responsible for this patient’s presentation?

choices.text: Gene deletion in chromosome 15 of paternal origin
Unbalanced Robertsonian translocation between chromosomes 14 and 21
Deletion of the short arm of chromosome 5

questions.solution:
A female fetus with increased nuchal translucency and septated fluid collection that extends along the entire posterior side of the fetus is consistent with a cystic hygroma seen in Turner syndrome.  

Turner syndrome, seen only in females, is caused by loss of the X chromosome due to nondisjunction during meiosis or mitosis (45, XO). The condition is characterized by short stature, ovarian dysgenesis, shield chest, bicuspid aortic valve, coarctation of the aorta, horseshoe kidney, high-arched palate, shortened 4th metacarpals, and lymphatic defects.  

Turner syndrome is associated with lymphatic dysplasia, and individuals with this condition often present with a webbed neck, cystic hygroma, and lymphedema of the hand and feet. Cystic hygroma, also known as cystic lymphangioma, is a benign congenital lymphatic malformation composed of small cavities, typically found in the posterior triangle of the neck. After birth, infants with cystic hygroma should be monitored for airway obstruction. Needle drainage may be used to reduce the volume of the cystic hygroma to prevent facial deformities and airway obstruction.    



Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons



Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons

Option Analysis

❌ Gene deletion in chromosome 15 of paternal origin:
Incorrect: A gene deletion in chromosome 15 of paternal origin is the pathogenesis behind Prader-Willi syndrome. Infants born with this condition typically present with hyperphagia, obesity, intellectual disability, hypogonadism, and hypotonia. It is not associated with increased nuchal translucency or fluid collections in the posterior side of the fetus.  
❌ Unbalanced Robertsonian translocation between chromosomes 14 and 21  :
Incorrect: Unbalanced Robertsonian translocations between chromosomes 14 and 21 are responsible for up to 4% of the cases of Down syndrome. Most cases are due to meiotic nondisjunction. Infants born with Down syndrome typically present with intellectual disability, flat facies, prominent epicanthal folds, single palmar crease, increased gap between 1st and 2nd toes, duodenal atresia, Hirschsprung disease, and congenital heart disease (eg, atrioventricular septal defect). Although Down syndrome is the most common aneuploidy associated with increased nuchal translucency, it typically presents in the first trimester, and it is not associated with a septated fluid collection that extends along the entire fetus.   
❌ Meiotic nondisjunction of chromosome 18:
Incorrect: Meiotic nondisjunction of chromosome 18 is the cause of Edwards syndrome (trisomy 18). Infants born with this condition typically present with intellectual disability, prominent occiput, rocker-bottom feet, clenched fists, low-set ears, micrognathia (small jaw), congenital heart disease, and omphalocele. Although increased nuchal translucency can occur in Edwards syndrome, septated fluid collection along the entire fetus favors another diagnosis.   
✅ Loss of paternal chromosome X :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Deletion of the short arm of chromosome 5:
Incorrect: Deletion of the short arm of chromosome 5 is the cause of Cri-du-chat syndrome.  Infants born with this condition typically present with moderate to severe intellectual disability, microcephaly, high-pitched crying, epicanthal folds, and cardiac abnormalities (VSD). It is not associated with increased nuchal translucency on ultrasound.

questions.text:
A 75-year-old man comes to his primary care physician for a routine visit. Five months ago, his wife died from a stroke. The patient reports feeling depressed, and he has been consuming large quantities of vodka on a daily basis. He previously ate a balanced diet. However, he has had little motivation to cook since his wife passed away, and he currently eats crackers and beef jerky purchased from a convenience store. His temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), blood pressure is 117/81 mmHg, pulse is 71/min, and respiratory rate is 12/min. Complete blood count reveals a hemoglobin of 9.2 g/dL and a mean corpuscular volume (MCV) of 110 µm3. A peripheral smear is ordered and the results are as follow:  



Reproduced from: Flickr  

Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's findings?

choices.text: Iron deficiency secondary to bleeding in the gastrointestinal tract
Impaired DNA synthesis resulting from vitamin B12 deficiency
Impaired DNA synthesis resulting from vitamin B9 deficiency
Replacement of bone marrow by scar tissue

questions.solution:
This patient has macrocytic anemia secondary to vitamin B9 (folate) deficiency. Common causes include poor diet, medication side-effects, and excessive alcohol consumption. Folate is obtained by consuming leafy greens and fortified foods. It is converted to tetrahydrofolic acid (THF), which plays an important role in the synthesis of nitrogenous bases that are incorporated into DNA and RNA. As a result, folate deficiency impairs DNA synthesis and hinders the maturation of hematopoietic cell lines.  

Folate deficiency causes macrocytic anemia. This is because RBC precursors are normally big (MCV > 100 µm3) and undergo cell divisions as they mature, resulting in normal, smaller RBCs. With folate deficiency, RBC maturation is impaired. This causes megaloblasts (structurally abnormal immature RBCs) to be released into the bloodstream. The net result is macrocytic megaloblastic anemia. Likewise, folate deficiency impairs white blood cell (WBC) maturation, resulting in immature hypersegmented neutrophils (greater than 5 lobes), as seen on this patient’s peripheral smear.  

Folate deficiency causes fatigue, pallor, and glossitis. Diagnosis relies on a peripheral blood smear, which shows large red blood cells and hypersegmented neutrophils. A bone marrow study can also be done to look for the megaloblastic changes in RBC precursors. Homocysteine levels are also elevated. Of note, methylmalonic acid levels are normal in patients with folate deficiency.  


Option Analysis

❌ Iron deficiency secondary to bleeding in the gastrointestinal tract:
Incorrect: Excess alcohol consumption can cause esophageal varices, erosive gastritis, and decreased synthesis of clotting factors, all of which can lead to gastrointestinal tract bleeding. This in turn may lead to iron deficiency anemia. However, iron deficiency anemia presents with a normocytic or microcytic anemia (MCV < 80 µm3), not a macrocytic anemia.  
❌ Impaired DNA synthesis resulting from vitamin B12 deficiency:
Incorrect: Vitamin B12 deficiency can impair nucleotide synthesis and cause macrocytic anemia (MCV > 100 µm3). His alcohol use puts him at increased risk of vitamin B12 deficiency. However, the body has a store of vitamin B12 that requires 3-5 years to deplete. In contrast, this patient has been consuming a nutritionally-poor diet for only five months.  
✅ Impaired DNA synthesis resulting from vitamin B9 deficiency  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Defect in homologous DNA recombination:
Incorrect: Fanconi anemia is secondary to defects in homologous DNA recombination. Patients with this condition present with pancytopenia, short stature, skeletal defects, and cafe-au-lait spots. While this patient has anemia, he has none of the other symptoms typically observed in Fanconi anemia. Moreover, patients with Fanconi anemia will present with symptoms beginning in childhood.  
❌ Replacement of bone marrow by scar tissue:
Incorrect: This describes primary myelofibrosis, a condition characterized by the uncontrolled proliferation of megakaryocytes and scar tissue deposition. Over time, the hematopoietic stem cells residing in the bone marrow are crowded out by scar tissue. This results in pancytopenia and a “dry tap” on bone marrow biopsy. However, it would be atypical for primary myelofibrosis to present with the hypersegmented neutrophil observed on peripheral blood smear.

questions.text:
A 41-year-old woman comes to her outpatient provider for evaluation of fatigue and dyspnea on exertion that started five months ago. The patient previously enjoyed biking on the weekends, but she has been unable to do so because of her symptoms. Past medical history is notable for seasonal allergies. She is currently not taking any medications. In the office, her temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), blood pressure is 128/88 mmHg, and pulse is 73/min. Physical examination is notable for diffuse skin thickening and telangiectasias. On cardiac examination, there is a loud S2 at the left upper sternal border. A chest x-ray is ordered, and the results are as follows:  



Image reproduced from Radiopedia 

Which of the following findings is most likely to be seen in this patient?

choices.text: Elevated pulmonary artery pressure on heart catheterization
Systolic displacement of the mitral valve on echocardiography
Pedunculated mass in the left atrium on echocardiography
Elevated pulmonary capillary wedge pressure on heart catheterization

questions.solution:
The patient has pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) secondary to diffuse scleroderma. PAH causes progressive dyspnea, fatigue, and reduced exercise tolerance. Vitals will reveal an elevated systemic blood pressure.  

PAH occurs due to a combination of factors, namely: small blood vessel damage causing intimal thickening; pulmonary fibrosis causing hypoxic vasoconstriction; and myocardial fibrosis leading to left heart dysfunction. The net result is increased pulmonary vascular resistance and elevated pulmonary arterial pressure. Over time, this process can lead to right heart failure (i.e. cor pulmonale), as the right heart is unable to pump against the high pressures of the pulmonary arterial system. Physical examination findings demonstrate right ventricular (RV) heave (parasternal heave), which is an impulse palpated to the left of the sternum; this indicates RV enlargement. Additionally, there is a loud pulmonic component of the second heart sound due to increased pulmonary artery pressure.

The work-up for PAH includes first obtaining an electrocardiogram, which may show right atrial and ventricular hypertrophy as well as right axis deviation. A chest x-ray can show similar findings. Right atrial enlargement will present with increased convexity of the right heart border. Right ventricular enlargement will present with rounding of the left heart border and elevation of the cardiac apex. In addition, a prominent central pulmonary artery or peripheral hypervascularity may be seen on chest x-ray. If either of these initial tests demonstrate findings concerning for PAH, right heart catheterization should be performed. A mean pulmonary artery pressure exceeding 20 mmHg is necessary to make the diagnosis. Vasodilators (e.g., bosentan, sildenafil) are used to treat PAH. Anticoagulants (e.g. warfarin) can also be administered to decrease the risk of thromboembolic events.    

Option Analysis

❌ Left axis deviation on electrocardiogram:
Incorrect: The patient has dyspnea and new-onset hypertension in the setting of diffuse skin thickening. This raises concerns of pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) secondary to systemic scleroderma. Over time, PAH can lead to right ventricle hypertrophy, not left ventricular hypertrophy (LVH). LVH results in a left axis deviation on EKG and is typically seen in patients with chronic systemic hypertension and aortic stenosis.   
✅ Elevated pulmonary artery pressure on heart catheterization:
Correct: See Main Explanation  
❌ Systolic displacement of the mitral valve on echocardiography:
Incorrect: Displacement of the mitral valve during systole on echocardiography can be seen in patients with mitral valve prolapse (MVP). Although patients can also present with fatigue and dyspnea, this patient’s systemic findings (e.g., skin thickening, telangiectasias) are suggestive of a different underlying condition.   
❌ Pedunculated mass in the left atrium on echocardiography :
Incorrect: A cardiac myxoma is characterized by a low-pitched, mid-diastolic rumbling murmur heard over the cardiac apex. Although patients can present with dyspnea due to outflow obstruction, this patient’s systemic findings (e.g., skin thickening, telangiectasias) are suggestive of a different underlying condition.  
❌ Elevated pulmonary capillary wedge pressure on heart catheterization:
Incorrect: Pulmonary capillary wedge pressure (PWCP) is an estimate of left atrial pressure, and is typically elevated in patients with a significant left-sided valvular pathology (e.g., mitral stenosis, aortic stenosis). This patient’s dyspnea, loud S2, and systemic findings are suggestive of a different underlying condition.

questions.text: A 44-year-old man comes to the emergency department with abdominal pain and nausea for the past 24 hours. The pain started a few hours after dinner, and he describes it as a constant pain in the upper part of his abdomen that radiates to his back and flanks. The patient also reports nausea, intermittent vomiting, and abdominal distention. Family history is significant for recurrent episodes of pancreatitis in his father and paternal uncle. He reports drinking an average of 2 alcoholic drinks per week. His temperature is 37.7ºC (99.9ºF), pulse is 92/min, respirations are 20/min, peripheral oxygen saturation is 96%, and blood pressure is 149/94 mmHg. He appears distressed and anxious. Abdominal examination shows tenderness and rigidity over the epigastric and periumbilical regions. Bowel sounds are diminished. No bruising of the umbilicus or flanks are seen. Which of the following laboratory results is the most specific in diagnosing this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Serum amylase > 3 times the upper limit of normal
Serum lipase > 3 times the upper limit of normal

questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with constant abdominal pain localized in the epigastric region that radiates to the back, highly suggestive of acute pancreatitis. Acute pancreatitis occurs when pancreatic enzymes are inappropriately activated, leading to tissue damage and an inflammatory response. This patient has a family history of recurrent pancreatitis in his father and paternal uncle, suggesting the diagnosis of familial hypertriglyceridemia, an autosomal dominant condition. The high concentration of serum triglycerides can cause acute pancreatitis because when pancreatic cells encounter triglycerides, they release lipase to break the triglycerides down into free fatty acids; excess free fatty acids can subsequently injure the pancreas.  

The most common causes of pancreatitis are gallstones and alcohol toxicity. The other causes of pancreatitis can be easily remembered by the mnemonic “I GET SMASHED”:  



To make a diagnosis of acute pancreatitis (from any cause), one needs 2 out of 3 of the following criteria:  
  •  clinical symptoms, such as persistent, severe, epigastric pain with tenderness on palpation 
  •  laboratory studies demonstrating serum amylase or lipase greater than 3 times the upper limit of normal; lipase remains elevated for a longer period of time and has a higher specificity as compared with amylase 
  •  imaging (computed tomography, magnetic resonance (MR), ultrasonography) showing focal or diffuse enlargement of the pancreas 
In this patient with a characteristic clinical presentation, the demonstration of an elevated serum amylase or lipase level will confirm the diagnosis of acute pancreatitis. However, serum amylase may be spuriously normal in patients with hypertriglyceridemia and spuriously elevated in patients with acidemia (arterial pH ≤ 7.32), therefore serum lipase is the preferred laboratory test for diagnosing acute pancreatitis. It is important to note, however, that there is no correlation between the severity of pancreatitis and the degree of serum lipase and amylase elevations. Additionally, an elevation in serum triglyceride levels is not sufficient to diagnose acute pancreatitis. Hyperbilirubinemia, leukocytosis, azotemia, and hypoglycemia are suggestive of more severe disease, but are not themselves diagnostic of acute pancreatitis.  
 

Option Analysis

❌ Serum amylase > 3 times the upper limit of normal:
Incorrect: Although serum amylase elevation may be used to show biochemical evidence of acute pancreatitis, it is affected by serum pH, lipids, and bowel inflammation, and is prone to false elevations or spuriously normal results. Therefore it is not the most specific in diagnosing this patient’s acute pancreatitis.  
✅ Serum lipase > 3 times the upper limit of normal  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Serum bilirubin > 4.0 mg/dL  :
Incorrect: Although hyperbilirubinemia may occur in up to 10% of patients with acute pancreatitis, bilirubin elevations are not specific to pancreatitis and do not contribute to the diagnosis. Serum bilirubin levels return to normal in 4-7 days.  
❌ Elevated blood alcohol leve:
Incorrect: Although alcohol abuse may cause acute pancreatitis in a dose-dependent manner, this patient only consumes 2 beers/week, which is unlikely to cause acute pancreatitis. Instead, his underlying familial hypertriglyceridemia is likely the cause of pancreatitis.   
❌ Blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level > 22 mg/dL:
Incorrect: Azotemia (BUN >22 mg/dL) suggests more severe pancreatitis that is causing vascular permeability and intravascular volume depletion or hemorrhage. However, azotemia is not specific for acute pancreatitis and is not included in the diagnostic criteria.

questions.text:
A 70-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of fatigue and weakness. The symptoms began 6 months ago and have progressively worsened. The patient has occasionally seen bright red blood in her stool since symptom onset. She denies constipation, straining, or trauma. Past medical history is notable for hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 92/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 115/68 mmHg. Physical exam shows conjunctival pallor. Cardiac auscultation reveals a harsh ejection-type systolic murmur at the second right intercostal space. Pulmonary and abdominal exams are non-contributory. Fecal occult blood testing is positive. Laboratory testing reveals a hemoglobin of 8.9 mg/dL and serum iron level of 47µg/dL. Endoscopy is performed, and the results are notable for the following:  



Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons

Which of the following best describes the pathophysiology of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Neoplastic proliferation of colonic epithelial cells
Benign overgrowth of colonic mucosal tissue
Blood vessel dilation in response to VEGF overproduction
Inflammation characterized by continuous colonic and rectal involvement

questions.solution:
This patient’s history of subacute gastrointestinal bleeding, in combination with the endoscopy findings, is most consistent with intestinal angiodysplasia. The condition develops when small blood vessels in the mucosa and submucosa become dilated. Although the exact cause is unclear, it is suspected that increased levels of vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) and obstructed venous drainage contribute to the condition. Angiodysplasia most often occurs in the right colon. Angiodysplasia is often associated with advanced age (>60 years), von Willebrand disease, end-stage renal disease, and aortic stenosis (as evidenced by the patient’s harsh ejection-type systolic murmur at the second right intercostal space).  

Most individuals with intestinal angiodysplasia are asymptomatic. However, mild or severe bleeding can occur. Over time, bleeding from intestinal angiodysplasia can lead to iron deficiency anemia, as seen in this patient’s low hemoglobin and serum iron levels.  

The diagnosis is often made incidentally during endoscopy in asymptomatic patients or during an endoscopic exploration for lower GI bleeding due to an unknown cause. The treatment for symptomatic patients is endoscopic obliteration of the affected vessels; this intervention is not indicated in asymptomatic patients.  

Option Analysis

❌ Neoplastic proliferation of colonic epithelial cells:
Incorrect: This answer describes colon cancer. The condition can also cause GI bleeding, anemia, and a positive fecal occult blood test. However, endoscopy would reveal a mass in the colon, rather than dilated blood vessels.  
❌ Benign overgrowth of colonic mucosal tissue:
Incorrect: This answer describes a colonic polyp. Polyps can bleed and result in a positive fecal occult blood test, but this patient’s endoscopic findings are more consistent with that of angiodysplasia than those of a colonic polyp.  
✅ Blood vessel dilation in response to VEGF overproduction  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Inflammation characterized by continuous colonic and rectal involvement:
Incorrect: Ulcerative colitis is an autoimmune condition that results in inflammation and ulceration of the colon and rectum. The condition has two peaks of onset: ages 15-30 years, ages 50-70 years. The condition can result in blood loss, anemia, and a positive fecal occult blood test; however, characteristic ulcerations would be seen on the patient’s endoscopy.  
❌ Inflammation of colonic outpouchings:
Incorrect: Diverticulitis occurs when colonic outpouchings, termed diverticula, become inflamed. Diverticulitis usually causes left lower quadrant pain. In contrast, it would be atypical for the condition to cause painless long-term blood loss that leads to iron deficiency anemia. Moreover, visualization of the diverticula would be expected on colonoscopy.

questions.text:
A 46-year-old woman, gravida 2 para 1, comes to the office for a routine wellness exam. She has no acute complaints. A Pap smear is performed and reveals the following:  



 Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons  

The patient was previously diagnosed with ductal carcinoma in situ of the left breast at age 40, which was treated with lumpectomy and tamoxifen. During the past year, she had a vaginal yeast infection that resolved after treatment with fluconazole. When she was 20-years-old, the patient had one surgical abortion by dilatation and curettage. She had one spontaneous vaginal delivery when she was 30-years-old. The patient has smoked one pack of cigarettes per day since she was 16-years-old, and she drinks 1 beer per week. Which of the following elements of the patient's history placed her at greatest risk for developing her current condition?

choices.text: History of ductal carcinoma in situ
History of surgical abortion (dilatation and curettage)
History of vaginal yeast infection with Candida albicans

questions.solution:
This patient has Pap smear findings consistent with a high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion (HSIL), which corresponds with moderate or high-grade dysplasia.  
 
Smoking is a major risk factor for developing cervical dysplasia and cancer. The reason is two-fold. First, tobacco smoke inhibits the local immune response against HPV and puts patients at increased risk of infection. Oncoproteins produced by HPV can block apoptosis and cell cycle arrest. Second, tobacco smoke is carcinogenic and leads to DNA damage.   

In addition to smoking, risk factors for cervical cancer include: young age at first sexual intercourse, oral contraceptive use (primarily associated with adenocarcinoma), multiple sexual partners and multiparity, immunosuppression through HIV infection or organ transplantation, sexually transmitted infections, and HPV infection, which is present in virtually all cervical cancer cases.  

Option Analysis

❌ History of ductal carcinoma in situ:
Incorrect: Ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) is the most common type of non-invasive breast cancer. It is a pre-invasive, early form of cancer which can affect both men and women. It does not constitute a risk factor for cervical cancer.  
❌ History of surgical abortion (dilatation and curettage):
Incorrect: Dilatation and curettage is a gynecological procedure used to manage first trimester miscarriages and abortions. It involves dilating the cervical opening and scraping the uterine lining. The procedure does not increase a woman's risk of developing cervical cancer.   
❌ History of vaginal yeast infection with Candida albicans:
Incorrect: Vaginal Candida infections are not associated with an increased risk for squamous epithelial cell abnormalities. As a result, women carrying Candida are not at an increased risk of developing cervical cancer.   
✅ Smoking:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Tamoxifen treatment  :
Incorrect: Tamoxifen is a selective estrogen receptor modulator. It is a nonsteroid with potent anti-estrogenic effects in the breast. The medication is used as an adjuvant treatment in breast cancer. Tamoxifen use has been associated with an increased risk of endometrial cancer but not cervical cancer.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of new onset shortness of breath and chest pain for the past 3 hours.
